name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statements by the Council and the Commission in preparation for the G20 summit on 7 and 8 July 2017 (2017/2762 (RSP)).

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: nõukogu eesistuja. – Suur aitäh, härra juhataja. Kõigepealt lubage mul öelda, kui uhke tunne mul on täna siin Euroopa Parlamendis esindada Euroopa Liidu Nõukogu ja Eesti eesistujat. Ma loodan väga heale koostööle Euroopa Parlamendiga ja tänan teid selle eest, kuidas Eesti eesistumist ja mind on siin majas juba vastu võetud.  Mr President, I am grateful for your invitation to discuss the G20 summit, which Germany will host from Friday in Hamburg. At the summit, G20 leaders, including Presidents Tusk and Juncker, will be faced with intense discussions on various topics of global importance. The international political environment is currently particularly charged and global cooperation can no longer be taken for granted. In this context, the mission of European leaders is clear. The G20 is central to this effort since it is – as G20 leaders stated in Pittsburgh in 2009 – the premier forum for international economic cooperation. It is also essential to give a clear signal that securing balanced and inclusive growth remains a top priority. Even if the global economy is showing positive momentum, political uncertainty surrounding the outlook is still high. Allow me to expand on a selection of issues which I think will take centre stage in Hamburg. I will refer to trade, climate, migration, digitalisation and countering terrorism. It should be the EU’s priority to send a strong signal to the G20 of our commitment to open trade and multilateralism. As recalled by the June European Council, the EU will pursue a robust trade policy, upholding an open and rule—based multilateral trading system with a central role for the WTO. The EU will also keep markets open and fight protectionism, firm in the belief that trade contributes to creating wealth and jobs. The EU will therefore actively promote an ambitious free-trade agenda on the global stage. In this respect, reaching a political agreement on the EU—Japan trade deal ahead of the G20 meeting would send a strong signal against protectionism. We need to improve the daily lives of citizens by ensuring that the benefits of globalisation are more widely shared. As was stressed by the June European Council, we need to foster a truly level playing field, while remaining vigilant concerning the respect and promotion of key standards, including social, environmental, health and consumer standards, which are central to the European way of life. Beyond that, we must also be able to better communicate the actual benefits of trade to the wider public. On climate change, we are all aware that the global community needs to act urgently and move forward with the implementation of the Paris Agreement. The unilateral decision by the United States administration to withdraw from the Paris Agreement is therefore a highly regrettable step. We already discussed this issue here in Parliament during the June session. As you are aware, the EU’s commitment to fully implementing the Paris Agreement was strongly reaffirmed by the June European Council. The agreement remains a cornerstone of global efforts to effectively tackle climate change, and it cannot be renegotiated. I can only further confirm that the Council under the Estonian Presidency will continue in its commitment to ambitious global action against climate change and support the global ownership of the Paris Agreement. The EU and its Member States are playing their full part in implementing the Agreement, both through the development of our domestic policies and in keeping with our commitment to global solidarity. We will have to minimise the effects of the US decision on the effectiveness and credibility of the climate framework. The Presidency believes that we should continue our dialogue and engagement with the US. At the same time, we can also be encouraged by strong statements of commitment, as well as pledges by local governments, businesses, cities, communities and other non-state actors in America. These developments underscore the importance of the action agenda as a platform to connect the different non-state actors. Its importance is expected to grow in the coming years, boosting the political profile and momentum for climate action. My third point is on migration. Dealing with the migration crisis has been at the core of the political debate in the EU, including here in the Parliament, and it is all the more pertinent today in the light of the news from the central Mediterranean and Italy. We naturally tend to focus on the migration crisis in our part of the world, but migration is not a European phenomenon. Nor is managing it solely a European responsibility. It is rather a global responsibility, requiring collective solutions in full respect for our obligations under international law. In this regard, the G20 is launching the G20 Africa partnership, which should foster sustainable and inclusive economic growth and development. It will contribute to creating decent employment, particularly for women and young people, thus addressing poverty and the root causes of migration. This also ties in closely with the ongoing legislative work in the EU on the external investment plan, including the European fund for sustainable development and the European Investment Bank’s external lending mandate. We are also committed to taking an active part in the follow-up to the UN summit on addressing large movements of refugees and migration, held in September last year. The EU intends to play a prominent role in the process leading to the establishment in 2018 of UN global compacts on migration and refugees. We would ask all G20 members to engage as well. Digitalisation is a key priority for the Estonian Presidency and, therefore, we welcome the inclusion of this topic at the G20 summit. Information and communications technology is no longer a specific sector. It is the backbone of all modern innovative economic systems. Therefore, we need to breach digital gaps based on, inter alia, age, geography, gender and income. However, technological progress also involves challenges to our security and democracy, which we expect to be reflected by the G20. These challenges highlight the need to strengthen consumer protection, transparency and security in the use of information and communication technology. Last but not least, the EU has been at the global forefront of the fight against terrorism financing. Recently an agreement on the revision of the Fourth Anti—Money Laundering Agreement was reached. Countering terrorism requires holistic action, including improved cooperation and preventing violent extremism conducive to terrorism.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. –Mr President, in the coming days, the G20 leaders will meet in Hamburg. It will be an important moment: there will be many new faces around the table, and there are many challenges to address. The agenda is more far-reaching than for previous meetings, showing that this format has the potential to look far beyond its initial economic focus. Economy and trade will certainly feature large, but also the fight against terrorism, as well sustainable development, climate change and energy, migration, Africa, health, digitalisation, employment and women’s empowerment. For the EU, the G20 summit is an opportunity to highlight the positive contribution we are currently making to global growth, our vision for fair globalisation, set out in the Reflection Paper on Harnessing Globalisation, and our consistent leadership across multiple areas of the global agenda. Examples include our commitment to the Paris Agreement, progress on our progressive, values-based trade agenda, and our engagement with developing countries through the European Fund for Sustainable Development on which the House will vote this week. In these times of turmoil, it is also the moment to show our unwavering commitment to global multilateral governance and responsible international political dialogue, aimed at delivering in the interest of people all over the world. Against a background of rising ultra-nationalist politics, posing a risk to global economic growth and the rules-based global order, the G20 Hamburg summit has the motto ‘Shaping an interconnected world’, to underline the necessity of multilateral cooperation for prosperity, security and freedom. Let me briefly run you through the main messages that we as the EU want to give. On the economy, we will highlight the positive contribution the EU is making to the global economy. The EU is growing at nearly 2% this year and next year. The European investment plan is well on track, having led to more than EUR 200 billion in additional and sustainable investments. We are getting our mojo back! On climate and energy, we will reaffirm our strong commitment to the Paris Agreement, clean energy transition and support for the poor and vulnerable in the fight against climate change, and we will maintain cohesion within the G19 despite the US decision to withdraw from the Paris Agreement. We would, of course, welcome it if the US would reconsider its decision, but let me be very clear: the deal cannot be renegotiated. On trade, we will present our vision for harnessing globalisation instead of turning inward and resorting to protectionism, because we all agree that there is no ‘protect’ in protectionism, but there is isolation in isolationism. We will demonstrate that the EU will stand up for free and fair trade and for the multilateral trading system as a whole, and we will showcase the progress we are making on our progressive trade agenda, with the EU-Canada Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement and now the EU-Japan trade deal. And, because trade should be fair, we are looking for a strong signal from China as to its full cooperation within the Global Forum on Steel Access Capacity. On taxation, we will maintain momentum for the fight against tax evasion and avoidance. Next steps will include defensive measures against non-cooperative tax jurisdictions and increased efforts to promote the availability, and international exchange, of information on beneficial ownership of legal persons and legal arrangements. On migration: this is a challenge that is going to be with us for quite some time to come – for decades. We must preserve a commitment to a comprehensive global response to tackling irregular migration and forced displacement, including support for the UN Global Compact on refugees and on regular, safe, orderly migration, and we must build support for a strengthened approach to break the business model of migrant smuggling. This is what we must do on the global stage but let me add one thing: it would already make a world of difference in Europe if every single Member State would live up to its commitments to show solidarity with those of our Member States most affected by this challenge. We cannot leave Italy alone with this. Everybody should play their part.  (Applause) We have shown in the past that if we stick together and find solutions that everybody shares we can reach results. Certainly the situation in Greece is not yet where we want it to be. There is still a lot to do, but if you look back at 2015 and then look at the situation now, you will see that much has also improved. There is an incredible level of solidarity with refugees and migrants in Greece and in Italy. But the rest of Europe cannot simply count on the solidarity of the people in Greece and Italy, because the people there also have their limits, and we need to show that the rest of Europe understands this and is playing its part in helping to resolve this crisis. (Applause) On terrorism, we need agreement on an action plan to advance the fight against terrorism. We will not win the battle against terrorist financing and the spread of radicalisation online if we do not work with our international partners on this. On Africa: we will support close partnership with Africa to foster sustainable growth and job creation. Just imagine if we do not do this: our refugee problem in the future will then be so much worse than it already is today. The only sustainable solution is growth and more optimism in Africa, so that people understand it is in their interest to stay in Africa and to develop their own countries, instead of going to Europe. Lastly, I welcome the fact that the German G20 Presidency has put strong emphasis on stakeholder involvement. All the groups concerned –business, labour, civil science, the think tanks, women and youth – have been active and have put forward recommendations. We are in a post-paternalistic society and we can no longer prescribe, from politics or governance, what should be done: we need to include global brain power to make sure that we find the right solutions. That is how globalisation will be shaped in the interest of humanity as a whole, because, at the end of the day, everything we do here in the European Parliament and in the Commission is at the service of citizens, their freedoms and their ability to pursue their hopes and dreams. (Applause)

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, distinguished representatives of the Council Presidency, honorable Mr Vice-President of the European Commission, ladies and gentlemen! The last few weeks have been overshadowed by sad news. I think of the death of our former German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, I think of the first female President of the European Parliament, Simone Veil, who we also thought yesterday, I think of a bus accident that we had in my home region in Bavaria on Monday at eighteen Dead and many injured, etc. If I look in advance what is happening in Hamburg, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues: demonstrations, riots, so all negative headlines, including the summit, which is now on Weekend takes place, dominate. If you then take a look at the agenda for the G20 meeting and look at the selection of topics, it seems to me that the area of ​​dissent is preprogrammed, especially in the area of ​​climate policy. But I have two messages: firstly, I believe that it is important that the industrialized and emerging countries come together and discuss. That is the lesson that I would like to learn again from the moving act of mourning that took place here in our house last Saturday. It was really unique for me to be reminded of Helmut Kohl's message again: Keep talking, try to develop solutions together. That's why I think it's good that the G20 summit is taking place. And secondly, I think to myself that if you get just a little, a few positive messages, if you only get ahead in the area of ​​trade policy and in the area of ​​support for Africa, then it is already a great step forward.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to pay tribute to the Commission and Vice-President Timmermans on the issue of harnessing globalisation and the very important reflection paper that the Commission produced this year. How do we ensure fair globalisation? Globalisation brings a lot of benefits to us but also a lot of challenges to our societies, and the G20 summit in Hamburg is an opportunity for the EU to lead on how to create fairer globalisation in which everyone benefits. Many important topics have been mentioned already by the speakers here on climate change, on sustainable development goals, on the migration crisis and so on, and it is important that we in the European Union take the lead on all these issues. I also want to say that globalisation issues have troubled a lot of countries and citizens alike. Let me be clear and honest: when it comes to globalisation, the free and unregulated market has, to some extent, failed us. It has worked extremely well for multinational corporations and already-wealthy individuals, but for far too many ordinary workers – like the steel workers in France and the UK or the slaughterhouse workers in Denmark and Germany, to take examples – globalisation has also brought unfair competition, negative wage pressure, job insecurity and, in many cases, unemployment. So at the same time as enormous wealth has been created, it has not yet been fairly shared: that is clear. Why are the world’s eight richest people now wealthier? They are now wealthier than half of the world’s population. Real wages for middle-income families have stagnated in many societies, including in various parts of Europe, and in many EU countries real wages have actually shrunk. This is an outrage and we need to do something about it. This is a result of market liberalism run amok, and we need to change course. Showing European leadership on harnessing globalisation means ensuring that European values, principles and standards shape globalisation, and not vice-versa. For the Socialist and Democrats, a key principle is global tax justice. It was also mentioned by the Commission and I was glad to hear that. We are calling for global tax justice to be a top priority at the G20 summit too. We want the EU to take the lead on concrete new initiatives: we need a global asset register so that taxable assets can be traced and recovered; we need a global register of beneficial ownership so that tax fraud can be revealed; we also need to coordinate efforts to stop, punish and prevent tax havens – and this too was mentioned by the Commission. I think it is important we take the lead in that fight. We also need to ensure that corporate income tax is fair. This is an opportunity for the EU. Let us take the lead on all of these issues! We look forward to the G20 Summit. And thank you, Mr Timmermans, for the great speech.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Commissioners, colleagues. These are turbulent times. We face challenges which spread far beyond the borders of the European Union. We face global challenges which connect us all and require a global response. We face a humanitarian crisis, conflict at our doorstep and a barely recovering economy. This is why we need the Summit to be fruitful. Talk is cheap, and our electorate wants to see results. Unfortunately, leader summits have become better known for updating the family photo than for plotting a strategic course for the next twelve months. Leaders need to start looking at what they can realistically achieve at a global level in the next few months, and whilst the EU is willing to take on more and more responsibility on the world stage, the EU cannot start believing that it can solve every crisis by itself. We do not need an EU which thinks that just one policy can solve the migration crisis, but an EU which works with the UN, NATO, and the G20 to end the funding of terrorism and to punish the barbaric practice of human trafficking. The EU needs to sit at the table and commit to making the EU as global-facing and pro-free trade as possible. The EU needs to champion less regulation and lower taxes, not more red tape and bureaucracy. We need an EU which lives up to its obligations to protect the environment without stifling business, because it is jobs and growth which draw people out of poverty and prevent unsustainable economic migration. It is jobs and growth which bring countries closer together and gives people more self-confidence and respect. That is what we need to better connect us as nations and to help us move forward with confidence, unity and renewed vigour in the coming months.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Estonian Presidency: you are very welcome in this House. Thank you, Mr Timmermans, for your speech, and I was very glad to hear you used the word ‘challenge’, and not ‘crisis’, when you were speaking of migration because we talk a lot about ‘the migration crisis’, whereas what is really going on here is that there is a political and a moral crisis. The Estonian Presidency is absolutely right in saying that migration management is a global responsibility, and therefore it is to be welcomed that the German Presidency wants to put this firmly on the agenda of the G20, making it a global issue. At the same time, it is also a European responsibility and, as the Commissioner set out very clearly, Member States are not living up to their responsibility. They are abandoning Italy and they are abandoning Greece. I am reminded of a statement made by the Dutch Prime Minister at the time of a previous mass influx of migrants into Italy, when a journalist asked the Prime Minister ‘Isn’t it sad for Italy that, because of its geographical location, it has to take in all the refugees?’, and the Prime Minister said ‘Well, tough luck for Italy.’ That has been the attitude of Europe, and it is a shame. We are the most prosperous continent in the world. If we cannot manage this migration influx, then who can? We have to start assuming our responsibility. I am glad to see that the Commission has taken action: it has put forward a kind of action plan for Italy. But, first of all, the focus is now very much on what NGOs are doing, and I think we should stop the blame game. You can never blame NGOs for saving people’s lives. (Applause) Secondly, I wonder why we are not using the legal instruments at our disposal, such as the Temporary Protection Mechanism. We have it: why is it not being used? It can be adopted in the Council by a qualified majority vote. Thirdly, when will we stop using European money to fund dictators and failed regimes? How much more money are we going to send to Libya to let people die in miserable circumstances, not only in the Mediterranean, but also in ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Fabio DE MASI
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mister President! “The G20 is an event without legitimation. Only the UN has legitimacy. ”This quote does not come from me, but from the great French diplomat, resistance fighter and author of the UN Declaration of Human Rights, Stéphane Hessel. Therefore Hamburg will be outraged. The G20 summit will meet in my hometown, the most beautiful city in Germany. Nevertheless, many will leave the city when the fine gentlemen Trump or Erdoğan visit us. Hamburg, the gateway to the world, will be like a restricted area so that demonstrators do not harass the leaders. We don't like curfew in Hamburg, as the world-famous Reeperbahn proves every night. Of course, heads of state should talk to each other, especially in times of global crises. You don't have to do that in the Rocky Mountains either. But the G20 are negotiating the fate of the world. These debates therefore belong before the United Nations in New York. Then Mr. Trump would not have that far from the golf course either. The G20, which accounts for 80 percent of the world's national product, come together to discuss important issues: trade, migration, tax dumping, climate change, security and terrorism. Tax evaders are the real expensive refugees. Up to $ 30 trillion is stashed away in tax havens. According to Oxfam, around eight people now own as much as half the world's population. This is a sick development with all due respect. We have not only needed public investment in housing, schools, universities or hospitals since the refugee crisis. But the negotiation - also here in the EU - on a black list of tax havens is turning into diplomatic horse-trading. We finally need sources and penalty taxes on financial flows in tax havens, inside and outside the EU. The wars in the Middle East - from Afghanistan to Iraq, Libya or Syria - have created chaos, state collapse, terror and displacement. Not only Bombs and free trade agreements - as the EU is now aiming for with Japan after TTIP and CETA - have created major economic turmoil in Africa. The arms exports and the chumbling with terror godfathers like Saudi Arabia or the new EU bouncer - Erdoğan - made the Islamic State great. But the G20 are now discussing military defense against refugees and other lazy deals such as with Turkey, for example in Libya or Egypt. The Saudi king wanted to bring his camels to Hamburg - he can do that, we have sheep and fish. The port of Hamburg, on the other hand, is sending weapons to the Gulf dictators. And the EU wants to continue arming with the Defense Union. NATO is aiming for up to two percent of the national product. This is the money we need to fight poverty and climate change. A large majority of Hamburgers will therefore take to the streets peacefully against this policy - and that is a good thing.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in these days of tribute to Simone Veil, what lessons can be drawn from her career and her experience for the debate we are holding today? Simone Veil was a fighter for Europe, because she had survived the worst that Europe could produce, but she never reduced Europe to a commemoration. She always considered that Europe was a project of civilization for every woman, for every man, for us Europeans, and for the rest of the world. Simone Veil, today, would she be satisfied with a European project which would be a project for the unhindered circulation of goods, services and investments, which would put our legislation, our environmental and social regulations and our democratic sovereignty within reach? cannon of old world multinational corporations, oil, nuclear and endocrine disruptors? What would Simone Veil say when she saw the walls, barbed wire and camps that lock up people who are also people who survive? Today, Europe is alone against Trump, Putin, Erdoğan and Xi Jinping, but only it can carry a project of cooperation on an international scale, a project of solidarity and a project of protection of the commons. For this to happen, it must change its footing and that at the G20, it must not be there to promote free trade agreements which produce all the chaos in the world and which fuel a development model twice the size of the planet, twice as big in predation and twice as big in pollution. If there is one element that Europe must bring to the G20, in particular, it is this question of the climate and, to raise this question, it is not enough to say that we will respect the Paris Agreement: Europe is not on the trajectory of the Paris agreement in terms of reducing its greenhouse gas emissions. So let's go with a lot more ambition strong.Let's go ahead and say that the G20 promise to end public subsidies to fossil fuels must be implemented immediately.This is your responsibility, this is our responsibility, including if we want to be sincere and faithful to the tribute paid to Simone Veil.

name: Raymond FINCH
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the G20 meeting gives the EU an opportunity to speak to the major economies of the world and to find out what their perception of the post-Brexit landscape will be. I strongly suspect that the EU – and particularly the host nation Germany – is in for an unpleasant surprise. The non-EU countries will be eyeing up how to grab a bigger slice of the lucrative market of exports to the UK from you if the EU pursues its active economic self-harm by trying to exclude the UK from fair access to the single market. The European Union’s decision in declaring a post-Brexit economic war on the UK won’t act as a deterrent to other would-be leavers. Your huge trade surplus with the UK will crumble and other non-EU G20 nations will be licking their lips at the prospect of trading with, and exporting to, the UK. The revitalised, liberalised United Kingdom will be seen as a key trading partner by these nations, and we will see cars made in Detroit, rather than Stuttgart, on British roads. For your own economic wellbeing, I urge the EU negotiators to look into the hungry eyes of your fellow G20 nations and reflect upon the damage your present course will have on your precious project. Thank you.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - What is the EU doing on the G-20? The Council and the Commission are incompetent. They are not even able to tackle and solve the major problems in the European Union. Unemployment is still dramatic, banks are still falling apart. The mountain of debt is still greater than ever, migrants are still pouring into the EU by the thousands a day and attacks continue almost every week. The solutions for today come from the patriots. This Commission should take an example from the Visegrad countries rather than condemn them. Mr Juncker must take an example from his fellow party member Mr Orban and close the borders. Chain the boats of criminal NGOs, put the crew under lock and key and confiscate the assets of these NGOs. Juncker must order Frontex to apply the Australian model. Boats must be towed back to Libya. Migrants are now safer in Libya than English in England, French in France or Germans in Germany. You are a completely incompetent and irresponsible driver and I say to Juncker and his sidekick, Mr Timmermans: get out! Let the patriots take over. We do take responsibility. We have the solutions and we do take effective measures. (The speaker addressed a "blue card" question under Rule 162 (8).)

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: "blue card" question.- Mr De Graaff, it is not the first time that I have heard you intervene on this in plenary, making accusations against people who work very hard.I think your statement that there are criminal NGOs because they rescue people at sea who would otherwise drown should be removed from the report.There are indeed people smugglers, human traffickers, that we must punish, but we must not scorn NGOs that do a very good job in the field as if they were criminals.Mr Chairman, I urge that these gratuitous allegations by Mr De Graaff be removed from the report.Let us as Europe pursue a truly European asylum and migration policy, so that we do not have to rely on NGOs, but that we are grateful to them for their work.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: I am very sorry but with all the understanding one may have for your point, the blue card is there to ask a question of the speaker. You did not ask a question of the speaker. Please use the procedures that are foreseen if you want to ask for something to be deleted from the Minutes. You may do so in a personal remark at the end of the debate.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Mr President, here we are again. I have a question for you, First Vice-President Timmermans. It is a very specific question, and I would like you to give me – as well as Hungarians and a number of other people who are interested – a very specific answer. Suppose we were to follow your order and receive migrants and refugees in my country, Hungary. You, as well as every single person in this room, know perfectly well that those people would not want to stay in Hungary because they want a better life. They would like to move on to richer countries like Germany, Austria, Sweden, and so on. Mr Timmermans, how can we hold them back? What is the order, so to say, in this respect? We all know very well that we cannot put these people into a closed institution; they have the right to freedom of movement. I know we should integrate them. This will probably be the answer, but this is the wrong answer, Mr Timmermans and dear colleagues, because they would not like to be integrated in Hungary, they would like to move on the next day to richer countries.  So you must have a strategy on that, because your whole strategy about the treatment of the migrant crisis is based on the idea of solidarity among Member States and forcing all Member States, including my country Hungary, to receive migrants. So how would you solve this problem? I look forward to your answer, Mr Timmermans.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! Today, on his way to the G20, the President of the United States lands in Poland, waiting for a promised, warm welcome, somewhat artificially organized. However, if it confirms today guarantees under Art. 5 NATO, it will be an extremely important value for all countries neighboring Putin's Russia and which have experienced “fraternal” help from the Red Army in the past. However, neither of these countries should play a part in weakening the European Union. Each of these countries, in the name of its own security, should create elements of European defense just in case. For many reasons, the G20 summit is a difficult task for the hosts, not least because of the demonstrations that actually make the headlines of the newspapers and media. Today it is difficult to find what we call the Euro-Atlantic community of values, which was the foundation of the post-war peace order and the world of free man. Hence, I believe, the very broad agenda of this meeting, but the slightly lowered expectations as to the effects of the G-20 in Hamburg. It is therefore necessary to be able to confirm the minimum that has in common, and what actually has in common is a common fight against terrorism, with the sources of terrorism, and slowing down the migration wave, because here the shaken sense of security in Europe and not only in Europe is resolved. But there is more and more evidence that we can handle it.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: - Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner Timmermans, ladies and gentlemen! Yes, there is a lot of bad news globally - Angelika Niebler mentioned a few - and that is why it is all the more important that we use all opportunities to re-establish global governance. Especially in view of the behavior of some countries that say “my country first” or “my America first”, we as Europeans have to counter this: “people first”. That must be the motto for global governance - to set up global structures in the interests of the people. And I do believe that the EU must set some priorities here. We heard: Africa must be a priority. No question about it, we have to develop a sustainable development strategy for Africa so that people at home have a perspective and can make their life chances a reality there. Investing and good governance for Africa is - in my view - a priority for the EU. Then of course it's also about empowering women. When the ILO speaks of the forgotten billion, the third billion forgotten people, it means women who are unable to develop their skills - empowering women, the second priority. The third priority: fair trade, of course, and not just freer, away from protectionism. When the ILO says that the 780 million people who also produce products for us in global value chains do not have enough income to finance their own lives - then something is wrong! We have to have fair conditions for global value chains, we have to strengthen workers' rights. Only then is trade not only free but also fair, and that must be the third priority. Hamburg is indeed a beautiful city, but Hamburg also represents the free and fair spirit of people, and that's why Hamburg should do this too be a symbol.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Mr President, in times of challenge, security should define the credibility of partners, including trade partners. I therefore welcome the agreement with Japan. The dreams before G20 were already overshadowed by an exclusive deal between Russia and China, as well as rather unfriendly military exercises on the Baltic Sea. Our response to this – the Western response to this – should be a closer transatlantic alliance, with both the US and Canada.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: - Mister President! First of all, I would like to say clearly: I think it's good that this G20 summit is taking place. The G20 summits are one of the few places where different actors speak to one another at a time of globalization and the crisis of multilateralism. You have to seize this opportunity. In addition, however, it must also be made clear that the debate before the G20 is determined by false alternatives. Because there is also something between the global trade order and financial market order as we have it today and Trump's protectionism. The way in between is the globalization of social and ecological rules, which must go hand in hand with the opening of the markets, and that is why one can only say to the EU: The time has now come, with the free trade agenda, with the bilateral agreements as they have been drafted so far are, as you have now drafted them again with Japan, not just to carry on like this, but we need contracts that use the opportunity of the hour to anchor social and ecological rules enforceably as part of these standards. We cannot continue like this there; we need to strengthen international cooperation, but in such a way that social and ecological rules are strengthened. What is currently happening in Hamburg at this G20 summit is sad in other respects too, because Hamburg is indeed a liberal city, and part of this liberal spirit is that not only the heads of state are welcomed, but also the demonstrators Protesters demonstrating peacefully. An open city must be valid for them too.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: - Economic growth, trade, taxation are, as a rule, the main topics of such meetings.However, I do not understand one thing: as is the case here, as the economy grows every year, the supposedly good trade agreements expand, the globalization presented as an advantage, the world community becomes more and more poor and food becomes more expensive.Maybe the reason for this is the misallocation of income, agreements between global companies and banks, raising capital without social responsibility?Maybe the economy is grown far from the welfare of society?Income inequality, the risk of poverty, the persistent unemployment of millions of people are the most important problems today.It is also far more important that economic growth is properly exploited to create the common good, to rationally invest earnings and redistribute income for the enrichment of society, rather than to increase the profits of individual corporations.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: - I am taking advantage of this geopolitical forum, the preparation of the G-20, to make a case for the revision of the Geneva Convention.Started as a concept with noble and lofty goals, it has now become totally maladjusted and has become outdated by the facts.The care for refugees, mainly from the then communist Eastern Europe, has now degenerated into an ordinary industrial mass invasion resulting in cultural uprooting, rape and endless unemployment, a dark alliance between a dirty business, between NGOs, human traffickers and that.all under the auspices of the European institutions.Stop the Geneva Convention, replace it with genuine refugee status with reception in your own region, and, as we now see in Syria, a return to the countries of origin after the conflict.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr President, my thanks to Mr Timmermans. As we approach the G20 Summit, we do so with our world facing huge challenges that threaten the common values and ideals that we share. In the United Kingdom, in London, in Manchester, in cities across Europe, Brussels, Paris and Berlin, terrorist attacks have brought death and destruction. The events in the Korean peninsula are a stark and vivid reminder of darker days we thought were in the past. The migration crisis continues. In the past ten days alone, an estimated 10 000 migrants have arrived in Italy from Libya, and yet we continue with the same bit-part solution that we have always had.  On all of these issues, a coordinated approach is required right across the G20 to bring about meaningful and lasting results – strong and united leadership based upon shared ideas of freedom, democracy and tolerance.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: - Mr President, Mr President of the Council, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, the world lives on a volcano which can wake up at any time. The eruption may be due to the war in Syria, to the confrontation between the Shiites and Sunnis in the Gulf, especially in Yemen, or even to the aggressiveness of North Korea, which are symptoms of a deeply unstable world. The eruption can also be economic and social, if we are not careful to strengthen ourselves in the face of globalization, in particular by continuing financial regulation, fighting against dumping or working for fairer taxation. Terrorism, migration challenge, climate challenge, democratic challenge, economic challenge… It is high time that the European Union finally looked at the African continent in a different way and helped it to develop and become peaceful. It is up to us to occupy the leadership position that America has given up, because Donald Trump is figuring, but his posturing does not fool anyone. G20 leaders know that in the game of musical chairs, the fastest wins. If it is not Europe, it will be China or Russia that will win, and we will sit there with our arms dangling. The European Union has always aimed to share and disseminate its values ​​and ideals. On this commemoration day in Paris, in honor of Simone Veil, the first President of this Parliament, let us be inspired by her exceptional example of life. The G20 must be an opportunity for European leaders to show that they have a vision, not only for our continent, but also for the rest of the world.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, Mr Head of the Council, multilateralism is in the DNA of the European Union. The G20 will be held at the center of Europe at a time when both Brexit and the Trump administration deny the value of multilateralism. Basically, for you, Mr. Vice-President, for the European Union and for each of the Heads of State or Government who will participate in this G20, there is a double task. In the G20 itself, we must ensure that what the left arm says ceases to be ignored by the right arm. We cannot have played this exemplary role in the conclusion of the Paris agreement at the COP 21 and leave a finance which, in the Basel fora, ignores the objectives of financing the ecological transition. For this, the work carried out by the think tank entitled "Task force on climate related financial disclosure" (TCFD) must be supported, while the Trump administration wants to ignore all the conclusions it has reached under the aegis of Mr. Bloomberg. You must, on behalf of the Commission, tell the Member States how much this think tank needs to be supported and how important it is that its conclusions become the roadmap for the G20. For the European Union, this means that, in each of the bodies, first in Basel, but also within the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB), you must defend, and implement in the form of market regulation, these requirements of a change in the investment climate in favor of a transition to the financing of long-term investments, of renewable energies to the detriment of fossil economies, which continue to irrigate too many criteria of excellence of the European economy . Without forgetting this meeting on the fight against tax havens: the OECD proposal, for a list which would now only contain Trinidad and Tobago, cannot be the sheet of route of the European Union.We are counting on each of the European players in this G20 to carry a strong voice.May the fight against tax havens remain a priority!

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! The European Union is one of the three big players among the G20, which is why the European Union is setting itself big goals: Africa should be led to growth and jobs - all of Africa - and that would then be the solution to the migration crisis. Ladies and gentlemen, can we please stay on the carpet! The European Union has not even managed to bring Greece back to growth and jobs, little Greece, which compared to African countries is a really well-organized, well-developed state with a strong government. We have not been able to lead this small country to growth and jobs. And that is why it is unrealistic to talk about all of Africa now and want to stabilize all of Africa and lead it on a growth path. We have to concentrate, we have to formulate realistic goals. These realistic goals in the course of the immigration crisis can only be that we concentrate on the north of Africa, on the Mediterranean countries in Africa, on the Arab states, where growth and jobs are also required and where Islamic terrorism finds its breeding ground. That is the priority and that is what we should focus on!

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: – Mr President, the G20 will actually revolve around Presidents Trump and Putin, not you. These two men working together can defeat ISIS. These two men understand the threat of migration and culture, jobs and identity. And migrants – no, no, no! What don’t you understand? We have got to secure our borders. Our cultures and identities are under threat and you are incapable of dealing with it. Presidents Trump and Putin actually get this. They understand the nation state and putting up walls and barriers. We need to arrest and deport the migrants and tow them back to Libya. The Paris climate change agreement is a bad business deal, and Trump gets that because he is a businessman and he is right. And you are obsessed with the gender agenda. Please, we women do not need special treatment. I am not special needs, I take it most of you are not special needs. Stop singling us out. And get real to the threats we face: it is migrants, ISIS and security. You do not have the solutions. The nation state is the way forward, as we are showing in Brexit and the Visegrad countries. Your speeches this morning have confirmed that the death knell of the EU is ringing, so get used to it and go back to your nation states.

name: Diane JAMES
text: –Mr President, good morning everyone in the Chamber and thank you, Mr Timmermans, for the lack of tantrums that we saw yesterday from Mr Juncker, entertaining as it was. I have two observations to make, and they are serious ones. We have heard this morning the usual calls for open markets, improved trade agreements and religiously enshrining and making sure delivery of consumer protectionism and such. But just remember please, everyone attending the G20, that when we talk about the impact in terms of job losses, falling wages and decreasing lifestyles and living standards, that’s what voters measure G20 meetings by, and we need to be a little bit more flexible in terms of that approach and the timing to achieve the objectives. But the other clear message for me that I would love the G20 to address is the existing European Union monetary policy, which clearly favours one major Member State and penalises so many others. We have young people out there who want jobs – want to work – and they have to leave their countries because of the EU monetary policy. So please can we send some very clear messages and change tack.

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: - Mr President, Council, Commission, it should be remembered that in human history there has not been a single period in which progress has been made, in which progress has been made through isolation and protectionism. That must never be forgotten. But today more than ever, in a globalized society, only through an open economy and an open society can we continue to advance. That is why the European Union has to maintain a constant leadership position in the G20 in the face of the isolationist vagaries that some countries are now showing. This is essential. But openness and non-isolationism begin with the house itself. And, in that sense, the digital single market needs to be a full reality, because it is the determining factor of the global competitiveness of our economy. That is why we should welcome the fact that the Estonian Presidency has made the banner of digital affairs in this period. And, in that sense, I have to say that I am confident that we can reach an agreement on the European Code of Electronic Communications and thus contribute to the full connectivity that our companies and our society need.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, as the rapporteur of this European Parliament for the trade agreement between the European Union and Japan, I want to underline the enormous strategic importance of the political agreement that the two parties are due to announce tomorrow at a bilateral summit on the sidelines of the G20. This agreement between two of the world's largest economic powers is a great opportunity for the European economy and is a strong message against protectionism and in favor of not only open trade, but fairer and more regulated global trade. Let's be clear, though. This is not the end of the road. Important issues are still open and Parliament will remain vigilant until the end of the negotiations, demanding more transparency, starting with the disclosure of a negotiating mandate and the full safeguarding of our environmental, social and labor values ​​and standards, within the framework of a strong chapter on sustainable development. It is that fair and ambitious agreement that we want between the European Union and Japan.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Vice-President Timmermans, yesterday we read an agency where you say that, since Austria has not notified the controls at the Brenner border, the Commission cannot give its reaction. Unfortunately today in Italy the front pages of the newspapers are full of this news, and you can imagine that instead the citizens react, and how. Unfortunately, the veil of hypocrisy has fallen, we can say it clearly, because the European countries seem different in words, in fact they are all the same, they really all prove to be the same. In Berlin, someone had deluded themselves that they had brought home some results; rhetoric aside, we have brought home a very meager result, the code for NGOs, while the ports of other European countries remain all sealed. This is why we are placing our hopes on the G20. You have also said here that it is the most important international forum, where collaboration is shared. Well, we hope that this forum will take care of migration in the Mediterranean, a phenomenon of such proportions that it must be managed by the whole international community. And I bring a message to President Juncker: don't settle for ridiculous solutions, please, and take home something concrete. We remembered Helmut Kohl in this House on Saturday. He was remembered as a man of the future, because he chose the right path and history followed him. Here, he sees, either Europe takes back this capacity, it will be able to take back this capacity, or it won't be. In that case, we won't regret it much.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: - Building a connecting world sounds a tiny bit cynical when you see what's going on in Italy again. You yourself said, Vice-President Timmermans, that if all the Member States were to do what we had agreed to tackle the crisis, we would not be in trouble today. It's really outrageous that we're back there. I say this because many intervene. I certainly want to support that too. But I also say it because we now know that we are not going to solve the migration crisis by taking short-term measures, but effectively by creating a connecting world. One of the first and most important things we need to do in the G-20 is to make sure that there can be, should be, some kind of united position on how to apply the Paris climate agreement. Because if we don't tackle the climate, then these are the appetizers, the problems surrounding migration today will be the appetizers of tomorrow and those problems will continue to grow. Yesterday at the Commission's work program I stressed very much that the first thing we need to do is lead by example ourselves and I also look at my colleagues in the hemisphere. We are working hard on a number of dossiers such as the clean energy package. Let us make that as ambitious as possible, that is our first responsibility. Second, the United States. We all know, I am not at all positive about what President Trump can and will do, but above all let us not turn our backs on the United States. Let us reach out to those states in the United States that do want to make progress, that are not at all served by Trump's policies. I think that the necessary work must also be done there within the G20 in bilateral contacts. A third point: we have tradable emission rights today. Let's not just hold on tight to that, but let's use it as a connection to get into the rest of the world also install a very good pricing mechanism for CO2.Good luck I would say.I think it is more than ever necessary to take these actions on a global level.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: - Mr President, Presidency of the Council, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, I would like to leave three notes: the first does not go directly to the G20 agenda, but to the international situation in which this meeting is taking place. What is happening to North Korea at the moment and what is happening on the Arabian peninsula with Qatar and a number of Arab states, namely Saudi Arabia and Egypt, requires global intervention. For many long-term policies that we are agreeing on in the G20, if there is a serious crisis, whether on the Korean peninsula or the Arabian peninsula, all these reinforcements will be immediately called into question and here Europe is able to build bridges between the United States, China and Russia, between the United States, Iran and Saudi Arabia, and we must not renounce that role. Two words later for the G20's own agenda. The first to say that the European Union - and here we do not need the G20 - cannot leave Italy, Greece, including Spain, alone on this issue of refugees. It is everyone's responsibility: from the north, east, south and west of Europe. And, secondly, I would like to say - with the great experience that the Portuguese have in Africa - that, if we do not bet seriously, and this may already be a responsibility of the G20, in the development of Africa, we will all end up continuing to increase this tragedy that is taking place in the Mediterranean.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! The next weekend - as so often - the question will be: How do we deal with the challenges of globalization and its undesirable developments? We are all well aware that we have to shape globalization so that globalization doesn't shape us. To do this, Europe must join forces. The problems within Europe do not just begin or end at the external border of the European Union. I therefore expect the G20 to make a clear commitment against protectionism, for multilateralism, for fair international trade and for compliance with international agreements, international law and international values. Yes, we need global governance. Yes, we have to make the future of our shared world a shared responsibility. Refugee and migratory flows are a global challenge, Africa is a global challenge. Let's finally fight for more fairness, justice, responsibility and cooperation! Who isolates himself ... (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Mr. President, 20 countries, 20 different political systems, 20 different levels of development, 4/5 of the world's gross domestic product, 3/4 of global world trade, 2/3 of the world's population. Who better than these G20s can solve the problems we face? So far, we have always dealt with financial and economic crises and these issues, but this time the title is: "Shaping a Connected World". How to connect the world, how to use globalization in the best possible way, how to use globalization positively? Against protectionism, against isolation, against narrow-minded national policies, and for connecting the world and for the positive exploitation of globalization. I will not forget the issue of women and equality of women, which is one of the topics at the G20. I’m glad you put that on the agenda, but I’m sure there will be many other topics opening up in the world these days, like North Korea. I hope that the G20 will answer these questions and that Putin and Trump will finally meet and get closer.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, for the last twenty years globalisation has defeated poverty in region after region. There is more to do, but it is a process that is thanks to globalisation, and it has created bigger markets for European companies than we have ever seen: crucial for the recovery we are just seeing in the European economy. We need to defend the stability of this world order that has provided for this. We need to see Russia as the threat it is, with the disinformation, cyber war and the warfare we see, for example, in Ukraine. We need to see that the US is not the credible partner we are used to seeing. When the US gets smaller, we need to get taller, reaching out for free trade and supporting with the national governance. That is the most important aim: that we can take leadership in this global development.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: - Mr President!It is sweeping a wave of protectionism around the world, and Trump and Brexit are perhaps two of the clearest examples of that.The G20 summit in Hamburg is the most important opportunity we have right now to fight this protectionism and isolationism.We cannot afford this protectionism.In our part of the world it costs money and jobs, but in poor parts of the world it actually costs lives.Since 2008, three times as many protectionist measures have been introduced as those of trade facilitation, a total of 3,800 worldwide.In the past, the G20 made a statement in support of free trade, but at the last meeting, Trump put a stop to it.When the US fails then the EU must take the lead.That is why the free trade agreement with Japan is fantastic news, but it is not enough.We must move forward and conclude a free trade agreement with Mexico, South America, Australia and New Zealand, because it depends on Europe, now that the United States is failing.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - The G20 could make a difference against inequality, for global justice in taxes, for the destruction of tax havens, but I don't expect anything from the G20, nor does it even have a formal existence. But from the Estonian presidency, I expect, and ask, for decisive action in two absolutely crucial areas to save or sink the European Union. First, intelligent management, with a strategic vision and respect for human rights and international law, the unstoppable phenomenon, the unstoppable challenge we face in migration, which we cannot continue to manage as if it were a threat and not an opportunity for Europe in demographic decline. Managing migration means tackling the causes of terrorism. The European Union needs to open secure, controlled legal channels for immigrant refugees and not continue to feed the business of drug dealers. There is no European Union if we leave Italy and Greece alone to face this problem, as has been said, and we cannot think about externalizing our responsibilities by paying detention camps in Libya. The second priority is obviously tax justice and is linked to this because otherwise the phenomenon of migration will not stop.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: - Mr President, as the United States becomes more and more introverted, it means that Europe has the opportunity and the important role to play in taking more space and leadership in the international arena. When the European Union is united, we are strong. A good example of this is the Paris Climate Agreement, which would not have been possible without the European Union's hard work in international fora. Trade policy and development policy, which are on the agenda, are now particularly important themes at the G20. I am very glad that the Commission has taken a truly active role in trade policy. We know that there is now global demand for European trade, and the rules and agreements we enter into with international partners govern the whole of world trade. In managing globalization, it is important that we are active internationally. In this way, we aim to increase entrepreneurship and work in Europe from the point of view of international trade. Here, the Japan negotiations are now in good shape.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the G20 Summit on 7 and 8 July comes at a time when full trade liberalization and globalization have dismantled European societies and created armies of the poor and unemployed. This is because world trade rewards countries with unfair practices. Thus, American and European multinationals have established, through the practice of outsourcing, their industrial production in Asian countries, where child labor flourishes, Chineseization of wages, the dissolution of labor relations and the violation of health and safety conditions, and all this is done with the aim of making a profit. It is time to demand an end to unfair trade practices and to implement policies that will protect the citizens of the Union who are losing their jobs. It is time to block CETA, TTIP and the various other multilateral trade agreements, and this can only be done by applying the principle of Community preference. At the same time, measures are needed to limit the migration flows affecting Greece and Italy.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Timmermans, the G20 is not a formalized structure nor does it act with a single legal personality in the international community; the European Union, yes, and it is represented in the G20 not only by the Commission, but by up to five Member States of the European Union. And it would be very good if there were no cacophony, but unity of position to stand up to the populist-in-chief, who withdraws the United States from the pact against climate change; and to demand a relentless fight against avoidance, evasion and, of course, tax havens, to combat the globalization of exasperating inequality; but, above all, to demand a global response to the challenge of migration. And for that, it would be very good for the European Union to honor the Lisbon Treaty and the commitment and mandate of solidarity between the Member States; not to leave Italy alone and left to its own devices; and that it establish, once and for all, legal channels and humanitarian visas so that the desperate people of the Earth would have a chance to try to reach Europe without abandoning themselves to the mafias or losing their lives in the attempt.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, at the forthcoming G20 Summit, all the serious issues that concern not only the countries of the European Union but also all of humanity will be discussed as always. But the problems that arise from these serious issues, such as the economy, trade, fair taxation, development, tackling terrorism and immigration, cannot be solved by the global governance sought by the G20 and which is suggested by many of you. Globalization and global governance mean leveling, which does not solve problems, but imposes the views of international sovereigns. International problems will be solved with a sincere and serious cooperation of sovereign and independent states or an association of such states that know their particularities and on the basis of these particularities try to find the most feasible and pragmatic solution.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I will try and react to some of the comments that were made and questions that were put to the Commission. First, on the refugee crisis and our cooperation with the Italian authorities on a code of conduct. There is no one at the Commission who accuses NGOs of anything. I have stated very clearly yesterday in the press conference that the intentions of the NGOs are noble and good. What they are trying to do is save people from drowning in the Mediterranean. Nobody contests that. The only thing I have said very clearly yesterday is that a code of conduct could be helpful to avoid accidents at sea, to avoid misunderstandings, to make sure that the Libyan coast guard, once it is at the level needed, can do its job in Libyan territorial waters. That is the intention of our cooperation with the Italian authorities. I want to be crystal clear about that. To the honourable Member, Ms Gardini, I would say this: I understand your criticism of the Commission and of what we are doing, but I think we are in this fight together. We are doing our best to encourage Member States to do what they have promised and to join with extra efforts to make this situation in Italy more bearable on all of us. But I would also ask her and other colleagues here in Parliament: could they please help us in talking to the prime ministers who are part of your political families, and tell them also they should take the responsibility? I understand – Ms in ‘t Veld said very clearly – she criticised the prime minister from her political family. Great. But talk to the prime ministers in your political family and convince them to do what needs to be done, and then we can all do the same job together instead of criticising each other. We are on the same line, the Commission and the European Parliament. Let’s join efforts and convince the leaders of our nations, who are all part of one of mainly three political families in this House, to make sure that they do their bit. I believe if we do that together, we will get results fairly quickly. Now, just a remark about Brexit. I know that Mr Finch operates under the Farage doctrine here in the European Parliament, which is to make outrageous statements and then run away before anybody can react. But still, I want to use the opportunity to react. I think we are all under an economic, political and above all moral obligation to do the least harm possible in this Brexit process. I think nobody disputes that position and attitude of the Commission, of the Member States and, I would argue also, of Her Majesty’s government in London. But to go from there and to say that the whole of the European Union is going to suffer terribly in the G20 because of Brexit is a bit rich, frankly. And Mr Finch, just so you know, I am a great admirer of British culture and I love the UK deeply, whether they are in the EU or not, but Mr Finch really reminds me of a character created by John Cleese in Monty Python’s The Holy Grail. It is the Black Knight, who, after being defeated terribly and all his limbs cut off, says to his opponent: ‘Let’s call it a draw’. What I would like to say to Ms Morvai, who has developed a new practice of asking questions to me every time I am here – and credit to her, she waits to hear the answer – I wanted to say this. She asked me precisely the question about refugees. But let me turn this around one moment. What would have happened if, in 1956 the Swedish Prime Minister, the Danish Prime Minister, the German Chancellor, the Dutch Prime Minister, the Belgian Prime Minister, the Luxembourgish Prime Minister, had said: ‘These Hungarians, these people culturally don’t belong here. These people will change our culture in a way that we cannot accept.’ What would have happened in 1956 if that had been done? I am proud of the European legacy where, when people are persecuted by an inhuman Communist regime such as the regime at the time in Hungary, they find safe refuge in other European countries – and the Hungarian communities across Europe have made an incredible contribution to our societies and have reached the highest level of all these societies in the first, second and third generation. That would be my answer to you, Ms Morvai. And to Ms Atkinson, I really would like to say: how can you develop this profound admiration for President Putin on the basis of national sovereignty? Who in Europe has had more disregard of national sovereignty than President Putin, who occupies part of another sovereign nation? Who has had less disregard for this? How can you admire a man and his politics based on your analysis of national sovereignty? It is completely beyond me. Finally, if you will allow me, I will answer Mr de Graaff in the same language that he and I share. Mijnheer De Graaff heeft het over de patriottische lente die door zijn politieke leider in Nederland voortdurend werd verkondigd. Mijnheer De Graaff vertegenwoordigt een politieke beweging die in het land dat ik het beste ken, succes heeft geboekt bij een deel van het electoraat dat zich in de steek gelaten voelt door de traditionele partijen, zoals ook mijn eigen partij. Als mensen naar je partij toe komen, geeft je dat ook een grote verantwoordelijkheid om iets te doen aan de zorgen die ertoe leiden dat mensen denken dat je een oplossing hebt. Maar de beweging van de heer De Graaff laat mensen alleen maar in de steek, door alleen maar woede te voeden, door alleen maar boosheid op tafel te leggen, door nooit eens een keer met een constructieve oplossing te komen, door nooit te proberen onderdeel van de oplossing te zijn, alleen maar proberen het probleem op te kloppen en groter te maken en ik zeg tegen de heer De Graaff – en hiermee wil ik eindigen – ik zie inderdaad een patriottische lente in Europa.  Het is een Europese patriottische lente die in Bratislava werd getoond door de Europese leiders toen ze samen een toekomst uitstippelden die we samen gaan vormgeven; die in Rome werd getoond door de Europese leiders toen ze aangaven samen de toekomst te willen aangeven; die op de G-20-top zal worden getoond door Europese leiders als ze aangeven dat de toekomst van de wereld, het welzijn van de Europeanen, alleen maar op duurzame manier kan worden gerealiseerd als Europeanen dat sámen doen, niet op basis van een vals idee van nationale soevereiniteit tegen mekaar, niet door neer te kijken op andere Europeanen of minderheden in de eigen samenleving, maar door iedereen de kracht te geven om samen een betere wereld te vormen.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Thank you, First Vice-President, and thank you also for reminding us of John Cleese and his contributions to our common European culture. Please do inform us when you charge a Commissioner with a department for silly walks!

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank all Member for their comments, which remind us once again that we are facing challenging times on several fronts, especially with the geopolitical and political uncertainties which are still very high. I therefore look forward to a strong message of confidence from G20 leaders. We need to preserve the spirit of cooperation in the G20 and to continue providing multilateral answers to the challenges that we are facing. This also means maintaining and building on their achievements of the past and not giving in to protectionism and isolationism.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: That concludes the item. (The sitting was suspended for a few moments) Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: in writing. - I would correct Mr Timmermans's remarks on the '56 revolution and the subsequent escape of Central European Hungarians to Western Europe. A II. Until World War II, Europe was a diverse but unified continent with a Christian-Jewish culture. This unity was broken by the communist regime, wreaking physical and mental destruction. Unfortunately, the damage caused by the four-decade rupture has not yet been fully remedied. That is why the analogy that the few thousand '56 Hungarian refugees are the same as the mass influx of refugees from the African and Asian continents into the EU today is unfortunate. Following the events of '56, some of those who still believed in freedom and democracy left Hungary in the direction of a better life, which was previously valid in their homeland as well. The ’56s knew why and where they were going, which is not clear in the present case. It is not fair to separate the eastern and western parts of the EU with such non-truthful statements. It does not serve unity, it does not even lead to a solution. In addition to solving problems from outside, if we want a better Europe, we must pay the same attention to Europeans, be they Dutch, French or Hungarian, or even living in a minority. I am thinking of indigenous minorities, for whose rights the EU has not yet taken decisive action.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: written. - The G20 is not a formalized structure nor does it act with a single legal personality in the international community; the European Union, yes, and it is represented in the G20 not only by the Commission, but by up to five Member States of the European Union. It is essential that there is no cacophony, but unity of position to speak with one voice in front of Donald Trump and his desire to withdraw the United States from the pact against climate change; and to demand a relentless fight against avoidance, evasion and, of course, tax havens, to combat the globalization of exasperating inequality; but, above all, to demand a global response to the challenge of migration. And for that, it would be very good for the European Union to honor the Lisbon Treaty and the commitment and mandate of solidarity between the Member States; not to leave Italy alone and left to its own devices; and that it establish, once and for all, legal channels and humanitarian visas so that the desperate people of the Earth would have a chance to try to reach Europe without abandoning themselves to the mafias or losing their lives in the attempt.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- The G20, which accounts for up to 4/5 of the world's gross domestic product and 2/3 of the world's population, will meet this month to discuss important issues of trade, tax dumping, climate change, migration, security, terrorism and other important topics of general interest.I am glad that this summit is taking place.In an age of globalization that brings us many benefits, but also many challenges, it is an opportunity to engage in a dialogue for a fairer globalization and focus on creating and realizing realistic goals.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I hope that EU leaders can come to the G20 summit better equipped than before, because after fruitful debates over the last two years, the June European Council was finally able to go beyond the refugee crisis to address and decide on common challenges for the future of the world and European citizens. such as global economic growth, the importance of implementing the Paris Convention and common security. Without underestimating the importance of Africa and the sustainable development goals, I believe that the key issue of the meeting for European interests, the future of migratory movements, is to guarantee international peace and security, especially in Syria and Iraq. I find the EU's position vis-à-vis global partners on migration less reassuring. Important resolutions in principle on border control, refugee distribution and a humane approach to migration cannot be considered a decision defining joint EU action until the EiT is able to put an end to the European and foreign mine action of its own members, such as the Orbán government. . At the same time, the EU must continue to play a critical, guiding and exemplary role in the G20 and the international arena in addressing migration in the management of migration, human rights and the humane treatment of refugees.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - With regard to a Social Pillar designed to whiten the neoliberal policies of the EU, 20 concrete proposals are made which appear to be an authentic manual of exploitation and leveling under labor and social rights. They promote the deepening of exploitation and precariousness through "flexibility", attack the right to social protection and public and universal social security, align the "retirement age with life expectancy". They defend the precariousness and the submission of social and labor rights to the wishes of employers, big business and the interests of the EU's power directory. Any reference to public service policies, such as education or health, is eliminated. They assume a mercantilist view of rights, whether in social protection, health, education, water, sanitation, energy, transport, among others, whoever wants them to pay them! An exploration manual that urgently needs to be rejected and with it the EU's policies and constraints that promote poverty, inequality and the asphyxiation of sovereign peoples and countries.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the presentation of the programme of activities of the Estonian Presidency (2017/2659(RSP)). I give a very warm welcome to the Prime Minister of Estonia, Mr Ratas, who is now President-in-Office of the Council.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: nõukogu eesistuja. – Austatud istungi juhataja! Juulis 1979 pidas esimese kõne esimese otsevalitud Euroopa Parlamendi ees Louise Weiss, kelle järgi see maja on oma nime saanud. Oma kõnes viitas Weiss, tollal 89-aastane „Euroopa Vanaema“, Hermann Keyserlingi loomingule. Keyserling oli Eestis sündinud filosoof, kes juba 20. sajandi alguses omas visiooni ühtsest Euroopast. Euroopast, kus riigid töötavad koos, aga säilitavad oma unikaalsuse. Euroopast, mis on tugev just oma mitmekesisuse tõttu. Samal istungil presidendina oma esimese kõne pidanud Simone Veil (keda just neil hetkil Pariisis viimasele teekonnale saadetakse) rõhutas, et ainult Euroopa dimensiooni kaudu on võimalik leida lahendus kolmele suurele väljakutsele: rahule, vabadusele ja heaolule. See on endiselt nii. 38 aastat hiljem on mul au seista siin, et esitleda Eesti Euroopa Liidu Nõukogu esimese eesistumise prioriteete. Keyserlingi ja Weissi ajaga võrreldes on palju muutunud, kuid idee Euroopa rahvaste liidust on püsima jäänud. The European Union is not only an idea. For 500 million people in the EU, it is their daily reality. Europeans want and deserve a union that is strong and decisive and that delivers. To achieve that, we must ensure that every voice is heard and balance the different traditions, interests and opinions in Europe, fairly. This is why the overarching theme of our Presidency is Unity through Balance.  First, before I turn to our plans, I acknowledge that no Presidency can succeed, alone. We will work very closely with you, honourable Members of the European Parliament, to make sure that citizens are at the heart of everything we do. We need your wisdom and input on every topic on our agenda. We are very grateful to Malta for their excellent work paving the way for us and our trio partners – Bulgaria and Austria. In Bratislava, Malta and Rome, we had a frank and honest discussion about where we stand and what we need to do to weather the storms ahead and emerge stronger.  It is our shared agenda, with the honourable Parliament, to find concrete answers to our citizens’ most pressing concerns – unemployment, security and immigration – and to bring Europe closer to our citizens. For the Estonian Council Presidency, our key aim is to move forward with the EU’s positive agenda The four priorities that we will focus on over the next six months reflect these discussions and are guided by the spirit of the Rome Declaration. They include an open and innovative European economy, an inclusive and sustainable Europe, a safe and secure Europe and, of course, a digital Europe with the free movement of data. Our priority of an open and innovative European economy, a strong and competitive European economy, supports growth and employment. Of course, that will make our plans and vision in every other policy area possible.
