The Single Market is one of the greatest assets of the EU, and the free movement of goods, services, people and capital benefits us all. However, the Single Market is not complete. Some of its potential is still untapped.  Our Presidency is prioritising the creation of an innovative, European social market economy that is open to changes, opportunities, free and fair trade and original ideas. For companies to succeed, the business environment must be transparent, simple and free of red tape. We are focused on ensuring a stable banking sector and taking forward the Services Package, and we stand ready to reform EU company law.  Equally, a smarter, cleaner and more cost-effective energy system with an enhanced role for the consumer is an important part of a competitive European economy, and one that we will aim for.  Our next priority is an Inclusive and Sustainable Europe. Of course, a strong economy must be based on the core European values of inclusivity and sustainability. The EU is not just for the few, or for the here and now. We want to ensure that every European citizen can continue to enjoy a Europe that is beautiful, sustainable, free, prosperous and safe.  One of the biggest challenges for this generation of politicians is technological transformation. It is one that I am confident we can shape. Because of our changing society and the influence of technology, the very nature of work is changing. Remote working in a digital economy means an employer and an employee may never actually meet in person. Along with robotisation and artificial intelligence, it represents the ‘fourth industrial revolution’. In response, we need to adapt our social security systems and respond to changes in the economic environment. Skills must meet the needs of future jobs, whether it be building self-driving cars or designing virtual reality experiences.  During our Presidency, we will focus on ways in which the EU can offer equal opportunities and conditions for people, both in their own Member State and also when working and living in another.  Equally, we owe it to our future generations and we owe it to our planet to fulfil our commitment to the Paris Agreement and ensure that sustainability is a key feature of all European policies. Despite the United States withdrawing from the Agreement, we will not change our own commitment.   Our next priority is a safe and secure Europe. Born from the destruction of two bloody world wars, Europe came together, united. It is our utmost duty to keep Europe safe and secure. We cannot fail in that. Let me underline this to the House. In the 21st century, we must not accept aggression against a European country or the illegal annexation and occupation of part of its territory. Were it not for the 1983 European Parliament resolution on Soviet-occupied Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, perhaps I would not be standing in front of you today.  I remember what it means to live inside closed borders when the Berlin Wall, the Iron Curtain, divided Europe. We were not allowed to visit foreign countries. Even Estonian islands were highly guarded border-zones that could be visited only with a special permit. I remember my parents watching Finnish television and listening to the Radio Free Europe – the only access to the free world.  I know what it means to wish for freedom and democracy. I believe that it is not impossible that one day in the future, a Ukrainian President may stand in front of this house in the same role as I am today. It is clear that the European Union must assume greater responsibility for security in and around Europe. No single country is able to stand up to the threats we face, or solve these challenges, alone. The Global Strategy, the EU-NATO joint declaration and the debate on the future of defence rightly set out a high ambition. In order to keep those ambitious promises and deliver results, we need to spend more and we need to spend better on defence. That means joint development of the necessary capabilities.  At the same time, we need to make full use of the existing and new mechanisms, such as the Battlegroups, Permanent Structured Cooperation and the European Defence Fund. Practice makes perfect, so we must regularly carry out coordinated crisis-management exercises. The EU has a vast toolbox ranging from industry, to cyber defence, from strategic communication to Battlegroups.  The EU’s external borders need better protection and tighter control over the movement of both irregular migrants and illicit goods. Law enforcement needs a targeted toolbox for cooperation and information sharing.  Sadly, many of the recent terror attacks have proven that often the threats to our safety are not caused by shortcomings on the ground, but by the lack of information sharing. Therefore, we must continue to create modern IT solutions for the rapid exchange of information. We must improve the interoperability of information systems and the quality of data exchange. There cannot be known ‘unknowns’, when peoples’ lives are at stake.  The ongoing migration-crisis remains the most urgent challenge that we have seen for decades. It is our responsibility, not only as Europeans but as human beings, to assist those seeking refuge in Europe from the tragedy of the Syrian war. Once again, no one Member State can resolve the crisis on their own. We can only keep Europe safe if we act together, in the spirit of solidarity and responsibility.  The EU cannot only look inwards. We must look outwards, actively assisting countries in our neighborhood, both in the south as well as the east. We must reconfirm our political commitment to the Eastern Partnership in order to better respond to the ambitions of all the partners.  In addition to the Eastern Partnership Summit, we will also contribute to the preparations of the EU-Latin American and Caribbean States Summit and the EU-Africa Summit. In summary, our citizens expect safety and security, and we must deliver it together and without hesitation. Next, our priority of creating a digital Europe and the free movement of data. In Estonia, we think of the free movement of data as the fifth freedom of the EU. Therefore, we will start a political debate in Europe on this essential freedom. The digital revolution is at the core of every challenge and opportunity that Europe faces today. Together with our Trio partners, Bulgaria and Austria, we are committed to delivering a Digital Single Market in 2018. But we must also look further afield, which is why we have a digital dimension to almost every aspect of our Presidency programme, from fisheries to space, and the use of data – the raw material of the digital society.  The development of cross-border services and e-commerce has tangible benefits for EU citizens. Buying goods or services online, watching your favourite domestic TV-show, or using e-prescriptions in another European country should be possible and easy. Concluding the current negotiations on geoblocking, audiovisual media services and taking forward the reform of copyright will help get us there.  A critical aspect of a functioning digital society is trust. Europe should be a safe place where rules respecting privacy, data protection and our digital identity are vital. As seen from the recent global cyber-attacks, we need to up our game to keep Europe safe. To support this digital society, Europe requires fast, seamless, always-on and always-available connectivity. Europe needs to be among the pioneers in rolling out 5G and developing new connected products and services. Updating the telecommunications regulatory framework will contribute to these goals. A data driven economy and the fourth industrial revolution will also need a Digital Government.  Every person in Europe should be able to interact with the government with ease and without worry. During our Presidency, we will encourage the use of IT solutions in daily life, including our health, justice, and financial systems. Trust me on this point, once you have filled your tax declaration in just three minutes while sitting by the river on a nice Sunday, you will never want to go back to paperwork. In the Estonian Government, we save a stack of papers as high as the Eiffel Tower each month – that means twelve Eiffel Towers per year! In September, I look forward to welcoming the Heads of States, governments and institutions to the Digital Summit in Tallinn to discuss these very issues and opportunities.  There is one more topic that I would like to address before I conclude – Brexit. We are sad to see the UK withdraw from the EU. It is a loss for our country, for the European Union and for the United Kingdom. I hope that the United Kingdom will remain a close friend. The negotiations need to be conducted in a constructive spirit, tackling first the citizens’ rights, the financial settlement and the border in Ireland.   However, the Presidency’s task is also to make sure that EU27 continues to work and continues to deliver for our future. We will not let Brexit negotiations dominate our work or prevent us from achieving results. In Conclusion, Honourable Members of the Parliament, I hope that our Presidency will be remembered as one that allowed Europe to put the crises behind us and once again look optimistically towards our future. In the words of the great Irish poet Seamus Heaney, this could be a ‘once in a lifetime’ moment when hope and history rhyme.  My own country and people have been very lucky. Our hope and history have rhymed twice in less than a century so, in a way, it makes us experts on ‘seizing the day.’ I am sure we are not alone in feeling that change is in the air. Europe needs to be redefined for every generation, to adapt and to inspire. Helmut Kohl was one of the key architects of Europe. We sent him on his last journey from this very room only a few days ago. He said: ‘the visionaries of yesterday are the realists of today’.  I believe that things we never thought possible are happening, right before our eyes. So, there is no excuse for not acting, there is no excuse for thinking small. We will turn tomorrow’s reality into the one we want. Today, it is up to us to begin creating that vision, creating that reality.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: President Ratas, thank you for a very comprehensive and ambitious programme that we in Parliament certainly look forward to working on with you, and if I may say, the fine choice of poet that you quoted. And I remember – if I may be indulged – he also said, ‘There is no such thing as innocent bystanding’, and perhaps we might remember that.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I am honoured to stand here today, on behalf of President Jean-Claude Juncker and the entire Commission, at the start of the first ever Estonian Presidency of the Council of the European Union. This moment comes after a long wait for a country that joined the European Union some 13 years ago, but good things come to those who wait, and Europe has many good things to look forward to over the course of the next six months. Along with President Juncker and my fellow Commissioners, I was in Tallinn last week and saw first hand how well-prepared the Presidency team is. Knowing how the Estonian civil service works, I never doubted this for a moment. This is also reflected in the programme of the Estonian Presidency, which is fully in line with the joint declaration which the Presidents of the three institutions signed at the end of last year. Both go to the heart of the issues that matter the most for Europeans. The timing of the Estonian Presidency could not be better. I say that because it comes at a time when we need to make progress on making the digital part of Europe’s DNA. The next six months are crucial for making our economy digital. Since this Commission came into office, we have made some real progress towards completing the digital single market, having made 35 proposals since November 2014. Together with the upcoming Bulgarian and Austrian Presidencies, Estonia has set the goal of reaching agreement in all of them by the end of next year. That will be important if we are to benefit from the EUR 415 billion that completing the digital single market could unlock. I am delighted that the Presidency has highlighted 5G coverage as a priority area. We want 5G to be commercially available in at least one major city of each EU Member State by 2020, as it will be in Tallinn by next year. But in the long term, all urban areas, as well as major roads and railways across Europe, should have uninterrupted 5G coverage. Achieving that could bring EUR 146 billion worth of benefits a year and is likely to create 2.39 million jobs in the European Union. Jobs matter to Europeans, and these are the things that we must focus on. That is why we are also making sure that we are investing in our digital future. There is no shortage of European innovators and entrepreneurs with new and fresh ideas to bring to a thriving digital market. But Europe cannot afford to lose these ideas to other parts of the world because of a lack of opportunities or financing. That is why we are focusing on investments, so start—ups and small businesses can access the financing that they need to scale up and bring their ideas to market. The capital markets union is already helping to make venture capital easier to access, and the Juncker Plan has now mobilised EUR 209 billion across Europe. One of your first achievements will be to secure an agreement on extending the fund so it can unlock at least EUR 0.5 trillion by 2020. But the success of the digital single market will also depend on trust and security. That is why I hope we can learn from Estonia’s experience on cybersecurity. The scale of the risks is significant. By 2020 there will be 50 billion connected devices. Just last year there were 4 000 ransomware attacks per day – a 300% increase compared to the year before. We saw the damage that the data ransomware attack caused to institutions in Europe and elsewhere just last week. That is a very stark reminder and a very clear warning that we cannot take our cybersecurity for granted. With that in mind, we will review the EU cybersecurity strategy with targeted initiatives by September. I know we can rely on your support and expertise on this and on all other broader security issues which I know your Presidency has prioritised. Finding agreement on the European Travel Information and Authorisation System and the Entry—Exit System by the end of the year will be absolutely crucial to ensuring that. Equally, the reform of the Common European Asylum System has taken too long to come to fruition. I sincerely hope that the ‘Unity in Balance’ slogan of your Presidency can be applied here and across the board. There is much work ahead of us over the next six months, and I am glad that the Estonian Presidency will be leading the way. I will not only wish them – or Jüri – good luck, but I also thank you in advance. (Applause)

name: Tunne KELAM
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, there is an old saying that a person will be remembered for two things only – the problems he has solved, and the problems he has left. I think Estonia has a good chance of qualifying in the first category. As a small country that is not too much burdened by its national interests, Estonia can better play the role of an honest broker to bring the 27 Member State governments more closely together, because this is needed more than ever today. I like the Estonian message, which could be called ‘back to basics’, that the fundamental freedoms need to be fully implemented. As you said, Prime Minister, the single market is not yet complete. I also like the focus on concrete results for EU citizens in terms of better provision for security, safety and quality of life. And similarly, for our neighbours, I am encouraged that Estonia sees the Eastern Partnership as a cross-cutting priority for our foreign and security policy. It should remain a special commitment to help neighbouring nations become part of the same area of rule of law and prosperity. Yesterday evening, Commission Vice-President Timmermans said something which moved me. He said that if Poland and the Baltic States had not joined the European Union in 2004, they would have shared today the fate of Ukraine. Let us now address together the fate of Ukraine and finally agree on a realistic common strategy to counter, without hesitation, Russia’s aggressive policy. The ultimate goal of that policy is not Ukraine, but the weakening, confusing and compromising of the EU itself. The same is true in relation to energy solidarity. I trust Estonia will lend momentum to the completion of the digital single market, boost digital Europe and advance the free movement of data. And, to conclude, I look forward to an active and coordinated approach towards the Mediterranean and Middle Eastern crises, building an efficient border guard system and preparing for an active post-Isis role in Iraq and Syria. I think Estonia has a chance to make Europe cosier and closer to our citizens, and greater for the outside world. Good luck Estonia! Good luck Europe!

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, it is really a great day of joy for all Estonians, because all Estonia have been preparing ourselves to this first Presidency. I remember when we started this way to the European Union in 1997, we were poor but we were bold, and we were absolutely sure that the European Union is our destiny: it is our goal and we bring the best of us to that. The same year, we started also the programme ‘Tiger Leap’. It was a programme of digitalisation. We brought computers in all the Estonian schools, and we were sure that digitalisation is our shortcut – shortcut to the future; shortcut to the future where we are now. Here our Prime Minister is standing – the youngest prime minister in Europe – and bringing here both programmes connected with digitalisation, digital revolution really in Europe. What I want to stress is that our experience is showing that digital revolution is total. It is not only market, it is not only technology. In the first place it is new relationships in the whole society: a new type of services, a new type of well-being, a new type of engagement and activity and participation of people, and for that, I suppose, it is very important also to build trust. And as a President said, I suppose that is the most difficult task, because we can tell whatever we like about our good experiences, about digital and so on, but you have to convince the other 27 or 26 that it is that, and very often you will hear what we have heard here – ‘Oh, you are so small and bold, you can do that.’ But we are much bigger; we have bigger risks. We will wait. But we know that Europe cannot wait. Europe cannot wait; Europe needs this; Europe needs to be the most competitive, biggest market in the world for most advanced technology, but also for most advanced society. And I will also stress very much what already was said here. We are living not in a very happy moment for the world. We are looking what is going on around us. Yesterday we saw how Putin and the Chinese leader were embracing each other. We see what is happening in Turkey. We know that really Europe is one of the most important hopes for the world to preserve ideals of democracy, liberal democracy, human rights. These are values which cannot be left just to free flow. We have to protect them, fight for them, and as was said by the Prime Minister, Estonia is like also Latvians, Lithuanians, Poles: we know really the price of freedom. We know the price of the democracy, and for that I am sure that, under our Estonian Presidency, the European Union as a whole will be stronger also in this fight. So I wish you good luck. I wish you strength and wisdom and trust. (Applause)

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I would first like to wish the Estonian Presidency every success. Going very quickly through the three priorities of your programme, I would like to start with an open and innovative European economy. It is not an easy time for this task because we know there is a global shift in thinking about free trade and also, even on a single market issue, particularly in several service sectors, we see that it is not really a single market. I wish you a very strong position to succeed in this field and to go in a protectionist direction. In particular in Estonia you have had great experience, since Estonia regained independence, of creating a small, open economy with free trade and a very simple system of how to start doing business. The second issue is security. With the EU having a border with an aggressive neighbour, I think you know very well why you have such priorities as increasing defence expenditure. You have always kept all your promises to NATO. I would point out that they are promises, not obligations. Tunne Kelam spoke of supporting and strengthening relations such as with eastern partnership countries. This is also very important. On EU—NATO relations on the security issue, it may not be well known that Estonia is home to the NATO Cooperative Cyber Defence Centre of Excellence. Any EU Member State can get cybersecurity advice and excellence from this centre so it is not necessary to create some kind of European agency for this purpose. Regarding digital matters, I think you will succeed in the next six months with the digital single market. I hope this will also be done with Commissioner Ansip who knows this issue very well. I would just like to add what has already has been said about digital issues, namely that the e-residency programme in Estonia could also perhaps remove some obstacles which would be created if the outcome of the Brexit negotiations goes the wrong way. Prime Minister, a final point, you are here today with your closest allies. There could be more of us – also on the Commission side – but it is not ridiculous.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: for the ALDE Group. - Madam President! To begin with, of course, I would like to wish the Estonian Presidency all the best. You are taking over in a time marked by both populists who question all the common but on the other hand, and this is positive, a very high expectation from the citizens of Europe to find common solutions to common cross-border problems. Citizens say in the latest Eurobarometer, more than 70 percent say, that when it comes to counter-terrorism, climate change and, first and foremost, all policies that must now be focused on building an asylum and migration policy where everyone takes joint responsibility. It is very important for this Union and for our future that we are actually able to create a policy that lasts and where each country has its proportionate share of the shared responsibility. As rapporteur for the Dublin Regulation, I hope, of course, that you will prioritize this and work for a common and really well-functioning policy in this area. It is obviously the case now that the policy we have does not stand and does not stand the test that reality has faced us. We must guard the external borders and all people who pass must be registered. A system where we share responsibility for those who are forced to flee is a European commitment, and I am afraid that very much of our future is at stake if we do not succeed in delivering this time. Citizens expect that it will be legally secure, that protection will be provided to those who need international protection, but that together we will also be able to return those who do not meet the criteria, so that they are not only here in an irregular way without being returned to their countries of origin in an orderly and dignified manner. I think it is important to say that after my meetings now with many of the Estonian Government with the Prime Minister and the other ministers, we can have very high expectations. You will deliver with quality and with a European anda.Let us find solutions for the common good of all.I hope that when you take over now, you will fight for us to find these solutions, and when you leave the presidency, we will be even more of a European Union than now when you take over.Good luck!

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, Mr Ratas, I welcome the first Estonian presidency and I would also like to congratulate you on the important steps of digitization, both in your economy and in your public administration. But I would like to dwell on what you did not tell us in your opening speech and ask for answers to your deuterology. What will you do to promote a strong social pillar in the European Union if social and regional inequalities are growing dangerously? What will you do about tax harmonization, which is a necessary tool to curb blatant tax evasion, where multinationals pay little, through tax havens, and taxpayers, employees, retirees and small and medium-sized enterprises pay the cost? What will you do about European solidarity on refugees, which is lacking as Member States refuse to honor their commitments? What will you do to complete the banking consolidation with a bank deposit guarantee scheme proposed by the Commission but stumbled upon reactions within the Council? What will you do to strengthen cohesion policies as inequalities grow dangerously? I am waiting, in your deuterology, for specific answers and commitments and work on these issues when you come to make your report, so that we do not remain in likeable generalities.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I am happy to intervene in this session on behalf of my Group. Estonia has chosen four main objectives for the next six months. The logical order of these four objectives seems clear. The inclusive and sustainable Europe that Estonia wants to promote, as the fourth objective, will be closer if the first three objectives are achieved. They consist in the promotion of an open and innovative economy, and, as required by that, security in daily life as well as significant advances in the modern digital world and the exchange of information. These three goals may certainly facilitate a more inclusive and sustainable Europe.  The programme adds in its introduction that, in pursuing those objectives, Prime Minister, you will respect human rights and fundamental freedoms. So far, so good. However, I would have liked to see an entire chapter in the programme devoted specifically to the defence of human rights, not just as a consequence to be drawn from other objectives but as a specific objective in itself. Estonia, which is a small country and is a friend of my country, Catalonia, must be guided not only by the logic of inclusion and sustainability but also by the explicit defence of human rights. Indeed, the human-rights deficit is not found only in third countries, which we constantly criticise: unfortunately it also occurs in many countries within the Union.  I am confident and convinced that, in the months to come, Estonia will go in the direction of denouncing any breach of fundamental rights in the European Union. Having said this, I must also say that my Group is pleased with the announcement of this project. We can only wish the best to Estonia and to Europe under this new Presidency.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Estonia is the country where the revolution of electoral voting via the Internet has started, and it is the first time that this is chairing the Council. Estonia indicates four priorities, which are undoubtedly shared: an open and innovative European economy, a secure, digital, inclusive and sustainable Europe. But in the past we have seen beautiful promises hiding something less glamorous. And unfortunately, behind the Estonian screen, we find the priorities of the Commission, with the accelerator foot on the Capital Markets Union, on the EFSI, on the Banking Union, but also on the omnibus and on the increase in military spending that supports the joint declaration with NATO a year ago. Nothing new under the sun, then. Instead, I would like Estonia to reverse the trend with respect to a well-established tradition, which sees the States use this opportunity to achieve greater prestige, with fine words, but unfortunately with empty policies. Has Estonia been able to revolutionize its electoral system? Well, bring a wave of change here too, because European citizens would really need it.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, good work. Beyond electronic voting, I think there are two emergencies in Europe: work and security, dear President. Unemployment theme: there are 20 million unemployed European citizens, of whom four million are young people. So I beg the Commission and the Presidency to stop giving gifts to multinationals; to stop signing suicide agreements like those with CETA Canada, against which Italian farmers are demonstrating at the moment: 300,000 farms producing wheat at risk; to stop passing crazy directives like the one on banks and the Bolkestein directive; to stop giving away at zero duty the landing of thousands of tons of Tunisian oil, Moroccan tomatoes, Cambodian or Thai rice on our tables, with the health of our children paying the consequences; to remove the sanctions against Russia, which must be a trading partner and not an enemy, and which is not preparing to invade anyone or anything; and to defend borders. I understand that Estonia does not have this big problem because it hosts a maximum of 150 immigrants. Italy is becoming a huge refugee camp. In this building, someone said: "Long live Macron, long live France!", And now Macron is closing the ports to foreign ships. Someone said: "Long live Austria that stopped the populists!", And Austria puts the army and armored vehicles on the border with Italy. Shall we stop being invaded? Five hundred million European citizens pay you to give them jobs and security, not to give gifts to smugglers and bankers. Good job.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, Prime Minister! Congratulations to you on your ambitious plan, the four points you outlined. And congratulations to the first Estonian presidency as well, I wish this program to be implemented as planned. Although you mentioned that you did not want to focus specifically on Brexit, you obviously acknowledge that Brexit will be an unavoidable factor in your presidency. Moreover, I say that once the negotiations begin now, it is very important what starting points we will set. It is important for you, for your country, for all European countries, how EU citizens working in Britain remain. Moreover, I can also say what situation British citizens remain in the European Union. A common, good agreement must be reached. He mentioned the digital economy, which I consider to be a very important thing, as one of the ways to complete the internal market. It is EUR 430 billion if this program is implemented. Still, I would like to draw your attention to another topic that is closely linked to this - the circular economy. I have a report, which is an excellent report on crop-enhancing products, the trilogy of which will begin now. This can contribute to the development and completion of this circular economy. I wish you a good presidency for this!

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Madam President, it is a real pleasure to receive Prime Minister Ratas here among us, and we welcome the Estonian Presidency’s commitment to an open and innovative Europe. This is a really big vision, and we would like to align that vision with European values too. That is why your contribution, Prime Minister, will be very important in making the best of the digital revolution, as we believe that many benefits can come from this, and I would say that, more than just a digital single market, we need a digital Union, making sure that everybody can benefit from the digital revolution when it comes to quality of public services, when it comes to full access for all citizens and when comes to the transformation of people’s working conditions in the digital environment. That is why the European social pillar, to be proclaimed during your presidency, should be geared to the future and should empower young people in Europe.  We also approve of your commitment to an open Europe, and indeed Europe is now negotiating very important trade agreements. We believe that, in negotiating these agreements, we should pay attention to the Union’s commitment to the sustainable development goals. That is why the new instruments for defence are so important. However, in a nutshell, all the best for your very promising presidency.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: - I recently paid a working visit to Estonia and I have to say that I was impressed by the pioneering role you play in the field of digital and then very specifically in the field of e-government and administrative simplification.You yourself gave the example that your taxes can be filed from anywhere.Well, my expectations of this Presidency are high, because a Presidency so focused on that digital, will undoubtedly be able to help us to accelerate the development of the digital single market, which is so important for Europe, or at least to a higher level.shifting gear.I think that it is not only in the interest of a properly functioning digital internal market, but certainly also of the European consumer to bring together the important ongoing files, such as the file on geo-blocking, but also the file on the type-approval of vehicles.To bring to a good end.Good luck in advance.

name: Yana TOOM
text: – Madam President, I will try to make all of my speech fit into 60 seconds. According to the digital economy and society index for 2017, Estonia is number one in the EU in terms of supply and use of digital public services. The Estonian Government system is praised for its openness and trust. The Estonian Presidency will hopefully promote cross-border use of digital public services and Estonia will share its experience with other Member States. Like other colleagues, I highly appreciate that the Estonian Presidency’s priorities include the development of cross-border e-commerce in these services and modern electronic communications. Nevertheless, during trialogues, the Presidency will face challenges related to the review of the Audiovisual Media Services Directive. This piece of legislation is rather controversial and Estonia still has an opportunity to address such issues as the inappropriate extension of the scope of the directive to social media. This is only one of several controversial files which will be on the table during the Estonian Presidency, but I strongly believe that sometimes small countries like Estonia are much better at searching and achieving compromises than big ones. And that is the reason I’m looking forward for a really fruitful and friendly Estonian Presidency.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: - A Uachtaráin, táim ag labhairt inniu ar son Martina Anderson, comhghleacaí nach féidir a bheith inár dteannta ar maidin. Tá an Eastóin, cosúil le hÉirinn, tar éis fulaingt mar thoradh ar ghníomhaíochtaí a gcomharsan mór. Ní gá dúinn ach féachaint ar an stair maidir le hionsaí míleata agus slí bheatha ag ár gcomharsan féin. In Éirinn, táimid ag tabhairt aghaidh anois ar éiginnteacht de bharr ár gcomharsana móra atá tar éis vota a chaitheamh ar an AE a fhágaint. Glacadh an vóta gan aon aird a thabhairt don phróiseas síochána in Éirinn nó gan aon aird ar an éiginnteacht shóisialta agus eacnamaíochta atá anois ag cnagadh ar dhoras mhuintir na hÉireann. Tá athruithe móra le feiscint san Eoraip le linn ár saol, agus anois arís, tá athrú mór eile ag druidim inár dtreo. I 1991, bhí an AE ábalta tacú le tíortha beaga, cosúil le bhur gceann, a bhí ag fulaingt de bharr fadhbanna le bhur gcomharsana mòra. Ní mór don AE anois tacú le mo thír leis na deacrachtaí until againn lenár gcomharsana móra. Ní mór don AE céim chun tosaigh a thógaint agus tacaíocht a thabhairt don chuid is mó de na daoine sa Tuaisceart atá ag iarraidh fanacht san Aontas Eorpach agus ní mór don AE tacú le stádas faoi leith d’Éirinn.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: - I would like to congratulate and wish success to the Baltic sister Estonia, which is taking over the Presidency of the European Union at a particularly important time.It has set out a serious and ambitious program, but nevertheless Estonia also faces the difficult task of leading the ongoing debate on the future of the common agricultural policy.The European Union must ensure a level playing field, and the areas it supports must be supported in the same way in all countries.I want to believe that the Omnibus regulation, which includes provisions on the flexibility of coupled support, will also be successfully concluded.I believe that Estonia will also be able to properly organize the solution to the next major challenge, the construction of Nord Stream 2.This issue is a test of the European Union's solidarity and solidarity with its partners, an essential step in allaying the current ambitions of the Russian regime.I wish you success in your presidency.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr Szanyi, I know you wish to ask a question but I am going to make a ruling that we will not have blue cards because of our time constraints, so thank you for your understanding.

name: Petr MACH
text: - Madam President, I do not know if you have all noticed, but the European Union is in a process of disintegration. The United Kingdom is leaving, individual Member States are no longer complying with your regulation, whether it concerns Schengen, whether it concerns the budgetary rules and Greece, France, or whether it concerns your quota regulation and the position of the Central European countries. But let's not be sad about it. The European Union is not Europe. Europe is not falling apart. The European Union is a bureaucratic mole, it is such an official gray, these are palaces, behind the walls of which officials and politicians are often detached from reality. In contrast, Europe is a beautiful continent with more than fifty states, more than 700 million people live here, speak dozens of languages, have countless interesting and beautiful traditions. And this does not disappear. And when the European Union falls apart, we must see in it the hope, the hope that the states of the former Soviet Union have gained. When the Soviet Union disintegrated, the people regained their freedom, the states gained independence. And when the European Union falls apart, we must trust and strive for the individual Member States to be able to work together, but on a voluntary basis, to be able to trade together so that we can continue to travel visa-free, and that is why I am asking you to negotiate with the United Kingdom. Britain, do not trample on this principle, if we respect the principle of free trade as a principle that is mutually beneficial, then let us have free trade with Great Britain, let us have free trade with others. I look forward to a European Union without bureaucracy, to a free Europe.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: - Madam President, Prime Minister, if I believe the interview you gave recently to Benedict Vitkine, you are not as hostile to Russia as the Baltic politicians often are. I understand the concerns of your countries about the preservation of your respective identities, but the new Cold War into which the European Union is dragging us seriously harms the interests of European nations, including yours. On June 22, the Union once again extended its sanctions against Russia. Taken initially under pressure from the Americans, these measures have triggered a spiral of sanctions and counter-sanctions, of which our farmers are the first victims. After the Franco-German reconciliation, our continent now needs a Polish-Russian reconciliation, beyond the legitimate resentments inherited from the communist period. Yes, the time has come to focus on the great challenges posed by migratory flooding and Islamist terrorism. It is in this spirit that we want to build the Europe of tomorrow and that is what led me to take part in two delegations from our group. Two weeks ago we were in Moscow and last week in Warsaw for the Europe of Nations and Freedoms Congress.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, Prime Minister, thank you for presenting your four Presidency priorities. I think you made the right choice, but there are many tasks. Let me focus on two. The Audiovisual Media Services Directive has already been mentioned here. I consider it very important that the negotiations be completed, because this is a proposal that has been adopted here in Parliament with great support in committees, and it is about improving internet safety, especially in relation to the protection of minors. The second priority concerns the internal market. You yourself mentioned that you want to facilitate the movement of services and the provision of services and business across the European Union. You will therefore certainly be negotiating the Posting of Workers Directive, which has met with great and justified criticism here in the European Parliament. I would therefore like to call on you to take an active part in the negotiations, for example, the Slovak Presidency has proposed a so-called dual system, which has not received wider support. Likewise, negotiations on a mobility package await you, which tightens the conditions for carriers. This is an example where there is again a risk of a division into new Member States and old Member States and the re-creation of a barrier. It is up to you to try to find a good compromise. And you chose a great password for it. "Unity through Balance", so I wish you a lot of strength and look forward to working with you.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Madam President, I would like to welcome the Estonian Presidency and I am convinced this presidency will be a very positive one. At a time of unprecedented challenges, we have only one possible way to succeed and to further enhance the European project. This is through unity and solidarity when discussing the future of the Union, and through more integration, in particular in key fields such as security and defence. Any specific initiatives by Member States, while possible, must be transparent and open to all others with no shifting criteria or objectives. When it comes to internal and external security and stability, which are closely interlinked, I am confident the new presidency will bring fresh pragmatism and realism to the Eastern Partnership ahead of the November summit. At a time of challenges, as I said before, during the Estonian Presidency it is fundamentally important to reassess the situation with regard to the ‘frozen conflicts’ and the way Russia is using it in order to destabilise the countries in question.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Prime Minister, the Estonian Presidency will discuss the Electronic Communications Code and the new structure of BEREC. In the future, we are laying the legislative foundations for a high-capacity communication infrastructure, the development of digital systems and the digital market. If we can set the parameters sensibly and without too much bureaucracy, we can also help European digital business a lot. Digitization will change the vast spectrum of technology and affect every corner of our lives - from computers to cars. During the Estonian Presidency, the European Parliament should also go through the whole winter energy package, which also outlines the rules for decades to come and will have a huge impact on the economy of each Member State in the future. That is why I wish your presidency every success, it will not be an easy period. And I emphasized only two technical and, from my point of view, important legislative packages, and I did not mention other areas such as Brexit or migration.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: - Mr President,I also wanted to talk about digital developments, because probably everyone in this house knows that Estonia is a digital country.But listening to this debate and listening to the good words that colleagues have to say about Estonia, I would like to share a different emotion with you.I am very proud of Estonia.I am proud that in one generation we have fought for our freedom and for an equal place among European countries.I am also proud that there is one particular area where we can lead and set an example for the European Union.And to show that Europe as a whole has a lot to gain from a digital single market.I believe that with this Estonian Presidency, we will be able to prove that Estonia is as important to Europe as Europe is to Estonia.Thank you!

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Madam President, Estonia comes to the presidency at a time of great political decisions. Without a doubt, her main diplomatic challenge is Syria, where only dialogue with the current government and respect for international law can end the war. Europe has a commitment to peace that is at serious risk, if the commitment to military adventurerism and the increase in defense budgets to the detriment of public policies is confirmed. Her priorities are clear: banking, energy, digitization, business environment, and yet she has missed a fundamental part of this technological transformation that she suggests. And they are the workers and the necessary framework of social dialogue, to generate quality employment, combat precariousness and end the deregulation of working conditions and stop contributing to generating a new source of inequality, such as the digital divide. You propose to us today continuity, to maintain the objectives of economic policy against social and environmental objectives, and this is not the way for European workers.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen.Terrorism is probably the biggest security threat in the European Union today.Question: What can we, as legislators, do to stop terrorism?It is not possible to pass a law that terrorism is illegal - it already is!But we can deprive terrorists of easy access to funding, cut their source of money.The law is now open, which is in the process of a trialogue in which Parliament is trying to reach a final decision with the Council, the anti-money laundering directive.So far, Parliament has not been able to reach an agreement with the Council, ie the Maltese Presidency.We want to have a clear register of true beneficiaries, where we will identify both offshore and trust owners, which is an important weapon in the fight against terrorist financing.I call on the Estonian Presidency to pay particular attention to this and to ensure that we can reach a final solution as soon as possible.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Madam President! There are rightly great expectations of the new Council Presidency. Estonia - although a small country - has done great things and in many ways Estonia is a model, not just for the post-Soviet countries. At a time when the European project is beginning to regain its footing, this is a very important requirement. I have two expectations in particular: first, that the Estonian Presidency, with a cool look, steady hand and the necessary pragmatism, will make the Union capable of acting again on the refugee issue and that the digitization of Europe will be advanced. Internal market, e-governance, cybersecurity - you have rightly made these your main priorities, and that will have a positive effect on the next presidencies. We expect a lot from you. But despite all the euphoria that we share with you, we must not forget that your actions also have social consequences and that it is also about that we must do everything we can to ensure that these developments also lead to everyone benefiting from them.

name: Urmas PAET
text: - Mr President, European defense co-operation is an area in the development of which Estonia, as the Presidency of the European Union, has high expectations. Estonia now has a unique opportunity to help increase the European Union's defense capability and defense cooperation. Estonia has not only been a consumer of security, but also a contributor to security. Thus, Estonia has met the 2% defense spending criterion for years, and Estonia has also made a significant contribution to international missions. As a member of both NATO and the European Union, Estonia can contribute to the rapid development of European Union defense cooperation so that the European Union and NATO complement each other's capabilities to the maximum. I recall that in November last year, the European Parliament adopted a report on the European Defense Union, or defense cooperation. It lists the things that need to be done to develop European defense cooperation. The Defense Fund and the command center in Brussels have been set up, but twenty issues still need to be decided and acted upon in order to be able to talk about effective European Union defense cooperation. Next year, Estonia will celebrate its 100th birthday, and I believe that in a hundred years, we can all celebrate Estonia's 200th birthday together in a secure Europe. Good luck!

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: - Madam President, after passing the European electoral interpass and having spent the last few months in reflection, the time for action has come. It is true that we have been concatenating, in recent years, crisis after crisis, some that we have not finished solving - from the refugees to the economic crisis - but the arrival of real internal and external threats, existential for the Union and for everything we represent in the world, gives us the great opportunity to take steps forward in integration, learn from our mistakes and respond to the discomfort of citizens, taking steps forward, towards a safer and stronger Europe, more influential outside; a more flexible and efficient Europe; and a more sensitive and just Europe, which the citizens feel that it protects them. But re-legitimizing the European project will only come hand in hand with the social dimension. So let's take advantage of the Social Summit - the Social Summit - and put in place the European pillar for social rights, because our legitimacy goes to us in all this.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Prime Minister, in six months, when we take stock of this Presidency, it is easy to predict that we will talk about the excellent results in the field of digital and innovation. Instead, we ask you to surprise us, Prime Minister, not on digital, but on the issue of immigration and refugees. It amazes us by engaging the Council, starting from the next Tallinn summit, on the issue of welcoming and relocating refugees. Surprise us, as a leader of the northern country capable of identifying true solutions to a crisis that is being borne mainly and only by the southern countries. What are we going to do, Prime Minister, of a Europe that is digital, if not is it supportive? And what is the use of an innovative Europe, if we do not preserve the values ​​that are the basis of our being European? Mr President, be ambitious: tackle difficult issues where many others have failed, nail European leaders to the responsibilities of history. These are the reasons why we would like to remind ourselves of the semester that opens today. Good luck.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: - Madam President! I think these are very valuable words that Tunne Kelam said about the Estonian Presidency that it was a return to the sources. In fact, we would like it to be so. Thank you for those words, and at the same time for the conviction that the Estonian Presidency - as the Prime Minister said - is carpe diem, that is, seizing the moment when your country is presiding over here and now. You propose as a priority an open and innovative economy, but at the same time a sustainable economy, also involving our societies, as well as a Europe of the future, which talks about digital tasks, and in particular about building the free flow of data. And what is important for everyone - that Europe is safe, that all our countries are safe. It is extremely important. However, I would like to ask the Prime Minister to ensure that the key - regardless of the priorities - is to respect the treaty principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, to ensure legal certainty and, what I would like to emphasize at the end, that the Eastern policy is implemented.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, Prime Minister, Commissioner, I want to say, in short, that I liked what you presented as a program and a project.It is clear: everyone must have citizens in their hearts and souls.Congratulations on being the youngest President of the Council!But I want to ask you: do you still intend to have no more virtual fences or real fences inside the European Union?Do you intend not to have different spaces?Do you propose that Romania and Bulgaria, which comply with the conditions of 2012, be in the Schengen area?There are citizens who have the same rights and I want, Prime Minister and Commissioner, to propose this to you in addition to the social pillar that we need to have, because without social cohesion we cannot have a better Europe.Thank you and I wish you success!

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Madam President, I would like to welcome the Prime Minister to the Chamber. As Prime Minister of a small country – a country similar in size to Ireland – I wish you luck. As a young Prime Minister who hopefully has a long life ahead of him, you will be looking at a long life ahead in the EU no doubt. Within that context, I have a question to ask you about the White Paper on the future of Europe. We were told on 1 March by Jean—Claude Juncker that we would have a series of ‘Future of Europe’ debates in cities and regions around Europe. I have asked Donald Tusk about these debates. He didn’t answer me. I asked Commissioner Hogan about these debates. He told me that maybe he could organise them himself. I have asked Jean-Claude Juncker about them. If I stood on a cat’s tail, I would have got a more logical answer. Can you tell me, Prime Minister, when and where these debates are going to take place or is it the case at this stage – as is said around Ireland – that it isn’t the White Paper on the future of Europe, it is the invisible paper on the future of Europe.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - I would like to ask the Prime Minister: we are looking forward to the Estonian presidency, we Hungarians and other former socialist and communist countries.He hinted that there are many elements in common in our past, but he did not hint that there are many elements, pain, and problems in common in our present as well.In particular, the huge wage and income disparities between the EU Member States of Central and Eastern Europe and the Western Member States are causing your citizens, like Hungarian citizens and citizens of other former socialist countries, to leave their country,and they are forced to go to other countries to work for higher incomes.What is your position on this?We know that Estonia was also one of the initiators of the civic movement fighting for the wage union on the basis of the principle of “equal pay for equal work”.What is your attitude, what is the attitude of the Estonian Presidency to this problem?

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank Members for this very fruitful debate. Everybody understands that it is impossible in just five minutes to respond to all of the questions raised here today, but I would like to touch on some of the issues. Taxation was mentioned. I would like to state that this Commission took a very clear position: all taxes have to be paid in the countries where the companies generate their profits. I am absolutely sure that during Estonia’s Presidency we will continue to follow that approach in our activities. Regarding connectivity, as you know, we have set three main connectivity aims for Europe. We would like to achieve those concrete results by 2025. I am talking about the Gigabit Society, 100 megabits-per-second networks and 5G networks. As we know, to reach those aims at least EUR 500 billion in investment will be needed. If we continue on the basis of the existing rules, there will be an investment gap equal to EUR 155 billion. The message is clear: we have to change our rules. That is why I would like to ask Parliament and also the Presidency to pay attention to those connectivity issues and to deal with spectrum issues for example. When we asked for deeper cooperation in the field of spectrum, we asked about the timing of spectrum allocation auctions. It has to be harmonised. Regarding the duration of licences, there is a minimum of 25 years and, as we know, in some rural areas 25 years will not be enough to break even and start to make profits. This is important in terms of giving predictability to mobile operators and, of course, regarding coverage issues. As we know, in Finland, Sweden and Lapland, population density is less than one person per square kilometre, but there is excellent access to 4G networks. Here, however, when travelling from Brussels to Strasbourg, there are tens of kilometres without any kind of access to the internet. So we have to change our rules.  Then we have to pay attention to geoblocking. As we know, this is a real headache in the European Union. According to our mystery shopping survey, two per cent of people who wanted to buy goods and services from another EU Member State just could not get access to the websites selling those goods and services, and 27% of people who got access to the websites were not able to register because their IP address was wrong. They were from the wrong countries – from France, from Germany, from Italy, from the United Kingdom, from Estonia, anyway from EU Member States – while 32% of those people who were able to register faced delivery problems. To deal with those problems, we launched our parcel delivery proposal. I hope that, during the Estonia Presidency, we will be able to reach consensus on these issues. However, 26% of the people who did not have any kind of problem with delivery issues could not pay. In the European Union we have the Single Euro Payments Area (SEPA) but, nevertheless, 26% of people could not pay because their credit cards were issued in the wrong EU Member States – in Germany, in France, in Belgium, in the Netherlands, anyway in the wrong EU Member States. All in all, just 36% of all those people who wanted to buy goods and services from another EU Member State were able to conclude their purchases successfully. The issue here is not just about the single market we would like to have in the European Union, if only every third person is able to conclude purchases successfully: it is much more about discrimination on the basis of nationality or where a person’s credit card was issued. We do not have to accept that kind of discrimination in the 21st century in the European Union. (Applause) My speaking time has already expired. I hope that, during the Estonian Presidency, we will also be able to achieve concrete results in dealing with cyber security issues and many other important issues. I wish Estonia’s Presidency every success. (Applause)

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to say thank you to Members for all their statements and your comments. I have taken note of all your positions and opinions. We will work very closely with you, honourable Members of the European Parliament to make sure that citizens are at the heart of everything we do. The four economic freedoms of the single market are very important principles of the Union. The European Union has to be strong and united to go forward. I am certain that we will overcome all the current and future challenges. Now some remarks about your questions or your remarks. First of all, migration. I take it very seriously. It isn’t a question for the one or the other State. It is a question for all 28 Member States. Our goal during our Presidency is to find consensus. We must find consensus, and solidarity is an important topic here. I could say it is the cornerstone here. The first informal Council meeting of our Presidency will take place in Tallinn tomorrow. I would like to stress once more that we are fully committed to finding solutions to the refugee crisis. The issues are difficult but we are working towards a common solution. Solidarity must be there. The previous presidencies, Slovakia and Malta, have done a good job. Estonia is doing its best to keep the process on the right track in order to help to strengthen a common asylum system. We are highly committed to doing our share. Also I would like to mention that at the beginning of this week, the Estonian Government decided to allocate EUR 1 million to the EU trust fund for Africa. We encourage all Member States to increase their contributions to this fund. Some words about security and terrorism. There is no doubt that security and defence are top priorities for Europe. The European Union can only be taken seriously as a global player if Member States strengthen their own security and defence. Hence the need to raise defence expenditure levels. We must also take into account the interconnected nature of our internal and external security challenges. In addition to strengthening defence cooperation with the European Union, we must continue to move forward with EU-NATO cooperation. Some words about the social pillar. We are taking the social pillar very seriously. It is one of our top priorities. We will move forward on all social files, including the posting of workers and hope to adopt the proclamation endorsing the social pillar together with you. Some words about Brexit. When it comes to Brexit, Estonia’s main goal is the unity of EU 27 and to ensure that the divorce process is as smooth as possible. We must protect the rights of EU citizens in the United Kingdom. The second urgent question is the financial settlement and the third is the border issues with Ireland. These questions have to be settled before entering the second phase of the negotiations. Estonia fully supports Mr Barnier as the chief EU negotiator and also Parliament. We will be at the service of the Member States and work closely with all EU institutions involved. Honourable Members of Parliament, Estonia wants to contribute to making the EU a better place to live for everyone. One of our main priorities is a digital Europe and the free movement of data. We must deliver it because the unfinished nature of the digital single market costs us about EUR 400 billion a year. Completing the process is important to improve the everyday lives of our citizens. Ladies and gentlemen, if I may, I would also like to say some concluding remarks in my mother tongue. Siin oli arvamusi ka selles osas, et kas Euroopa Liitu on vaja ja kas tal on tulevikku. Eesti usub väga tugevalt, et Euroopa Liidul on ühine tulevik. Me oleme kindlad selles, et meie eesistumise ajal Euroopas tuleb ka näidata neid positiivseid samme, mida Euroopa Liit on pakkunud, olgu see rahu, olgu see inimeste, kaupade, teenuste vaba liikumine või olgu see ühine kultuuriruum.  Auväärt parlamendiliikmed! Ma näen, et teil on väga palju külalisi kõige kõrgemal korrusel. Ja mõned nendest on noored inimesed. Nad on väga õnnelikud, et siin Euroopa Liidus on Erasmus – ja see on ka üks näide Euroopa Liidu ühtsusest. Eesti soovib igal juhul ehitada oma eesistumise ajal sildu, mitte tõmmata piire või ehitada seinu. Eesti soovib igal juhul, et me Euroopa Liidu tulevikku arutame koos, mitte igaüks eraldi toas. Me soovime, et Euroopa Liit on järgneva kuue kuu jooksul rohkem ühtsem, tugevam ja turvalisem. Thanks for all these positive comments and to all those wishing us success. We will need good cooperation with all of you to make our Presidency a successful one. Thank you for your attention and thank you for our discussion. (Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you, Prime Minister Ratas, and you have our good wishes and support. The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - In recent years, we have been concatenating crisis after crisis, some of them still in force —from the refugees to the economic crisis. But the arrival of real internal and external threats, existential for the Union and for everything we represent in the world, gives us a great opportunity to take steps forward in integration, learn from our mistakes and respond to the discomfort of citizens by giving steps forward, towards a safer and stronger Europe, more influential abroad; a more flexible and efficient Europe; and a more sensitive and just Europe, which the citizens feel that it protects them. Re-legitimizing the European project will only be possible if it is endowed with a true social dimension. The Estonian Presidency is faced with this situation. With an ambitious agenda: an open and inclusive economy, the protection of European citizens, the environment or jobs in the face of the migration crisis. As socialists, we will collaborate so that these goals can be achieved.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - Congratulations to Estonia on 1 July this year. with the launch of my first presidency of the EU Council, and I wish it success and contribute to finding the much-needed solutions to ensure the well-being of EU citizens. Having read the Estonian Presidency's program and listening to the presentation of priorities, I would like to welcome Estonia's emphasis on the importance of gender equality, including support for work-life balance, to ensure that the growing need for skilled labor is met. The unequal division of labor in caring for children, the elderly and other dependent family members affects women's participation in the labor market and men's participation in family life. I therefore welcome Estonia's intention to continue the debate on reconciling family life, so that women can participate more actively in the labor market and the burden of their family worries can be reduced. I would also like to congratulate the Estonian Government on emphasizing in its presidency program that all Europeans must have equal access to the necessary skills, high-quality education, employment or services in order to ensure the sustainability of society and Europe's economic and social well-being. It is important to maintain high social guarantees for all EU citizens in order to ensure the free movement of persons, workers and services. At the same time, I would like to call on the Estonian Government to keep in mind other very important issues, such as the fight against gender-based violence, the fight against human trafficking, the reduction of the gender pay and pension gap and women on company boards and in decision-making positions.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - In recent years we have been linking crisis after crisis, some of them still in force — from refugees to the economic crisis. name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - I would like to welcome the fact that the Estonian Presidency is making the idea of ​​an inclusive and sustainable Europe a priority. It considers it important to help citizens develop their skills so that they can be as active participants in society as possible and have access to quality education, job opportunities and services. Both the Hungarian Government and Hungarian civil society have already made a number of efforts to achieve these goals. Building on the Hungarian example, the European Talent Support Network was established, which actively contributes to the discovery and development of talent, regardless of age, gender and social background. I also welcome the fact that, in the field of justice and home affairs, the establishment of the ETIAS system, which aims to identify in time any potential migration, security or public health risk, is a priority. As the parliamentary rapporteur for the dossier, I hope that serious progress will indeed be made in cooperation with the Estonian Presidency. This system also contributes to reducing the threats posed by migratory pressures. At the same time, adequate protection of the external borders and the separation of genuine refugees and economic migrants outside the EU's borders are essential. I hope that the Estonian Presidency will make this a priority.

text: written. - In recent years we have been linking crisis after crisis, some of them still in force — from refugees to the economic crisis. name: András GYÜRK
text: - Congratulations on the ambitious program of the Estonian Presidency. Estonia is a small country, but its excellent achievements in a number of policy areas demonstrate its exemplary performance by underestimating the size of its resources. In the energy program, I was pleased to read that further integration of energy markets is a top priority alongside energy efficiency. It is also to be welcomed that the Estonian Presidency intends to make rapid progress in the negotiations on the Clean Energy Package. I would like to draw the Presidency's attention to the fact that, although we have talked and done a lot in recent years to increase security of supply, we still have a long way to go in this area. It is enough to think about the Nord Stream expansion project, the implementation of which would reduce the opportunities for diversification in many Central and Eastern European countries, including Hungary. In addition to security of supply concerns, the possible realization of the project could also lead to higher energy prices, causing competitiveness problems. I call on the Estonian Presidency to support the Commission in its efforts to ensure that only infrastructure is built and operated in the European Union that supports the objectives of the Energy Union and meets the relevant standards.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: in writing. – In 2017 Estonia will be president of the Council of the European Union for the first time. Estonia was one the ten countries admitted to the European Union on 1 May 2004 and it is hosting the Presidency of the Council in the second half of 2017. Estonia is among the fastest-growing economies in the EU. Estonia has a strong digital society and economy. One of the major tasks of the Presidency of Estonia will be digitalisation. The main point in the field of digitalisation will thus include the development of cross-border e-commerce and e-services for the benefit of consumers, producers and businesses. Estonia will also push forward the promotion of e-solutions and so it is not surprising that Estonia held the first online elections in 2005 and it is the first country to offer an e-residency. Applications for the e-residency are growing fast. Prospective buyers must pay EUR 100 and wait around one month. After that procedure you can become a digital citizen of Estonia and you have access to the single market. In two years these digital immigrants founded 1 600 companies. The target for Estonia is to get ten million e-residents by 2025.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: in writing. - On 1 July 2017, Estonia officially took over its first rotating presidency of the Council of the European Union since accession. The priorities of the Estonian presidency presented at the plenary session include: supporting an open and innovative European economy, the sustainable development of the Union and enhancing security. Estonia - with extensive experience in cybersecurity and modern IT solutions - intends to focus also on digital issues during the presidency and help accelerate the implementation of the objectives of the European digital single market. This is one of the strong points of this Baltic country: since independence in 1991, Estonians have actively promoted digitization, including in administration, offices, education and public life. Estonia includes the first country in the world to introduce the possibility of voting in elections over the Internet. The Estonian presidency will therefore be responsible for negotiating a number of key technology projects, including the development of e-commerce and e-services for the benefit of consumers, producers and enterprises, amendment to copyright, new rules on telecommunications and free data flow. I fully support these ambitious plans and believe that, if implemented, they will put Europe on the path of innovation and modernization, revitalize the European economy and bring many positive social effects to the Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing. - The Estonian Presidency must reconsider and take important initiatives to tackle and reduce migratory flows. This requires the following: 1. Relocation of refugees from Greece and Italy, as agreed. 2. Time extension of the relocation program. 3. Putting pressure on third countries to accept the repatriation of their citizens who have immigrated illegally to Greece and the rest of Europe. 4. Immediate abolition of Dublin III which has turned Greece into a storehouse of souls. 5. Take initiatives to consolidate peace in the Middle East. 6. Tackling poverty in Africa.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: signed up. - The conclusions of the European Council are intended to be optimistic and firm. They want to give a boost to the Union, after Brexit and citizens 'grievances have called into question the legitimacy of Brussels' policies. However, major problems have been avoided. After Brexit, the Union's budget will be about 17% smaller. This means either that EU projects will be more modest or that rich countries will give more money. Germany has avoided clarifying this dilemma. The other obstacle in the Council is also related to money - the relocation of refugees. It is said that Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic must be punished for not accepting refugees. The direct threat is that these states will no longer receive EU funding. Blackmail is outrageous, as it was not these states that opened the borders and invited refugees to Europe. Did the rich Western states in 2004 and 2007 want the Union to expand with equal members or did they simply annex some territories to have sources of raw materials, cheap labor and, if necessary, a closet? for undesirable?

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: in writing. - You have made the slogan "unity through balance" the common thread of your presidency. In these times when the Union must face several major challenges, unity is more than ever a necessity. But to tackle the refugee crisis, revive the economy, respond to the climate emergency, unity needs rediscovered solidarity in the face of national selfishness. The defense of European values ​​must also be at the heart of your action. Hungary and Poland continue to challenge the rule of law and violate our core values. What will your presidency's response be? Do you support the Parliament for the activation of Article 7.1? We will no longer have any credibility for our citizens if we are unable to protect them. Finally, I would like to challenge you on a subject that will directly impact the lives of millions of workers and more than 500,000 European companies. This is the mobility package. What is your ambition on this file? Are you going to try to overcome certain divisions in order to find a common position in the Council? The integration of the internal market in the road sector has contributed to the deterioration of working conditions. Do you plan to balance this sector by strengthening the social dimension of road transport?

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - In recent years we have been linking crisis after crisis, some of them still in force — from refugees to the economic crisis. But the arrival of real internal and external threats, existential for the Union and for everything we represent in the world, gives us a great opportunity to take steps forward in integration, learn from our mistakes and respond to the discomfort of citizens. , taking steps forward, towards a Europe that is safer and stronger, more influential abroad; a more flexible and efficient Europe; and a more sensitive and just Europe, which the citizens feel that it protects them. name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, just very briefly. From time to time we are able to welcome distinguished people in the gallery. Today we will vote on the agreement with Cuba, most likely positively. Some of us have invited also the representatives of the Cuban opposition. Many of them could not make it, for obvious reasons. So please, allow me just to welcome one of them, someone who spent 16 years in prison in Cuba, Mr Fuentes, who is one of the coordinators of the Cuban opposition. I think they deserve our recognition. (Applause)

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: You preceded me because I would also like to welcome a delegation: I am pleased to welcome the delegation from the Japanese Parliament, together with you, who are now making an official visit to the 37th interparliamentary meeting between our parliaments.Welcome!Japan is a strategic partner of the EU.We hope that the negotiations on the Economic Partnership Agreement and the Strategic Partnership Agreement will be concluded, after which both parties will submit it for parliamentary scrutiny.Mr. Gotoda President, honorable and lower house members!Welcome to the seat of the European Parliament and to Strasbourg, I wish you fruitful discussions today and tomorrow, and I hope ...

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: You preceded me because I would also like to welcome a delegation: I am pleased to welcome the delegation from the Japanese Parliament, together with you, who are now making an official visit to the 37th interparliamentary meeting between our parliaments.Welcome!Japan is a strategic partner of the EU.We hope that the negotiations on the Economic Partnership Agreement and the Strategic Partnership Agreement will be concluded, after which both parties will submit it for parliamentary scrutiny.Mr. Gotoda President, honorable and lower house members!I welcome you to the seat of the European Parliament and to Strasbourg, I wish you fruitful discussions today and tomorrow, and I hope that your negotiations will be a success.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: - Madam President, I will be very brief. I fear I was misunderstood yesterday when I made a point of order based on Articles 3 and 4 regarding the fact that the French authorities did not notify the names of the successors of our colleagues who were elected to the Council. 'National Assembly. I was told that we would wait for the notification from the French authorities, which is quite natural and I respect the competence of the national authorities. This is obviously very much within their competence. The problem is that the French authorities refuse to notify on the grounds that our elected colleagues are, for some, the subject of an appeal. This, moreover, does not seem to me to be the case for Mr. Mélenchon, for example, who, according to public rumor, has tendered his resignation. Therefore, Madam President, what I am asking is that, pursuant to Rule 4 (6) of Parliament's Rules of Procedure, our President, as the Rules allow him, and even requires him to, request the French authorities to proceed urgently with this notification.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Thank you very much for warning us once again.The next item is the vote.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
