text: speaker.- Madam President, just a second to thank the political groups for the work we have done during these months to bring this Agreement between the European Union and Cuba to this Chamber today.I think we can send a positive message.At a time when the world is reordering itself, the European Union can maintain fruitful cooperation with Latin America and the Caribbean.Cuba was an exception and today it may cease to be.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: speaker.- Madam President, just a moment to warmly thank Mrs Gräßle, co-rapporteur for this important initiative on criminal law, and the parliamentarians who participated in the debate, no less, than after midnight this very morning;a criminal legislation initiative that frames the criminal legislation of the Member States and shows that this Parliament matters, criminally legislating against fraud in the European budget and, consequently, ensuring the necessary resources to repair the battered European social model.This Parliament really matters.It legislates on fundamental rights and on criminal legislation, and we cannot but thank the parliamentarians who were here after midnight, this very morning, for making it possible.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: – Madam President, sorry but I think there were several MEPs who were not able to vote during the last vote. The machines on a whole row were not working. Can we please repeat the vote?

name: James NICHOLSON
text: – Madam President, I rise from my seat to point out that Amendments 19 and 20 to this report refer to the ‘North of Ireland’. I am a Member from the north of Ireland and there is no such entity as ‘the North of Ireland’. It is the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, and if Northern Ireland is referred to it should be referred to as Northern Ireland. So please, Parliament’s administration, take that on board. This is the second time I have had to point this out in this House, so please, do not require me to do it again.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: – Madam President, sorry, just 30 seconds. I think that one word has accidentally been forgotten in that amendment? It says ‘to maintain full support for the efforts undertaken by the UN to facilitate the comprehensive settlement to the division of Cyprus’. We need to add one more word and the word is ‘end’, i.e. ‘to maintain full support for the efforts undertaken by the UN to facilitate the comprehensive settlement to end the division of Cyprus’.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, the oral amendment I would like us to suggest is ‘to end the division of Cyprus’.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: I close the voting time.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favor of this recommendation because I believe that this political dialogue and cooperation agreement that puts an end to the 1996 common position is vital for the European Union to assert its political presence in Cuba, at a time when the Cuban regime faces the consequences of Venezuela's economic collapse and the tightening of American policies. Dear Colleagues, if this agreement is undoubtedly a platform for the development of bilateral cooperation, it is also a landmark for the intensification of political dialogue. This House, which, on three occasions, awarded the Sakharov Prize to Cuban dissidents and opponents, Osvaldo Payá to Guilherme Fariñas and Damas de Branco, cannot fail to stress the importance of making its application conditional on the scrupulous fulfillment of the commitments made in matters political dialogue and human rights, including an end to repression and the release of political prisoners, respect for press freedom and the guarantee of the rights of assembly and association, so that next year's general elections can be free, plural and fair and they are not just another episode of political and ideological monolithism.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Madam President, I did not support this proposal. I am convinced that at a time when Cuba is still ruled by the Communist Party, when there is a Communist dictatorship, there are political prisoners, so we should be more cautious in strengthening cooperation with that country. In short and well, for me today, the adoption of the agreement is a form of sacrificing the principle of protecting human rights to economic interests and to the interests we should defend, that is, the interests of European trade and business, and we should defend the principles of human rights, freedom, democracy. I am in favor of cooperating with Cuba, but today's form of cooperation, when it is an important agreement, is, in my view, a premature step. Only when Cuba shows concrete changes, concrete shifts towards democracy, to the protection of human rights, then, in my opinion, we should support such an agreement. But at the moment, in my opinion, it is a premature step.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, sola mors tyrannicida est, says Sir Thomas Moore: death is the only way to get rid of a tyrant, and so it proved in the case of Fidel Castro, who survived, by some counts, more than 40 assassination attempts, including an exploding cigar and a poisoned wetsuit. But that has changed the dynamic on the sultry island of Cuba. I was for a long time in this Chamber sceptical of political engagement in the way that we were doing it in this House, refusing in particular to give full weight to the opposition groups. Now, on the other hand, we are in a position of disruptive change. Cuba is in an unfrozen moment, and any disruption tends to be bad for a dictatorship. The thing that will eventually bring about the democratisation of that island and freedom is now economic engagement from the rest of the world. Investment and the rule of law, private property and all the things that bring civil freedoms in their wake. The United States has changed its policy in a welcome way. We should follow.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am making an explanation of vote on behalf of my group. As the GUE / NGL Group we voted in favor of the EU-Cuba political dialogue and cooperation agreement because this agreement represents a step forward in bilateral relations between the European Union and Cuba, putting an end to a common position that was guided by the logic of Cold War. The same logic, however, unfortunately inspired the resolution accompanying the agreement which, with the votes of the right of this Parliament, instead of strengthening the agreement itself and its implementation seems to follow more the agenda of the new US administration than that of the European Union, and for this reason we voted against. In the resolution, with the amendments voted today, the request for lifting the US economic embargo, requested by the UN General Assembly since 1992 - we want to remind you - is softened until it almost disappears. The European Parliament has thus today expressed a more backward position than that of the Council and the Member States. For what reason? For whom, if not to please an ideological vision that we have just heard expressed by my colleague, to please the American right, which wants to impose a destiny decided on Cuba in Miami and not by its people? Cuba is the target of the world and European neoliberal right because, despite the embargo, it has managed over the years to build a health, educational, sports and cultural system of excellence, an example for all developing countries. We demand an end to the embargo. We absolutely ask for it in this House, with conviction, we have also asked for it through an appeal and a petition supported by parliamentarians not only from my parliamentary group. We express once again our solidarity and our gratitude for the struggle of the Cuban people. Hasta la victoria!

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: - Madam President, also on behalf of my group - the Group of the Left - we have voted, without any doubt, in favor of the Agreement of the European Union with Cuba, which means, finally, the normalization of relations. We also celebrate that, once and for all, this Parliament has supported this Agreement, which buries the infamous Common Position that the European Union had against Cuba, which was also promoted by the Government of Aznar in 1996. It was a bad attempt to a copy of the blockade imposed by the United States, which fortunately most of the Member States of the Union did not follow, since most of them maintained bilateral relations with the island. The isolation against Cuba has not worked, and with good judgment the European Union has reconsidered; And, as Mrs. Mogherini pointed out last night, this European Union-Cuba Agreement is based on a frank, constructive and sincere dialogue, on an equal footing between the two parties. For this reason, as Mrs. Mogherini also said, from the European Union and Parliament we reiterate our call for the end of the blockade and we deplore the recent announcement by the Trump Administration.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Madam President, I did not support this agreement, because what is being said here I think is quite a huge nonsense.We cannot have a dialogue with someone who does not respect democratic principles.I was in Cuba, I was there on December 10, 2015, and, dear ladies of the Communist Party, I saw people beating up there.Every time I visited someone, he ended up in the base very early.He ended up in prison and, of course, was beaten in prison.How do you want to have a dialogue with these people?How do you want to have a dialogue with the Communists, who are actually beating their opponents and not letting them speak.That is why I cannot vote in favor of starting a political dialogue.Laugh, I think those who haven't experienced communism are just dreaming about it and slapping nonsense like you.And you are constantly proving this by your behavior now when explaining the vote.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Madam President! Ladies and gentlemen, Communism is not only a political dictatorship, it is a totalitarian tyranny that discriminated against entire social groups it considered hostile, and continues to do so in Cuba, for example. There may be changes in Cuba in the near future, but it is an open question whether it will be a real decommunization or a post-communist transformation, i.e. the takeover of state assets by those who rule today, leaving those who are persecuted today dependent. Everything we know from Central Europe, and especially from Eastern Europe. Unfortunately, there is no indication that the European Union wants to take the side of real liberation, real help for those who have been persecuted. In this resolution, which we have adopted today, we obviously have - as always - LGBTI, we have sex education centers, but unfortunately - to the disgrace of this Congregation - the amendment was rejected in defense of religious freedom, in defense of persecuted Christians, as you can see, this is not a group that deserves special care The European Parliament.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Ms. President!I agree with the rapporteurs that the directive is of paramount importance, as it is a first step towards harmonizing European criminal law for offenses against the EU budget.I particularly welcome the fact that Parliament has established a legal framework for the activities of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, which defines the powers of the prosecutor, and that an important breakthrough has taken place in the field of cross-border VAT fraud.I am pleased to see that the majority of Member States take the fight against corruption seriously and are committed to tackling crimes involving EU funds.However, I regret to note that the Hungarian does not belong to this club.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, today we agreed at second reading on the Council's position, adopting a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the fight against fraud to the Union's financial interests by means of criminal law.The title and the process that led to the adoption of the directive are important.That's why I named him here.This is a first step towards the harmonization of criminal law in Europe in cases of crimes against the EU budget.It is a long-negotiated consensus among all actors, including the justice ministers of the Member States.In this case, the Directive defines the powers of the European Public Prosecutor and introduces the prosecution of cross-border fraud in cases where there is a loss of at least EUR 10 million in two or more Member States.Of course, it will now depend on implementation, including the work of the European Prosecutor, whose work we will, of course, monitor.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Madam President, the Member States pay into the budget of the European Union, and the legal, purposeful and efficient use of these funds is in the interests of all states and their citizens.Under no circumstances should fraud and criminal acts in the use of EU budget funds be allowed to go undetected or prosecuted.Money from the EU budget is used in all Member States and everyone must approach it with equal care and in order to achieve the greatest possible value for their citizens and the European Union as a whole.There are many examples of fraud in the use of EU funds and that is why I am glad that today's vote is one step closer to adopting a directive to combat fraud committed against the financial interests of the Union by criminal means which means harmonizing criminal law in Europe in all cases of fraud.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: - Madam President, tax and financial fraud is a real stigma for society. They point to gross disrespect for citizens and disrespect for God as the highest authority who demands honesty. Unfortunately, I have such experiences mainly from my own country, which has been plagued by corruption and financial fraud of gigantic proportions for many years, even now on the political scene. I am not in favor of the Union's excessive interference in what is happening in our states. However, it is clear that if the state cannot help itself, if it fails and loses the trust of the people, if the government, with its shameless behavior, leaves room for extremist currents, outside help is needed. I consider Slovakia to be a modern, sovereign, successful country to which a parasite of corruption and financial fraud has stuck, and therefore the cost must be removed. I therefore welcome and support the negotiations on the directive on the fight against fraud to the Union's financial interests. I believe that they will significantly help, in particular, the Member States with a legacy of the communist regime, where stealing and deceiving has been a common occurrence and persists.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - I voted in favor of this report because yes, there is a need to harmonize criminal law. Crime, tax evasion is cross-border and it is unfair to have 28 ways to punish those who impoverish national budgets, they impoverish, in the end, the citizens of the European Union. For several years, the European Parliament's committees have looked into this issue, and even so, it has taken a long time. That is why I believe that, by voting on this report, both the national governments and the Commission for monitoring the application of this report and the harmonization of criminal law must take responsibility. I do not think it is enough for us to approve, here it is a shared responsibility, we must also hold national parliaments and national governments accountable, but the Commission must take care to monitor the implementation and monitor the concrete results, not crime, tax evasion and whether the penalties are applied correctly.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - The customs union is a concern of ours, of the European Union, because now, when we talk, there is tax evasion precisely because the information system does not work.We have repeatedly asked the Commission and the Commissioner responsible to have sufficient budgets and not to delay the computerization of customs systems, because we know that tax evasion is also by crossing the border, through customs, tax evasion especially VAT, the amounts are veryand I believe that by voting for this report, which I emphasize I voted for, by voting on this report we can put pressure on the Commission to speed up the allocation of money to complete the computerization of the Customs Union, the implementation ofapproved since 2016, but which still does not work and due to which evasion is still happening, especially on VAT.I hope we have a correct application.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Madam President, I voted in favor of this resolution in recognition of the need for an integrated European Union strategic framework on HIV, tuberculosis and viral hepatitis. I was a shadow rapporteur for the report approved in this House on 2 March on the European Union's options for improving access to medicines, in which the Commission and Member States are urged to adopt strategic plans to ensure access to life-saving medicines and to coordinate a plan to eradicate hepatitis C in the European Union through the use of instruments such as European public procurement. Europe is an area of ​​solidarity and, therefore, the European Union has the task of fulfilling the United Nations' sustainable development objectives, namely objective number 3, which includes the objective of eradicating the HIV and tuberculosis epidemics by 2030 and fight hepatitis. Parliament has systematically asked the Commission about the Union's responses to HIV-AIDS, tuberculosis and hepatitis C. I believe that the Commission must take all measures to promote effective public solutions in the prevention of these diseases and I I will continue to follow this subject in a committed way so that European citizens have a healthier future and better living conditions.

name: Bolesław G. PIECHA
text: - Madam President! I voted in favor of this resolution, of course, but I have to say that the worrying phenomenon at the turn of the 21st century is that in Europe there is an increasing incidence of both old types of infectious diseases such as tuberculosis and new types of viral diseases such as HIV, AIDS or viral diseases. hepatitis C. There is a need for increased preventive measures. It is a shame that a modern Europe with very good medical technology could not stop these infections. Of course, the strategy in viral diseases is different - here what counts is enormous education, preventive health care, and making citizens aware. The tactics of treating, for example, tuberculosis are different. In one such brief summary, efforts should be made to strengthen research into modern drugs - unfortunately most diseases and the development of tuberculosis are drug resistance. Regarding HIV and hepatitis C, I am calling for the cost of modern drugs across Europe to be similar.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Ms. President!I voted in favor of this motion because it highlights a number of issues that are not necessarily known to the public, such as whether, according to the European Center for Disease Prevention and Control, one in seven people living with HIV does not even know if they are infected, ornor is it estimated that an average of four years elapse between HIV infection and diagnosis.In addition, tuberculosis, a disease other than an airborne disease, poses a cross-border health threat in a globalized world where population mobility is increasing.The report rightly draws attention to the problem of co-infections, especially tuberculosis and viral hepatitis B and C, as tuberculosis and viral hepatitis are very common and result in a rapid course and higher morbidity and mortality rates.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Dear Members! I am convinced that the world will be changed by people whose minds and hearts are in place. To my surprise, I even found such a man in the Juncker Commission: Commissioner Andriukaitis, who is of Lithuanian descent and responsible for health. He was deeply touched when I wrote him a letter about a tragic death: an 18-year-old boy died in Hungary from infectious meningitis. Incidentally, this case was followed by several others. I asked you to take action to make vaccination mandatory. I have shown a great deal of humanity, and which is also exceptional in the College of Commissioners, as a doctor, so that I believe that, as long as he is the Member of the Commission responsible for health, I can vote in favor of a report on stronger action on communicable diseases. thank him again this time.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - Madam President! I was the rapporteur for the ECR. I voted with the report the more so because it was the cause of a very interesting debate revealing many problems, including abuses by pharmaceutical companies that inflated the prices of drugs, especially new ones, administered for viral hepatitis, but also for other diseases. Again, I would like to draw attention to the problem of over 40 million HIV-infected, who, apart from health care, lifelong treatment against retroviruses, and improved diagnosis, need to be provided with psychological and psychiatric help, because - as I emphasized - the most important role in controlling the epidemic, in preventing HIV transmission to other people people living with HIV play, which creates a need for their education with the need to inform partners. Also, the observed sevenfold increase in infections in the MSM group requires drawing conclusions regarding prevention with the need to inform and protect not only against stigmatization, but also informing about patients' responsibility, including legal ones.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - I took part in the plenary debate before voting on this report and I also presented to the plenary the arguments for which I support and vote on this report. It is absolutely unimaginable not to vote, as elected people here, on an issue related to people's lives. We do not have, as we have said in this chamber, left, right, center policies. We must support people's lives, people's health. We do not have an integrated program. We now have labor mobility, we have migration from other continents. There is no prevention, no information, no access for medicines to all citizens. There are countries, as is my country, where people with hepatitis C do not can not give that large amount of money, too large, there is no amount needed and this violates the right to life of citizens. I hope that it will not be just a report, I hope that the Commissioner, as a specialist, will talk to national governments and find a way to bring that right to life to every citizen.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: - Madam President, viral hepatitis, tuberculosis and HIV are still a threat to Europeans' health. However, the Commission states that it will contribute to improving the situation by monitoring the reports and examining progress towards the sustainable development goals. In my opinion, this is very little, especially when we read how many people die each year from different types of hepatitis. It is certainly desirable, if we know where the incidence of HIV, tuberculosis or hepatitis is high, that we take measures to prevent the spread of these life-threatening infections and not just monitor them. In 2015, I asked the Commission to what extent the Commission had a mapped vaccination of children against diseases such as tuberculosis, whooping cough or polio. The answer that Member States have competence over vaccination policies cannot be satisfactory, because we still have outbreaks of other diseases that are dying. I therefore join in the call for the Commission and the Council to play an important political role in dialogue with the Member States, but also with neighboring countries, and to ensure that they take responsibility for combating HIV, tuberculosis, viral hepatitis and other epidemics.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: - Madam President, I do not know if we are aware - although many do not listen to us - that a rather strange situation has occurred this morning, because no work program that Parliament sends to the Commission has been approved. This does seem quite ridiculous to me, much more than what Mr Juncker said yesterday, because what has really taken place is a lack of agreement between the groups for the European Parliament to send the Commission its work program for the the next year. And, unfortunately, there is no proposal from Parliament. And why, we would have to ask ourselves. Because we have each voted our proposal and the proposal that has been presented by the PPE, ALDE and ECR Groups has not been successful, because different amendments have been received from different Groups. The truth is that what has been revealed is that there is no stable majority in this Parliament if it is not agreed with the Socialist Group. This is what has been seen today and, unfortunately, this Parliament has done a disservice to its own prestige without being able to present its working document. This is the reality.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Dear Members!Surprisingly, the European Commission has accepted the European Citizens' Initiative, launched by representatives of eight former socialist or communist countries, in order to close the huge income and wage gap between western and eastern countries, which has led tomany people from the Central European Member States are forced to leave their homeland, resulting in tragic situations in families and thus in different jobs.Well, I missed the Commission's work program for 2018 to start tackling a phenomenon that affects many Member States.So to say that I am setting up a serious professional committee, I am starting to explore the reasons, the solution to this huge gap between wages and incomes in the West and the East, respectively.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Madam President, the Resolution on the preparation of the Commission's work program for 2018 was rejected by a large majority of MPs.I abstained in the vote because of course there are a lot of important messages and parts in the Resolution.However, the changes that took place during the vote changed the content and focus on key activities, and therefore, of course, we could not fully support this Resolution.What is important, we all need to know that we face key challenges in 2018 and that of course in the next vote we must take this into account, that the implementation of the program must be strengthened, the implementation of the program accelerated because our citizens expect visible results at least in 2018.years for this perspective.Likewise, crisis management has become our daily routine.Together, we must design and implement the best solutions for both the fight against terrorism and migration management.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: - Madam President, I consider the Commission's program to be very important from the point of view of the people of the EU, so it is a great pity that we have not been able to agree on a joint motion for a resolution across the political spectrum. Of the many good proposals, e.g. strengthening the strategy for industrial recovery, but also the tools for implementing the Paris Climate Agreement. There are other urgent tasks ahead of us, which if we do not solve them immediately, it may be too late tomorrow. I consider demography and the aging of the population, low birth rates, weak support for family life and work-life balance to be such an acute task. Today, older people are becoming a burden and an insurmountable problem in many Member States. That is why I expect the Commission to have a single, coordinated strategy to address this issue. On the other hand, there are young people who rightly expect support from us in education and in the labor market and in a dignified life when starting a family. Therefore, the Commission's 2018 program should also provide a perspective for the young generation in a common Europe.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Ms. President! I voted in favor and reaffirmed the key role of agriculture and rural development in the budget during the plenary debate. Areas such as active farmers, producer groups, the fight against unfair commercial practices, market observatories, phytosanitary measures and the smart approach provide significant security. I would point out that Brexit will also have a major impact in this area, so this issue should already be at the heart of the 2018 budget and it should be examined whether Member States can contribute to the current 1% EU budget. e to 2%. The report also highlights the importance of pilot projects and preparatory actions, which are essential tools for setting political priorities and preparing new initiatives that can become permanent EU activities and programs, such as the "smart villages" concept.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - From the beginning of my term of office I have been dealing with budget issues, financial issues in the area of competences: culture, education, sport and tourism, and therefore I have no problems with accepting the mandate for the trialogue, as well as this stage of work on the budget.What I want to draw attention to, however, is the fact of some parallel debates on various items with the effect, I must say, far from what we expected.On the one hand, culture is being deprived of funds for the European Solidarity Corps that is being created, announcing a compensation that is nowhere written anywhere.I pay attention to this detail, because there are many, many of them.Both the pace and the technical details related to the design of the 2018 budget raise my doubts due to the fact that they are characterized by far-reaching inconsistency.Nevertheless, I supported the project.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Madam President!Thanking Elmar Brok as well as Silvia Cosa for the work done, I would like to emphasize that there are two shortcomings in this document.Firstly, it is being created 10 years after the first formal European cultural agenda was built, which is an extremely distant time.This does not build a good perspective for further tools in which culture would be taken seriously.Secondly, I would like to say at the same time that we write in this document that the "Creative Europe" programs, the scholarship programs for youth, the "Europe for Citizens" program, "Horizon 2020" and at the same time "Horizon 2020" are losing financial resources for investment programs, andprograms dedicated to culture, funds are collected for new projects without compensation.I pay attention to this because we have either a certain schizophrenia or at least inconsistency in this matter.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this report because undoubtedly culture is a common good; it is inseparably linked to human rights and fundamental freedoms. But culture is also a tool that builds bridges between people and reinforces mutual understanding. Looking from this perspective, I warmly welcome the EU strategy for intercultural relations, because it aims to promote a global order based on peace, rule of law, freedom of expression, intercultural and interreligious dialogue, mutual understanding and respect for fundamental values. In light of this, I call on the Commission to strengthen the impact of the cultural dimension in international relations by including the cultural dimension systematically in negotiations and in association agreements. In addition, the Commission and External Action Service have to include international cultural relations in international cooperation instruments and programmes in a horizontal way in order to ensure a coherency and to turn them into efficient tools.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Madam President!Ladies and gentlemen,The Treaty on European Union declares that one of the sources that inspire cooperation between our countries is the religious heritage of Europe.But when we look at the EU strategy in the field of international cultural relations, there is no confirmation of this declaration at all.This document is a manifesto of multiculturalism, where "the diversification of cultural identity" is to replace our tradition, our spiritual values, our history.The EU's cultural strategy is one more document of the structural crisis of the European Union, just like our opposition, it is one more testimony that the Christian civilization of Europe is still alive.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, culture and education as soft-power resources in the EU external policy arsenal are still not adequately reflected in our efforts to counter radicalism, resolve conflicts and promote reconciliation and sustainable socio-economic and human development in the world. These tools could and should be among Europe’s most effective weapons in the promotion of the ideas of non-violence, equality and respect for human rights. I would note too that not enough effort has been put in by the EU on protecting the cultural rights of national minorities, including in the Eastern Partnership countries. Effective cultural diplomacy has to be a strong force for the promotion of cultural and linguistic diversity and the preservation of minority languages and cultures. The slogan ‘Unity in diversity’ should become a universal approach both within and outside the EU.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Madam President, today's Resolution once again calls for the European Union to support the work of the Special Representative of the United Nations Secretary General for Western Sahara and, for this, it must make effective the right to self-determination of the Saharawi people. Next Tuesday the trial of the Gdeim Izik prisoners will resume, in which independent observers have highlighted serious violations of international law, starting with the Convention against Torture: a political trial against the Sahrawi people and their desire for independence. The European Union must act and suspend its agreements with Morocco, as even required by the Court of Justice, until the latter ceases its occupation and colonization of the Saharawi people. International legislation and the Charter of the United Nations are clear: only a self-determination referendum can put an end to the plunder and exile of the Saharawi people. We will work together to carry it out.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: –Madam President, I had to double check but indeed this report says in point (al) that there should be more open expression of opinion, especially by citizens, in the context of migration. Indeed, go ahead, dear citizens of the European Union, express your opinions like we did in Hungary. This reminded me of, for example, the population of the small jewel called Martonfa, a community near the town of Pécs, who said, ‘we do not want a migration camp or a migrants’ camp here and we shall stay here in this territory and we shall not leave until it is decided that there shall be no camp here’. What was the result? The Hungarian Government decided to watch our borders instead of putting camps into beautiful areas of Hungary. Do the same.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: - Madam President, as the Member States of the European Union, we are the largest financial contributor to the UN system, which is about 50% of all contributions. In the European Union, therefore, we boast that we are the world's leading leaders, setting the pace and direction, which is certainly true to some extent, and unfortunately sometimes we have nothing to be proud of in such a leadership. In a resolution of the European Parliament's recommendation to the UN General Assembly, the EP once again called for, and approved, the active promotion of support measures for LGBTI people, which, of course, I could not support. This week alone, we have three more resolutions on the agenda supporting that strange and unscientific LGBT agenda. So I really ask how it is sung in one song by the Slovak singer Simona Martausová: “where does this world sleep, when the teeth are supposed to be only white, murders are also in the folder, reason does not always go with age, we are always dependent on someone, and we fall asleep thanks to drugs that do with the human soul, man serves a special god, women become men who conquer forts ”. Thank you for understanding.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, the European Union cannot outsource its industrial capacities to other continents. That is not wise, in the same way that a human organism cannot declare that it will not use its liver because livers are not as cool as kidneys. The result for the organism would be devastating. My country, Latvia, has lost 25% of jobs in industry since joining the European Union and now my country depends heavily on help from European funds. Without a proper industrial policy, we cannot say that our European economy is sustainable. That is why it is very important to strengthen and modernise the industrial base in Europe. The Commission, together with the Member States, should adopt a holistic European industrial policy strategy. We cannot only scratch one another behind the ears and call it a modern service economy. We need a modern and developed industry in Europe.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Madam President, today we voted on a resolution on an ambitious industrial strategy and it is extremely important for the whole of Europe and for each member state because without a strong industry we cannot have a very leading economy, and we want to be world leaders.The industry, unfortunately, has been falling all the time for the last twenty years and its share in GDP has fallen from 19% to 15%, and our goal in this strategy by 2020 is to be 20%.How are we going to achieve that?We need to significantly change our attitudes and ways of working, we need to reduce dependence on raw materials from third countries, we need to increase energy efficiency.Also, change the education system and harmonize it with the needs of industry, connect industry with science, encourage innovation and, of course, reduce regulatory burdens.There is a lot of work ahead of us and this resolution makes that clear.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: We have reached the end of the explanations of vote.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for the debate on the report by Kati Piri, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the 2016 Commission report on Turkey (2016/2308 (INI)) (A8-0234 / 2017).

name: Kati PIRI
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, adalet is the Turkish word for justice. As we speak, thousands of people are marching from Ankara to Istanbul in protest at the large-scale purges that started after the failed coup attempt one year ago. The numbers are swelling every day, and more than one million people are expected to attend a peaceful march for justice when they arrive in Istanbul this coming Sunday. In a deeply polarised country, people from all walks of life are uniting to call for the restoration of the rule of law in their country. That is not only historic, it is also a hopeful sign that many in Turkey do not accept the authoritarian drift in their country. These people are fighting for their democratic rights, and we in the European Parliament stand side by side with all those in Turkey who believe in the same European values as us. At least half of the population voted against the new constitutional package in the referendum. Turkish students are protesting against the government-appointed rectors in their universities. And teachers fired under government decrees, Nuriye Gülmen and Semih Özakça, began a hunger strike in protest. As their strike neared the 80-day mark and their health faded, they were arrested and they have been in custody ever since. This shows how little space is left nowadays for freedom of speech in Turkey. But all of these examples also show how millions of people in Turkey are not giving up hope. One year after the failed military takeover, Turkish democracy is under great pressure. A heavy price is being paid by the Turkish people. The parliament and the constitutional court are bypassed as the government rules by emergency decrees. More than 150 000 people have lost their jobs, more than 50 000 people have been jailed, and all without having an opportunity to defend themselves. The continually deteriorating situation is South-East Turkey deserves special attention. Not only is the leader of the pro-Kurdish People’s Democratic Party (HDP), Selahattin Demirtaș, imprisoned, so are 12 of his colleagues and 87 mayors from that region. Especially in the areas where curfews were imposed, excessive force has been used by security personnel, and collective punishment has been applied to the inhabitants. However, this in no way justifies any of the killings conducted by the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK), an organisation which has been on the EU’s terror list since 2002, and last week’s murder of two local Justice and Development Party (AKP) politicians is another sad example of how this conflict affects many people’s lives. The EU believes that there can only be a political solution to the Kurdish question.  When looking at the widespread crackdown on all dissent in Turkey, silence is the worst strategy for the EU to take in reaction. Not only does it leave millions of Turks out in the cold, it also fuels euroscepticism in our own countries and sends the wrong message to the other EU candidate countries in the Western Balkans. Let us take a look at some examples from the past weeks. Why was there no EU statement when journalists from the Sozcu newspaper were targeted? Why was there no EU reaction when the head of Amnesty International’s Turkish branch was arrested? And why was there no condemnation when a 14th member of the Turkish Parliament, Republican People’s Party (CHP) MP Enis Berberoglu, was jailed and sentenced to 25 years? We understand that Turkey is an important country and we have many joint strategic interests. We are not pleading for a stop to all dialogue and cooperation with Ankara, but what we are asking the Commission and the EU leaders to do is simply to stand up for our own values. By looking away, we are seriously undermining our own credibility. We support the Commission’s proposal to start negotiations on the modernisation of the current customs union with Turkey. This would not only be beneficial to both sides in economic terms, but it is perhaps also the only leverage the EU still has in making the Government of Turkey commit to European standards. On visa liberalisation, we encourage the Turkish Government to comply with the last five remaining benchmarks. Finally, while the political Groups in this House have very different views on EU-Turkey relations, I would like to thank especially my colleague rapporteurs from the other Groups in making sure that this Parliament speaks with one, clear and loud voice in condemning the Turkish Government’s serious decline in democratic standards, while continuing to support the Turkish population, millions of whom would like to continue to see the EU as an anchor for reforms in their country. And for all those millions of people in Turkey it is also important that we continue to uphold our own values when dealing with a candidate country. To those in Turkey following this debate, we would like to say that your struggle in difficult times does not go by unnoticed. Together with you, we hope that adalet – justice – will return to Turkey soon.

name: Kati PIRI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, Turkey is a candidate country and a key partner for the EU. We cooperate in many important areas of joint interest, such as counter—terrorism, foreign and security policy, energy, the economy and trade, as well as migration. The EU—Turkey joint action plan for refugees and migration management and the March 2016 statement continue to be applied in the interest of both parties. So far, this cooperation has led to a significant decrease in deaths at sea and a substantial reduction of irregular migrant arrivals from Turkey. It has also led to an improved situation for Syrian migrants in Turkey. The EU Facility for Refugees in Turkey has made a significant contribution through additional funding in the areas of humanitarian assistance, education migration management, heath, municipal infrastructure and socio—economic support. We continue to appreciate Turkey for its enormous efforts in hosting and addressing the needs of around 3 million refugees from Syria and Iraq. Work continues on the issue of visa liberalisation, which, however, remains conditional on Turkey’s fulfilment of all the requirements of the road map. We look forward to any further progress regarding this issue during our Presidency this year. We follow the domestic developments in Turkey with deep concern. Regarding the April referendum this year, President Juncker, High Representative Mogherini and Commission Hahn issued a joint statement, which stressed that the constitutional amendments and their implementation will be assessed in light of Turkey’s obligations as an EU candidate country. We share many of the concerns to which you Parliament referred both in its resolution on Turkey from November last year and in relation to the draft resolution recently discussed and voted upon in the Committee on Foreign Affairs. Many of these concerns were also reflected in the Presidency conclusions of the General Affairs Council, adopted on 13 December 2016. The significant backsliding in the areas of the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights are deeply worrying and should be urgently addressed by the relevant Turkish authorities. The unequivocal rejection of the death penalty is an essential requirement for EU membership, and it is also part of Turkey’s international obligations. In contacts with Turkey the EU side takes every opportunity to recall these and other concerns, and we will continue to do so. Turkey needs to normalise its relations with Cyprus and fully implement the provisions of the additional protocol of their association agreement. Nevertheless, continued engagement and an open dialogue with Turkey remain important. The EU should remain the anchor for Turkey’s reforms. We continue to expect Turkey to respect the highest standards when it comes to democracy, the rule of law and respect for fundamental freedoms, including the freedom of expression. As for the situation in the south east of Turkey, the EU will continue to call for an immediate cessation of violence and terrorist attacks. This needs to be accompanied by a return to a credible and inclusive political settlement process and a genuine political dialogue, aiming at a political solution there.

name: Kati PIRI
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to start by commending the rapporteur’s efforts to capture the main challenges in the complex EU-Turkey relationship in a very comprehensive report. I share the strong concerns of this House when it comes to the domestic situation in Turkey as already reflected in the Commission’s 2016 country report and in our public positions ever since. The number of jailed journalists remains very high – currently over 160, including some EU citizens. The situation of academics and of civil society in general has worsened. The opposition finds itself under ever-growing pressure. Honourable Members, I am deeply committed to improving EU-Turkey relations, but only tangible steps by Ankara, reversing the worrying trend on the fundamentals of our relationship, can accomplish this in the mid- and long term. For instance, the ad hoc committee offering remedies to excessive government measures after the attempted coup needs to produce urgent results. Continued close cooperation with the Council of Europe is vital in this context. I also echo Secretary-General Jagland’s call for the release of the two teachers on hunger strike, whose life-threatening situation is rapidly deteriorating. The letter to President Erdoğan, signed by the four largest political groups in this House on the situation of the freedom of the press, will hopefully show its the desired effect. In short, we cannot and we will not ignore the worrying developments in Turkey, precisely because we want fruitful bilateral relations. Turkey is a candidate country. With the statutes come rules and obligations, obligations and standards to which Turkey itself has subscribed. At the same time, our common challenges are growing by the day, from security in the wider region to the fight against terrorism to the handling of migration and refugees. To tackle these challenges together, it is in our European self-interest to have a stable, democratic, prosperous partner who acts under the rule of law. That is precisely why the EU was among the few first international actors to declare its full support for Turkey, its citizens and its democratic institutions after the terrible coup attempt nearly a year ago – that horrible night during which more than 240 people lost their lives, 2 200 were wounded and the Turkish Grand National Assembly was attacked and severely damaged. Madam President, honourable Members, when Presidents Juncker and Tusk met with President Erdoğan a few weeks ago, they agreed to pursue our agenda of engagement and open dialogue. This will include a number of high-level thematic dialogues and bilateral visits over the coming months. Furthermore, last week’s steering committee of the facility for refugees in Turkey, the rapporteur, Ms Piri, as well as the Chair of the Committee on Budgets, Mr Arthuis, could witness themselves that the facilities are being smoothly implemented, and it is delivering very tangible results on the ground for the refugees. We have given hundreds of thousands basic livelihoods. We have trained thousands of teachers, and they are giving hundreds of thousands of refugee children a formal education. We are now providing many with a socio-economic perspective. All of this is key to reducing migration pressure. Right after our discussion here today, I will fly to Ankara to meet with Minister Çelik and Minister for the Economy, Zeybekci. I will also visit a health project founded by the EU Facility for Refugees. My message will be clear. The European Union sticks to its financial commitments under the refugee facility. Our support has a clear impact, but our overall relationship can only move forward if there is a clear improvement of the domestic situation in Turkey. Honourable Members, closely engaging with Turkey is crucial. It is, however, equally important that we make it crystal clear that we all expect positive and tangible developments in and by Turkey. Yes, we engage, but we are not moving the goalposts in either direction. We continue to have a very close eye on what is happening in the crucial areas of rule of law and fundamental freedoms. That is not only a matter of fulfilling EU criteria and universal values; it is, first and foremost, the only way to end the deep divide in Turkish society.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President! First of all, I would like to thank our rapporteur, Kati Piri, and also my colleagues from the other groups for the good cooperation. It is very remarkable how we got this report through this year. We have seen dramatic developments in Turkey, and the situation has already been adequately presented here: thousands of layoffs, hundreds of arrests, a witch hunt for politically dissenters, actually the abolition of the rule of law and a climate of fear, that prevails in this country. So how should we deal with such a country? In fact, I think we should have voted on this report, which we are voting on tomorrow, much earlier, namely before the referendum. Then we could have used our report to explain to the Turkish people what this constitutional referendum actually means. Because I claim: Hardly anyone in Turkey really knew what this referendum was about. The Turkish government has managed to mislead its own people. Because the constitutional changes are just not good for the country. But it is now clear to us: we must finally draw conclusions. And the Council of Ministers must finally have the courage to do this. Our citizens at home have long failed to understand why these bogus negotiations on EU accession are still going on and why the Turkish government is still receiving considerable financial resources from us. Of course, it is clear to everyone here - as has already been said - that a close and privileged relationship between the EU and Turkey is absolutely essential in the interests of both sides. But that can only be achieved if the relationship is based on respect for human rights, fundamental freedoms, democratic values ​​and the rule of law. After all, the Turkey accepted these conditions when it became a candidate for membership in 1999. But unfortunately she has long refused to accept these core values ​​as her own. This shows that this country's accession is simply out of the question. And it is only logical if we now call for the negotiations to be formally suspended, which in plain language will mean the end of the accession negotiations if the constitutional reform package is implemented unchanged. The constitutional amendments clearly violate the Copenhagen criteria. However, Turkey has not met these criteria for a long time, and it has now underlined that again with the expropriation of Christian cultural heritage. Churches and all of their cemeteries were confiscated and transferred to the Diyanet religious authority. It is a mockery that Turkey says in the same breath: “And we want to continue to become a member of the European Union. “This is a very clear violation of our basic principles. We cannot accept that. We have to concentrate on another level, that will be the customs union. We should work towards this together, but also on the basis of the rule of law and respect for fundamental human rights.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, it was a very difficult year for Turkey. A very difficult and dramatic one. The failed coup d’état, the Syrian war in the sixth year, and Turkey has received more than three million refugees. The conflict in the south east continues. Turkey has faced a series of terrorist attacks. It is important to say it, and I understand that the security environment has change in Turkey as well as in the surroundings of the European Union. Therefore, yes, I’m worried about the Turkish democracy. I’m extremely worried when it comes to the fundamental freedoms in Turkey and the way the mass liquidation of media outlets is the result of the state action. The way in which there are mass arrestation of journalists, academics, judges, elected representatives of the opposition and so on and so forth. Today they are endangered by the actions taken by the current leadership of President Erdoğan. Our report is rightly pointing out all of this. Our commitment to the people of Turkey remains, nevertheless, strong. The civil society and the opposition in Turkey are waiting for us to be further engaged and support them not only in their survival – the physical survival sometimes – but in preserving the remains of the democracy in Turkey. Today they are continuing their march from Ankara to Istanbul, a march for justice and democracy. I salute them, all of them. So this is not the time to give up on Turkey. It is the time when criticism should be strong when necessary and when a constructive, open and pragmatic dialogue should be maintained. It is the appropriate time to stress that Turkey and the European Union does have a strategic interest and have to continue their cooperation in very important areas – migration, counterterrorism, Syrian war in the Middle East region, where Turkey can play a positive role. It is more than now to say today to put an end to the escalating populism within the European Union, the rhetorics which call to cut the relations with Turkey. And the best we can do is to support the customs union.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: - Madam President!I have a very brief point of order.Here speeches are overdrawn by three quarters of a minute, and if we can talk for just a minute, then you should apply the same law to everyone.Or is there some rule that allows some to talk a minute longer, talk 45 seconds longer, and we hit the jackpot at exactly one minute and two seconds?Equal rights for everyone, or you can explain the rules to us anew!

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: I'll give it to you, madam, and we'll try to re-establish ... No, Mr Fleckenstein, everyone will calm down, and we will resume our debate as normal.Everyone respects the speaking times and so everything will be fine.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Turkey is much more than Erdogan and the AKP. I am pleased to hear the voices of Turkish citizens with an “open mind” within and outside their own borders. These courageous Turks fully deserve European support. Two concrete examples. Every week I look forward to “the letter from Istanbul” in the Frankfurter Allgemeine by editor Bülent Mumay. High level information and analysis! Independent reporting on Turkey is of great value to the EU, especially now, and we must also support it. A second example. Last Friday, the Turkish columnist Guzde Berderoglu wrote about the monastery Mor Gabriel (founding year 397!): “Mor Gabriel is our history”. She continues, "Until we understand that this is our common history, our decline will continue." These courageous words from Turkish pen directly oppose the current expropriation of dozens of churches, monasteries and estates of the Aramean community around the city of Mardin. Commissioner, also stand firmly for a Christian presence and cultural heritage in Turkey, also because of our values ​​and our history! MdV, I reserve my last words for two fellow countrymen, rapporteur Kati Piri and former colleague Joost Lagendijk. Kati, you combine expertise with an open perspective, we need, tribute! Joost, I wish you a speedy reunion with your Turkish wife, also thanks to our European support and solidarity.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President! Turkey has been a candidate for membership for 18 years and negotiations have been going on for twelve years. One would think that during that time relations between Turkey and the European Union would have improved. Exactly the opposite is the case. Relationships get worse and worse year after year because there is no one on either side who seriously believes that this negotiation process could one day lead to success. I think that is as true for Brussels as it is for Ankara. We have in the population opposition to Turkey's accession, calculated through the European Union, of a total of 77 percent, in Germany 86 percent are calling for the end of the accession negotiations. We have more journalists in prison in Turkey than in China or Iran, in universities academic freedom of research and teaching has been eliminated with an iron broom, the judiciary is no longer independent. I think it is good that the Commission says it will not be ignored. I am amazed, dear President of the Council, when I hear a sentence from you here: We expect Turkey to fulfill the highest standards in democracy, fundamental rights and judicial independence. Please don't just read out what your officers write for you; have the courage to use your own mind. Because nobody can believe that it really is as you have described it here. Ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament is proposing to freeze accession negotiations with Turkey. That is not the same as proposing to end the dialogue with Turkey. On the contrary: it is the proposal to finally put the dialogue on an honest basis: about energy policy, about the customs union, about visa liberalization, about tourism, about environmental issues. We have so many things that we have to regulate together with the Turks and be able to regulate - even with difficult domestic political developments.That is why, ladies and gentlemen, we are making the dialogue with Turkey honest!Let's put it on a foundation that works!Let's say yes to the dialogue, let's say yes to the treaties that we can conclude with Turkey!But let's make it clear that accession cannot and will not happen.The country is moving away from Europe.Let's not ignore this any longer, let's draw the necessary conclusions!

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, this is a report that clearly reflects, in my view, the current situation in Turkey, which has been wonderfully described by both Commissioner Hahn and - mainly - the rapporteur, Mrs Piri, whom I would like to thank. especially for the efforts he made - and with the shadow rapporteurs - but also for the work he did to bring about this result. Thank you very much, sincerely. Ladies and gentlemen, I expect you to say a few words about the Cyprus issue in the very short time I have. We also expect positive results from Switzerland at some point, in order to escape from this problem that torments all Cypriots, although so far we do not have all the positive information we need. Dear colleagues, Turkey owns one third of Cyprus. The Greek Cypriot side said it was handing over part of this piece that was taken by force to come under Turkish Cypriot rule; they will have their own police, they will control their municipalities, education, religion, etc. There will also be federal police, they will participate in the central government in all systems of power, councils of ministers, Upper House, with a proportion of 50% - much more than 20% of the population. Why is it not solved? Why is the Cyprus problem not solved with this solution, which is the absolutely correct one? Because Turkey does not want to leave Cyprus. That is why you, here, the Commissioners and the representatives of the Council and the Members of Parliament, must exert as much influence as you can in Turkey, so that its foot leaves the chest of the Cypriots. There is nothing else you can do and the reference to the upgrade in the customs relationship made in the report unfortunately does not allow us to vote in favor of it.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! I think it is extremely sad that we are once again standing here and regretting that developments in Turkey are going in the wrong direction. It went in the wrong direction last year and the year before that, and I wonder when we last rejoiced at the progress that has been made. Since the military coup took place just a few months after we debated our previous report, a state of emergency has prevailed. President Erdoğan has strengthened his grip on power, he has had government-critical party leaders, parliamentarians, mayors and journalists imprisoned without legal proceedings. In addition, well over 100,000 teachers, government officials and others have been fired for sympathizing with the opposition or Gülen movement that Erdoğan blames for the coup attempt. But it is not just Turkish citizens who are affected. A former EU parliamentarian, also chair of the Joint Parliamentary Assembly with Turkey, Joost Lagendijk, who now lives in Turkey, has been refused home for a year. We are pleased that his case is being highlighted in the report. We Greens do not want to close the door on Turkey, but we are still behind a freeze on the negotiations and we are also saying no to a modernization of the customs union in this situation. The EU and Turkey have strong ties and we hope that they will continue, but it is not easy today to defend further negotiations on either accession or an upgrade of the customs union with a regime that does not maintain any respect for either the democratic rules of the game, human rights or the rule of law. New in this year's report is that for the first time we are explicitly talking about interrupting the accession negotiations if the proposed constitutional changes go through unchanged. It is a strong signal not only to Erdoğan but to the Turkish Parliament and to the Turkish electorate. The ball is now with them. But the report also addresses deeper cooperation within other counter-terrorism and migration, and there our view is not entirely in line with that of the majority.On the one hand, we believe that it is not possible to have cooperation on terrorism with a country that refuses to change the terrorism legislation, which in principle can cover anyone who expresses an opinion other than the president's, and on the other hand, we believe that Turkey is not a safe country to send people.back to.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with tomorrow's vote, this House will finally take note of what we have been saying for some time: Turkey does not have the qualifications to be a candidate country for the European Union. The unacceptable changes proposed to the Constitution, the referendum campaign and the referendum itself, not to mention the polemics against some member states, the purges in the public administration and the crushed freedom of the press, make more and more evident an authoritarian tendency manifested by Erdoğan who, to tell the truth, we have been reporting for too many years. It was therefore inevitable - and I thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for the excellent work we have done together - that this annual report would finally formalize this state of affairs and prove us right. The request to officially suspend the negotiations when these constitutional amendments are implemented was and is a duty. And so it is also to say that talking about visa liberalization today is out of reality. Yet, despite this electoral campaign defined by the OSCE as unfair, due to the lack of equal opportunities, unilateral coverage and limitations on fundamental freedoms, the "yes" in four major cities, in the four largest cities, has won by measure, indeed lost in these centers of greater importance. It means that many citizens have understood that civil society is more alive than ever. Yes, we cannot renounce Turkey, but above all we must not renounce the Turkish people. Ankara's future is written in the eyes and courage of university students who protested against the rectors imposed on them by Erd-oğan, to defend freedom of opinion, expression and teaching. It is also written in the eyes of those who march from Ankara to Istanbul to reaffirm the rights of the opposition and minorities, especially the Kurdish one. Yes, we have a duty to be by their side and to use all leverage, including commercial leverage, to defend their right to have rights frankly and consistently.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe there is a certain consensus. I think that we all aspire to one thing: to ensure that Turkey, this great people, can come out of its doldrums. Nevertheless, here there is a double, even a triple language. I heard Mr Lambsdorff and Mrs von Storch. Let me tell you, Mr Lambsdorff, that Mr Juncker yesterday weakened our institution. I think this is not a very good thing for the democratic spirit of the European Parliament. Then, Mrs von Storch, of course, we freeze the accession agreement with Turkey, but nevertheless in my committee - the Committee on International Trade - the customs union is maintained. It’s double talk. That is to say, politically, we oppose Turkey's presence in the European Union, but economically, we continue to set up this customs union. Where do we want to go? Today, the EPP Group - because this is the group that has the key here - wants Turkey's continued membership of the European Union. In my opinion, it would be harmful if we were on this wavelength, because I think that Turkey is not European and that it represents a real danger, not only for our union of civilizations, but also for the very cohesion of the European Parliament. Therefore, as long as the PPE Group does not understand that we have to get out of this logic with Turkey, we will not move forward. Today, unfortunately, I believe that the PPE Group will continue this double talk which will lead us to the abyss, that is to say towards the end of our European structure.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Madam President, the European Union, despite being well aware of both Turkey's uncompromising stance and its blackmail and threats, is confronting it with a policy of complacency, fear and contradiction, which leads to deadlocks. On the one hand, it condemns Turkey's aggression towards all its neighbors and, on the other hand, calls for a deepening of their relations on issues of common interest. It condemns the human rights violations in Turkey, but at the same time calls for the upgrading of the customs relationship. Turkey only understands the fist and the determination. The European Union must make it clear that as long as Turkey continues to threaten Greece and Cyprus, as long as it does not recognize the entity of the Republic of Cyprus, as long as it does not withdraw the occupying troops from Cyprus and as long as it does not stop the flow of illegal immigrants to Greece, will not receive funding and accession procedures will be suspended indefinitely. This is how Turkey should be treated if we want to solve the problem it hears in the name of Turkey, unless you are afraid that Mr Erdoğan will accuse you of following Nazi methods.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: - Madam President, a year has passed since the coup attempt against the Turkish Republic and all of us here in the European Parliament condemn in the strongest terms the coup plotters and their practices and pay tribute to the hundreds of victims of last July 's coup. We all here in the European Parliament want a Turkey that will be a factor of stability in the wider region. Especially when we have two essentially devastated countries in the wider region, Syria and Iraq, and in our south, Libya. We all want a Turkey firmly oriented towards European ideals. But the Turkish government - Mr Erdoğan's government - is moving away with its practices of press freedom, minority rights, justice and the administration of justice, the arrest of hundreds of civil servants and teachers and the reinstatement of the death penalty. from the European acquis. Turkey has lost its European dream. Politically and value-wise, Turkey is moving away from Europe. Mrs Piri's report is a balanced report that captures the reality in Turkey today. We want the dialogue to continue, that is what we are doing as the European Union-Turkey Joint Interparliamentary Committee, and that is why we will be voting in favor of the report.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: - Madam President, dear Kati Piri! I think we have a really good report here, which not only shows expertise but also a bit of empathy - something that is not to be found in every report. The common future with our neighbor, Turkey, is far from over. But - we have heard the reasons - if the referendum is now translated into concrete law, we will suspend accession negotiations or propose that the Council suspend them. Because it really doesn't make sense anymore. And, Count Lambsdorff, it wasn't the case that they started negotiating 18 years ago and then went down the mountain year after year. Mr Erdoğan in particular was one of those people who gave us hope a long time ago that things would go up a bit. It is more honest to interrupt or suspend these negotiations, and it is important because it also shows others that you have to choose where to go. You can't shut a door and keep shouting, “Let me in!” There is this need to make a decision. But it's just as important that our friends know that we will not fail them. And our friends are those who want a different Turkey, who want democracy and the separation of powers, for which the rule of law is important, and especially civil liberties. We will continue to support the opposition parties, journalists, professors, and the many young people in civil society who live in Turkey or, in some cases, in our cities. And concrete proposals are made. If we suspend the negotiations, then we must also see that the pre-accession funds are used to bring civil society and refugees in Turkey, but also other people through Erasmus +, together through other things. Those who are not our friends must too be clear.On the one hand there is this government, and on the other hand there are those who carry out coups or terrorists.There are no good ones and no bad ones ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Madam President, this is by far Parliament’s most critical report on Turkey that I have ever seen and it is wholly deserved. Far from dismantling the Turkish deep state and the pursuit of democracy, Erdogan has instead replaced one authoritarian regime with another. After years of increasing his power base, he has now fully cemented his, and the AK Party’s, dominant role across the whole of the Turkish state. Having purged public institutions and silenced the media under the pretext of responding to the attempted coup last year, the referendum this year has now confirmed constitutional changes that ensure that President Erdogan is soon to assume his much—coveted sultanesque role.  Turkey, as a NATO state and EU candidate country, however, is too important and too close to Europe to simply ignore. Difficult choices now lie ahead of us as to how to adapt the EU’s relationship with Turkey in the future, but we should take care to ensure that those choices are not dictated purely by necessity, rather than by our common values. I hope, above all, to see a solution to end Turkey’s military occupation of Cyprus very soon.   (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – Thank you, Charles, for taking my blue card. This isn’t a personal dig at you, but do you understand my frustration that your party, the British Conservative Party, sits in the same pan-European group, the ACRE, as Erdogan’s AKP party? Do you think that is an extremely difficult position for your party, and would you welcome their withdrawal from it?

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: blue-card answer. – Well, thank you for reminding me of that rather unfortunate fact, Mr Carver. It is extremely difficult for me, as somebody critical of AK and what it has been up to in Turkey, so I would call upon the Conservative Party leadership – I am not part of the leadership – to expel the AK Party as soon as possible.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Madam President, for the past years the progress report has become a reflection of regress of the rule of law and of democracy. This regress weighs on the people of Turkey as well as on our relationship. Our group, and this Parliament, have been consistent. We supported accession as we believed it would serve the rights and the freedoms of the people in Turkey. We urged the freezing of negotiations last year after the massive response to the failed coup attempt, however despicable that attempt was. Yes, perpetrators should be held to account, but with fair trial and due process. The package of constitutional amendments, if implemented unchanged, would de facto put an end to the accession process and negotiations. Still, we do not want to slam the door in the faces of the population of Turkey and we insist that any form of a future relation between the EU and Turkey cannot be transactional only, focused on trade security, asylum and migration, but will have to be deeply rooted in the rule of law and respect for human rights.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: - Madam President, Turkey 's accession negotiations have been going on for twelve years. For twelve years, Turkey has pretended to be willing to comply with European rules to become a member of the Union, and Europe pretends to believe it. In practice, the Turkish regime is becoming increasingly authoritarian within itself, increasingly aggressive towards neighboring countries. These facts are reflected in the report we are discussing today, but unfortunately this leads to inconsistent conclusions, such as the need to upgrade the customs union of the two sides or to liberalize the visa regime for Turkish citizens entering European territory. If these references are not deleted, we are not prepared to vote in favor of this report. (The speaker agreed to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162 (8))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question asked under the 'blue card' procedure.- I understand the problems and I think that what you said is very good from the report, but do you think that the request to completely close the dialogue and the customs union you talked about brings a better situation for Turkish citizens than it is now?Do you believe this?Because, in my country, there are Turkish citizens whose passports are unfortunately taken away and they can no longer be protected in a country in the European Union.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: blue card answer.- Turkey, ladies and gentlemen, refuses to comply with the customs union status and its obligations under its previous agreements with the Union.By what logic could this regime be upgraded now, which Turkey itself does not respect?It is completely inconsistent and I repeat that we are not prepared to vote in favor of such a thing.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Madam President, the report we are going to adopt tomorrow, which is comprehensive and balanced, calls for the suspension of accession negotiations if the constitutional reform package is implemented unchanged. Suspension would be bad news for those like me in the European Union and Turkey who would like to see Turkey become a Member State in the near future. We would have preferred to talk about freezing the negotiations instead of suspension, but if we want to see the glass half full, this warning also leaves some room for hope, the hope that the Turkish Government changes its course and goes back to where it should never have departed from: the defence of democracy and respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. It is useless to keep pretending that you can negotiate while there are over 100 journalists and over a dozen Kurdish mayors and some MPs in jail, when there has been a huge collective dismissal of civil servants and when many media have been closed down. But if we cannot have negotiations, let’s at least keep the door open to dialogue.

name: James CARVER
text: – Madam President, until very recently Turkey, an important NATO ally, was firmly on the path to EU accession, and in this very Chamber speakers praised President Erdoğan’s new Turkey. However, since then, Turkey’s accession to the European Union, and indeed their commitment to NATO, now both seem questionable. Despite failing to uphold recent nature commitments, citing financial pressure, Turkey has since funded the deployment of 3 000 troops to Qatar at a time of heightened tension across the Gulf. Perhaps symbolic of this change in Turkey’s path was instruction to chisel out the poignant words of Atatürk carved into a stone WWI memorial at Gallipoli which I now quote ‘Those heroes who shed their blood and lost their lives you are now lying in the soil of a friendly country. Therefore, rest in peace. There is no difference between the Johnnies and the Mehmets to us, where they lie side by side here in this country of ours. You, the mothers who sent their sons from faraway countries, wipe away your tears your sons are now lying in our bosom and are in peace.
