After having lost their lives on this land they have become our sons as well’. How Turkey has changed. (The President interrupts the speaker) The desecration of this moving epitaph leads many to suggest this is a further sign of the cultural shift taking place in Ankara. It seems to me that regrettably Turkey, under Erdoğan, is turning its back on secularism. I call on this House to acknowledge what we have long argued: Turkey is incompatible with EU membership. This report must go further and call for an end to this illusion once and for all. Mustafa Kemal Atatürk must be turning in his grave.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a brief reflection for the rapporteur of this soft report on the situation in Turkey. Suppose absurdly that this debate took place in Turkey already entered: we would be bordering Syria, Iraq and Iran. Let's suppose that some of the speakers who spoke more critically had said these things with Turkey already in Europe: European arrest warrants from prosecutors in Istanbul or Ankara would already be ready. Let's reflect on this, perhaps also thinking about the fact that yesterday we recalled the values ​​that inspired Simone Veil. What would Simone Veil say to hear all these enthusiasts about the continuation of relations with Turkey? It is a battle for freedom that must be fought in deciding whether to continue or, as we say, permanently terminate these relationships for the reasons listed in the report itself. But today I have the moral duty to remember a great freedom fighter who died a few hours ago in Sardinia, in his Sardinia: Doddore Meloni, a freedom fighter. You see, the Italian state, which is often very weak with real criminals, has been obsessively harsh towards this fiscal objector, leader of Sardinia's battle for independence, whom I intend to honor and duly remember. He was an honest, clear man, a poet of politics, and this Europe which should be - as he hoped and thought, like us - a Europe of peoples, regions and even nations, of course, a Europe that should be a Europe of liberties, should not allow people to be incarcerated just for dreaming of the freedom of their own land. Honor to this patriot, and we remind Sardinia to be proud of this ensign of freedom, son of a land that wants to be free, disinterested and clear fighter for the independence of the island, of this beautiful Sardinia, which I want to remember. Therefore let's stay outside, let's keep Turkey and these counter-values which are the exact negation of what these patriots aspire to, these people who exalt their attachment to their land, to their freedom with their example.Long live the freedom of Sardinia, no to Turkey in Europe, never Turkey in Europe!

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: - Madam President, the report on Turkey reflects the escalation of tensions between the European Union and the Turkish bourgeoisie, in an area where forces are redeploying, imperialist rivalries are raging for markets, energy, transport routes, in which the bourgeois order of Turkey. The European Union seeks to continue its strong intervention in the interests of European monopolies in the region. The report indicates a freeze on accession, citing existing dangerous threats and violations against neighboring countries, such as Cyprus, Greece, as well as the violation of the rights of the Greek people. At the same time, however, it keeps open the prospect of the accession process, promotes the upgrading of the customs union, the implementation of the unacceptable EU-Turkey agreement on refugees, and cooperation on the so-called fight against terrorism. The peoples must coordinate and organize their independent struggle outside and against the rivalries and imperialist alliances of the European Union and the bourgeoisie, rejecting the poison of nationalism, expressing their solidarity with the suffering Turkish people.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: - Thank you Madam Chairman, and thank you also to Kati Piri for the report. It has been said by many, but I think that the suspension of negotiations is no longer taboo for a very large majority of this House is a big step forward. Because the situation in Turkey is simply not positive and is going in the wrong direction in many areas. Nevertheless, the report still sets some conditions and ifs and buts before that suspension can possibly be implemented and I personally think there are already reasons to consider such a suspension. I will give you one example, because my speaking time is limited. And that is the way Turkey has been dealing with its minorities, such as Arameans, for a long time. Before the genocide of 1915 - and I use the word very consciously - there were one million Aramean Christians in the region, 40 years ago 70,000 in Eastern Turkey. And now only 3,000: 20,000 in Istanbul, but 3,000 in the east, de facto in a village or seven-eight. And it is precisely in that region that Turkey has recently confiscated 50 churches. I will close, Madam Chairman. But with that, Turkey appears to be pursuing the strategy of systematically bullying Christians away. I ask the Commission to raise this explicitly in any case.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: - Madam President, human rights are systematically violated in Turkey. Many thousands of citizens have lost their jobs or been imprisoned without any substantial evidence against them. The recent referendum and the resulting constitutional changes undermine the democratic functioning and the principle of separation of powers. Turkey causes, on a daily basis, violations of Greek airspace and territorial waters. Also of concern is the lack of respect for world heritage sites, such as Hagia Sophia. Yesterday, Mr. Çavuşoğlu said, while efforts are being made to resolve the Cyprus issue, that Turkey wants to keep the occupying army in order to have the right to intervene. Mr Çavuşoğlu probably wants to forget that Cyprus is a member of the European Union. I am glad that the referendum is a response to the aggression of Turkey and the Erdoğan government and at the same time a message of support to the suffering Turkish people, to the democratic citizens, who, like the rest of the people in the region, want to live in peace and prosperity.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: - Madam President! When we stand here today and look back at the developments that have taken place in Turkey, it is quite clear that Erdogan has very wisely used the negotiations on EU membership as a means of weakening the Kemalist institutions in Turkey. almost a hundred years managed to make Turkey one of the most prosperous, free and democratic Muslim countries in the world. When we stand here and look back, we must at the same time note that the Turkey we see today is heading in the completely wrong direction. Mass arrests, killings, torture, murders, public sector dismissals have become commonplace in a country that is in a state of permanent emergency and where a constitutional reform has just been implemented that is anything but democratic. Therefore, the time has come for us to not just freeze, but to end the accession negotiations with Turkey. Turkey has never been and will never be a country suitable for membership of the European Union.

name: Nedzhmi ALI
text: – Madam President, concerning the 2016 report on Turkey, we can underline several developments which play a significant role in EU—Turkey relations: the coup attempt, the measures taken under the state of emergency, the delayed process of EU accession negotiations and the outcome of the referendum at the beginning of 2017. Despite making conditions for a formal suspension of the negotiation process, the report invites the Commission, the Member States and Turkey to hold an open and honest dialogue and discussion on all areas of mutual interest. Several important issues for the reinvigoration of the accession process could be underlined. There are areas in which both sides are interested in continuing to work: counter—terrorism, migration, energy, the economy and trade. Due to the geopolitical challenges, it is necessary for the EU and Turkey to undertake measures for closer cooperation and coordination of their foreign policy activities; a structured and more frequent high-level dialogue on key thematic issues should be supported as well. In order to enhance relations in the future, we should continue to work closely on the upgrading of the customs union, visa liberalisation, the continuation of the EU’s long-term sustainment of refugees in Turkey. Stronger cooperation between Europol and Turkish law enforcement agencies is of the utmost importance.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: - Madam President! When my friend Selahattin Demirtaş was arrested, everyone in the house said: Opposition is not a crime. When more and more journalists were arrested in Turkey, we said: journalism, including critical journalism, is not a crime. Today we finally have to say that working in a school or teaching at a university that belongs to the so-called Gülen movement is not a crime. And I think that the European Parliament must absolutely reject the idea of ​​collective guilt and the collective persecution that is now affecting the people who are included in the Gülen movement. We have therefore tabled an amendment on this. As a German member of the European Parliament, this is of particular concern to me, because my country has brought this evil experience to Europe, which has shown what it is when such collective persecution occurs. I believe that we have to ensure that there are no extraditions - only on the grounds that someone belongs to the Gülen movement. I believe that the European Court of Human Rights will finally have pilot proceedings ... (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: - Madam President! An exciting debate about Turkey's accession to the EU. The CDU - Ms. Sommer - spoke and said: These are sham negotiations, they cannot lead to accession, we must finally draw conclusions from our speeches, and drawing the consequences means: suspending negotiations, not breaking off. Mr. Fleckenstein for the SPD is of course only for the suspension of the negotiations, and not because of the referendum in Turkey for the Islamic dictatorship, but only when this referendum is implemented. The exciting question, Count Lambsdorff, remains: What are you going to do? Because you said: “Let's make the dialogue honest. Yes to dialogue and no to accession. ”I did not hear“ break off negotiations ”. But you have a chance tomorrow to sort that out. My amendment is number 2. It is a roll-call vote and you can agree to break off negotiations there so that we can see that you really mean it.

name: Georg MAYER
text: - Madam President! And the marmot greets you every day here in the house. It is, I think, the third or fourth time since I was here in this house that we have dealt with this subject. I'll say one thing very clearly: Turkey is simply not a European state, Turkey is simply not a democratic state. Because we know that Erdoğan has been ruling this country by means of emergency decrees since July 2016. Erdoğan is even planning - quite openly, without further ado and without trying to cover it up - to introduce the death penalty. How can it then be assumed in this report that this Turkish administration could still be brought up to European standards? How can it be that this Turkey still enjoys accession status? It is a candidate country to join this club, the European Union, which is occupying part of this country or part of a member state in Cyprus with military means. And this country still has accession status! In five years, EUR 4.4 billion in pre-accession aid will be paid to Turkey. I ask myself: what is being introduced to whom? What actually happens to this tax money? We are paying six billion euros for this supposedly good refugee deal. What will happen to this European tax money? And the question remains for me: Who is still pursuing this membership status so massively? There must be very influential circles who want to see this Turkey as part of the Union. Count Lambsdorff said it today: freeze the accession negotiations. What does that mean? That means nothing else than that what I freeze can be thawed again. We don't want to defrost anything. Turkey can no longer have membership status, it must be ended. On the other hand, that does not mean that we want to prevent any dialogue with Turkey. No, just the opposite! But it has to be clear - and be honest: there can be no membership status for give this to Turkey in the European Union.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! So the report reads like an indictment, and I do not understand in this House why there is still a need to debate accession to the EU and not want to close the doors. What still has to be done with Turkey? We all know that the Turks are Orientals. You are just not European. And in the Orient people have different ideas about gender politics, human rights, animal welfare and religion than we Europeans. So I find it a bit presumptuous, Ms. Sommer, when you express the arrogance of the house here and literally say that we could finally have explained to the population what is good for their country and what is not good. Do you want to tell them what to do? Do you think the Turks are all stupid? No, let's stay out of domestic political interference and let's say clearly to the Turks: They have no business in Europe, they should withdraw their troops from Cyprus and accept the sovereignty rights of their neighboring states! What they do in Turkey is none of our business.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: – Mr President, alarming reports are reaching us from the Syriac Assyrians of Tur Abdin in South-East Turkey. They are asking the world to listen to their plight. Their churches, monasteries and cemeteries have been confiscated by the state. Before today’s debate, Kuryakos Ergun, director of the Mor Gabriel Monastery Foundation, sent me the following statement, and I quote: ‘While the Turkish Government should protect our roots and our religion, it is instead threatening our existence by grabbing our holy buildings and making us believe that Christianity no longer has a place in Turkey.’ The European Union must act on behalf of the Syriac Assyrians of Tur Abdin and return to them what is rightfully theirs. If Turkey fails to do so, the EU should not freeze negotiations of EU membership but rather consider closing them indefinitely.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: - Mr President, the question should be: 'what kind of Europe do we really want to have'? Unfortunately, we do not learn from our tragic mistakes. "Do we want a Europe whose policies are based on principles and values ​​or a Europe whose policies are based solely on economic interests?" It is at least hypocritical but also destructive to talk about the upgrading of the Turkey-European Union relationship at a time when we see Turkey's unacceptable behavior and the Commission pretending that nothing is happening. I know very well that when you make a deal, both parties should win and you should get in return. Did we ensure the withdrawal of the occupying troops from a Member State of the European Union? Did we ensure the return of the refugees and the verification of the fate of the missing in Cyprus? Have we ensured the creation of conditions of democracy in Turkey itself where those who think differently are imprisoned? None of this has been guaranteed, instead there are discounts that offend European ideals and the peoples of Europe. Let's stop rewarding Erdoğan's logic and let Europe invest in the prospect of a democratic Turkey.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: - Mr President, you all know how anti-democratic Turkey is, ladies and gentlemen. However, the European Union supports an anti-democratic solution to the Cyprus problem, which violates its principles and values ​​and the Charter of Human Rights, by constantly giving an alibi to Turkey; because only such a solution is accepted by Turkey for the Cyprus problem. Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, would you accept a racist state system with citizens without human and political rights? Do you accept that European freedoms should be given to Turkish citizens especially for Cyprus? And then, why not for the whole Union? Do you accept Cyprus to become a province of Turkey? Do you accept guarantees from foreign countries in a Member State of the European Union? Do you accept a solution incompatible with the European acquis and the Charter of Human Rights? Do you agree that Ankara controls the attitude of Cyprus in the European Union through the veto of the settlers? Do you accept that 18% of the population controls 82%? If you accept, the Cypriot people will not accept. Do not be surprised by a new thunderous "no" to an anti-democratic plan. And then the European Union will not be without responsibilities.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: - Mr President, it has been thirty years since Turkey applied for membership of the European Union and twelve years since the accession process began. When will the European Union end this masquerade which dishonors Europe as much as it humiliates the Turkish people? Should we insist again and again that, by virtue of its geography, its culture, its religion, its language and its history, Turkey cannot claim to be European? It is not an insult to say it, it is a fact that Brussels refuses to admit. In wanting to turn Hagia Sophia into a mosque, Turkish President Erdoğan is posing as heir to the Ottoman Empire, an empire whose armed conquests have seriously endangered our European and Christian civilization. Remember Lepanto and Vienna. At a time when the provocations and meetings of Mr. Erdoğan, even in this city of Strasbourg, arouse only weak protests on the part of the European Union, at a time when the Christian communities are expropriated in Turkey, At a time when political parties affiliated with Turkish power are emerging in the Netherlands, Bulgaria, Germany, Austria and even France, finally have the courage to put a definitive end to these absurd negotiations.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, I wonder how lethargic the Union, which is still politically flirting with Erdoğan's Turkey, is. Right-wing, neoliberal and left-wing internationalists are forgetting centuries of Turkish atrocities, with expansionist wars, destruction of cultural monuments, violent Islamizations, child masses, slave markets and genocides of Christians, Pontians, Armenians and Assyrians. Some dream of a western Turkey and talk to the Islamist Erdoğan, who supports ISIS, trades in Christians, Yazidis and Syrian Shiites, trades in smuggled oil, drugs and stolen archaeological treasures. It imposes Islamic terrorism, with pogroms of persecution and imprisonment of political opponents, journalists, the judiciary and the military. You may miss Erdoğan's statements about the Dutch, that they are Nazis and fascists. Of course, I do not look forward to supporting policies of slander and hypocrisy, nor do I expect Northwestern Europeans to understand me. But Greeks and Greek Cypriots know very well what a Turk is. I personally do not intend to become anyone's rage, neither European nor Turkish.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: - Mr. President, Commissioner, the long-term state of emergency in Turkey has negatively affected fundamental human rights and freedoms, the rights of religious and ethnic minorities, freedom of religion, freedom of association and peaceful protest, and the recent referendum on constitutional change and eventual implementation. in the form in which it is proposed may jeopardize the separation of powers and the principles of verification and balance. All of the above are key elements not only for the successful continuation of negotiations for membership in the European Union, but also for a sincere partnership with the European Union, based on sound foundations and mutual trust. However, this debate, as well as tomorrow's adoption of the resolution, is not aimed at severing ties and cooperation with Turkey, but aims to help find solutions and models in achieving Turkey's transformation into a democratic, inclusive and tolerant society high level with the European Union in key areas of common interest, namely the fight against terrorism, migration and security.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: - Mr President, first of all what I would like to do is congratulate and acknowledge the work that the rapporteur - for another year - Kati Piri, has done on this report on Turkey and send four messages, four ideas. One: it is clear that Turkey is living turbulent years, very turbulent times, from the terrible coup d'état to the continuity in the decline of democratic rights in the country to the consolidation of that democratic decline in a very polarizing referendum on an extreme situation; two: the European Parliament sends this message with this report: the European Union must reconsider the way in which it cooperates with Turkey, mainly because we need a more influential, more influential way; three: we closely follow what is happening in the country: the march for justice, the will, from unity, of a good part of the freedom opposition, to demand freedom for prisoners and freedom for politicians; and four: the time is now, with a very high-level dialogue between the European Commission and Turkey that must forge a new relationship of cooperation and dialogue, but putting aside, once and for all, "business as usual".

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Hahn, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Piri's report is critical, which means that it is largely good. This is the first time such critical words have been heard in this Chamber, and they have a reason. There is a small irony in the fact that I have been repeating these words in this room for three years and they have finally started to be heard. Anyway, better late than never. The fact is, the things listed in the report are true: Turkey is not a democracy at the moment, Erdogan's Turkey. Erdogan is violating human rights, violating the rights of journalists, supporting Islamic State in Syria and Iraq, fighting illegally in those territories, and let me add - not only that. Erdogan intervenes through fake parties in a number of EU member states, including my homeland Bulgaria. These things must end. This cannot continue. This Turkey - Erdogan's Turkey - continues to occupy Cyprus and hold a 30,000-strong occupation army, and to prevent the rapprochement and reunification of Cyprus by not wanting to withdraw its troops. So, ladies and gentlemen, it is good to be aware of these things as soon as possible - better. It is good to forget about political correctness and to say things as they are.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Mr. President, for a week now the President of the Republic of Cyprus, President of a European country, a member of the European Union, has been fighting for everything, the battle against the Great Wall of Turkish intransigence, to rid a member state of the European Union of occupying troops, from unacceptable guarantees, to rid its place of occupation. In this endeavor, we believe that the support we need from the European Union, from the European Parliament, is of paramount importance. I call on all of you to mobilize to rid the territory of the European Union of the occupying troops, in order to curb Turkish intransigence. Until yesterday, Mr. Çavuşoğlu stressed in a provocative, unacceptable and offensive way for the European Union itself that the Turkish army will continue to remain in Cyprus. It is time to send, Mr Commissioner Hahn, a clear and strong message that the European Union cannot accept occupying forces, that there can be no guarantees in a European Union member state and that the four fundamental freedoms cannot be exercised. I find it unacceptable to discuss upgrading the customs union - essentially a reward for Turkey for everything it does inside and for what it does in Cyprus - when this customs union does not implement and does not implement it. It is unacceptable, Mr President, to say that we continue to provide accession assistance to Turkey, when it commits all these crimes against Cyprus.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - The repression by the Erdogan regime, which has been aggravated since the failed coup d'état in 2016, violates the Copenhagen criteria across the board. The European Union must draw consequences and cannot continue illegal and immoral businesses that use refugees as a bargaining chip. The amendments to the Turkish constitution, voted in a manipulated referendum, violate the principle of the separation of powers. Countless reports of human rights violations come to us, not only from recognized organizations, but from desperate citizens who write to us directly, disappearances, compulsory dismissals, confiscation of property without a legal basis, media censorship, political prisoners, torture, threats of reintroduction the death penalty. The European Union must, of course, continue to dialogue and relate to Turkey, its neighbor, including to end the division of Cyprus, but above all it has to direct support to Turkish civil society that is fighting repression. There are no conditions for us to continue Turkey's accession process to the European Union at this time. That is why I support the proposal to formally suspend negotiations, with hope, and I wish Turkey to reverse the disastrous trajectory on which it was embarked by Erdogan's greed for power.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - For a year now, more than 150,000 people have been expelled from office in Turkey, more than 60,000 people have been arrested in Turkey, including judges, teachers, human rights activists, lawyers, businessmen. Their businesses are confiscated. Turkey is no longer a democratic state, it is an autocratic state, it is a dictatorship in which only Erdogan sets the rules and Turkey is the Turkish people who are in prison today. They were fired - the Turkish intellectuals, as they say in Turkey, are all in prison. They are victims, they are being tortured. We must all take action against this. There is no question that we do not care about what is happening in Turkey, yes, we do care. I would also like to say that the threat to the million immigrants they would release in Europe is false. I hope no one believes that anymore. Erdogan will never do that, because he will use them to vote for him, give them citizenship and use them in the fight against the Kurds. And last but not least, in January of this year, he set up a special commission of inquiry to look into complaints lodged with the ECHR. So it practically blocks the complaints filed with the ECHR of the victims. Over 120 complaints, none resolved to date.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, I think it is necessary to tell the Turkish side that we do not agree with what is happening in their country. We should tell them in person and, as a member of the EU-Turkey delegation, I am not satisfied that we do not have the opportunity to visit Turkey and exchange information with our colleagues and tell them our views. It is not possible to count on Turkey as a candidate country for accession to the EU, this is heard from all sides. That is why the European Parliament's report calls for the suspension of accession negotiations and pre-accession assistance. I have never been in favor of full membership, but I saw this possibility as an approach to dialogue, to reforms on the Turkish side. And I believe that our report should also call for a new partnership with the European Union. This should be a signal to those who have not come to terms with the current situation in Turkey, to those who have gone to peaceful protests today, such as the justice march from Ankara to Istanbul.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: - Mister President!Thank you, Kati Piri!Yawning emptiness on beautiful beaches, bazaars in which hardly any visitors get lost, hotels that make offers with which they cannot earn money - yesterday evening on television.Turkey pays the price for moving further and further away from Europe and European values.For years we stretched out our hands, and the other side showed the fist more and more often.Ladies and gentlemen, think about it for a moment: Would we invite a country that has imprisoned journalists, judges, teachers and members of the opposition, that has practically suspended the rule of law, to come to us?But we have to keep talking, because Turkey's geostrategic location is too important, and a good half of the population rejects the government's current course.But negotiate about joining the EU?Certainly not under these conditions!

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! The Turkish constitutional referendum ended with a tight yes - a very tight yes. Many of us have certainly got the feeling that things may not have turned out right. But can we prove it? Ladies and gentlemen, yes, we can now prove it. Because a few days ago a scientific study appeared in a refereed specialist journal that made exactly this kind of statistical analysis of the election results, which shows that manipulation took place here. This shows a noticeable cluster of electoral districts that have a voter turnout of almost 100 percent and at the same time have shown far above-average yes results. So here it was statistically proven - with an error probability of less than one per thousand - that it cannot be a coincidence that the ballot boxes have obviously been crammed with yes votes. Ladies and gentlemen, we have the smoking gun in hand. We have seen it, we can prove it: the constitutional referendum in Turkey has been manipulated. Unfortunately, that comment is missing from the report we are about to adopt tomorrow.

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: - Mr President, I am reading you an excerpt from a book: "But now, after the assassination attempt, it was obvious that not only the newspaper, my profession, my freedom, but also my life was in danger. Five years and ten months in prison for leaking state secrets. The court returned my passport the same day. Did he imply "get away from this country"? I would like to address all of you: Support the struggle for survival given by the democratic forces of Turkey! "Europe can embrace the Islamic world's only secular democracy and defeat the growing Islamophobia." These are the words of Can Dündar, former editor-in-chief of Cumhuriyet, now a resident of Berlin. And I clearly remember his words at an event we held in the European Parliament: "Do not stop Turkey's accession process. Do not make the best gift to Erdoğan ". Kati Piri rightly links the accession process with the criteria of the Venice Commission. Let us use them not as an opportunity to close the door, but to convince ourselves that it is open, if and when, of course, Turkey accepts that the rule of law is non-negotiable.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: - This Turkey report is jet black. But we knew this was coming. How many times have I here warned against the authoritarian course of this regime and said: "This Turkey does not belong in the European Union, the means of accession may no longer go to Erdogan." EUR 640 million next year. Money Erdogan invests in rubber bullets to shoot gay pride, in ink to sign the arrest warrants for teachers and journalists, in bullies that are reducing Kurdish villages to rubble. How do we explain to our citizens that the minus on their pay slip is the plus on Erdogan's bank account? The delay in the Union to stop accession negotiations and funding plays into Erdogan's hands. More than 200 journalists in jail. Thousands of academics, judges and civil servants have been expelled. Schools and universities closed ... Are we really still not convinced that this course is at odds with all EU principles? Democracy is a difficult ghost from the past for Erdogan, which he tries to scare away with brute force and our money. Choose credibility and principles now and stop!

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: - Mr President, I will speak in a language the Presidency will understand without translation. I would like to say that, indeed, it is high time we clearly acknowledged that, in the view of all of us, Turkey is moving towards a totalitarian dictatorship, a situation that is very well known to both the Germans and to us from the Soviet Union. Close your eyes and say that maybe things will get better is no longer justified in any way. Kati Pir's report is very true in this sense, but we must also realize that the people we need to support are the real people who are suffering today. We must give special support to those Turkish citizens who have now been able to leave, who have fled Turkey and who are waiting for our support here, too, in order to establish and make their voices heard here and their testimonies of what is really going on in Turkey. I very much hope that our democratic media, whose mouths are not closed, and our own Parliament, which is able to discuss these matters in public, will provide this opportunity for us to hold a hearing (either with AFET and LIBE or in some other way) to: to get a real and objective overview of what is really going on in Turkey, what is happening with these trials, what is happening with the Turkish media and how we can move forward with Turkey in such a way that we do not lose dialogue but do not pretend that nothing is happening.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the 2016 report on Turkey is being discussed at a time when Turkish Foreign Minister Çavuşoğlu is provocatively declaring in Geneva that Turkey will never withdraw Turkish occupation troops from Cyprus. At the same time, Turkey continues to illegally occupy 37% of the territory of the Republic of Cyprus, as well as the threats within the Cypriot EEZ. The report on Turkey is being discussed at a time when Ankara is maintaining the casus belli against Greece, at a time when Turkey is violating Greek airspace and the maritime territorial waters of my homeland, at a time when Turkey is desecrating Hagia Sophia. The report is being discussed at a time when Turkey is violating human rights and imprisoning thousands of dissidents, while Turkey is killing Kurds, invading Syria and Iraq and supporting ISIS. It is therefore necessary, Mr President, for the immediate cessation of accession negotiations with Turkey and the imposition of sanctions on Erdoğan, because only then will he realize what he must do in the future.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I have taken the floor to also support the report that is being presented today and that we will be voting on tomorrow. I'm also glad that it's factual, critical, that it doesn't try to repaint reality in pink. I think that the debate here has made it clear that an absolute majority of Members perceive that Turkey is moving away from the values ​​of Europe, from the values ​​of democracy, the rule of law, the protection of freedom, the people, the press, political competitors, and I think it has really happened. time for the European Commission to make it clear that negotiations with Turkey are not just freezing but stopping. I think that our citizens want to hear that we will not pretend in the future, that the process of bringing Turkey closer to the European Union continues, and that there is some chance that Turkey will join the European Union. The citizens want to hear the truth, and it is that Turkey has chosen a different path. Nevertheless, we must work with and communicate with Turkey. But on a basis other than a false attempt to make Turkey a member of the European Union.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with the political choices made in the last year, Turkey is moving away from accession to the European Union. The support for the reintroduction of the death penalty, repeatedly declared by the Turkish president, the disproportionate measures taken following the declaration of a state of emergency, which have affected dissidents and opposition political parties, the serious violations of freedom of the media, the the unconstitutional lifting of immunity of a large number of deputies, the arrest and dismissal of over 4 000 judges and prosecutors, the lack of respect for religious freedom lead us to the conclusion that the rule of law is called into question in Turkey. However, the European Union and Turkey continue to have common interests in many areas - the fight against terrorism and the migration crisis in the first place - and cooperation in these areas is an important investment in stability and security. Dialogue and collaboration in these areas must continue, but on condition that commitments on fundamental rights and freedoms are respected.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr President, as many speakers have already mentioned, the situation in terms of freedom, democracy and the rule of law in Turkey is getting worse, and it is hard to watch. I want to draw your attention specifically to the situation of Christians. Even though the Turkish Government claims to have freedom of religion, on the contrary they have confiscated many churches and monasteries. Just recently they confiscated the buildings of Tur Abdin, giving them to the Turkish religious authority which takes care of mosques. I call upon the Commission to protest against this and to urge the Turkish state to give these buildings back immediately. A country which does not respect its ethnic and religious minorities, and does not respect human dignity and freedom, has no place in the European Union. Commissioner, I have to say you admitted that democracy and the rule of law in Turkey have been violated. These things are in the Copenhagen criteria. I therefore call upon you immediately to break off the EU accession talks with Turkey.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: - Mr President, we welcome the calls in the report to Turkey to start withdrawing the occupying army from Cyprus, to support the CMP work, to end the settlement policy, to implement Resolution 550 on Famagusta and the supplementary protocol, as well as to contribute constructively to the solution of the Cyprus problem, on the basis of the bi-zonal bi-communal federation with one sovereignty, one citizenship and one international personality. However, we expect active support and call on the European Union to put pressure now, at the moment of the talks in Switzerland, so that Turkey can contribute constructively and substantially to the solution of the Cyprus problem, to contribute to a fully demilitarized Cyprus and to end the anachronistic system of guarantees. With regard to the opening of negotiations for the upgrading of the customs union, these negotiations can only begin when Turkey fully implements all the obligations arising from the current customs union with the Union, including the recognition of the Republic of Cyprus. Our position is clear: Turkey's accession process goes through the democratization of the country itself but also the implementation of its Cypriot obligations.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - I also join those colleagues who emphasize that the report is critical enough to reveal the path that Turkey is embarking on, and that it must also be a serious reminder to the European Parliament and the European Union that we have a so-called partner on the other.it does not meet those standards that are expected of a democratic society.Over the last year, the situation in Turkey has changed dramatically in many areas and cannot, of course, be the pride of democracy.That is why I do not think that the European Parliament can be silent on this either.Colleagues before me have already talked about so-called political prisoners, persecuted journalists, closed groups, even fired teachers, in fact as if it were a purge, to take full power, which can be a dangerous example for the wider region.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: - Mr President, the mere fact that we are again discussing accession negotiations with Turkey is funny. This country is hostile to Greece and Cyprus, two member states of the Union. Violations occur daily on the Greek-Turkish border, while the illegal occupation of part of Cyprus by Turkey continues. At the same time, European countries continue to have relations with Turkey, promoting their own interests. Turkey is an extortionist and terrorist state and an immediate threat to anyone who does not serve its interests. Turkey understands only one language, the language of the fist. Stop the negotiations, stop the benefits and immediately impose sanctions that should not be lifted until Turkey lifts the casus belli against Greece and until the last Turkish soldier leaves Cyprus. Then and only then will we be able to reconsider if we want and can trust Turkey enough to have some trade relations perhaps, but in no case accession. The Sultan's state has no place in Europe.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, during the Arab springs, Turkey was pointed out as an example of compatibility between Islam and democracy. However, the failed coup d'état of 2016 gave President Erdogan the pretext to eliminate the strongholds of this secularism and democratic institutions and, under a state of emergency that still exists today, to dismiss more than 130 thousand people and send to public officials, journalists, judges, military and opposition politicians. The tangential victory in the April referendum this year, the only thing he did was to institutionalize the transformation of the Turkish parliamentary system into an authoritarian presidential regime, where the Head of State accumulates executive functions, being able to govern by decree, dissolve Parliament and appoint the majority. members of the High Council of Judges and Prosecutors. Dear Colleagues, we have not seen an authoritarian drift so marked by disrespect for human rights and the values ​​of freedom and the rule of law in Europe for many decades. This drift and the new Constitution are contrary to the Copenhagen criteria and, therefore, without prejudice to the need for constructive dialogue, Turkey's accession negotiations with the European Union must be suspended and pre-accession funds channeled to the support of society. and improving the situation of the three million refugees in this country.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: - Mr President, this report lists most of Turkey's commitments to the European Union, including the Additional Protocol on the Recognition of the Republic of Cyprus, as stated by the European Council. However, we must ask ourselves why the policy we have pursued so far has failed. This is a question we need to answer. And a fact: if a neo-sultan regime has indeed prevailed in Turkey, the prediction is that every day that passes with this regime in power, the human costs that will be paid for years by the people inside and the people outside Turkey will increase. And a few words about Cyprus. Talks are now taking place in Geneva with a focus on security issues. This issue primarily concerns the European Union. Turkey can not demand an invasion right and the stay of occupation troops in Cyprus. This concerns us all here in Europe.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - The Turkish state sees the Kurds as a potential enemy. It does so despite the fact that there were promising negotiations between the parties in the period before that. But as there has been scope for tougher action, under the guise of retaliatory measures after the coup attempt, there is a systematic attack on the Kurds in the country. States often make the mistake of not trying to integrate national minorities living on their territory, but of rejecting them, not acknowledging their historical contribution to nation-building, but shouting at the enemies of the state and trying by all means to push them to the margins of society. However, both sides will emerge from this fight as losers. Dialogue, openness and acceptance of each other's views are needed. The current Turkish-Kurdish relationship is very, very far from this, and hopefully the parties will not cause irreversible damage to each other before they realize the need for this dialogue.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, on behalf of Turkish nationals and minorities who live in my North-West England constituency, and also those who live oppressed in Turkey, I would like to say thank you to my colleagues for their work on this file. I would also like to draw attention to the destruction of cultural heritage in the ancient Mesopotamian town of Hasankeyf, where historical sites and artefacts are being destroyed and removed to make way for a new dam. This is a Kurdish-majority and, historically, an Armenian area along the Tigris River. The Dutch company Bresser is helping the Turkish government remove and relocate historic monuments and take apart ancient tombs on a site whose history goes back 12 000 years. This must stop, and we must let Bresser and the Turkish authorities know that. I ask the High Representative and the Commission to call out to the Turkish authorities on this and make a clear statement that the destruction and removal must end.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, from the beginning of my term I had pointed out that the policy of tolerance towards Turkey would exacerbate the problems. Today's harshly critical progress report, although it took a long time, confirms this. After the coup, the situation got out of control and Turkey is now exporting its internal problems. The report rightly points out violations of Europe's maritime and air borders, casus belli with a Member State and threats to the EEZ. However, he did not manage to include the direct threats of the Turkish Foreign Minister for the action of the occupying army in Cyprus. Nevertheless, and while Parliament has repeatedly taken a clear position, the Council seems to despise reality. I therefore wonder, Commissioner, what else the progress report should include and what else should happen in order to immediately suspend the accession negotiations.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is an objective contradiction that we must be able to resolve in order not to appear inconsistent between the things we say and those we practice.The report denounces the violations of the Turkish state in the field of human rights and on the basis of this justifies the suspension of the accession negotiations, but at the same time calls for the deepening of trade relations without particular conditions.I must say that this seems a bit bizarre to me, because we should be aware that trade policy is a powerful lever for pushing democratic processes and the enlargement of rights forward.I wonder if, by doing so, we are not actually rendering our pressure weapons ineffective and, perhaps for fear of the resumption of the migration process, we are politically surrendering ourselves to Erdoğan.We will certainly not make progress in the Turkish regime.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank everyone who spoke today. Listening to the very strong, clear and converging points made in this House today, I think we are all equally concerned that Turkey is moving further away from the European Union and not closer. That is the reality we have to face. I believe that the best way to strengthen Turkey’s democracy is by remaining engaged with it and keeping channels open. We must continue to promote the values on which our Union is based. This is all the more evident when it comes to a strategic partner. The ball is now in Ankara’s court. It must clearly and tangibly move back towards these values and principles, and we stand ready to support it completely. We are ready to do this on many levels, ranging from high-level political dialogues to protection of human-rights defenders in Turkey’s civil society and continued investment in the roots of a future open society, from economic support to education, research and free media. In short, we must continue our principled, firm engagement with Turkey and support the positive currents in Turkish society, and I expect that we will continue the discussion here in the House to follow up on the events in Turkey and to stay in contact and in touch with them. As some speakers today pointed out, we have to keep in mind that there is a huge part of Turkish society which is very much interested in the European perspective.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank Members for this very rich and very timely exchange of views that demonstrates that we, the Parliament and the Council, share deep concerns with regard to Turkey. As I pointed out earlier, the Council is well aware of existing shortcomings, especially in the field of the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms. Several ideas were floated about how the European Parliament can help in this respect, not least by Marju Lauristin, on the ways of giving voice to those people who have to flee Turkey. This work must be continued. At the same time, it is are important to remember that the EU and Turkey have many ties. Our relations go back a long time. We have had – and are having – close cooperation in many areas, cooperation that has been positive for both parties. We continue to follow developments in Turkey very closely. We will continue to bring up our concerns in all our meetings and at all levels with Turkey. The EU should remain the anchor for Turkey’s political and economic reforms. That is where the continuing expectation of the standards that Turkey must fulfil comes in: continuing expectation enshrined in the Presidency’s conclusions from the General Affairs Council last December. The standards are there for all EU candidate and aspirant countries. If anyone says that we should give up on the expectations that those standards are being met, we may wonder whether this sends the right signal. Foreign policy is a very complex domain, but even there, some things are relatively easy – leaving the chair open, walking away, pulling the plug, if you will. It is so much more difficult and tiresome to engage patiently, with the aim of transforming your partner. That is what the EU’s foreign policy is doing in its relation with Turkey, and that is why continued engagement in the accession process with Turkey remains vital.

name: Kati PIRI
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I am grateful to all the colleagues who have contributed to this debate. As I said at the start of the debate, I would like especially to give a warm thank you to the shadow rapporteurs who were also here during the whole debate, because we worked in the third year consecutively towards a very constructive text. I would also especially like to thank colleagues from the extreme right for being here in the debate, because their presence and their contempt for this report shows clearly that the agreement reached by the other Groups is not based on Islamophobia. It is not based on any hate towards the Turkish population and I am proud that you will vote against this report as I absolutely do not share your racist positions. Allow me to welcome here a former colleague, Joost Lagendijk, who is sitting here with us. For many years, he chaired the Turkish Joint Parliamentary Committee. After having lived in Turkey for the past nine years, he has not been allowed to return to the country where he has been living. We hope he can go back soon and join his wife, Nevin, in Istanbul.  When it comes to the Presidency of the Council, thank you for also participating in this debate. We hope that curtailing migration is not the new priority of the European Union with EU candidate countries. Please allow me to draw your attention to the fact that we also call on the EU Member States in the report to start the resettlement of the most vulnerable refugees from Turkey as we agreed. I very much hope under your presidency we will see more progress on that.  Finally, Commissioner Hahn, we know you are on your way to the airport. We wish you a good stay in Turkey. We look forward to continuing our cooperation and hope that the EU will be more confident in the coming months to stand up for its own values while maintaining an open, constructive dialogue with Turkey. As a final remark, because many colleagues raised the issue, we know the talks on Cyprus are ongoing and we all hope that there will be a viable long-lasting settlement reached.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 6 July 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: in writing. - This year's report on Turkey essentially records the country's serious setback on its path to the European family. 2016 was a difficult year for Turkey as a result of the war in Syria, the influx of hundreds of thousands of refugees, a series of brutal terrorist attacks and the failed coup attempt last July. However, President Erdogan's reaction once again surprised Europe. The measures taken after the coup were illegal. Serious events followed, such as the shutdown of many media outlets, the arbitrary arrest of thousands of citizens, journalists, judges and human rights defenders, the closure of schools and universities that are not in line with Western culture, the violation of human rights and the questioning of the state. At the same time, the threatened implementation of the constitutional reforms by the Turkish government does not comply with the criteria for EU membership. Turkey will have to decide whether it really wants to continue the accession negotiations and stop undermining its accession prospects with talks to restore death penalty. In addition, international law, the sovereign rights and the territorial integrity of Greece and Cyprus, which has been repeatedly and deliberately challenged by escalating violations and provocations, must finally be fully respected.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item on the agenda is the report by Eduard Kukan, Doru-Claudian Frunzulica and Eider Gardiazabal Rubial, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, the Committee on Development and the Committee on Budgets, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Fund for Sustainable Development (EFSD)and on the establishment of the EFSD Guarantee and the EFSD Guarantee Fund (COM (2016) 0586 - C8-0377 / 2016 - 2016/0281 (COD)) (A8-0170 / 2017).

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, let me start by thanking the co-rapporteurs, the Council and the Maltese Presidency, as well as the Commission, for their very good cooperation during the preparation of this report. The European Fund for Sustainable Development (EFSD) is a milestone in our approach to development and migration. We have been struggling to find the right answers to challenges coming from our neighbourhood and Africa, from countries affected by extreme poverty, conflict, under-development ... (Interruption)

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Minister Maasikas, please can you respect our MEPs?

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, please take note of the time that elapsed since I had to stop my speech.  We have found ourselves under external pressure from migration flows driven by geopolitical and economic factors. The consequences are deeply felt on a day-to-day basis in many European countries. However, they are only a fraction of the discontent felt in many countries beyond our borders.  Facing mounting tragedies in countries thrown into conflict or extreme poverty, our responsibility is to act, to address the root causes of this situation and to help to create the conditions for a better life in these countries. It is clear that this will not happen from one day to the next, not even after a year. Therefore we need to look for long—term sustainable solutions, solutions which would bring growth, more stability, more jobs opportunities and solutions that would help societies to develop and adapt to the current world. There is no magic spell to solve the problems of the developing world, just as there is no magic spell to safeguard Europe from the increasing pressures of migration. We will be constantly challenged, yet we need to try new approaches and propose new solutions.  I therefore welcome the proposal for the External Investment Plan proposed last year by the Commission. With this framework, we can promote sustainable investment and tackle some of the root causes of migration in Africa and the neighbourhood. The European Fund for Sustainable Development is a vital part of this plan. It provides guarantees in order to stimulate private sector involvement in the socio-economic development of the partner countries.   I think this is the right approach in the long term. We need to match our development and investment expertise to enable the EU and the private sector to cooperate. We need an instrument which will operate in high-risk situations where investment would not be possible without our guarantees. This opens new challenges to boost investments and improve the business climate in the most fragile countries. In order to do this we need to stimulate investment in such areas as socio-economic infrastructure, SMEs or microfinance.  Once again, I am glad that we are ready to make this Fund a reality.  It will be a vital instrument to stimulate development in our partner countries and an important tool in our external policies. I hope that its innovative approach will help to improve living conditions in countries where it is needed and address the root causes of migration in the long term.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, as you know, on 14 September 2016, the Commission tabled a proposal for establishing a new European Fund for Sustainable Development (EFSD) aimed at mobilising up to EUR 44 billion of investment in Africa and the EU neighbourhood. The EFSD is the first pillar of the external investment plan under which the Commission also plans to enhance technical assistance in partner countries (pillar 2) and to work towards improving the investment climate and overall policy environment in those countries (pillar 3). The main assumption is that supporting investment and private-sector involvement through innovative financing can foster sustainable and inclusive economic and social development and address the root causes of the migration crisis and promote the resilience of the partner countries in Africa and the EU neighbourhood, including in the least developed countries, with a particular focus on growth, the creation of decent jobs, youth and women, socio-economic sectors and, of course, small and medium-sized enterprises. A final package agreement was approved by COREPER last Wednesday. The progressive points we managed to include in the EFSD text are the following: reference to development effectiveness, resilience, decent job creation, the aim of poverty eradication and Articles 21 of the Treaty on European Union and 208 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union in the purpose of the instrument; and the implementation of the Paris Agreement and the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development as objectives. On compliance in respect of tax standards and transparency, we managed to achieve major progress. We have ensured that counterparts are prohibited from entering into operations with entities incorporated or established in jurisdictions listed under the 11th EU policy on non-cooperative jurisdictions, or identified as high-risk third countries or countries that do not comply with the EU and internationally agreed tax standards on transparency and exchange of information. There is a reference, as well, to the relevant EU policy on non-cooperative jurisdictions for tax purposes and specific reporting by the Commission. We now have greater transparency in relation to financial support provided by EFSD with an obligation for the Commission and counterparts to make information on projects, beneficiaries and expected development benefits publicly available wherever possible. The participation of the European Parliament in the strategic board as observers is warranted. We made a reference to the principles of development effectiveness and the conformity of objectives with the eligibility criteria for use of the EFSD; fulfilment of the OECD Development Assistance Committee (DAC) criteria for the projects funded; and safeguard clauses on human and labour rights, including full observance of the UN principles for responsible investment, the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, the OECD guidelines for multinational enterprises, the UN-FAO Principles for Responsible Investment in Agriculture and Food Systems, and all ILO Conventions, as well as international humanitarian law. We insisted on having a particular focus on climate-friendly investments, thus contributing to implementing the Paris Agreement, and setting a binding minimum target of 28 investments for climate action, renewable energy and resource efficiency. There are more things that I would like to highlight but, because of time constraints and last but not least, I would like warmly to thank the Commission negotiating team and the Maltese Presidency for their good cooperation, enabling us to agree on this new, innovative and important instrument of EU development policy.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: speaker. - Mr President, Commissioner, so far this year almost 100 000 people have reached the European shores who have had to leave their countries, their homes, their families. This morning, 49 have died trying to reach the Spanish coast. Because the greatest tragedy is not that they arrive, the greatest tragedy is that they lose their lives in the attempt. Today we are debating in this plenary session the launch of the European Fund for Sustainable Development, a fund that, unfortunately, is not going to totally eradicate the reasons why these people are forced to emigrate, but which intends to invest in their countries of origin to achieve sustainable development, to give them the opportunity to live in their country and have a decent life project. The causes of migration are many and complex, but the most important factors are security, economic, environmental and social factors. The objective of this fund is precisely to attack these causes at the root, by investing in projects that contribute to meeting the sustainable development objectives. Because this fund has to be a complement to official development aid, it has to pursue the same objectives, but it cannot and should not be a substitute. Because what we want is to mobilize private investment up to 44 billion, using the European budget as a guarantee, developing innovative mechanisms and thus reducing the uncertainties of investors. Getting the private sector involved in the economic and social development of these countries is a strategic objective. And this fund is not going to act alone - we have already mentioned it here -, it is part of the Foreign Investment Plan that has a technical assistance component to help partner countries attract that investment, private capital, and help prepare and promote projects. likely to benefit from this fund. And it also has a third pillar, fundamental for achieve the objectives, which is based on political dialogue, with the aim of developing a legal framework, policies and institutions that promote the necessary stability. This political dialogue ranges from the fight against corruption, tax fraud, organized crime, to the promotion of entrepreneurship, the development of local markets or an inclusive gender policy. This Parliament, with its proposals and during the negotiations, has sought and managed to improve the definition and realization of the objectives. In this way, we wanted to place special emphasis on financing projects that have a real impact and that focus on the creation of employment in decent conditions; to follow a strategy of sustainable and inclusive growth, and with special attention to the empowerment of women and youth. As I said at the beginning, migration has multiple causes, and one of them, to which we often do not pay the attention it deserves, is migration due to environmental causes. And, in this sense, I believe that the agreements that Parliament and the Council have reached allow us to allocate more resources to the fight against climate change, to renewable energies and to the efficiency of energy resources. Finally, I would like to highlight the very important step that we have taken in the fight against tax fraud, against tax evasion, against money laundering, as well as the elimination of any type of relationship with non-cooperative jurisdictions. And here I would like to especially thank the European Commission for its determination to put the fight against tax fraud as a priority, for promoting greater controls, country-by-country reporting and improving accountability. From Parliament, and I know that from the European Commission and from the Council, we have worked against the clock to be able to launch this fund as soon as possible and make it operational with a view to the Association Summits Eastern and the European Union-Africa.I hope that this fund is the first step in a renewed commitment by the Union to the development of our neighboring countries.We cannot allow thousands of people to continue leaving their homes due to lack of opportunities, risking their lives, dying at sea or in the desert, because the European Union has not done everything in our power.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the European Parliament, and notably the three committee Chairs and rapporteurs, for their extraordinary engagement and excellent cooperation over the past months on this file. In spite of its complexity, a compromise was reached. This is a success and I congratulate us all for that. I also thank the Council, and in particular the Maltese and Slovak Presidencies, for their efforts to reach the agreement on the European Fund for Sustainable Development, which delivers on the request of the European Council to do so in the first semester of 2017. Our ambition must now be to quickly start the implementation of the external investment plan with a view to present tangible progress to the EU-Africa summit in Abidjan and to the Eastern Partnership Summit, both of them in November. Let me underline that the External Investment Plan with its European Fund for Sustainable Development will become an important instrument for attaining the objectives of the UN 2030 Agenda and will complete our toolbox for development cooperation. This is primarily a development instrument rather than exclusively a banking or financial one. It will steer our development partnership with the private sector in a focused and effective manner in order to contribute to reaching development goals in partner countries. The plan builds on experience. Since 2007 we have been implementing eight investment facilities which have leveraged a total investment volume of EUR 57.3 billion in our partner countries, with a total of EUR 3.4 billion of EU grants. To a large extent, this cooperation has been successful, as confirmed by the recent external evaluation on lending. The external investment plan is taking lessons learned into account. Let me reiterate the substance of the plan. It provides a holistic framework to improve investment and therefore decent job creation in Africa and the EU neighbourhood. It has three pillars: financing, technical support and enhanced investment climate. These must work hand in hand, and we are serious when we say that via the guarantees of the fund and existing investment facilities we want to leverage more than EUR 44 billion of investments in Africa and the neighbourhood until 2020. Our ambition for the European Fund for Sustainable Development is to go beyond existing instruments by supporting innovative financing models developed by partner financial institutions and an enhanced engagement of the private sector, in particular through the innovative new guarantee and the European Fund for Sustainable Development. Let me emphasise that the concept of additionality is very important. For us, it is really important. We do not intend to guarantee investments that the private sector would have made anyway. Under the European Fund for Sustainable Development, our partners must be able to prove that this is not the case by bringing in new products, new ideas, investments sustainably and where they otherwise would not go. We will also be coherent with the international fight against tax avoidance by making sure that financial vehicles supported under the instrument are not benefiting from any location in non-cooperative tax jurisdictions. All this will be implemented in a transparent and accessible way through comprehensive reporting requirements to the European Parliament and the public and through a new web portal managed by the Commission, and the European Parliament will have observer status on the strategic board. The board’s tasks will be to provide strategic guidance on overall investment goals and to ensure external policy coherence. This will give the European Parliament the opportunity to participate in the steering and monitoring of the overall implementation strategies and objectives of the European Fund for Sustainable Development. Therefore I am very much looking forward to a fruitful cooperation in this regard, also in the years to come.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mister President! I would like to congratulate on this big step because we are getting closer to our goal of setting incentives locally, in developing countries and above all in our neighboring countries, so that employment is created and that people get confidence in the future. We have made available a total of 350 million from the European budget, with 400 million from the European Development Fund. We then have the guarantees and the mixed financing with 2.6 billion, and then we actually trust that the private sector will accept these incentives accordingly. We know that, especially in developing countries, we have to make sure that the focus here is on rural areas, because of course the influx of people into the big cities and slums creates additional problems and we should therefore focus on incentives in rural areas . Your colleague has already said that, of course, small and medium-sized companies from the European Union and companies in our neighborhoods and in the least developed countries must have a chance to work together in the future - the main focus here should be on renewable energy . We have tied down this 28 percent financing share for climate change, so that we can set up digital markets there, that training and further education are established and that above all the sanitary conditions with water and sewage - especially in hospitals - are improved that the focus here is also on the social component. But in the end there must of course also be investment contracts, because most of it is made up of guarantees and the real equity - the cash - plays a very minor role. That is why the Commission is asked to manage these projects as well as possible.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, many people have talked about this being a first for the Parliament because three committees worked on a codecision file for the first time. So congratulations to our three co—rapporteurs. Not only have they delivered, but they have delivered in record time: in just four months. Special thanks also go to Marlene Bonnici, the Ambassador from Malta, who pushed this through, and our staff, who worked very hard. They know who they are and they deserve our special thanks. But we don’t need it to be speedy just for institutional reasons to get it done under a certain Presidency. We need it because we promised this kind of thing in Addis Ababa two years ago. We promised that aid would be one part of the picture for funding development, and that we would also have private sector leverage and more tax revenues going in to help fund. I want to make this link with Addis Ababa to remind people that this is not an instrument to tackle migration except in as much as the instrument is to tackle poverty at its roots, create jobs and bring investment. It is not about managing flows into Europe. Most of the money comes from the European Development Fund, so it is right that the fund should focus on the least developed countries and fragile states. When the plans come forward, I hope we will see the funding in those domains. It is also timely because we have the G20 this weekend, the high-level political forum in a couple of weeks in New York and we’ve got the Africa summit coming up. A lot of people are talking about a Marshall Plan for Africa. I am not very good at maths, but I worked out that Germany got USD 15 billion of aid in today’s money in the late 1940s; about EUR 267 per person. If we do the same thing in Sub-Saharan Africa, that is about USD 66 billion today. So the European Fund for Sustainable Development can be part of the beginning of a new plan for Africa. It is part of the picture. We need to make sure it is spent properly and that it leaves in the aid that we have promised.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the European Fund for Sustainable Development  (EFSD) is the flagship policy of the EU’s external investment plan, launched last year in response partly to the migration crisis. High population growth across Africa without the employment opportunities to match is a growing problem, likely to be made worse by the effects of climate change as time goes on. Fragile states with weak public institutions, limited track records in the rule of law, and challenges to democracies are particularly affected and are naturally a deterrent to the necessary private investment required to generate jobs. The EFSD and the EFSD Guarantee are seeking to try and plug that gap by the European Union and aims at aiding and leveraging investment from private business and institutions. It is projected that EUR 3.5 billion of EU investment could generate as much as EUR 88 billion of total investment. The EFSD will also seek to provide technical assistance to governments in the region in order to mobilise further investment. It is something that I fully support.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, the only lasting solution to curbing uncontrolled migration in the long term is to improve living conditions and create jobs in the countries of origin. That is why the EU is now setting up a Sustainable Development Fund, and one of the key objectives of this fund is to improve living conditions and achieve sustainable growth in the EU's neighborhood, especially in countries of origin and transit - creating jobs, livelihoods and hope. The purpose of the fund is therefore to support investment in Africa and in the EU's neighborhood. The fund does not provide direct financial support, but supports private sector investment, including loan guarantees. Once this decision has been taken, implementation must also be carried out as a matter of urgency. I am particularly satisfied that Parliament was driven to this new regulation objective, so that would be used for 28 per cent of investments in such destinations to promote actions against climate change. These measures are important for the stability of Europe and the world, and it is precisely through these measures that we are preventing the development of climate change that we are specifically addressing these root causes of emigration and immigration.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, I am going to be quite critical of this Fund, because this European Fund is called "Sustainable Development", but it neither seeks cooperation for development nor the sustainability of this development. It seems again propaganda of the European Union to clean its image in the face of the disastrous management of the border crisis. When people say that you have to act at source in the face of immigration forced by war, hunger or climate change, they are certainly not referring to this type of funds. What this Fund seeks is to alleviate consciences and for the border states to act as a wall for this forced immigration, a style that, unfortunately, the Spanish Popular Party has already invented on the southern border with Morocco. To do this, the European Union is resorting to the same bad magic trick: a fund in the style of "Juncker plan" that will cover possible losses from private investments, but which, in this case, will be losses of European multinationals doing business in countries of the world. south. Development cooperation does not consist in safeguarding our backs so that other countries act as guardians of our borders; It is not a question of seeing what financial ruse we use to make a good deal of these investments. The European Fund for Sustainable Development should serve to enable egalitarian development, help local actors, rather than transnational ones, and put resources for endogenous social and sustainable development. Conditioning the cooperation policy on the control of migratory flows is Machiavellian. Cooperation and migration policy must be separated; otherwise, we are not cooperating, we are profiting.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I think we have created an innovative development instrument, and a lot depends on the implementation and on the safeguards that have been put in this instrument. We need to make sure that we indeed measure development outcomes already before funding decisions have been made, and we must make sure that we have the best expertise, which should be brought through the other elements of the external investment plan, such as technical assistance and political dialogue. I believe that this is a unique contribution to financing for development commitments. Let us make this a real innovative development instrument.

name: Raymond FINCH
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the disinterested observer can immediately see several problems with the EU’s plans for the EFSD. Firstly, these funds appear to be nothing more or less than a means of using taxpayers’ money to expand the EU’s regional hegemony. The two regional platforms, one for Africa and one for what is ominously termed the ‘EU Neighborhood’, offer for the purported recipients nothing more than serfdom. The funds come with strings attached, which means there will be strategic boards imposed upon the clients, with Commission and EIB representation. This means, as always with EU largesse, that those who are supposed to benefit have their hands tied and are reduced in their own nations to the role of supplicant. This is surely wrong from the start.  The second major issue one can immediately spot is that citizens’ money is expected to leverage private investments, essentially throwing taxpayers’ money down a well. Please stop treating other people’s money with such contempt.

name: Maurice PONGA
text: - Mr President, less than a year after the European Commission proposal to create the European Fund for Sustainable Development (EDFD), this new instrument will enter into force.
