I am happy that we were able to find a compromise in such a short time with the Commission and the Council on this new instrument, the main objective of which is to help the private sector in African and Eastern Neighborhood countries, by supporting the employment, growth and stability, which I am sure will help tackle the root causes of irregular migration. The text on which we are going to vote tomorrow is a good text. The role of the European Parliament has been strengthened, which will allow better control of the Fund. The "development" dimension has also been strengthened, but in a smart way, in order to make the instrument flexible and adapted to the specificities of the private sector. Finally, our European financial institutions will participate in the FEDD, and a Community preference will be achieved while respecting the principle of fair treatment. Thanks to this instrument, we hope to be able to mobilize up to 44 billion in investments. The stakes for developing Africa and the countries of the Eastern Neighborhood are considerable, and the private sector has an important role to play. It is therefore crucial that this sector is mobilized and that the Member States support and accompany the EDF, in order to make it an instrument for sustainable development.

name: Soraya POST
text: – Mr President, the European Fund for Sustainable Development (EFSD) is for development. A wide array of actors can apply for economic support, but money is never an answer in itself to secure development. In the work of formulating the framework of the EFSD, we have been persistent in securing transparency, a clear gender focus and also a complaints mechanism at the Commission’s webpage. I have also been very determined in having explicit references to human rights and also to Article 21 of the Treaty on European Union. Let me please remind you about Article 21: the Union’s action on the international scene shall be guided by the following principles: ‘democracy, the rule of law, the universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms, respect for human dignity, the principles of equality and solidarity, and respect for the principles of the United Nations Charter and international law’. All these are crucial elements if the EFSD is to become successful in addressing the root cause of the migration crisis and promoting resilient societies. I have to be frank, migration is not a problem. People should be able to move freely between places and regions if they wish and like. But it becomes a problem when the conditions in the one region are so bad that people are forced to move due to the impossibility to lead a good life. This is why it should be ensured that the EFSD enhances respect for and the fulfilment of human rights. Civil society is instrumental in monitoring the human rights record. I call on civil society to use the complaint mechanism and to let us know when there are faults and how to improve the work of securing human rights for sustainable development.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: - Mr President, I welcome the agreement on the European Development Fund and I congratulate our rapporteurs on it. This fund aims to support, in the long term, the economic and social development of African countries and the eastern neighborhood in order to fight against the causes of the migratory crisis that we have been experiencing for more than two years, in particular illegal economic emigration. If this new fund is added to the galaxy of instruments revolving around the European budget, I dare to hope that the Commission, under the control of Parliament, will be able to ensure its coherence, transparency and efficiency and will be able to ensure that partner financial institutions faithfully serve our rules and our political objectives, especially in the fight against tax havens. For this fund to be successful, it is therefore essential that it is part of a clear vision and political strategy. I am counting a lot on the High Representative, Mrs Mogherini, as well as on Commissioners Hahn and Mimica to formulate this vision and carry this strategy. It is not enough to equip ourselves with an additional instrument: the time has come to express an ambition and to construct a discourse that speaks to European citizens, citizens who call with their wishes for a Europe that protects them.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: - Mr President, the innovative and open European Sustainable Development Fund, by mobilizing EUR 44 billion for Africa and the countries in the eastern neighborhood, will enable the beneficiary territories to have more economic growth, more jobs and stability. It is also essential, when approving projects and platforms, to ensure geographical and thematic diversification. This geographical diversification should also allow, at the same time, to ensure the reduction of poverty and the promotion of human rights. Small projects and small and medium-sized enterprises must be cherished. We are not always aware that the European Union is the largest donor in the world. But we also have to promote entrepreneurship, well-being and financial independence of peoples at the same time. Sustainable projects should allow the creation of jobs and, in particular, youth employment. This fund, with respect for additionality, must be used in complementarity with other financial instruments and also with the European Development Fund. The European Commission should support the so-called second pillar and should support the development of investment platforms. Transparency in management, transparency in approval and then also in the monitoring and execution of projects is also essential. This is an imperative that cannot be overlooked. On the other hand, Parliament must remain associated with this important fund and be informed about the approval of platforms and projects.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the extension of the so-called Juncker Plan to developing countries responds to a very specific need: there can be no integration and security without a real commitment to stabilize the most unstable and most troubled areas of the world.To do this, however, it is essential to set clear and precise limits: no European collaboration should support or finance regimes that do not respect human rights and minorities or in general lack minimum democratic standards.This is an important plan, but it is a plan that will have an effect in the future, in the near future.But in the immediate future, for the present and for the current migratory situation we are experiencing, the only possible response from Europe is the solidarity of the Member States towards Italy and Greece, which are now experiencing unsustainable situations.

name: Nedzhmi ALI
text: –Mr President, the European Fund for Sustainable Development (EFSD) as a new financial instrument should mobilise more than EUR 40 billion of investment in the states of Africa and the European neighbourhood. It will create growth and employment, deliver innovative products and involve private sector funds. The European Parliament on several occasions has expressed its position, stressing the need to strengthen the link between migration and development policies. By keeping poverty eradication as a main priority, it is necessary to involve the private sector in this effort. For the successful implementation of EFSD, several conditions should be taken into account. Regarding the nature of the blended finance, financial institutions and private entities should respect EU commitments toward full transparency and accountability, guaranteeing a balanced geographical approach in order to allow potential beneficiaries to have access to funding, providing information and guidance for investors in the development activities as well as assessment of the quality of operations. Finally, I would like to underline the importance of the external investment plan to the implementation of the new partnership framework. The security dimensions of the plan are unconditional.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we approve an important instrument, the European Fund for Sustainable Development, with the awareness that its implementation will need to be carefully monitored, in a manner that this Parliament has wanted to put pen to paper, and for this I thank colleagues which contributed to ensuring our priorities in the text. Public resources and development aid will remain essential, but they are not sufficient to unleash the enormous potential in Africa and other neighboring countries and to meet the goals of the sustainable development agenda for 2030. The purpose of the Fund must be to contribute to fight against poverty and inequality and to create opportunities for young Africans. We will ensure that it does not pursue the council's nefarious policies to outsource borders and build walls in Africa. Projects must be rigorously chosen, they must bring true additionality, and the benefits must go to local populations and small businesses, not large multinationals. It is crucial to have in place safeguards on the fight against tax evasion and avoidance and the principles of corporate social responsibility. We will therefore be vigilant and expect transparency from the Commission.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! I thank and congratulate all my colleagues for the good work they have done and for the fact that the European Fund for Sustainable Development bears the signature of the European Parliament. The following three points should be particularly emphasized. First: The United Nations' sustainability goals for 2030 must be visible as the most important criterion in all projects and policy areas and be identified as a reference. Second: The Paris Agreement must be supported and implemented by Europe - especially after Trump's termination - as the most important goal more than ever. I therefore welcome our commitment to use at least 28% of investments in combating climate change, renewable energies and sustainable resources. And third, the projects that contribute to employment must fully respect workers' rights. This includes both compliance with the ILO core labor standards and the anchoring of the OECD guidelines for multinational companies in the partnership agreements. I will work to ensure that these points are adhered to.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: - Mr President, by approving this instrument we not only mobilized around € 44 billion to create job opportunities in many countries in Africa and our neighborhood, but, above all, we sent out a signal: the signal that the Union Europe has changed its way of seeing problems, it has changed its behavior. It is not just about responding to the consequences of emigration, or refugees, or poverty in Africa; It tries to attack the causes that promote this exodus, that impoverish those countries and that, in turn, make our border management difficult. But what it is about is to put opportunities in investments that maintain official development aid, that are consistent with climate change and the 2030 Agenda, that fight against tax havens and that, finally, provide opportunities for less developed countries that avoid having to emigrate or have to escape as a result of conflicts.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: - I strongly support the establishment of the 44 billion European Fund for Sustainable Development for Africa, which aims to improve the situation on this continent. We know that Africa is a continent with high poverty, a continent that lacks basic infrastructure, lacks economic infrastructure, and on the other hand, a continent where there is a huge amount of war conflicts, corruption. It is therefore right to focus these funds on development projects that will create new jobs, while also paying attention to the state of the environment, because environmental problems are also increasing in Africa with the growing population. After all, we are solving the key problem we are facing today in the right way, which is migration flows. If we do not start solving this problem at source, we will not be successful in this process. And the fact that Africa will double in population by 2050 is a clear sign that there will always be a lot of pressure if the situation in Africa is not better than it is today.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: - There is no doubt that the decision on the European Sustainable Development Fund is important for the whole of Europe.It is important for our ambition to expand and strengthen the area of security and stability around the European Union.I hope that this report will be approved by a large majority of Members of the European Parliament.I want to emphasize that this fund must contribute to the goals of sustainable development, stability and the promotion of private capital investment, not only in Africa but also in our eastern neighborhood.It is vital that the potential of this fund is maximized in the European Union's Eastern Neighborhood, the Eastern Partnership countries and, in particular, Ukraine, as the future of the whole of Europe depends significantly on the stability and economic sustainability of the Eastern Neighborhood.

name: Claude TURMES
text: - Mr President, I want to thank President Juncker and especially his Commissioner for International Cooperation and Development, Mr Mimica, for what I consider to be one of the best initiatives this Commission has taken. It has been three or four years that I have been fighting alongside Jean-Louis Borloo, former French Minister of Ecology, to organize a future for young people in Africa. Poverty is linked to the fact that there is no electricity in the villages. When there is no electricity in the villages, people migrate to the capital and its slums, and if they cannot find a future there, they pay mafia and risk their lives to come to Europe. Therefore, the only way to fight these floods of migrants and their desperation is to bring solar power to Africa. The good news is that solar is quite cheap for that purpose. This instrument will allow us to offer African countries reduced capital costs and institutional dialogue to help them put in place the national laws necessary to attract investors. As a result, well done also to all the colleagues who have accelerated this process!

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, the proposed financial support for Africa and third countries in Europe's neighborhood is based on the wrong basis. It is immoral to direct money to third countries based on the saying "money can not buy happiness, but it can make misery more enjoyable". It is absurd to provoke illegal immigration by seeking cheap labor and solving Europe's demographic problem, while blaming the countries of origin for failing to keep their citizens. It is costly to channel European taxpayers' money into these countries effortlessly in advance and hope to reduce migration flows, human rights violations and human trafficking. Dealing with the ongoing economic crisis in the countries of southern Europe is paramount, unless you consider these people to be third-class citizens.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Fund for Sustainable Development complements the European External Investment Plan and will provide financing in the form of grants, guarantees and other financial instruments for Africa and the Union's neighborhood. It will serve to address the migratory pressures resulting from poverty, conflict, instability, underdevelopment, inequality, human rights violations. However, a careful monitoring phase must be carried out: if the objective is to mobilize investments up to 44 billion euros, a non-formal monitoring is needed, but aimed at the quality of the investments, both in terms of performance and sustainability. I welcome the simplification granted to this Fund by two regional investment platforms, one for Africa and the other for neighborhood policy countries, which will act as a one-stop shop for receiving proposals from financial institutions and investors. However, it will be necessary to give the right transparency, making available to the public the information relating to all the financing and investment operations covered by the Fund guarantee.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Honourable Members, thank you for these encouraging words and the support of the European Parliament in this file. Let me emphasise that the Commission will really regularly report to Parliament about the implementation of the plan. The Commission will take its responsibilities and ensure that the Regulation is respected in all its aspects, such as ensuring additionality, poverty alleviation, more and better and decent jobs for young people and for women, policy coherence for development and value for money.  Let me conclude by underlining that I am very much looking forward to fruitful cooperation under this instrument. Now the real work starts with the implementation of the regulation, setting up the secretariat, preparing and defining the investments windows. I am now waiting impatiently to continue the excellent work with the European Parliament and to invite Parliament’s representatives to the first strategic board meeting. Thank you very much for the attention and your cooperation.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, I would like to thank my colleagues for their interest, but especially for the majority support for this fund. I'm not sure if some of those who criticized him were really familiar with him. We have before us an important financial and foreign policy instrument to help the sustainable development and growth of countries, which are often the main causes of migration. I know that the fund, regardless of its large financial source, will not solve all the problems, but it can certainly help to create the conditions for their gradual solution. We are talking about the involvement of the private sector in order to get investments that will help create jobs and job opportunities. I am also pleased that we have been able to agree with the Maltese Presidency on many issues that we have created an instrument that should complement existing foreign policy financial instruments. The fund will be managed by the European Commission, which will guarantee greater scrutiny by the European Parliament. I would like to say a fundamental sentence that I am convinced that we have managed to reach a good agreement. It needs to be implemented. That is why I would like to thank my colleagues, the rapporteurs, the Commission, the Slovak, Maltese and Estonian Presidencies once again for their cooperation. Thank you very much.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to mention and address some issues that have been raised by our colleagues in this Chamber. In fact, we have a clause in the report that the guarantee shall not be used to replace government responsibility for providing essential public services. The Commission now has the obligation to provide information to Parliament prior to the setting up of investment windows. There is an obligation on the Commission to publish on its website direct references to the complaints mechanism of the relevant counterparts, and the possibility of directly receiving complaints related to the treatment of grievances by eligible counterparts, as well as the clearly defined geographic scope – Africa and the EU Neighbourhood – which can be modified only by amending the EFSD Regulation. We also managed to improve the focus on addressing the root causes of migration by placing it more clearly in the context of fostering sustainable and inclusive economic and social development. The EFSD is addressed at, and is going to focus on, growth, the creation of decent jobs, poverty eradication, youth and women, socio-economic sectors, including small and medium-sized enterprises. Last but not least, I would like to thank the two other co-rapporteurs and the chairs and coordinators of the three committees. This is the first EP report to have three co-rapporteurs – with three committees involved – and I can tell you that it was a success. I am also looking forward to tomorrow, when the House is going to vote for this very important European Union instrument which will also promote our values in Africa and in our Eastern Neighbourhood.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: speaker. - Mr President, Commissioner, as you have seen, there has been great support for the agreement we have reached with the Commission and the Council and I hope that this great support will materialize tomorrow in the vote. Now, as you said, touch the real world and turn it on. If you have listened carefully to the debate, many of the MEPs have drawn your attention to those commitments that we have reached with the Commission, that accountability, that coordination that the Commission must have with Parliament, the explanation of the investment windows; but a lot of emphasis has also been placed - and I stressed this in my first speech - on the fight against tax fraud and on non-cooperation with tax havens. So we strongly hope that, as the Commissioner said, they follow the Rules of Procedure and, above all, Article 15, which refers to these accounts reports that they have to deliver to the European Parliament, and Article 20, in which we talk about taxation. And I would simply like to end, of course, by thanking my co-rapporteurs, because they have been a pleasure working with them. It is true that it has been difficult to coordinate three commissions, but I think we have achieved it in record time. Of course, the European Commission - it has played a key role in the negotiations - and the Council - especially the Maltese Presidency, which has been leading these negotiations -; also to the shadow rapporteurs, to the chairmen of the committees ... we have all contributed and worked as a team and I believe that the result of the negotiations has been good because we have managed to work in that team, and, obviously, if it still fits, more than ever, to the secretariats of the three commissions and the three political groups. As I said, working three commissions has been extremely complicated. It has been a very delicate regulation and, if it is not for your work detailed, we would not have been able to reach this agreement in that record time of four months.Now we have to start it and we hope that we will see the fruits soon.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I am also happy to extend thanks to the three rapporteurs and I feel the genuinely positive atmosphere among you, so thank you. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 6 July 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: in writing.- We have been repeating in this Chamber for a long time how important it is to solve the problem of migration by acting to improve the situation in the countries of origin of migrants.I believe that the establishment of the European Fund for Sustainable Development is a very concrete translation of these words into action.I believe that stimulating investment in Africa and neighboring countries can make a real contribution to job creation and economic recovery, and thus reduce the number of economic migrants coming to Europe.However, we must remember that the Fund for Sustainable Development is one of the three pillars of the European External Investment Plan and it is extremely important to put equal emphasis on the next two pillars, in particular measures to improve the investment climate and the general political environment, and to fight corruption.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: in writing. - The proposed European Fund for Sustainable Development aims to mobilize investments worth EUR 44 billion in Africa, as well as in the southern and eastern neighborhood. The money would come from regional investment platforms, and investments would be made in cooperation with financial institutions such as the EIB, the EBRD, as well as international, regional and national development banks. This is an extremely important undertaking as the most effective way to deal with problems such as instability and migration is to support the economic development of the countries of origin of potential refugees and to provide them with decent living conditions. During the negotiations on the proposal under discussion today, some funding concerns have been resolved, including that Member States will not be required to make additional contributions to the budget. The regulation is scheduled to be adopted ahead of the EU-Africa Summit and the Eastern Partnership Summit later this year and, if it enters into force, will be an important impetus to economic growth, wealth creation and stability for developing countries.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the joint debate on – the report by Seb Dance, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on EU action for sustainability (2017/2009(INI)) (A8—0239/2017), and – the Council and Commission statements on the High-Level Political Forum on Sustainable Development (2017/2715(RSP)).

name: Seb DANCE
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, let me begin by thanking the shadow rapporteurs in the other groups for their excellent work and cooperation throughout this process. And may I please also pay particular tribute to Emily Stewart in my office whose work on this has been exemplary and without whom I would not be able to be standing here and present this report to this House? I’m also extremely grateful to the committees that put their input into this report, namely the Development Committee, the Agriculture Committee and the Cultural Committee. But I am very disappointed that there were not more committees contributing to this process, because we have had many MEPs put forward their expertise, but we need a full breadth of committees involved in this process, because a key ask of this report is that the Commission use all of its departments and instil the UN sustainable development goals throughout all of the Commission’s departments. And unless we practise that in this Parliament, it will be difficult to act as the exemplar for others. Imagine if you will, a world where no child is born into hunger, where no child is born into poverty, where access to health care and clean water – some of the things you might take for granted – are available to everyone, where well-paid jobs, decent jobs, don’t come at the expense of the environment, and where we all act together as stewards, not owners, of this planet, and that we can forward it to the next generation. This doesn’t just have to be a pipe dream, and it certainly doesn’t have to be the preserve of one group in this House. This goal is something we as humans must all own and make a reality. The goals defined through the UN’s 17 sustainable development goals will achieve this if we put the necessary measures into practice. I am very grateful to the Commission for its initial assessment of progress, again but I have to be perfectly honest, it is not enough to look at existing work and then backfit it into the 17 UN sustainable development goals. We have to be honest with ourselves, not just about the scale of our ambition, but the scale of the task at hand. When we conduct our trade, when we develop shared energy networks, when we draw up financing rules, when we draw up strategies for transportation, when we evaluate education, when we drive forward change at a local, city, regional, national and European level we must always ask ourselves: ‘are we doing enough and is what we are doing delivering the UN’s sustainable development goals?’ We and our generation are running out of excuses, and we don’t have the excuse of previous generations of ignorance. We know how our actions today will affect the world around us tomorrow. There is a school group up there! Hello, it is your future we’re discussing today, and the decisions that we take in this place and across all of the EU’s institutions will have ramifications. It is great news that Vice-President Timmermans will chair the multi-stakeholder forum, but it is essential that the Commission use this forum properly to learn from other actors, to share best practice and to report back to this Parliament. We didn’t get everything through that we wanted to in this report and I’m sure we will hear from others about some of the compromises that don’t go far enough, and that is a fair criticism. But we must use this infrastructure to have a proper discussion; a proper discussion across all layers of government and hold the Commission to account on its promises, but also have the Commission report to us. I ask each and every group in this House to have somebody on their Bureau responsible for delivering this, because the world needs leadership. Mr Commissioner, when you go to the UN in New York, we want you to take the views of this House forward, because it is time for the EU to step up and show that leadership.

name: Seb DANCE
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the EU was leading the international community when we shaped, negotiated and adopted the transformative, comprehensive, universal 2030 Agenda. The EU must now also demonstrate strong leadership in the implementation of the Agenda, both at home, at the EU Member State level, and in the context of the high-level political forum on sustainable development.  The Council conclusions adopted in June, ahead of the fifth session of the forum this month, stress our full commitment to the 2030 Agenda and the importance that the EU and its Member States attach to driving forward its implementation. Eradicating poverty in all its forms and dimensions is an indispensable requirement for sustainable development, which must be achieved in all its dimensions in a balanced and integrated manner. There can be no doubt about our commitment to achieving the 17 sustainable development goals by 2030, ensuring that no one is left behind and seeking to reach the furthest behind first. No doubt, we must promote social inclusion, with special attention to those who are disadvantaged, vulnerable and marginalised. Like the European Parliament, the Council continues to stress the need for the Commission to demonstrate that it takes the implementation of the 2030 Agenda seriously. We call on the Commission to elaborate an implementation strategy, outlining timelines, objectives and concrete measures to reflect the 2030 Agenda in all the relevant EU internal and external policies, taking into account the global impact of the EU’s domestic actions. This strategy should be based on a clear vision of how all relevant EU policies will contribute to the realisation of the 2030 Agenda.  There is an urgent need to identify gaps in all relevant policy areas within the EU to assess what more needs to be done by 2030 in terms of EU policy legislation and governance structure for horizontal coherence and means of implementation.  Even though much remains to be done in terms of concrete action, the Council of 20 June welcomed the steps proposed and taken by the Commission with regard to the implementation of the 2030 Agenda and the sustainable development goal. On 7 June, the Council, represented by the Maltese Presidency, along with the European Parliament and the Commission, co-signed a new European consensus on development, which sets out our shared vision and framework for action for development cooperation. The new consensus aligns the Union’s development policy with the 2030 Agenda. This will be our main deliverable when we attended the high level political forum in New York in a few days. The Estonian mission to the United Nations has invited Ms Linda McAvan, chairwoman of the Committee on Development, as a speaker at one of the side events.  We, the EU institutions and Member States alike, should be proud of this achievement. It is our new ambitious collective European development policy, and it addresses in an integrated manner the main focus points of the 2030 Agenda: people, planet, prosperity, peace and partnership.  This year’s theme at the Forum is at the heart of our new consensus –eradicating poverty and promoting prosperity in a changing world. Indeed, poverty eradication remains the primary objective of our development policy. At the same time, it integrates the economic, social and environmental dimensions of sustainable development and underlines the links between development and other policies, including peace and security, humanitarian aid, migration, the environment and climate change.  The new consensus also reaffirms our commitment to a rules-based global order with multilateralism and the United Nations at its core. Given the strong link with climate action, through the new consensus we are also giving a timely political signal to reaffirm our strong commitment to implement the Paris Agreement.  The EU Member States consider the High Level Forum as the main forum for sustainable development issues within the UN framework and are committed to progress towards implementation of the sustainable development goals. After the four EU pioneers, including my own country Estonia, which were among the first 22 countries to present voluntary national reviews last year, this year 10 out of 44 reports will be presented by EU Member States.  The European Parliament’s report on sustainability goals, adopted in May 2016, shows broad convergence with Council views on how to advance this ambitious agenda through effective implementation and we are looking forward to cooperating with you on this topic to ensure that, together, we reach our goals by 2030.

name: Seb DANCE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by thanking Mr Dance for his excellent work as rapporteur. The Agenda 2030 declaration itself acknowledges the essential role of Parliament through their enactment of legislation and adoption of budgets and their role in ensuring accountability for the effective implementation of the Agenda 2030 commitments. So this report is very welcome, and we appreciate the high level of interest that it has raised as a signal of Parliament’s own commitment to engage in implementation and the review of progress. The United Nations 2030 Agenda, adopted unanimously by world leaders in 2015, represents a new global sustainable development framework. It is a commitment to eradicate poverty and achieve sustainable development by 2030 worldwide, ensuring that no one is left behind. The EU has been instrumental in shaping the 2030 Agenda and it is also committed to remain a frontrunner in the implementation phase. Sustainable development is a shared responsibility. It implies leadership from the Commission and other EU institutions, but also the full engagement of Member States and all levels of government at national, regional and local level and of civil society. I therefore welcome the opportunity here today to react to the European Parliament’s own initiative report in response to the Commission communication ‘Next Steps for a Sustainable European Future’ presented in November last year. From the perspective of my own portfolio, I am pleased to see in the report several strong references to how the environment and natural resources underpin the achievement of the broader sustainability agenda. I also welcome the references to the 7th Environment Action Programme, whose objectives map well on to the sustainable development goals (SDG). Indeed, it is crucial to ensure the full coherence between the different policies and ensure that the EU’s priorities as highlighted by President Juncker integrate our international commitments. I will ensure that the current 7th Environmental Action Plan evaluation will look at its consistency with our priorities and sustainable development goals commitments to pave the way for the period post 2020. The Commission’s communication of November highlights key EU policies for each of the 17 SDGs, particularly in the context of the 10 priorities of this Commission, and also outlines what further steps are envisaged. The response to the 2030 Agenda includes two work streams. Firstly, to mainstream the sustainable development goals in the European policy framework and Commission priorities, sustainable development becoming a guiding principle for all our policies. We are using our better regulation tools for this purpose. Secondly, further developing our longer-term vision and the focus of sectoral policies after 2020. In addition to that, we have said in our communication that the new Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) beyond 2020 will reorient the EU budget contributions towards the achievement of the EU’s long-term objectives. Stakeholder involvement will be crucial in implementation of the 2030 Agenda. The Commission will therefore launch a multi-stakeholder platform chaired by the First Vice-President, Frans Timmermans, with a role in the follow-up and exchange of best practices on SDG implementation across sectors. The input of the platform will be very important for developing our vision for the future of SDG implementation through the second work stream. We need to have a good dialog with the European Parliament, the Council and the Member States in the second stream process as well. We are currently reflecting on how to best organise this. The successful implementation of the SDGs requires consistent monitoring. As requested by this House, the Commission will, from this year, provide regular reporting of the EU’s progress on the implementation of the 2030 Agenda based on a reference indicator framework. Stakeholders have been consulted on the choice of these indicators. A periodic report is expected to be published in November this year. Initiatives, supported by the Commission for the next month, include a non-toxic environment strategy, an ambitious plastics strategy and a comprehensive review of water legislation. The report recognises that economic growth will only be possible by respecting planetary boundaries to ensure a life of dignity for all. The evidence is clear that moving from our linear to a more circular economic model significantly improves resource efficiency and therefore cost efficiency, and creates more jobs. I also noted the report considers that significant acceleration of green investment, innovation and growth in the EU is needed, including use of new financing tools and different approaches to current investment policy. I particularly welcome the reference in the report to the Commission’s joint communication on the future of our oceans and could not agree more with the statement that urgent action is needed in the EU and globally. This was made clear at the UN Ocean Conference in New York last month and will frame the agenda for the EU Our Ocean Conference in October in Malta. The UN high-level political forum starts in just 5 days and leads to a ministerial meeting on 17 to 20 July. My colleague Commissioner Mimica will attend on 17 and 18 July. We see the high-level political forum as a critical component of the implementation of the 2030 Agenda. It is the principal UN body to review progress, identify challenges and make recommendations to help ensure we achieve the SDGs. During his visit, Commissioner Mimica will also highlight progress with the EU’s implementation of the 2030 Agenda, both internally as well as externally. He will also make clear that the EU is determined to play its full part in promoting the implementation of the Agenda through its internal and external actions. The Commissioner is also expected to highlight the new European consensus on development as a landmark document for the EU, having been agreed by the Commission, Member States and the European Parliament and applying to both the EU and its Member States, in their national capacity. The Commissioner will make a statement on behalf of the EU and its Member States in the general debate of the ministerial meeting of the high-level political forum on 17 July. He will also host a separate side-event at the high-level political forum to introduce the new consensus to our international partners. Other sessions of the high-level political forum will cover a range of issues, including sessions on specific sustainable development goals: sustainable development goal (SDG) 1 on poverty, SDG 2 on hunger, SDG 3 on health, SDG 5 on gender equality, 9 on infrastructure and 14 on oceans. In addition, 44 voluntary national reviews will also be presented at this year’s high-level political forum, including from ten EU Member States.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: Dréachtóir do thuairim an Choiste um Chultúr agus um Oideachas. – A Uachtaráin, maidir leis an tuarascáil seo atá faoi bhráid an Choiste um Chultúr agus um Oideachas, ba mhaith liom an bhéim is mó a chuir ar SDG 4, cursaí oideachais agus nascacht tuaithe. Ní hamháin go gcaithfimid forbairt inbhuanaithe a dhéanamh inár gcathracha, ach tá sé tábhachtach dúinn tagairt agus freastal ar ár gcónaitheoirí tuaithe chomh maith. Sin an chúis gur chuireas béim ar mo thuairim ar iompar poiblí mar aon le gnéithe eile.  Tá sé tabhachtach go ndéanfar tagairt faoi leith dóibh siúd nach bhfuil na hacmhainní acu i dtaobh forbairt oideachais agus cultúir. Tá neart cumais ag ár ndream óg agus tá sé tábhachtach maoiniú a chur ar fáil dóibh go háirithe san earnáil chruthaíoch. Is cearta sibhialta atá i gceist i dtaobh ábhair oideachais agus cultúir a chur ar fáil go forleathan. Failtím go mbeidh monatóireacht á déanamh air seo mar a luaigh an Coimisnéir níos luaithe. Má táimid chun a bheith dáiríre faoi fhorbairt inbhuanaithe a chur i bhfeidhm, caithfear a chinnitiú go mbainfidh gach saoránach leas as an bhforbairt a déantar.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Draftsman for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. - The term sustainability was coined by Hans Carl von Carlowitz in Germany over 300 years ago. In 1713 he introduced sustainable forestry and explained to people that no more wood should be felled than actually grows back. Today sustainability is a big, sometimes inflationary word. It affects us all. The question of how we shape sustainability has a direct impact on our present and our future. The United Nations adopted 17 detailed sustainability goals in the 2030 Agenda, which were also the basis for our report. For me in the Agriculture Committee it was important that we consider all three pillars - social, economic and environmental - to be taken into account as being equally important. Sustainability can work if a feeling for regionality and production processes in the primary products develops again. The social pillar in rural areas - with tourism, lived village culture with associations such as voluntary fire brigade and music bands - creates more than just living and working space. According to a study, the world population will rise to nine billion people. This presents us farmers with major challenges. On the one hand, it is about food production, but also about increasingly scarce space due to infrastructure and living space. Let us finally stop seeing agriculture and forestry as a problem and instead recognize agriculture as part of the solution with us.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the meantime I thank my colleague Seb Dance and those who worked with me on the opinion approved in the Committee on Development. The new sustainable development goals are universal and ambitious: we cannot leave them on paper. We need a European implementation strategy, which we have been calling for since day one, and also a clear roadmap to reach them. The EU must do much more for policy coherence for development and make impact assessments of its policies on sustainability and on developing countries. Resources are needed, not only by reaffirming the commitment to reach 0.7%, but also with a relentless fight against tax evasion and avoidance globally. Furthermore, we must abandon the dangerous tendency to make development aid conditional on border control. Colleagues, let's face it: with everything that is happening around us, with American presidents denying climate change and playing with everyone's future, the European Union must take the lead in implementing the new agenda and accountability. we have towards future generations, for a finally sustainable future.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, the Union's environmental and climate diplomacy has been showing a leading role in the implementation of the global agenda for 2030 and in the commitment to eradicate poverty and achieve sustainable development within the framework of the seventeen sustainable development goals and 169 targets which address all aspects of Union policy, and in compliance with the Paris Agreement. I was appointed shadow rapporteur for this report on the European Union's action for sustainability, which provided an opportunity for the European Parliament to anchor its vision and agenda in a European action for sustainability. However, it must be said that we still have a long way to go. We need the definition of the global strategy to implement the 2030 Agenda, which encompasses the areas of internal and external policy, a detailed timetable until 2030, an effective and complete system for monitoring and monitoring and specific progress indicators relating to the internal application of the sustainable development goals in the European Union. In my opinion, this is an ambitious and well-attended report. 308 amendments were presented by the different political groups and more than 30 compromise amendments. In this report, emphasis was placed on the fight against climate change and the decarbonisation of the economy, the protection of the oceans, the circular economy and resource efficiency, the promotion of science, technology and innovation, sustainable agriculture, nature conservation, the integration of Agenda 2030 in the European Semester, the fight against inequalities between other Member States and between Member States and the protection of the most vulnerable and marginalized. We recognize that, in order to achieve sustainable development goals, the participation of all stakeholders in the European Union will be required and, therefore, we urge the European Commission to ensure that the multilateral platform announced in its communication becomes a model of good practice to facilitate the planning, execution, monitoring and review of the 2030 Agenda. I believe that the European Parliament must have a clear and decisive role in the implementation of the 2030 Agenda that is deeply alignedwith the principles and values of the European Union.I also believe that achieving the sustainable development goals and the 2030 Agenda can be the legacy that Europe will leave to future generations.I close, Mr. President, by saying that this report shows that this house has an undeniable role in creating a better and more sustainable future, and I want to thank Seb Dance for all the effort and all the effort that he has dedicated, especially together with the rapporteurs-shadow for the development of this work, which is a beautiful work.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, let me start straightaway by congratulating you, Seb, on the amazing work you carried out. I know it wasn’t an easy task, but you managed to come up with a very good and well-balanced report, and congratulations once again for that. As we have heard today, today’s challenges call for both policies and approaches, because we have a number of challenges. For example, global economic growth is far from being robust. Fast technological progress and globalisation are creating opportunities for some, but they are causing immense challenges for others. We have societies that are aging rapidly and others with as much as 66% of the population under the age of 26. The former are finding it difficult to support their aging population; the latter are finding it difficult to create enough opportunities for their young. Many countries are also being impacted by great natural disasters and with climate change, weather events will continue to worsen for decades to come. And this is why we need to make sure that the sustainable development goals are implemented and are not merely words on paper. This is why today and every single day until the goals are achieved, we must take concrete steps to make the world more sustainable. But to do this, leadership in all countries and at all levels of society is badly needed. Governments, parliaments, businesses, civil society organisations, the media and citizens need to be all engaged to find efficient sustainable solutions locally, nationally and also globally. This is an issue of international solidarity. It will not be an easy task. It will take a lot of effort, but it is our responsibility to work together and address this very important issue.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group.- Mr Chairman!Ladies and gentlemen!Sustainable development applies equally to each of the three pillars: environmental, economic and social.I am glad that the rapporteur has agreed with me on this point.At the same time, however, I must point out that achieving these goals will not solve all the world's problems;we cannot interfere with such detailed areas of life as the way people eat.I cannot agree with the provisions regarding the need to reduce the breeding of fattening animals, reduce meat consumption or restrictions on rapeseed fuels.It is surprising that the project also interferes with reproductive and sexual rights and wants to influence the migration policy of countries.The European Union should not create recipes for life, it is naive to believe that regulating everything can fix the world's problems, which is why we cannot support this report.

name: Stefan ECK
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, colleagues! Alongside global warming, the rapidly growing antibiotic resistance is the greatest threat to humanity. We have to focus on that very specifically. According to a study by the Berlin Charité, in 2050 ten million people worldwide will die every year from multi-resistant bacterial strains that no longer respond to antibiotics if we do not immediately find alternatives to the cruel animal husbandry systems that are the breeding grounds for these deadly germs. The result of the vote on this report in committee was warmly welcomed by numerous NGOs in the fields of poverty reduction, health, the environment and animal welfare. It is disappointing how after that the conservative forces in this House have once again gone to great lengths to water down this report. I'm telling you, this short-term thinking will backfire. We are then responsible for what future generations will have to pay for. I appeal to you: give the future a chance, vote for sustainability!

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Seb Dance, for his excellent cooperation and marvellous work. The set of SDGs creates a very important guide of action for environmental, social and economic development, good governance and poverty measures, but is the EU really prepared for a thorough implementation of the SDGs? That is really the question. In the committee, we have concluded a very good report, and I hope that Parliament will remain strong and united at the plenary level and maintain the position as expressed at committee level.  I would like to draw your attention to some specific points. First of all, I argue specifically for due consideration of the social aspects of the SDGs and specific action for vulnerable groups. There are several deficiencies, also within the EU, in access to water, sanitation, along with other natural resources and basic services, such as air, water, affordable and sustainable energy, health and nutrition, which particularly hit vulnerable groups. The Commission and the Member States must urgently ramp up their efforts, correct these deficiencies and provide specific tailor—made support for marginalised, low-income households and groups like the Roma community within the EU. Moreover, there is a broad agreement on the need for a comprehensive EU strategy for the implementation of the SDGs. Last but not least, there is a pressing need for systemic screening of EU policies and public funding to be in line with the SDGs when we spend the EU’s public money.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe is unfortunately still light years away from achieving many of the sustainable development goals set out in the UN agenda. It takes a sharp turnaround to change this direction. The report proposed, and on which we have worked, my colleague Dance - whom I thank for his work - contains many, many positive points on many aspects: on the climate, on biodiversity, on the participation of territories, on agriculture. However, it still lacks courage and ambition on many fronts: I want to refer in particular to waste management and incineration. I expect and I expected that a guiding document of this type would be much more ambitious, because I think it is absurd that it is not and that it does not look far, that you do not try to dare a little more. And instead we find ourselves reiterating what is already written, what is already the obvious. Tomorrow we have the opportunity, with the amendments of the 5 Star Movement, to ask to put an end to the subsidies for incineration, to public subsidies, as requested by the European Commission communication earlier this year.

name: Peter LIESE
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals are a commitment to all of us, and it is about the future of us all. That is why it is important that tomorrow this Parliament approves the Seb Dance report by a large majority. I was all the more annoyed that there were problems with the vote in committee, so that the EPP was initially unable to agree. We found some passages to be very aggressive, in particular they were viewed by the farmers as an attack on the farmers. However, we need sustainable development with farmers, with industry, with all partners, and that is why I am very happy that we have succeeded in working out compromises with the rapporteur, so that we can do this more clearly in the report than it has been up to now do. We want to take people with us, we want to take everyone involved who also has to adapt. But I also say very clearly: those involved must also be ready for it. Nor can one say: nothing must change in industry, nothing must change in agriculture, we have to work together to find new ways - innovative ways - of how we can actually reconcile economic growth, social and environmental aspects. I believe that if we can do it a little better in the vote tomorrow than in committee, then we will have a large majority in Parliament. And then I urgently request the Council and the Commission to take this up accordingly, so that we as EU organizations can represent this together - with all those involved in a good future for our children and for our planet. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Question "blue card".- I would like to ask my colleague Liese if he does not think that the EPP Group, the European center-right, is in fact hiding what is called the "elephant in the room", or rather the huge and enormous contribution of environmental impactwhich has agriculture on the environment and also on health, considering that the consumption of meat is absolutely unhealthy.So I ask her: Aren't you denying the evidence?

name: Peter LIESE
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- First of all, I urge you not to mention the European People's Party in the same breath as the European right.We are the Christian Democrats, we are a people's party of the center and we are not the European right.Second, we know, of course, that we need sustainable development in agriculture and food.But in the original report it was worded as if we wanted to tell people what to eat now in the future.And so other parties - in Germany z.B. - had very bad experiences in the election campaign, and I would not recommend that to the Movimento 5 Stelle to tell people what to eat.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not believe that the European Union is in a position to act for sustainability, given that it advocates an ultraliberal model whose primary characteristic is precisely precariousness, that is - that is to say the reverse of sustainability, both social and environmental precariousness. On the other hand, I believe in the ability of our nations to act for the sustainability of the world and for their own sustainability. This is particularly the case with regard to the harmonious development of the planet, which alone will be able to slow down the immense population movements from south to north, the beginnings of which we are only just beginning to see. I would like to talk to you here about the formidable project carried out by Mr. Jean-Louis Borloo for the benefit of the electrification of the African continent. Energy is obviously one of the first human rights, which conditions access to so many other human rights, be it water, health or employment. Energy is an absolutely powerful territorial balancing factor. Mr. Borloo, of course, is not from my political family, but whatever. I discussed this project with him, he explained it to me and I would like to make my contribution here. Our nations - France in the lead - must mobilize. Africa's electrification will naturally help this continent and its people, but it will also benefit us greatly, by curbing already insane migratory movements and accelerating our own rate of economic growth. Three billion euros per year for ten years would be enough. At the level of our nations, this is not much, especially if they are united in healthy cooperation, far from the cold and blind mechanisms of the European Union. It is largely doable: we have to mobilize fully.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: – Mr President, what is happening the week after next in New York is an extremely important meeting – the High-Level Political Forum – because it is a chance for the European Union to show leadership in multilateral governance at a time when others, the US in particular, are moving backwards on this. I think we need to do more, though, to have more influence in New York, and the first thing is we need to do a lot more to coordinate our positions.  The Commissioner said that they are working on an implementation plan on the SDGs, but Seb Dance is right. It is not enough for the Commission to make a list of what it is already doing institutionally. We need to push our Member States to do more, we need to be collecting data from our Member States, finding out if they – as well as the EU institutions – are meeting their targets, and then we need to be pushing to make sure the EU does deliver on the 2030 Agenda, a little bit in the same way as we do on the climate change targets. We have the effort-sharing and we monitor that, and the Commission publishes data and we push that forward. Otherwise, I do not think we will implement the SDGs.  We need to get other donors on the development side to work with us as well. The EU is doing a lot but we need other non-traditional donors to work with us. And finally, we need accountability. You said that you would come back and report to us on a regular basis, but we need to know what you are measuring – are you establishing base lines on statistics, and will you give us regular updates on how that is progressing?

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: - Mr President, European development policy must reflect the mandate of this House, starting with the implementation of strategies to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals. But we observe with concern how many of the principles defended from these forums do not find translation in the policies of the Union. A development policy focused on the interests of the people and not only on our businesses requires transversal approaches that do not relegate the principles of justice, equity and environmental sustainability to simple beautiful words to calm our consciences. There are principles that must be respected in order to guarantee coherence between the Union's policies, such as the non-conditionality of aid for outsourcing and militarization of our borders, the implementation of binding instruments in trade policy for the real defense of human rights. and environmental justice, the fulfillment of the 0.7% objective, or the promotion of fair and transparent tax systems. Let us not make the mistake of turning development policies into business or security and defense strategies. Let us not pervert the founding values ​​of the European Union.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: - Mr President, Honorable Commissioner Vella, I take this opportunity to highlight three facts on which the European Union must work harder and be more ambitious.The first, like light brochures published by one association, is to bring the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals closer to all citizens of the European Union so that they can recognize our policies.Second, the fight against food waste.We are completely unambitious here, calculating that 50 million citizens of the European Union have to take care of how they will eat every day, not to mention the rest of the world.And when we move to a more ambitious policy, then we need to show this in legislation that is unfortunately lacking even in the circular economy package that we are currently negotiating with the Commission.And third, in our oceans, in our seas ends up too much waste.Again, when it comes to concrete goals, there is a lack of an active and ambitious policy of both the European Commission and the Member States.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: - Mr Chairman! We all recognize that the 17 goals set in the 2030 agenda are important goals. But among them - depending on the degree of economic development and social problems - there are more important goals, because undoubtedly access to water, access to food or possibly security, or combating poverty, in some countries these are more important goals than, for example, in EU member states. European. In order to achieve these goals, we must cooperate, cooperate not only within the Union, but above all on the international forum and also share our experiences. What I would like to highlight as one of several goals are also actions within the Union itself, which will affect the entire economy. In particular, they can contribute to the creation of, for example, new jobs or new methods of resource management. This is bioeconomy, an innovative approach to renewable resources, including food, but also energy, the issue of circular economy necessary for the efficient use of resources, but also necessary to use them repeatedly, energy policy, which on the one hand it will make it possible to secure supplies and eliminate poverty, but on the other hand, it will contribute to the achievement of climate goals or even clean air. We also know how important the issue of rural areas and forest areas is. They provide many public goods, and it cannot be such a situation that we say that agriculture is less important, it provides those goods that we are sometimes not even aware of.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: - Mister President! Two years after the UN's 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development was adopted, the Commission has still not presented a comprehensive strategy or timetable. I was in New York with the commissioners myself. We need more commitment and a faster, more active approach here. Transparent strategies that are binding in terms of time and that the Committee on Development is calling for contain three points in particular that I would like to emphasize. Point one: the financing. Official development cooperation, i.e. ODA, must finally achieve the status of the central instrument for the realization of the 2030 goals. This will only happen if all member states and the EU finally fulfill their binding commitment to finally provide at least 0.7% of their gross national income for official development cooperation. We should continue to design the future multiannual financial plan in such a way that the Agenda 21 goals are prioritized and achieved. Second: trade. Trade agreements between the EU and the Member States should pay more attention to fair and sustainable conditions. This includes compliance with the core labor standards of the International Labor Organization, i.e. the anchoring and implementation of the OECD guidelines for multinational companies. And third, climate diplomacy should be pursued as the central goal. The whole world is now looking to Hamburg for the G20 summit, to which this challenge will be the main theme. Here the Commission finally needs a strategy that must be presented on how it can achieve this goal together with the European Parliament, the Member States, academia and civil society.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, to speak of sustainable development is to promote food sovereignty, it is to promote energy sovereignty, it is to abandon industrial agriculture, it is to set binding goals for reducing the global energy consumption of materials.In 2003, the planet's regeneration capacity was exceeded by 25%.The planet will not support the sustainable development proposed by the European Union, proposed by the center.There is an urgent need to abandon this development based on economic growth, speculation and massive global trade.It is necessary to promote the relocation of industries and production, to change the model of transportation of people, privileging the collective use over the individual.In land transport of goods, bet on rail.Also end the plundering of natural resources in developing countries.Only then will the 2030 goals not become a dead letter.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, the Parliament delegation that will attend the High Level Political Forum on Sustainable Development next week will have a lot of work to do. In New York, under the umbrella of the United Nations, there will be a debate on the eradication of poverty in all its forms, a key issue and, in fact, the common cause, among others, of energy poverty, water poverty or water poverty. malnutrition. We must attack the root of the problem, without forgetting that in 2014 there were 122 million Europeans who lived at risk of poverty or social exclusion, according to data from the Commission. Equality will be discussed, and it is the same Commission that stated that it would take us seventy years, to follow the current progression, to reach full equality. How do I explain to my daughters that, for the same work, they will earn 16% less than their brother for the simple fact of being born girls and it will only be their granddaughters who will live in a reality that today should be normal? The promotion of well-being for all, for all, at all ages will be discussed, and I would like to recall that, according to different studies that the Commission has, malnutrition among the elderly in Europe is alarmingly high. They will talk about food security, industrialization, emissions, innovation, the protection of our oceans ... All of them are essential issues, and gigantic challenges for the 2030 Agenda, because we still have a long way to go to transform the words spoken and the objectives embodied on paper in actions that our citizens feel fulfilled. This is our duty: delivery.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: - Sir.Chairman!We learned from the UN World Goals 2015 that it is useful to set high ambitions for the development of the world.The goals showed us that when we jointly set a direction, then we can also create a change that really makes a difference for many people.That is the lesson we must take with us in the new development goals.The UN has set the direction, now we others must start acting!The EU can and must take a leading position in the implementation.We already have EU policies in many areas.We also have the money, and we have research environments, yes, we have even sustainability written into our treaty.It should not be so difficult to get something done.The world needs leadership.We Social Democrats believe that the European Union must take on that leadership, show solidarity, coordinate and create sustainable development in everything we do, and then, moreover, measure it as well.That way, we are helping to make the world a better place for everyone, and we really need that!

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: - Soil, water, air and climate require global and European efforts. But the Paris climate agreement also calls for food production not to be endangered by climate policy, and that is a fact. I would therefore like to point out that the agricultural sector is already making a major contribution to sustainable production. By maintaining the landscape, farmers and female farmers contribute not only to sustainable food security, but also to the environment and nature. Much has been said about sustainable agriculture. Do we realize enough here that the majority of European agriculture, livestock and horticulture already produces sustainably? Don't we forget that? Through innovation and increasing environmental awareness, Dutch farmers and horticulturists save CO2 and deliver top quality products. These good examples must be better rewarded by the European Union. Let's beware of moving our food production to third countries with less environmental legislation. Only a level playing field with effective measures and without unnecessary bureaucracy can stimulate sustainable agriculture. European and Dutch farmers and horticulturists have been feeding the world population with meat, dairy, grains, fruit and vegetables in a sustainable and resource-efficient manner for years now. Our European farmers and horticulturists are therefore real champions of the global climate, rainforests and biodiversity. And they want to contribute to the climate agreement and are working hard on it. But it must be feasible, affordable and doable. And looking at this a little positively would be very valuable.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: - Mr President, first of all my congratulations to Mr Dance on an ambitious sustainability report. I would like to focus and emphasize the aspect of the environment and climate change as the source of new inequalities in the world. And it is that, to combat it, I consider that recognizing the socioeconomic value that the environment has is crucial. That is why I would like to highlight and celebrate in particular point 23, which calls for sufficient resources to finance the environment. In short, coherence in the European Union between the policies and actions that we ask for. The many recommendations that are requested from the European Union to preserve the environment need to go hand in hand with sufficient financial resources. That is why we need specific and sufficient funds to finance the Natura 2000 Network, the Habitat Directive or the European Union forest reforestation plan. Therefore, to decarbonize the economy, we first need to preserve and value the environment. In short, coherence between what we do and what we say in the European Union, highlighting the environment.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: - Honorable Members! Allow me, as the People's Party leader in the opinion written by the Committee on Development, to draw attention to the development policy aspects of sustainability. Climate change is one of the greatest challenges of our time, posing a serious long-term threat to all of us, but its effects primarily affect the poorest and most vulnerable. The dwindling resources due to climate change are exacerbating the economic and social tensions that are already present in these areas. Millions of people cut him on a risky journey to the developed world, but most often they do not find a new home but end up in camps. This often life-threatening emigration, which divides families, cannot provide a real solution in either development policy or sustainability. Living conditions must be created locally and in certain regions. The European Union must develop sustainable, international development programs that consider not only so-called non-governmental organizations, but also various religious organizations and churches with a long tradition in the regions and often thinking of millions as a single organization. This can also be considered part of development and sustainability. From the compulsion to accept the consequences of post-colonial traumas, the only realistic solution must be reached: the development of a culture of help provided locally in the given regions, which is the basis of sustainability.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, culture is an important driver for behavioural change through the creation of new lifestyles and sustainable development paradigms. This approach must be community based or locally rooted and it implies finding a local understanding of sustainable development. But it could also be global and virtual. Proper recognition must be given to the mediating and facilitating role of culture, which helps us find a balance between the competing needs of the economic, social and environmental goals of sustainability. Culture is therefore a driver for sustainable growth and innovation, urban regeneration and rural and regional sustainable development, as well as for social cohesion and individual and collective well-being. It is crucial to maintain a global perspective and not to deal with these various aspects in silos. With determination and creativity we can make our cities, towns and villages more liveable, more sustainable and more inclusive, and promote innovative economic models which are fairer, cooperative and put people and the planet first.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr Chairman!Donald Trump, the president of the United States, is flying to Poland today.Tomorrow he will have a public speech in Warsaw, we will see if he will devote at least one sentence to the sustainable development goalsI am mentioning it only because I am convinced that the goals of the United Nations General Assembly for sustainable development by 2030 will not be possible without the cooperation and cooperation of countries that are leaders in economic development, countries such as the United States, Russia, China, India and so on.For now, however, the US is questioning the Paris Agreement, for example.The European Union therefore faces a difficult task of achieving our goals.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: - Mr President, the term 'sustainability' is used so often in so many contexts that I wonder if it has not become a cliché used only to give weight to initiatives. Poverty eradication, reducing inequality, decent work, quality education, economic growth and respect for the environment - these are landmarks of sustainable development, but instead of contributing to their achievement, many voices use the concept of sustainability simply to justify individual or business interests, and people begin to lose confidence in this concept. However, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, who has done an extraordinary job in defining the environmental challenges and the seriousness of the problem. We are, however, far from achieving the ambitious sustainable development goals set by the UN. Instead of repeating concepts, we should build policies that even bring concrete results for people.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: - Mister President! In a democracy workshop I had the opportunity to talk to ten-year-olds about the topic of “sustainable development goals”, and one of their questions was: Why haven't you done it this way up to now? And they gave each other the answer at the same time. There came tough judgments like: "Maybe you were too greedy or just jealous". A few said: “Politicians probably wouldn't have cared.” And some were a little milder and said: “Maybe they didn't know what they were doing. “Ignorance of what we are causing is no longer an excuse, and the formulation of the 17 sustainability goals shows that we care about the future of our children, the future of future generations. The task now is to translate these goals into very concrete political action. This own-initiative report is a valuable guide to action in the fight against hunger and poverty, for health and well-being, for equality, education, employment, and protecting the climate and the environment. Thank you, Seb Dance, for this excellent initiative proposal.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the UN Development Goals are essential targets for achieving the best results in terms of health, global prosperity, action against climate change and conservation of the environment. The integration of these objectives in the strategy for better lawmaking certainly goes in the right direction, allowing European legislation to work at full capacity by clearly indicating the areas in which the sustainable development objectives are achieved. However, the various areas of intervention require constant monitoring and revision of the legislation. I refer to the effects that the ETS system and the sharing of efforts, the European Fund for sustainable development and investments in energy efficiency and renewable sources, the attempt to reduce inequalities through cohesion policy, the Fund for the fight to poverty. Many objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy closely linked to those of the UN agenda will presumably not be achieved within the set deadlines. There is no doubt that if Europe is to continue to exercise leadership, it must accelerate the implementation of its sustainability policies.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, I will address three points of interest, the first of which is energy poverty. I think this is a serious issue that needs to be addressed. We have populations that really do not have access to energy. Especially in Greece, there are thousands of households which at the moment, due to the policies of the troika, do not have access to electricity. We have over 100,000 households in which the electricity has been cut off. These households do not even have access to heating. After all, oil prices have skyrocketed because the troika has imposed increased taxes on heating oil. That was the first issue. The second is immigration policy. Unless there is a serious intervention, we will continue to have huge migration flows in Greece and Italy and the populations there can not stand other refugees and illegal immigrants. The third is tax justice. This story with the tax havens must finally stop, the multinationals must finally pay their taxes where they earn with their activity.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: - Mister President! I would like to thank Seb Dance very much. I have to say: The way the report was presented was very impressive. It's not just about the future of our planet, but above all about the future of our children. Sustainability is very important. Sustainable development - we noticed how many aspects it has in the articles.
