Above all else, I would like to focus on one sustainability goal that until now, apart from everyone else, only Commissioner Vella himself has mentioned. That's goal fourteen. It's about the ocean. I am firmly convinced that we live on the blue planet, 70% is water. If we really have nine billion people in 2050, then 30% earth will not be enough. We will need water for food, for the climate, for climate improvement, for energy, for raw materials, for transport and trade - for a lot - and also for health, for example, for medicine. And that's the point. The sea is not healthy. We absolutely have to do something to make the oceans healthier, to protect them. Only then can we use them sustainably, and only then will they really serve this planet with its future and the people who live on it.

name: João FERREIRA
text: - Mr President, the sustainable development objectives, 17 objectives comprising 169 goals and more than 300 indicators set by the United Nations in Rio, in 2012, justify this debate. It has two dimensions: that of the objectives themselves and that of the European Union's attitude towards those objectives. The objectives range from the eradication of poverty to the protection of ecosystems, covering a multiplicity of areas. They are, in general, pertinent and fair objectives, despite a certain bias - evident, for example, in the overvaluation of the role of economic growth -, since, with regard to the role of the European Union - and propaganda apart -, consideration of its general guidelines and sectoral policies requires the conclusion that the desired sustainability will not result from them - on the contrary. Sustainability requires breaks with free and unregulated trade, with the generalization of intensive production models, the deregulation of the financial sector and the free movement of capital, with the erosion of social and labor rights, with the attack on public services, only to give some examples.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: - Madam President, when the 17 Sustainable Development Goals were adopted in 2015, their text was also welcomed by people with disabilities. The previous agenda, the so-called Millennium Development Goals, did not mention their rights in any way, while the motto of the Sustainable Development Goals was: "Don't forget anyone". The ambition of the goals of sustainable development is to end poverty in all its forms all over the world. It is people with disabilities who are most at risk of poverty, not only in developing countries but also in the European Union. They are among those who are most excluded from society and do not have sufficient access to education, health care or employment. That is why measures need to be taken to think about them, and it is important that they be included in this report. In this sense, I have therefore proposed 2 amendments and I thank all the colleagues who have joined them across the political groups, and I hope that others will support them during tomorrow's vote.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all the MEPs for their very valid comments. The Commission welcomes the Parliament’s own-initiative report. It is really a great support to better integrate our policies and to develop synergies to achieve the SDGs. It is clearly a call for an ambitious response to the 2030 Agenda and I can assure everyone that sustainable development is and will remain at the heart of EU policy-making. But we have to be operational: sustainable development is complex and interlinked and so must go beyond simple declarations. The Commission is committed to ensure an agenda of results, and I have had the opportunity to remind the Environment Ministers that we will not be judged only on what we announce but on what we do. But we need to make certain that all of the other Ministers of all the other sectors are on board with us as well. Many MEPs spoke about implementation and accountability and, as I mentioned in my introductory speech, we will be monitoring consistently to ensure the successful implementation of the SDGs. The Commission will provide regular reporting of the implementation progress. The reporting will be based on a reference indicator framework. The indicators were arrived at after extensive consultation with a number of stakeholders, and we will start as of this year, and the report will be published in November this year. With regards to reporting, I would like to mention here the Environmental Implementation Review and, as outlined in the report, the EIR has already served as a useful tool in highlighting implementation gaps in the Member States, and the Commission has already started to take action based on these. For example, the clean air dialogues will help reach solutions to common challenges, and full implementation of the NHL action plan will help ensure that we meet the objectives of the Birds and Habitats Directives. Work is already being done by the Commission as well on other fronts. We mentioned circular economy. A lot is also being done on SDG 14 in protecting our oceans to the EU’s Ocean Governance Initiative. But let’s be very clear: SDGs are not exclusively and only about the environment and development, and in this context, I particularly welcome the proposal in the Seb Dance report for a cross-committee working group on sustainable development goals to ensure a horizontal working within Parliament as well. This would then also provide an opportunity for Members of the European Parliament who have not yet put forward opinions to also engage in this topic. Last but not least, we are committed to taking the implementation of the 2030 Agenda forward. Together with the European Parliament and together with the Council, also with other European institutions, international organisations, NGOs, civil society and other stakeholders. I would like to conclude by thanking you again for today’s debate, which represents a very important contribution to the whole process of further developing and further shaping a vision for the future of Europe.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the debate today shows that we share the same objective of achieving poverty eradication and sustainable development through effective implementation of the 2030 Agenda. This will be done only if we work together and if we ensure that we have a clear vision of how all relevant EU policies will contribute to their achievement of the 2030 Agenda. Therefore, we need a clear way ahead and strong commitment by the EU and the Member States to implement the 2030 Agenda in all relevant internal and external policies.

name: Seb DANCE
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, thank you very much to everybody took part in this debate, and particular thanks to you, Commissioner Vella, because it is very clear that you have listened to what the report is saying and what we are suggesting, and I am very heartened to hear a number of initiatives that you outlined in the response that you gave, including, of course, regular reporting to this place on the progress vis-à-vis the 2030 Agenda and the reference indicator framework which we very much look forward to in terms of seeing how that will be implemented. Again, I welcome very much your commitment to the side events and the participation at the UN high-level event in New York, because this of course is the opportunity for this place to take forward our ideas and to showcase to the world how we can work collectively. A number of issues did come up in the debate regarding how we go forward. Ms Wiśniewska from the ECR was right: we cannot be prescriptive in telling citizens how they behave and what they eat. That is not the role of this place. However, Mr Eck was also correct in saying we cannot shirk our responsibilities. We cannot pretend that things are not as they are. It is the case that current production methods in meat consumption, for example, are driving us towards an unsustainable future, but that doesn’t mean we can’t collectively find the solutions. Already across this Chamber we’ve heard ideas in this place. There are ideas that will be shared in the multi-stakeholder framework. It is only through this dialogue, through this process of conversation, that we will get to a stage where industry and businesses and citizens and NGOs and all of us can work together for that sustainable future. Because I meant what I said at the start: this isn’t something that is owned by the left or the right one political group, it is owned by all of us, and it is all of our responsibility to deliver it. And I think together we can do it.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The joint debate was closed.The vote will take place on Thursday, 6 July 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: In written form. - Insufficient investment in healthcare is a serious problem in many European Union countries. European health systems are struggling to meet the pressing challenges of an aging population, deficient public budgets and growing health inequalities. Against the background of the economic crisis, the stability of public finances has been brought to the fore at the expense of sustainable investment in health, but these goals are not incompatible. Ensuring equal access to quality healthcare is the key to sustainable health systems, as it has the potential to reduce health inequalities between and within Member States. More efforts are needed to overcome barriers to access to healthcare at the level of patients, providers and the healthcare system. The European Union must integrate its commitments stemming from the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development into all its actions and policies. The European Union must also encourage Member States to avoid short-term decisions about healthcare investments and help them provide quality health services that are accessible and do not lead to financial difficulties for patients.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. - European societies face many challenges related to sustainable development today, ranging from widespread poverty and environmental degradation to the dangers of climate change. The sustainability goals and related tasks are interdependent and indivisible. They are universal because they concern all people. Given the planet's constraints, resource scarcity, increasing inequalities and the importance of sustained economic growth in safeguarding our welfare systems, a common European approach to achieving the SDGs in all aspects of the Union's work is extremely important. The objectives constitute a program of interaction at all levels of public authorities and civil society, and their implementation should be continued in partnership with all actors. Living in dignity is the essence of sustainable development, so it is imperative to step up efforts to integrate the SDGs into cross-cutting projects and initiatives that will contribute to achieving better and more uniform outcomes in terms of health, citizens' well-being, combating climate change and environmental protection. We must meet the challenges of today and prepare for the future by responding to the pace and complexity of global change as well as to the needs of a growing world population. To preserve the European social model and social cohesion, it is essential to invest in young people, stimulate sustainable and inclusive growth, tackle inequalities and manage migration properly.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on Council and Commission statements on a single seat for the European Parliament (2017/2757 (RSP)).

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, you have invited the Council to speak on the issue of the seat of the European Parliament. As you know, Article 341 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union provides that the seat of the institutions shall be determined by common accord of the governments of the Member States. I would remind you that the matter of the location of the seats of the institutions is addressed by Protocol No 6 to Treaty, which inter alia provides that the European Parliament shall have its seat in Strasbourg. The issue of determining the seats of the institutions is thus a matter for the Member States when they discuss treaty changes at the Intergovernmental Conference and not for the Council. You will therefore understand that I am not in a position to intervene further in this debate.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, under the Treaties the Commission has no role in decisions on this issue. The question of the seats of the institutions is one exclusively for the governments of the Member States to decide by common accord. The present arrangements are set out in a Protocol to the Treaties, and this could only be altered using the process for treaty revision, which notably requires unanimity among the Member States and ratification according to national constitutional requirements. It is therefore not for the Commission as an institution to enter into the debate on the merits of the present arrangements or of any alternative that might be proposed.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Let us hope that our colleagues will have something to say about it.

name: Anne SANDER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, dear colleagues, let me tell you that this debate is absurd. First, for legal reasons. In the Treaties, it is neither the Commission, nor the Council, nor the European Parliament that decide on the seats of the institutions: it is the States. However, none is asking for change and, if we really had to reopen the discussions, we would have to talk about the location of all the institutions and rethink everything: the headquarters of the European Central Bank, the Commission, the Council , of all. Then I hear some people proposing to trade the European Medicines Agency or the European Banking Authority, or even both, for Parliament. Are we here carpet merchants? Would we barter? You forget the subsidiarity and the sovereign choice of France to present another city. Some people talk about saving money. I will suggest some to you: the hemicycle in Brussels is falling into ruin; the cost of the work would be 500 million euros over fifteen years. It would be outrageous to spend so much money when we can accommodate Parliament here in Strasbourg and have just inaugurated the Václav Havel building with new offices. Finally, the Strasbourg headquarters are not limited to legal or financial questions. By attacking Strasbourg the very week in which we pay tribute to Helmut Kohl and Simone Veil, you are attacking a symbol, a symbol of peace and democracy. By offering this exchange, you forget the very meaning of the European project. (The speaker accepts to answer a 'blue card' question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules))

name: Ashley FOX
text: blue-card question. – Ms Sander, are you aware that, on 27 April 2017, a majority of your Group voted for a single seat by 96 votes to 80. And, Mr President, why is Ms Sander speaking first when she does not even represent the majority of the EPP Group?

name: Anne SANDER
text: "blue card" response.- Dear Mr Fox, I would like to tell you that we have a single seat in Strasbourg.If you are proposing that we strengthen this single seat in Strasbourg, which is already in the Treaties, I am fully in favor, and France is ready to welcome a single workplace in Strasbourg.(Applause)

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: I would appeal to all colleagues to keep the level of the debate as a debate. We should not get emotional about it, although the matter is emotional. I would like to keep it that way.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: - Mr President, with all due respect, you are here to organize the debates.You are not here to comment on what any particular speaker, Member of this Parliament, may say.Mr President, if you wish to take part in the debate, give up your seat and come and sit in the aisles.We will be happy to hear your position on the subject.You do not have to take sides in this debate, you must respect the fairness between the various stakeholders, whether they are for or against.I find this method totally inappropriate, with immense respect, Mr President.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Also with all respect, I made an appeal that we should keep the debate with a certain level of understanding and not highly emotional. This is not checking what you are going to say – or anybody. Anybody is free to say whatever they like and I don’t participate in the debate, in spite of your kind invitation.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Mr President, even though we have just inaugurated the new Václav Havel building here, why come back to questioning our presence in Strasbourg? This discussion, like all those that have preceded it, is not timely. Article 341 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union provides that the seat of the institutions of the Union is to be determined by common accord between the Member States and, even if it is for us to decide, the debate would still be irrelevant. However, since it is open, I take the liberty of responding to the practical arguments put forward by the supporters of a single Brussels seat. Only the practice of parliamentary work has normalized the frequency of our presence in Brussels. The treaties inscribe the official seat of the Parliament in Strasbourg. Revising them to deprive Strasbourg of this status will open the way to many questioning and bargaining on all European institutions and agencies. In addition, buildings in Brussels could require renovation estimated at 300 million euros, or even reconstruction, which would weigh even more on the taxpayer. As for the proposal to allocate the seat of the European Medicines Agency to Strasbourg, let me point out that Strasbourg has already been ruled out by the French government in favor of the city of Lille. But, even more, the lack of opportunity for the debate is not only of a practical nature, it is above all due to the importance of our presence in these places. Being in Strasbourg is not a fantasy. This location has a history, a meaning and a future. Undoubtedly, Strasbourg is the very incarnation of part of the history of European construction, even of its essence. The city is precisely the symbol of the brotherhood of peoples that the Union seeks and consolidates a little more every day. It is a manifestation of the benefits of peace, of Franco-German reconciliation.It was in Strasbourg that Simone Veil presided over the first European Parliament elected by universal suffrage.It was in Strasbourg that Helmut Kohl received the tributes he was due last Saturday.I hear the lawsuit made by some colleagues, but turning our backs on this heritage would be a serious mistake, especially since the single seat that would end the transhumance could as well be in Strasbourg.(The speaker accepts to answer a 'blue card' question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules))

name: Peter LIESE
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mister President!Thank you, colleague.It is certainly undeniable that the importance of Strasbourg as the European capital needs to be recognized and that, of course, a possible relocation of the European Medicines Agency to Strasbourg does not give sufficient credit to this issue at all.Nevertheless, I would like to ask you: you just mentioned Lille.Do you seriously believe that Lille has a chance?What criteria - for example international schools, workplaces, research environment, pharmacological research - set by the Commission and the Council does Lille meet?Wouldn't it be interesting, at least from an independent point of view, to make another proposal from France?

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: "blue card" response.- Mr Liese, I believe that the debate before us today does not concern the location of the European Medicines Agency, since, in any case, we are very far from it.The debate today is whether we continue to sit here, to vote on our directives and regulations here in the European Parliament.The European Medicines Agency is not the subject, and mixing - as we say in France - tea towels and napkins makes no sense.Here we are talking about noble work, that of the European Parliament and that which we do as Members of the European Parliament.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, very briefly, I want to ask you: what is your policy on blue cards for this debate? Are you going to allow one or two blue cards after every speaker, and how much time have you allocated to the debate?

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: To be cynical about it, I can allow all the blue cards, because at 7.30 I have to leave. But I am not cynical and I will try to allow everybody who would like to intervene with a blue card to do that, as long as we keep this debate in reasonable conditions. This is my approach to this. We would not, of course, permit seven blue cards to one speaker or anything like this. I think that what is reasonable can be accepted.

name: Ashley FOX
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Strasbourg is an historic city. It is beautiful, it is clean, it is safe and, in 1957, it was a symbol of peace and reconciliation. But now, 70 years later, it is a symbol of all that is wrong with the EU. We have two Parliaments, one in Strasbourg and one in Brussels, and the endless travelling circus that we perform means that we are held in contempt by our citizens. Having two Parliament buildings wastes EUR 114 million a year. We emit 19 000 tons of carbon dioxide unnecessarily, and we waste thousands of hours of time of officials, our staff and Members. This Parliament has the power to propose an amendment to the Treaties. I think we should do so. I think it is disgraceful that the EPP and the Socialist Group both put up French speakers who do not represent their Groups. A majority of every Group in this House wants one seat. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: question "blue card".- Mister the deputy, dear colleague, it is perhaps unacceptable for you that French-speaking deputies speak in this hemicycle, but can you explain to me in the name of what, you who will leave the European Union in less thantwo years, when you agree between yourselves, will you take a position on the future of Europe and the future of the European Parliament in Strasbourg?In the name of what are you getting involved in this debate?

name: Ashley FOX
text: blue-card answer. – I have campaigned on this subject for eight years, and I shall continue as a full Member of this Parliament for as long as the United Kingdom pays its membership fee. If you want to suggest that we stop paying our fee now, then I will relinquish my right to vote, but I will wait to hear from you.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, it has been 18 years since I was elected to Parliament, 18 years of fighting for a single seat and, finally, today, this plenary debate. Finally, the resonance that the good governance of our work deserves, and it is not for lack of trying. As early as 1981, the Zagari report was already positioning itself for a single seat for the European Parliament, with a sort of interim status for Strasbourg. The arguments have already been made and we know them: 114 million euros, the lowest estimate for monthly transhumance imposed by the treaties; 89%, the building vacancy rate, which we invest only four days a month; two days per month, or 10% of the time, lost moving, with disastrous consequences for the climate: 19,000 tonnes of CO2 per year - the Paris agreement is crying because of our wanderings. I will stop, I said it and the arguments are known, as are known the positions of the European Parliament and, in particular, of the liberal group that I represent here, always clearer, always stronger and always misunderstood. The 2006 petition for the single seat: 1,300,000 signatures from all over Europe, a real European citizens' initiative before the letter, our votes in committee, in plenary and in successive and multiple working groups and, above all also , the polls in different countries - including France - for a single seat. The European Parliament is the only one in the world to sit far from its nerve center. We too are dear friends, dear French colleagues, viscerally attached to our imperative duty of memory and to the reconciliation which has made, which continues to do and which will make our history. But the symbols must be shaken up, they must be modernized. Strasbourg, today, has become one of bad governance in Europe and everywhere. Yet she deserves better, she deserves so much better. Why not take advantage of the opportunity that Brexit offers us with the transfer of the European Medicines Agency?Simone Veil, in her memoirs, dreamed of a European university in Strasbourg: the capital of Alsace as a European hub for medicine and biotechnology would be a magnificent version.It is up to President Macron today to dare to take this qualitative leap.(The speaker accepts to answer a 'blue card' question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules))

name: Anne SANDER
text: question "blue card".- Madam, dear colleague, you spoke about the cost of the European Parliament, here in Strasbourg, and you spoke about the bad governance of the European Union linked to the Strasbourg Parliament.Therefore, I would like to know how you think we will be able to justify to European citizens the need to start work in the European Parliament in Brussels.Also, how do you think you justify the misuse of public money and the mismanagement of buildings in Brussels?

name: Frédérique RIES
text: answer "blue card". - Madam, for years that this debate has occupied and preoccupied us, everything has been used: parliamentary filibuster, quibbles one after the other ... Obviously, the structural problems of the Brussels building are now bread blessed for you. I do not think that it is with this problem, which is cyclical and which will be resolved, that you will be able to say that you refuse to move forward on the resolution of a real structural problem, which is that of this mismanagement and this bad governance in Strasbourg. You save time, you play the clock. I find it a bit short. It seems to me that you could have done better here. The problems in Brussels will be solved, if ever they are proven, because the secret chamber where we can read the reports will be open from Monday. I will be going there and I am not convinced that these problems are of the order of what has been mentioned.

name: Rina Ronja KARI
text: for the GUE / NGL Group.- Sir.Chairman!Thanks to everyone who helped start this important discussion.There are, as one can hear, many different views on this subject.I do not mean now that we can fail to take the anger of citizens and their incomprehension that we travel back and forth, very, very seriously.EU auditors estimate that it costs DKK 850 million every single year.This leads to an emission of more than 10,000 extra tonnes of CO2!It is then a complete insane waste of citizens' money and leads to a violent extra pollution from a parliament that claims that we take the environment seriously.That is why it is extra important that we seize the opportunity now that there is actually a movement among the Member States.Now, as Parliament, we must stand together and put pressure on the Council and on the Member States so that we can put an end to this violent waste!And it should be better today than tomorrow!

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mister President! Today we are discussing an issue where the great majority of European citizens only shake their heads, namely the fact that we have several seats in this Parliament, that we have to go to Strasbourg once a month for four days, even though we - like I, for example - already have two places of residence anyway, one in Vienna and one in Brussels, where I spend most of my working hours, like all of us. For many of the citizens, it's not just a shake of the head, it's a decided rejection. At times like this, spending 114 million euros a year on this traveling circus - as a Greens, I also say that I also spend 19,000 tons of CO2 on it - only actually using this Parliament 48 days a year - most of the time it is empty - that is no longer possible these days. No company would do that. It also has a European aspect of democracy. As MEPs, we want to decide for ourselves where we meet. We are currently not allowed to. This Parliament has already said umpteen times by a two-thirds majority: we want one seat and not two. In other words, the point is that we want to start a dialogue - with the Council, the heads of state and government, but also with the new French government. I would like to remind you of what a colleague said: Simone Veil dreamed of a European university in Strasbourg. Let us make their dreams a reality, together with the dreams of European citizens and the vast majority of Members of this Parliament: one seat of the European Parliament, not two.

name: Roger HELMER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, Ms Lunacek and my old friend Ashley Fox have explained in considerable detail why the two-seat situation for the Parliament is totally indefensible. It is hugely wasteful. It wastes resources; it wastes vast quantities of time including, colleagues, our time. It wastes money, and if you care about it, it wastes CO2 emissions. But I have to tell you, Mr President, that I personally rather like it, and I’ll tell you why I like it, because it serves as a perfect metaphor for the hubris and futility of the European project. It is something that nobody can explain, nobody can justify, and yet nobody can change, and there are many, many policies of the European Union of which you can say the same. I think of the common fisheries policy, I think of the Emissions Trading Scheme. The list goes on. I have been able to use this metaphor again and again in speeches up and down Britain in order to explain to ordinary people who are not very familiar with the European project the complete absurdity of it, and they catch it straight away. Ms Lunacek said companies would never do this. She is right. I say to people: are you in business? Would you move your business from London to Edinburgh for a week and then back again, and then to Edinburgh for one week every month? Of course they would not, and they see the absurdity of it. Mr President, I am shortly to retire, and this is, I believe, the last speech I shall make in this Chamber as a Member of the European Parliament. I would therefore like to crave your indulgence to leave one final message. We need a quick, a clean Brexit and we need a fair and comprehensive trade deal. We need that not just for Britain but even more for Europe, and if you fail to deliver it, then you will find that you will be punished by the workers of Stuttgart and Munich and many other European citizens. I leave that thought with you.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as the only member of Parliament who is citizen of Strasbourg, even though I have other Alsatian colleagues, I would first like to thank the Commissioner and the Council, who have not taken a position, as well as the colleagues who took a stand in favor of Strasbourg. For the single seat, no problem, Strasbourg is ready to welcome it. But what is Strasbourg? More than a city, a crossroads of Germans, Celts and Romans from the 5th century. It is the place of all the kingships and powers which made the Europe of peoples and civilizations: the Carolingians, the Capetians, the Holy Empire of the Hohenstaufen and the Habsburgs, this in the lineage of Saint Odile and Aldaric . It is the place of all the issues and conflicts for 1,500 years between East and West, the bone of contention of fratricidal struggles and world wars, with this banner of the Virgin of Strasbourg, arms outstretched between the 'East and West, which calls for this permanent reconciliation. This territory is the axis of balance between peoples and nations, the basis of Europe. If you haven't understood this - which I'm afraid - you haven't understood anything in Strasbourg. But neither did you understand anything about Europe which cannot be under unipolar domination. The cabal against the siege of Strasbourg wants to be pragmatic. It is fundamentally ideological. Your arguments do not stand up to the facts: Strasbourg cost too much? The Paul-Henri Spaak building cost 1.8 billion euros and to renovate it would cost 300 to 500 million euros. Let's make the single seat in Strasbourg. Strasbourg would be too far from the other institutions? What about a multipolar Europe? My dear colleagues, if you are abandoning Strasbourg, it is because Strasbourg is outside the spheres of influence of pressure groups. Those who want to give it up? Lobbies that work against Europe. Abandoning Strasbourg is above all abandoning the Strasbourg of a real Europe of which you are, for some, opponents.It means abandoning this Europe of history, of identity, of memory.Strasbourg is also far from NATO.She has the Eurocorps.Strasbourg is a Europe of balance.Do not give up the balance, otherwise Europe will not happen.(The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Mr colleague, I want to express myself. You have always criticized any inefficiency, inconsistency in the functioning of the European Union, especially your political faction.And you said that Strasbourg was ready to take the European Parliament as its only seat.Can you tell me what savings we would make at this point if everyone had to travel to us?Does that mean the Council, the Commission?So what savings would be achieved?

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: "blue card" response.- In the Europe that I see personally as a European, but a particular European - I have always been for the Europe of States, the Europe of Nations - I think that there is indeed a place fora Council and for a Commission reduced to a Council secretariat, and that the place of this new Europe could be welcomed in Strasbourg.I recognize that we have efforts to make in terms of transport, but they will be made.I recognize that, for this, Brussels has an advantage, but this is not the reason in terms of savings, because it is quite possible - I say it - to put all the institutions in Strasbourg if we want to makesavings.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, just a few days ago, we received in this hemicycle the remains of Helmut Kohl, this great European, pillar of European construction. And now, by a cruel irony, we hear the arguments of those who want to put an end to Strasbourg, the place of Franco-German reconciliation and European unity. Frankly, ladies and gentlemen, the choice of the seat of Parliament cannot be an economic choice. It is a political choice that rests on historical foundations. Need we remind you that an Alsatian born in 1869, who would have been lucky enough to survive the two world wars, would have successively had four nationalities? Haut-Koenigsbourg Castle, not far from Strasbourg, bears both the marks of Charlemagne, of the entry of Alsace into France in 1648, and of the three Hs: Hohenstaufen, Habsbourg and Hohenzollern. I invite those of our German friends who are turning their backs on Strasbourg to go and recharge their batteries. At a time when so many forces seek to destroy the European construction, do we want to send the French people the following message: Europe is leaving, it is turning its back on Franco-German friendship? Brexit will not have been enough for some, they need Strasbourgxit! (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: "blue card" question.- Mr President, Mr Chauprade and colleagues from France, from France, from Strasbourg or wherever they are, I think they have got the debate wrong.I would like to remind you that here what we are discussing and what we are looking for is to agree on whether or not it is necessary to have a single seat for the European Parliament, not to decide whether it is Strasbourg or not, not the benefits of Strasbourg, not to make a claimhistorical, cultural or heritage of Strasbourg.If we can decide together that we have to have a single headquarters, as we have been asking for years, we will later decide, with a calm analysis, which is the headquarters.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: "blue card" response.- I am in favor of the single seat in Strasbourg.It is the natural seat of Parliament.The arguments have already been given, that is very clear.

name: Peter LIESE
text: - Mister President! Personally, I love the city of Strasbourg, and I want Strasbourg to be significant as an important European capital when Roger Helmer and Ashley Fox have long been forgotten in this Parliament. Strasbourg must have a European future. But I advocate a sustainable solution, sustainable for Strasbourg - that we don't have to discuss it every year - for France, for the European Union and also for the European taxpayers. The other member states should make France an offer so that Parliament can sit permanently in Brussels, but Strasbourg - economically and in terms of prestige - is more than compensated. And the location of the drug agency can be an element in this, an important first step. Strasbourg has excellent conditions for this: European schools, an international environment, an environment for pharmacological and medical research, a large department of the Council of Europe that deals with this topic. Strasbourg is much better suited than many other candidates and definitely much better than Lille. That is why I am now calling for everyone to put their national egoisms aside and for us to find a European solution together. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: question "blue card".- My dear colleague and friend, I fully understand your attempt to increase the number of compensations as we speak to say: "Frankly, you are so sad that Strasbourg is being taken back from you.we will give you even more. "The French government has just, less than an hour ago, through the official channel of the Minister responsible for European Affairs, to give a clear and definitive objection to the abandonment by France of the seat of the European Parliament.in Strasbourg.Don't you think we should therefore interrupt our proceedings, since it is an obvious waste of time?(Applause)

name: Peter LIESE
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure. - Well, if that was what the French government said, it is unfortunate. But then the debate will not stop. I think it would be a good opportunity. Of course, there are always times that get us into trouble. But I don't think that's a sustainable solution. And that's why I think there will be no end to the debate, it will keep coming back. My petition is really to talk together about how we can find a better solution. It is not directed against France. Personally, I like coming here, but we also have to take into account the taxpayers and the others who have to commute and lose a lot of working hours, and this problem certainly does not end today. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: question "blue card".- Mr Deputy, you who want lasting solutions, how do you explain that in Germany, your country, there is the capital in Berlin and still a significant number of ministries that are housed in Bonn?There, you are not surprised that there are unnecessary expenses incurred for the transfer, every week, of your ministers and their services from Bonn to Berlin?

name: Peter LIESE
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Dear colleague Grosstête, we are and almost always in agreement, but unfortunately we do not agree on that.But I think we also agree that Lille is a lost candidacy.By the way: That won't work, and there would at least be a chance - regardless of the single-seat debate - that France would propose another candidate.But about Bonn and Berlin: I tell my groups of visitors this every time.Every time the question arises: why do you have this second parliament, and why do you go back and forth so much?Every time I say: We in Germany are doing the same nonsense with Bonn and Berlin.And I would like to abolish that too, and I stand up for it as well.But I cannot permanently - and the citizens do not believe me either - justify one nonsense with the other nonsense.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: - Mister President!I would like to say a point of order.We all have our appointments, and now these little one-minute speeches keep coming up.We don't learn anything new!So, Mr President, I would ask you, simply for reasons of time economy, that you no longer allow blue cards.There is also nothing new with the questions!It only comes out of resentment!We want to have a factual debate.Please do not accept any more blue cards.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: I point out the following: First, for those who are registered in the list of speakers and are going to speak next, I will not give them a blue card, to allow those who are not registered to use the process of "catch the eye" ». Secondly, I will not give a second blue card to the same speaker and I also point out that those who use the blue card right from now on, I will not select them for the "catch the eye" process. I hope we save some time with these settings. The next speaker, Mr Weidenholzer, spoke for two minutes.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Mister President! “Every year again” - that could be put at the beginning of this debate. This discussion flares up again and again. We have gotten used to complaining about the apparently unchangeable and then shrugging our shoulders. Nobody understands this traveling circus, nobody understands this being torn. We have learned to accept that. Perhaps the word "accept" is a better expression. Our voters in particular do not understand this. This traveling circus is not exactly a plus for the European project. People want clear, binding answers from us that we cannot give them. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, there is a need for action - now, also because some fundamental decisions are being discussed. We should have this discussion offensively and not wait for us to be drawn into it anyway. We should conduct it seriously - weigh the various arguments - and without preconceived ideas. There are a few key points that we need to consider. Yes, there are binding legal bases that are set out in the contracts. As for the seat issue, the situation is clear. But there are also a large number of resolutions by this House that are unequivocal. We are committed to thrift, must be expedient and should avoid duplication. The more difficult the budgetary situation in the Union, the closer we have to look. And we must - I believe - accept that these principles only allow one seat. That is why, ladies and gentlemen, this House needs a definition. We cannot afford to remain vague forever. Parliament has to be involved for a final decision. That is why, in November 2013, we adopted a resolution defining the seats of the EU institutions, and it is up to the Heads of State and Government to take up this decision.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: - Dear colleagues, defining the location of Parliament is not a simple accounting question, but a political one. The question is to know what should be the European Union of tomorrow: an even more centralized Union or the Europe of subsidiarity? Within the ECR Group, we have always advocated both for the single seat and against bureaucratic centralism. To decide today that this Parliament will go to Brussels is to accept centralism. Does anyone here believe, without laughing, that we will one day speak of "Brussels DC"? And I'm not talking about the cost of the transfer added to the reconstruction of the Spaak building ... As long as the new course of Europe is not set, the question of the seat must remain open. Putting Parliament 500 meters from the Commission may seem more functional, keeping it in Strasbourg, politically stronger and meaningful at a time when Europeans need to define themselves. As for the two London agencies, I suggest hosting them in Copenhagen perhaps, but not here. The single seat, yes, but the choice of location, at the next Parliament.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: - Mr President, indeed, as some people recalled earlier, this debate is totally surreal for our fellow citizens, since here, in this Chamber, everyone has known for a long time that, in order to change the seat of Parliament, we have to go back to the treaties. A colleague recalled earlier that Nathalie Loiseau, the new minister responsible for European affairs in Mr. Macron's team, expressed an end of inadmissibility on the part of my country, France, for any modification of the seat. You will tell me that we can always open Pandora's box, but, at that point, we will bring into play the European Court of Justice, the European Central Bank, the Council, the Commission and so on… You know that this question cannot be dealt with at this time, because it is impossible. Without going back to the historical, political and legal arguments - the modification of the treaties - those of the convenience offered to Strasbourg, or those of the political need to refuse an excessive centralization of institutions and to return to unity in the diversity, which is the motto of Europe, let's not cut corners: yes to a single seat, yes to Strasbourg, this single seat.

name: Bart STAES
text: - I would like to urge you to think out of the box for a while. I note what France's Minister of European Affairs stated some time ago. And I also recognize that Strasbourg is a symbol of peace. It is also a pleasant city. I've been coming here since 1983, the city has also changed for the better. But many colleagues have pointed out that this entails a great cost and the opportunity that lies there due to Brexit and the transfer of a number of agencies after Strasbourg is an opportunity, a moment to see whether this is not a socio-economically positive story for Strasbourg. . It is said: we want to make Strasbourg a unique seat. French colleagues, can you handle this in the city of Strasbourg? It means that at present no fewer than 6,000 people work in the political groups and in the administration of the European Parliament, 6,000 people who have to find accommodation here. It concerns 751 MPs who have to find accommodation here. It concerns 1,800 accredited assistants who have to find accommodation here. It is about additional accommodation for journalists and lobbyists! Can the city of Strasbourg handle that? I doubt it!

name: Marco VALLI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, two minutes is too long to talk about this subject, also because this Parliament has been in agreement since 1981 on having only one seat and I think that, if we hold a referendum among European citizens, the overwhelming majority would be in favor of a seat of Parliament, and perhaps some not even one. So you can understand how 114 million euros a year are an insult to all citizens who struggle to pay taxes to carry out democratic processes; you understand how 11 000 to 19 000 tonnes of CO2 are a further affront to a Parliament that seeks to do its utmost to eliminate the climate disruptions linked to emissions. So try to understand how easy it is, from my point of view, because if we were in government in Italy, we, as the 5 Star Movement, would certainly be in favor of a provision to have only one seat. Here, in this Parliament, all the governments that govern Europe are also represented in some way. Take your cell phone, call your heads of state: let them come to an agreement quickly because citizens, Parliament and common sense have already expressed themselves several times.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, I fully support the European Union abandoning the current situation of two European Parliament locations. I fully support realising the saving of the millions currently wasted stupidly and inefficiently every year by transferring the EU parliamentary machine between Brussels and Strasbourg. But let’s be realistic. The EU is now resorting to the usual fudge and non-credible position, and proposing re-siting two London-based agencies here in Strasbourg, ignoring the fact that Strasbourg is a totally inappropriate location for either, so there will not be any buildings sold, there will not be any operational costs eliminated. In fact, the European Union will stay here, and any cost or efficiency savings will never actually be achieved. It is a real shame, isn’t it, that the European Union learns nothing, and allows politics to override sensible decision-making, which would mean closing its presence in one of the two cities for good. And I would say to a lot of people who keep on citing the war: stop living in the past and get real.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: - After all, we cannot destroy the symbols that help us understand what our Union is all about, how this best plan in the history of our continent was born. We are here in Alsace, in Strasbourg, in a place that brilliantly illustrates a terribly difficult and dramatic history, on the Rhine, which they say was filled with blood after the Second World War. Here, language, cuisine, architecture, people's names, family stories - all testify to overcoming wars, occupations, hostility and working them into the richness of several cultures in one place, the wealth of openness, hospitality and friendship, and this is possible thanks to the European Union. This is where it all started and here we should continue, in Strasbourg on the Rhine we should learn about the difficult past of our continent, and from this wonderful, beautiful, modern building, plans for our common future should flow. So one seat or two, but in Strasbourg. (applause)

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the issue of a single seat has been debated in this House for many years, and for many years this Parliament has been speaking out to overcome the current situation which forces us to divide our work between two seats. However, an easy mistake must be avoided: that of emptying the deep historical significance of the reasons that brought the official seat of our institution here in Strasbourg, the city on the border, a symbol of peace. Today, however, the historical situation is different compared to many decades ago: the institution that represents European citizens can no longer fall victim to the intergovernmental logic of crossed vetoes between states. Today it has a duty to emancipate itself, forcefully requesting a reform of the treaties that not only allows us to decide where to meet, but that finally allows us to change direction - I say in a federalist sense - to the structures and policies of our Union to overcome the innumerable impasses that damage European citizens in the fields of economic and social policy, of common external action, even before and much more than the very important question of our common seat.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: - Mister President! Ladies and gentlemen, I have never heard so much French here in this House as I have tonight. Madame Grossetête, vous avez tout à fait raison. Of course we also have two capitals in Germany. But I should like to draw your attention to the fact that the EU has three capitals - besides Strasbourg and Brussels also Luxembourg. Let us not forget: Let us remember Mr Juncker here two days ago, he said: 'The European Parliament is ridiculous.' I have to tell you - from what I have heard here: he is absolutely right. Parliament does not even have the right to choose its own seat. Where in the world is there such a thing? And we heard here from the British that they were leaving. Why are they leaving They leave because we have too much Europe. Ladies and gentlemen, if we continue like this, more will be possible. And then the problem will take care of itself: Then we no longer have two seats or one seat, and in the end we don't have any.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I was very pleased to hear this debate and I will continue to do so with you, but I find it a little extravagant, maybe a little extravagant.Basically, at the moment when a colleague from France stated that the French Government had made the decision that it did not agree to the transfer of its seat to Brussels, or rather the designation of that one seat in Brussels, I do not think that the debate is really going anywhere.I'll save your time and give up for the next thirty seconds, that is, let's continue that debate.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: - Mr President, ladies, gentlemen! Strasbourg is the seat of Parliament by chance. It was the joint assembly of the coal and steel union that was at home here. And she was only at home here because there wasn't a large hall for MEPs in Luxembourg. That is why they went to Strasbourg. Yes, it is historical, it has nothing to do with European history! And then Luxembourg is something very crucial. You have to imagine what activities Mr Juncker and everyone else have brought to Luxembourg. Nobody talks about it. We have a double seat here. The Luxembourgers are also there, and they are only there because it has historical reasons. Yes, and when I look at it now - I have my French colleagues - I understand everything. I like to be in Strasbourg too. But it doesn't make sense to have two seats. But we can calm down: no matter how upset we are, France will never consent to the abandonment of the Strasbourg seat! And then it is said: That costs 140 million. Oh, that is little compared to the waste that I usually experience in Europe in agricultural policy and cohesion policy! One should pass over it in silence, over these 140 million!

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: - Mr President, we are here because being in Strasbourg reminds us of our reason for being. We are here because Alsace reminds us every day why the founding fathers devised the European Union: to unite us, to overcome the borders that separate us, not to invent problems where there are none. The founders couldn't all be wrong. Kohl, either. And the images of the starry blue on the remains of the chancellor, here in Strasbourg, with President Clinton squaring before him, have gone around the world. Strasbourg is the symbol of reconciliation and peace between Europeans. To tear Parliament away from it is to tear the soul and identity out of the European project. The symbols are important, they are priceless and you cannot play with them. I will finish, Mr. President, in relation to the debate on agencies. Isn't Lille okay with you, Mr Liese? Bet on Barcelona, ​​it's ready. The Government of Spain is working hand in hand with the Generalitat of Catalonia and the City Council, in an exemplary way, united, so that this agency ends in Barcelona. It is a fundamental strategic project for which we will compete thoroughly and to the end.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr President, this structure of the European Parliament in three different locations, in Brussels, Strasbourg and Luxembourg, is expensive, inefficient, harmful to the environment and a great relic of times gone by. We have finally welcomed an official discussion on this issue and I can only welcome that. Over the years, a whole network of political and economic entities has been created around each of the seats of the Parliament, profiting from such a structure, so it was practically impossible to achieve a completely logical rationalization in the form of moving the entire infrastructure to one place. I believe that in the end we will succeed, despite enormous resistance. Strasbourg as a place of reconciliation has great symbolic significance, but I think it is time for Parliament to stop paying the price of symbolism. By moving to one place, we will save hundreds of millions of euros and thousands of working hours spent traveling to Strasbourg and be much more productive in our work. I think we owe it all to taxpayers.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Mr President, today we are reaching out to France to engage in a constructive and positive dialogue for a better Europe, closer to citizens. We in the Single Seat campaign want a more efficient, less polluting and less costly European Parliament. We are for – not against – democracy, for dialogue, for Europe, and not against Strasbourg. It is time to overcome this taboo. Strasbourg is – and should remain – a European capital, but we do not want a symbol of peace to become a symbol of waste. Let’s be honest: the travelling circus upsets our citizens. We have a responsibility not to let the single seat issue be used by populists against Europe. It is not a matter of horse trading. It is building consensus around a table for a win-win solution, providing both economic and political benefits for France, recognising its key role in Europe. Today we are calling for a legislative report asking for Treaty change, for Parliament to decide when and where to meet, and for the Council Presidency and Member States to draw up a roadmap for a single seat. In conclusion, the President of France, Mr Macron, has asked to change the Treaty for other reasons. We hope he will receive us in the Elysée. There is no mission impossible when citizens ask for it.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: - I understand, of course, the emotion of all colleagues who have spoken here today. I was here too last Saturday when we said goodbye to Helmut Kohl. Especially here, and rightly so here in Strasbourg as a symbol of "never again war". And yet we have to talk about that double seat. The Commission and the Council have just shown that they do not have the courage to do so. We need to talk about it, not only because it costs EUR 200 million a year, but also because it affects the legitimacy of our common Union. If you can't deal with this, how are we supposed to believe you and how are you still credible when it comes to the real, serious problems. Yes, this Parliament is debating with emotion, and no, we do not always agree, but we do have the courage to put it on the agenda. This is in contrast to many leaders in the Council who complain at home, but now remain silent. I say to those leaders: put your money where your mouth is. In other words, you complain at home and you do something about it. If you're not willing to do something about it, then I want the Council and I don't want to hear about it from my own leaders at home for the next five years.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, one minute to tell you everything I think about this debate is too short, because to answer each of the arguments against Strasbourg would take me hours. The European Association of Young Entrepreneurs has already done this perfectly; I urge you to read his report. But it is also far too long, because to spend a minute in this fruitless debate on a subject on which we are not the decision makers is already a minute too long. Also to those whose idea they have of their mandate is that of a Monopoly player - "against two hotels and a hemicycle, I give you a drug agency and a school" -, I tell them to take beware because, by dint of forgetting why we are sitting together here, in Strasbourg, and not elsewhere, they are anticipating an awakening which could be brutal and dangerous. Allow me in this connection to simply quote Mr. Wolfgang Schäuble, German Minister of Finance, who has made the preservation of public funds a quasi-religion. He said in 2013 that no other city explains so emotionally the meaning of the European bond. We must constantly remember that Europe can only function when Strasbourg is strong. We must constantly remind Members of the importance of Strasbourg. Europe can only function with several centers. (Applause)

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - Mr President, I am saddened by politicians who have no respect for history.Respect for history is not declared, it is alive.I am saddened by people who want to destroy traditions because they do not feel proud of what their predecessors have achieved.I am very sad about my colleagues who, instead of renewing the message of European symbols by their own work, want to destroy these symbols.The seat of the European Parliament we are talking about here is not a square in the game of Monopoly, on which we accidentally found ourselves after a roll of the dice.It is the intersection of our common European past and present.For those who do not understand this, history is just a fairy tale, Europe is just a market and the public budget is just an Excel spreadsheet.On a daily basis, we try to explain to citizens much more complex issues than the European Parliament's seat in Strasbourg.Well thank you.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for decades, every year, the European Union has been wasting hundreds of millions of euros to maintain the two seats of the Parliament in Strasbourg and Brussels. Despite austerity, cuts and real emergencies such as immigration, every year we repeat this discourse on the double seat, and every year the Council does not take a step forward in changing the treaties. The petition for the single seat, signed in 2015 by over a million citizens, went unnoticed, as did hundreds of newspaper articles and reports on this incredible and seemingly unstoppable waste. I find it embarrassing that the European Union sets its priorities on efficient resource management, sustainability and the circular economy, and then keeps such an obvious and useless waste standing. One of the two offices must be permanently closed if we want to restore credibility to the European institutions. We have a duty to show citizens that we are the first to believe in the renewal that we promote every day.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, Strasbourg has been chosen for historical reasons because it is an expression of the Franco-German approach and we must take this seriously. Secondly, we must remind some colleagues that, in accordance with Protocol 6, it is explicitly stated that the European Parliament is based in Strasbourg, where the 12 sittings take place. The seats of the committees of the European Parliament are in Brussels and the seat of the Secretariat is Luxembourg. That is what the Treaty says. The treaty also says that the seats are regulated by a joint decision of the governments and the French government has stated that it will not change its mind, so nothing is going to change. However, I call on my French colleagues, who want the European Parliament to function here, to make serious efforts to have a serious airport, so that we can come in our comfort zone and have connections with all the capitals. So invest here in Strasbourg and in the airport and other infrastructure to have a serious presence.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: - Mr President, the populists have convinced many that the institutions of the European Union are throwing money away: this is a big lie; But populists and nationalists don't need the truth at all, they just need little truths that they mix with big lies to deceive the citizens. To defeat populism we must do two things: expose their lies and leave them without arguments. The European Union in general does not waste money, but maintaining two seats of the European Parliament is an extra cost of 180 million euros per year and an environmental cost of 19 000 tonnes of CO2: this is an unacceptable waste in a Europe that has yet to recover from the crisis and that, furthermore, it is in a new phase of efficient and reformist Europeanism. We MEPs want a single seat and we have said it many times; an agile and efficient European Union would have already solved it. But in addition to the economic cost, there is a political cost: by not suppressing one of the headquarters we are giving arguments to the enemies of the Union. Strasbourg is a symbol of peace and reconciliation, we cannot allow it to become a symbol of waste. And this is the moment.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - The confidence of the citizens of the European Union in the European institutions is not as high as we would like.And I think that we must also show by our actions that we care about the European Union and, of course, about the European institutions and rationality.Especially after we went through a severe economic crisis, when we ordered austerity measures in many countries, which still has huge consequences today, we still spend 114 million a year to move from one seat to another, representing over 6% of the Europeanparliament.Colleagues have already said about other effects, which of course are not negligible.So I think it is worth rethinking whether these relocations are really rational and whether we may not be encouraging further anger at the expense of waste, and I think we, as those responsible, need to discuss this seriously.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, the debate on the single seat of the European Parliament is old and of course will not be completed, in my opinion, neither today nor in the near future. But because this issue affects the life and the way of work of all of us, the decision that will be taken should be free from emotions and political expediencies and an effort should be made to solve a real problem. There is no doubt that the seat of the European Parliament must be unified. At the moment, all the premises of the European Parliament are located in Brussels and, in my view, that is where the seat should be located. If you take into account the movements that take place, the suffering of MEPs and workers, the volume of material that moves, then this problem must be addressed in a realistic way. Having a headquarters in Brussels does not mean centralism, it means a rational approach to the issue.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, it is obvious that having two seats for the European Parliament is both illogical and unsustainable. Could you imagine if every school in Europe met in one location for three weeks of the month and then went off a couple of hundred miles away for one week every month? People do not understand this, and it needs to change. I would ask my good French colleagues to look at the situation and, if they are sincere about a single seat, let us decide on a single seat first and then decide whether that seat is Brussels or Strasbourg. I would also appeal to the French, who played such an honourable and central part in the COP 21 climate summit in Paris. How can they be so proud of that and, at the same time, condone and wish to continue a situation where 19 000 tons of CO2 are emitted every year unnecessarily? It is time for change.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: - (FI) Mr President, Brexit offers us and the EU a unique opportunity to rationalize the EU's activities and move to one location, to stop wasting both time and money.Historical reasons have been invoked here.I understand very well that, when this organization was once set up, Strasbourg was the seat.It has been acceptable then and it has had glorious reasons.But time has passed, the EU has expanded and, at the moment, having two locations is a waste and nonsense.So now is the time to move to one location.We cannot be history prisoners, nor can we be French prisoners on this issue.In any case, the situation should not be such that one Member State is able to block the decision altogether.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, it is obviously not up to the Council, the Commission, not even this Parliament, to decide this issue. The decision is for the unanimity of the Member States to change the treaties and allow the determination of a single seat for the European Parliament. However, I believe that we should take advantage of the election of the French President - the most pro-European of the candidates in the French elections - and the Brexit negotiations to relaunch the debate on the revision of the treaties that will allow this House to meet in one place. It is not a question of launching any anti-Strasbourg campaign, a symbolic place of Franco-German reconciliation and the starting point of European construction. It is a question of putting aside nationalistic selfishness and reaching a more efficient solution from an economic, environmental and parliamentary work point of view. The monthly trip to Strasbourg by MEPs, assistants, interpreters and journalists costs about 114 million euros and represents additional emissions of 19 thousand tons of CO2 per year. These values ​​are not justifiable in the face of who we all represent here - European citizens - and who have been demanded of so many sacrifices in the wake of the 2008 crisis. European people - can and should discuss this issue. In addition, in relation to the European Medicines Agency, it is proven that Portugal is the ideal place to have the agency.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: – Mr President, this umpteenth discussion about one seat is being conducted on the wrong basis because it’s not a question of choosing between Strasbourg and Brussels. Many of my colleagues have already quoted the Treaty and it is clear: our activities here are legal in Brussels. The issue, however, is not one of geography, it is a question of power. Most of us want to be in Brussels because then we can be closer to an executive branch of power, closer to Commissioners, life-time contracted civil servants and all that kind of ‘glamour’. I believe that our French colleagues would support me when I call on this Chamber to study carefully the works of Montesquieu, Rousseau and others. That means we must change the Treaties and give this Parliament more power. For instance, vote down Commissioners, Jean-Claude Juncker included if need be, and only after that can we discuss whether we like Strasbourg more than Krakow, for instance.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I have listened with interest to all the speakers today but I will not enter into the substance of the issue. As I said at the beginning, decisions on the seats of the EU institutions are not a matter for the Commission.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The discussion is over.The vote will take place on Thursday at 12 noon.Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ivo BELET
text: written.- The proposal to move the European Medicines Agency (EMA) to Strasbourg after Brexit is gaining more and more support.In exchange for the coveted EU agency, the monthly move of the European Parliament to Strasbourg can finally come to an end.80% of MEPs are in favor of one seat;let us work on that.The monthly move not only costs a lot of money, but is also extremely harmful to the environment.The end of that commuting will save up to 114 million euros per year and reduce CO2 emissions by 19,000 tons.Housing the Medicines Agency in Strasbourg also has undeniable economic benefits for the capital of Alsace: 1,000 highly skilled (permanent) staff and a daily comings and goings of hundreds of experts will broadly generate additional income for the entire region.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. - The debate on the single seat of the European Parliament now appears to be a surreal debate. Constantly re-proposed for more than 30 years, practically ever since the European Parliament was elected for the first time by universal suffrage, it now seems to have been reduced to a dialogue between the deaf. This is witnessed by the statements made in this debate by the Council and the Commission which disclaim all responsibility and leave it to the Member States of the Union. I will not stand here now to point out the waste, inefficiencies and inconsistencies that would justify a single and sustainable seat of the European Parliament. I limit myself to pointing out that also on this issue, as well as on the main others on the agenda of the political agenda of the Union, and among all immigration, once again the much-hyped rhetoric of the Union, of brotherhood and of solidarity gives way, without putting up any resistance, to the cynical, but much more realistic, selfishness of the Member States.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: written. - Two things have become quite clear over the years and decades that Parliament has decentralized its activities on a monthly basis between Brussels and Strasbourg. First, going back and forth is expensive, time consuming, polluting, and hugely unpopular. Both the majority of citizens and the majority of the European Parliament oppose it. Strasbourg is a hugely wonderful city, but this divide calls into question the EU's ability to cooperate and act. Secondly, it has become clear that the Member States do not seem to be able to reach an agreement on the move to Brussels, because France has opposed the move to Brussels. The Protocol on the location of the seats of the institutions and of certain bodies, offices, agencies of the European Union specifies that the seat of the European Parliament shall be Strasbourg, where twelve monthly plenary sessions shall be held. The most sensible option would be to amend the treaties so that the European Parliament can decide where it works. If France does not agree to change the current arrangement, I propose that the Strasbourg weeks be shortened first to three, then to two and finally to one day, while the plenary sessions in Brussels be extended. The travel rumba to Strasbourg would continue 12 times a year, but Parliament would only sit here for one day at a time. Perhaps at that stage the Treaty could be opened up even by reducing travel times. It doesn’t make any sense either, but it’s a less silly arrangement than the current one. Perhaps this will also open the eyes of France. I wholeheartedly support barter, in which France would have agencies that would soon be released from Britain in connection with Brexit if the country agreed to give up the Strasbourg sessions in return.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: written. - Year after year, three quarters of MEPs vote for a single seat for the European Parliament. We represent the European population, so you could say that an overwhelming majority of Europeans reject the money-consuming move between Brussels and Strasbourg. This was shown by the way in a survey signed by 1.7 million Europeans. In addition, the tendency to stick to multiple locations feeds Euroscepticism in the Union. No one can justify a waste of 180 million euros a year and an extra emission of 19,000 tons of CO2, the same as 4,900 flights between Berlin and New York. That Strasbourg symbolizes the reconciliation between France and Germany after WWII and therefore the deeper meaning of the Union is a valid argument. That is precisely why Strasbourg should not be written off. We have a unique momentum to make Strasbourg the seat of the European Medicines Agency. This move provides a new argument, namely that the economic yield for the city will exceed the 20 million euros in economic input that Strasbourg receives from the monthly relocation of the Parliament. Let's take advantage of this momentum and create a win-win situation, both for Strasbourg and for the European Parliament and the European people.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is Mr Younous Omarjee's report on promoting cohesion and development in the outermost regions of the Union: implementation of Article 349 TFEU (2016/2250 (INI)) (A8-0226 / 2017).

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: protractor. - Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs and my colleagues for their contribution to this report, as well as the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (AGRI) for its notice. This report comes a few months after the publication by the European Commission of its new communication on the outermost regions of the Union (ORs), a decision that I want to welcome. But more than a new strategy, what the ORs now need are concrete, rapid and effective measures for the employment of young people, for fishing, for their access to all the Union's horizontal programs. and trans-European transport, energy and telecommunications networks. All this through the full implementation of article 349. All the more so since we have, today, the legal force to do so, with the decision of the Court of Justice of December 15, 2015. What we are asking for Basically, it is not a larger budgetary effort - this debate will perhaps come - but simply the implementation of policies better suited to our particular situations, as authorized by the Treaty. What I call the OR culture must be better irrigated and better shared in all Union policies, in all Directorates-General, which is, you will agree, not always the case. The question which, from my point of view, is essential, is that of the necessary transversality and the alignment of European policies. Because it is not consistent that the major efforts made, on the one hand, in the cohesion policy by Commissioner Crețu, whose commitment I would like to salute here, are annihilated, on the other, by d other policies, by other committees which still refuse to fully apply article 349 and to take into account the particularities of the ORs. This is precisely what needs to be corrected. This is what President Juncker himself stressed at the OR Forum and it is this change that this report is advocating today. I am thinking of trade policy and free trade agreements which, as you know, are very often devastating for our fragile economies and which must, from our point of view, take into account upstream, in the negotiations themselves, the interests of our productions, such as sugar for Reunion Island, bananas for the West Indies and milk for the Portuguese and Spanish outermost regions, which are, moreover, already very weakened by the disappearance of quotas. The European Parliament therefore wished, through this report, to take an objective assessment of the implementation of Article 349 and to formulate a number of proposals. To conclude, I want to tell you about our concerns about the future of cohesion policy beyond 2020. I want to tell you about our concern about its risk of distortion in relation to these solidarity objectives. I want to tell you that, if financial instruments were to replace subsidies, the objectives we are setting for the outermost regions will then be very difficult to achieve. This is why, in the future of cohesion policy, the less developed regions of Europe, such as the outermost regions, whatever this policy, will have to be sanctuary.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank Mr Omarjee for his report. The situation of the outermost regions is unique, as is recognised in Article 349 of the Treaty. This report comes at a very appropriate time as the Commission is preparing a renewed strategy on these regions, which should be adopted by the end of October 2017. The report calls for more extensive use of Article 349 of the Treaty.
