I would like to reassure you that the Commission, within the framework of the upcoming renewed strategy on the outermost regions, and on the basis of Article 349, will look at all EU policies and consider, when relevant and justified, whether specific measures and adaptations are necessary. However, I would remind you that the Commission has already proposed specific provisions, spanning various EU policies, to take into account the situation of the outermost regions. The Commission will take stock of the progress made since 2012 when the last strategy for the outermost regions – for their smart, sustainable and inclusive growth – was proposed. Since then a lot has been done to boost the competitiveness of local enterprises and to reduce the ‘accessibility gap’. Let me take the recent example of state-aid-specific provisions, to which my colleague Commissioner Vestager has devoted a lot of attention, addressing the concerns expressed by these regions. However, major challenges remain, including high unemployment rates, which, of course, affect young people in particular. Hence we need to pool our efforts to address the concerns of ordinary people in these regions and offer them better prospects. The report sends important messages about the collective role of all EU policies and programmes in the development of the outermost regions. Cohesion policy plays a crucial role and specific provision for these regions addresses their needs and location. The Commission also agrees on the importance of investing in research and innovation, helping these regions to deploy their smart-specialisation strategies. We are committed to further boosting the outermost regions’ strengths and building on their extraordinary assets, their rich biodiversity and their unique position in the world. We would like to help them to have a leading role in fields such as renewable energies and the blue economy. In parallel, helping the regions to close their accessibility gap will be crucial. Here we are thinking not only about transport links but also about digital connectivity. Cohesion policies have helped considerably to reduce this gap. The collective involvement of all parties – the outermost regions, Member States, and all relevant stakeholders in the European Union – will be crucial to ensure that assets and specific issues are taken on board in an appropriate manner. This renewed strategy will guide our joint work in the years to come.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. - Mr President, Commissioner, I congratulate rapporteur Younous Omarjee on the initiative for this report and on its final content. The development of a socially and economically cohesive and supportive Europe is an everyday task. The different treatment of the outermost regions by all the Union's institutions and services is legally consolidated, but it requires continuous improvement. As responsible for the opinion issued by the Committee on Agriculture, I highlight the need to enshrine the consistency of Posei's appropriations in the next multiannual financial framework. Posei was a valuable aid, recognized by the independent analyzes promoted by the European Commission. I also emphasize the need for the Union's Milk Market Observatory to include the outermost regions, in an autonomous and independent way, in the assessment of prices in the country and in the establishment, of course, of the criteria for the definition of the crisis.

name: Maurice PONGA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, this report on the promotion of cohesion and development in the outermost regions (ORs) provides an initial assessment of the application of Article 349 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It is also an opportunity to clarify Parliament's positions with a view to the adoption by the European Commission of a new strategy for the ORs before the end of this year. In this report, we underline the support given by the European Union to the outermost regions, as well as the need to make better use of their strengths. This translates into concrete proposals in various key areas for the ORs. First, at the agricultural level, we call for maintaining the program of options specific to remoteness and insularity (POSEI) and to pay particular attention to certain sectors, in particular those of bananas and sugar. We also urge the European Commission to implement the recommendations that we adopted on April 27, as part of a resolution on the management of fishing fleets in the ORs. In terms of international trade, due to the fragility of the economy of the ORs, we insist on the need for the Union to take this into account when concluding trade agreements with third countries. If safeguard clauses are to be included, it is important that they are effective in order to protect our overseas producers. Regarding cohesion policy, we call for maintaining, after 2020, the specific arrangements for the ORs and for greater flexibility in order to better adapt to their specificities. Finally, with regard to policies relating to research, education, the environment, business competitiveness, transport and telecommunications, we invite the European Commission to take better account of the ORs in order to 'assure them effective participation in the various programs.I am happy that Parliament insisted on the Erasmus program in order to allow effective participation of all overseas territories - ORs and OCTs combined - in the program by adapting the grants to the remoteness of the continent.In a few months, the Commission will adopt its new strategy for the ORs.I therefore hope that it will be ambitious and will have concrete avenues for ensuring the sustainable development of the outermost regions.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, my first words will firstly be to underline the quality of my colleague Omarjee's report and above all to congratulate him on this collective work. Although she is absent, I also want to salute Commissioner Crețu's constant commitment to the outermost regions. Ladies and gentlemen, this report is Parliament's contribution to the communication that the Commission will publish by the end of the year. I hope that the latter will take up its content, in order to nurture the hope that aroused the judgment rendered on December 15, 2015 by the European Court of Justice. This judgment is fundamental. Indeed, it closes a conflict of interpretation on the scope of application of Article 349 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and above all confirms that the latter can be used to derogate both from the Treaty and from the law. derivative. However, dear colleagues, while we displayed our differences of opinion on this article, the handicaps from which our regions suffer remained. As proof of this, the recent social movement which paralyzed Guyana for many weeks. It reminds us of the urgency to act. The European Union, thanks to this article, has powerful means to adopt measures specifically dedicated to the ORs. This is exactly what the text proposes. By adopting it tomorrow, the European Parliament will demonstrate that it remains faithful to the Treaty and to the values ​​of solidarity on which our Union is based.

name: Sławomir KŁOSOWSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group.- Dear Mr. Chairman,Many thanks to the rapporteur for his involvement in the preparation of the report.The Group of European Conservatives and Reformists is a friend of the outermost regions.We wish them development and overcoming difficulties.However, I believe that the regions referred to in the report are not making full use of the possibilities of Article 349 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.I point out that the policies of countries with remote regions provide additional support.There are many areas on the European continent that suffer from similar problems because of their remoteness, climate, topography or the lagging behind by communism.These areas need support similar to that of remote regions.That is why I believe that remote regions should seek, above all, sectoral, structural and investment aid in the countries where they stay.

name: Matthijs van MILTENBURG
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Omarjee, for the hard work that has been done. There is a great distance between the outermost regions and the European continent. But since I have visited a number of these regions myself, the emotional distance has decreased for me. I am very fond of these areas and their people. The outermost regions are an integral part of the European Union, but due to their specific geographic location, they face particular challenges in their development. It is therefore only logical that we adapt European policy, where necessary, to their special situation. And then the much-discussed article 349 comes into play. And that Article 349 lays the legal basis for customization in European policy. The European Commission could be a bit more innovative with this. However, it should be noted that specific measures for the outermost regions need to be balanced and, perhaps, in the report, we sometimes call a little too enthusiastically for additional support to producers of bananas, cane sugar and milk production in the Azores . But I have to say that I endorse the overall thrust of the report. Let us also see the opportunities for development of the ultra-peripheral regions, whether it concerns sustainable energy generation, enhancing the unique biodiversity, tourism or the blue economy. Let's capitalize on those opportunities with the help of cohesion policy. The outermost regions could then become what I would call “the islands of excellence”. Sustainably connected with the rest of Europe.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, I would firstly like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Omarjee, for the quality and precision of the report. It is not only important to defend the rights of the outermost regions, but it is necessary to do so with strong arguments and by appealing to compliance with the Treaties and Regulations, which emphasize the particularities of these regions in terms of their socio-economic structure and their position. geographic. These regions also have differentiating potential in terms of sustainability, biodiversity and economic development in sectors such as agriculture, fishing or renewable energies or also, why not, tourism. But all this would not be possible without the appropriate policies of the Union and the coordination between institutions and administrations. It would not be possible without the protection of local economies. We must also remember that they will be the regions most affected by the consequences of climate change and, therefore, attention should be paid to adaptation and prevention programs. And last but not least, the report is a reminder of the importance of cohesion policy in the European Union, that it seems that sometimes we forget about the differences between regions.

name: Monika VANA
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mister President! I too would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur Omarjee for the excellent cooperation on the report on promoting cohesion and development in the outermost regions. The report really comes at exactly the right time - before the presentation of the Commission's strategy is presented. As a Greens, I very much welcome the fact that the report pays a lot of attention to supporting and training young people - especially participation in the European Youth Employment Initiative - and that students and young entrepreneurs should benefit more from the new Erasmus + program. As has already been said, because of their geographic location, the outermost regions are particularly interesting for research into climate change and biodiversity, and that is also a strength that should be emphasized. We Greens are of course campaigning for sustainable energy self-sufficiency in these areas - especially for the expansion of renewable energy sources, energy efficiency and the expansion of the circular economy. The report is clearly going in the right direction for us and we thank you.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too must express my appreciation for the work of my colleague Omarjee and I want to emphasize with him in this report that, both for the outermost regions and for regions in difficulty, the principle of solidarity does not it must only be a mere declaration of intent, but it must be important both in the planning phase and in the implementation phase of European policies. In the report we talk a lot about environmental sustainability and blue growth, but here I must point out two major dangers that our seas unfortunately run. The first are litter, marine litter, which is a real global emergency. According to a study by the European Commission itself, in addition to causing serious environmental damage to coastal communities, economies, tourism, navigation, fishing and biodiversity, they cost European taxpayers at least 630 million euros. I must point out another looming danger: the extraction of oil and gas, the exploration for minerals in deep-sea deposits. These have serious repercussions on sensitive marine areas and irreversibly damage marine species and vulnerable ecosystems. Gentlemen, if we do not address these issues and if we do not stop the multinationals, the strong powers, which aggravate environmental problems and destroy our economies with the TTIP, with the CETA, even a coherent and uniform implementation of article 349 will not be able to contribute to a truly harmonious and balanced development of the outermost regions, endowed with an incredible natural heritage to be protected and enhanced.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: - Mr President, many thanks to Mr Omarjee for his report. Remoteness, insularity, small size, difficult topography and economic dependence on a few products are permanent features of the outermost regions, including the Canary Islands. Europe's response to these handicaps must also be permanent and is supported by Article 349 of the Treaty. Three notes. POSEI plays an essential role in the maintenance and development of agricultural production and the processing industry in these regions, which suffer unemployment rates much higher than national averages. Therefore, it is absolutely necessary to maintain, and reinforce, where appropriate, these programs: without POSEI, there is no future for the agricultural sector. Fishing sector, where the need for restructuring and development, one of the main objectives of POSEI, is pressing. We need to have a POSEI-Fishing again. Fleet modernization is essential. The fleet, for safety reasons, older than twenty years, is dangerous, inefficient and polluting. With strict conditions, you don't have to jeopardize sustainable fishing. Finally, we will soon tackle the new multiannual financial framework. We need this new framework to meet expectations - let's not let them down.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Omarjee wanted to congratulate the final product of this report and to say, in fact, that the European Union must take into account the social, economic and structural situation of these regions, which are regions that are remote from insularity, small surface, relief, difficult climates and economic dependence on a small number of products. That is why we must all strive to safeguard the competitiveness and specificity of its traditional industries when concluding free trade agreements between the Union and third countries in an increase in investment achieved through the European Fund for Strategic Investments, in order to respond to the market failures in these regions, but also to the very high levels of unemployment, particularly youth unemployment, in the creation of a specific research program that allows the networking of the respective universities, research centers and innovative companies. The ORs, in fact, have all the characteristics of experimentation laboratories. I also believe that the internationalization of the accessibility of the ORs through infrastructure and transport routes is essential. I would also like to point out that I am particularly pleased that we are here speaking with one voice in relation to what we want for the ORs and we are, in fact, waiting for the OR strategy as early as next autumn.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: - Mr President, I highlight five points in this report that we defend. First: the creation of a POSEI Transportes due to constraints in the mobility of people and goods in these regions in view of their remoteness and associated associated costs. Second: no reduction in POSEI Agriculture, which is a fundamental factor for economic and social development, as well as for the territorial cohesion of these regions. Third: protection of sensitive products for the outermost regions under European trade agreements whose impact must be pre-assessed. It is necessary to clearly define what a market crisis is in these regions. The report also defends the need for the Milk Observatory to also have data from this sector of the ORs autonomously. Fourth: recovery of POSEI Pescas, whose integration in the FEAMP WAS a tremendous error, which must be corrected, causing damages that harm fishermen, as well as leading to the loss of autonomy in the management of this important fund. Fifth: increasing the application of Article 349. There is an increased responsibility for Member States to ensure that the scope of this Article is not limited to financing, by acting and exercising influence so that Commission documents already demonstrate respect for the Treaty and not only to remedy this situation. Finally, I would like to commend Mr Omarjee for his excellent work.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, all thanks to the rapporteur, our colleague Omarjee, for this report, which is the first strategic document on the outermost regions after the relevant judgment of 15 December 2015, the judgment on Mayotte, which states that there is a legal basis not only to exempt secondary legislation, but also to specialize policies with regard to the outermost regions to compensate for their remoteness and insularity. And it does so from the perspective of strategic planning: Europe after 2020, between 2020 and 2030, a strategic document for the ORs, which signals a radical change in orientation. In the first place, because we are no longer talking exclusively about regional policy or agricultural policy, but about a set of varieties ranging from trade policy to foreign policy. Second, because it is clearly said that being an outermost region is not a disadvantage, but rather it can be a strategic support. But, thirdly, because it indicates the potential of the insertion of the outermost regions due to their connectivity in the trans-European networks of innovation, energy, new communications, telecommunications, which means a huge lever for the future for, at once for all, to point out the presence of the outermost regions as a singular condition of European regional policy.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: - Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate Mr Omarjee on his work. Personally, I have been to two outermost regions, namely Martinique and the Azores, together with the Committee on Regional Development. Here I was able to see closely the difficulties that these regions face, whether we are talking about the great distances from the continent, the climatic conditions, the difficult topography or the economic dependence on a limited number of opportunities. The outermost regions, part of the European space, need strong support in order to create jobs, develop still fragile economies and ensure adequate protection of the environment, but also of biodiversity and cultural values. The implementation of the strategy on blue growth, development of research and tourism, but especially the capitalization of agricultural potential must become a reality in these areas. There is a need for better information and communication at the same time of the beneficiaries of European Cohesion Policy Funds and not only about the opportunities they offer, but also with the strengthening of collaboration between the relevant authorities responsible for their implementation.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the outermost regions are in a unique situation within the European Union, in a natural context marked by insularity, the tropical climate and a rugged and volcanic relief. These regions are very far from the European continent, but they have a relevant history: they play a strategic role in protecting Europe's maritime routes and defending its external borders. The ORs are privileged spaces with a potential for activities related to the growth of tourism, blue growth, the exploitation of renewable energies, the development of the circular economy and the enhancement of its rich natural heritage and vast biodiversity. My country, Portugal, has its history intrinsically linked to the sea and maritime expansion. The sea was, for centuries, the identity matrix of the Portuguese people and our relationship with the sea, throughout our collective history, made it possible to rescue a unique space of knowledge and opportunities for all of Europe. I understand, therefore, that the Portuguese ORs, Azores and Madeira, constitute a unique opportunity for a more sustainable Europe with the reinforcement of its vision and maritime dimension. So I think that the Union should allow the ORs to overcome their difficulties and take advantage of their unique assets and assets, and at the same time, that Member States assume greater responsibility for the use of the Union's available instruments to enable them ensure sustainable development of the ORs. This is the purpose we want for all these regions and I want to congratulate Mr Omarjee on the excellent work he has done on this report.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, Article 349 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union lays down a special regime for the outermost regions, and that is very right. However, I would like to take this opportunity to say that, due to the insularity which is also mentioned in the Treaty, the islands throughout the Mediterranean and especially the islands of the Aegean, the Ionian and Crete should be supported. Especially the Aegean islands, which are currently affected by huge migratory flows. However, instead of supporting these islands, we have, with the troika's orders, an increase in VAT in the Aegean islands. Mr President, therefore, there must be a boost to agriculture for all the Mediterranean islands, a tax incentive, especially in the Aegean, Ionian and Crete islands, to offset transport costs and boost fisheries and tourism. In this way we can really support regional development and cohesion in the Mediterranean islands.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Mr President, I subscribe to the roadmap of this report so that, in accordance with the provisions of Article 349 of the Treaty, the legal order and all European policies and programs are successfully adapted to the needs of the outermost regions, such as the Canary Islands, in order to guarantee the access of its citizens to all of them. The combination of distance and diversity has penalized the results of an effort that we recognize and that has contributed a lot and, to improve, we highlight the need to take into account in trade agreements with third countries that they are primary productions, that they are European productions, but with more difficulties; the urgency of adapting to the ORs the operation of the horizontal funds and cohesion policy and the maintenance of consideration of "less developed regions", reinforcing the agricultural POSEI and a fisheries POSEI; consider the dimension of the economy of the ORs when judging aid programs for economic development that, in another context, could affect the internal market in terms of competition; and, finally, the integration of the potential of the ORs in the field of the blue economy and renewable energies in the catalog of opportunities offered by these regions to the entire Union. And the Canary Islands are an example for this.

name: João FERREIRA
text: - Mr President, the outermost regions face factors of a structural nature, such as remoteness, insularity, among others, which permanently constrain their development. This is the basis that justifies positive discrimination that ensures these regions specific measures and provisions that help them to face these constraints. However, this positive discrimination has been applied in a very insufficient and limited way by the European Union. We therefore agree with the rapporteur's proposal - which I take this opportunity to welcome - to create an action plan for the ORs that potentiates and widens the effects of this positive discrimination. It is necessary to put an end to the devastating deregulation of markets, to further support regional production, to boost local markets, to even support the creation of inter-island markets, for example in the Macaronesian region, transport and the mobility of people and goods with creation of a POSEI Transportes. It is necessary to ensure that the ORs have control over the whole of their exclusive economic zone, support research and development in areas such as renewable energies, biodiversity, among others, and among other measures that can and must integrate this action plan.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Omarjee for an excellent report. I especially appreciate the fact that it turns us to the point of view of solidarity. This is, I think, a point of view that we sometimes lose sight of, and it is certainly not happy. The outermost regions deserve our support, they have a special status granted not only on the basis of primary law, but also on the basis of a judgment already declared. I believe that these remote regions must remain at the heart of territorial cohesion. They are facing problems, with their disadvantages, and what else is there than eliminating these disadvantages, and that is also a policy of cohesion, that is, of territorial cohesion. That is why I was a little surprised by what Mr Kłosowski said, who said that their problems should be solved within those states, I think that is just leaving the aspect of solidarity, and I think that we should not really lose sight of it as well. in relation to these remote regions.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr President, the outermost regions, due to their geographical location, are facing challenges that do not bother a good part of continental Europe. Although these are territories that are part of the European Union, traffic isolation and geographical distance from the political center of the Union, Brussels, affect their consumption of rights and European policies. That must change and the outermost regions must become an equal part of the Union in every way. Although their problems are specific, they are unfortunately not alone in traffic isolation and poor use of cohesion policy instruments. I will give the example of Croatian islands because I live on one of them myself. The demographic and economic extinction of the islands on the Croatian side of the Adriatic also requires an urgent reaction. With simpler procedures in the use of European funds and new island development policies, we can reverse this process and significantly help the islands, as well as the most remote regions, in economic development and the preservation of local communities.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to remind you that the report calls for a new chapter to be opened in relations between the EU and the outermost regions. The Commission is willing to build on the specific partnership the EU has with these regions, and to engage further with them to support their development, as President Juncker also stressed at the Forum of the Outermost Regions, which we hosted in Brussels at the end of March this year. The report also recognises the important contribution of EU policies and funds, and calls for better integration of the outermost regions in EU horizontal programmes. For instance, the report rightly mentions the need fully to exploit the research potential in these regions and to do so by improving their participation in Horizon 2020 with regard to the trans—European networks in the field of transport. For instance, the report calls on the Commission to ensure the effective integration of these regions. The Commission will explore how to include these regions better in the trans-European transport network, as connectivity remains an important challenge to address. The report also highlights the importance of specific regimes, such as specific taxation schemes. The Commission is aware of the role these schemes play in terms of supporting the outermost regions in developing their economies. However, their evaluation and possible adaptation over time are needed. The report also acknowledges the importance of agriculture – as you have already said – and specific support for the outermost regions to address their particular agricultural challenges. Without prejudice to the negotiation on the future EU multiannual financial framework (MFF), the Commission is committed to maintaining the specific aid provided by the Programme of Options Specifically Relating to Remoteness and Insularity (POSEI). Regarding your concerns about the situation of the fishing fleet, we agree on the need for safer and more efficient vessels. However, the total fishing capacity should be commensurate with the sustainable exploitation of fisheries stocks. In order to achieve that, we need data on the state of the stocks, which we currently lack. To fill this information gap, we will need the active involvement of both the Member States and their outermost regions so as to understand the situation of these stocks better and to recognise if management measures are needed. As for aid towards the construction of new vessels, something currently not eligible for public funding in the EU, the Commission understands the concerns of the regions and is examining ways, within its competences, to address them while remaining consistent with its internal and international commitments. The Commission will also look at the proposal for a dedicated support system for sustainable fisheries in these regions in the context of preparation for the post—2020 MFF, following close consultation with stakeholders and on the basis of an appropriate impact assessment. With regard to international trade agreements, the Commission will continue to pay attention to outermost regions’ concerns, not only in the negotiation phase but also in the implementation and review phases of the agreements, in particular the relevant economic partnership agreements. We cannot react here to all the important points that this report raises. However, I would like to assure you that the Commission will pay great attention to the full report as an important contribution to preparing the renewed strategy vis-à-vis these regions. In conclusion, let me again thank Mr Omarjee for this report and let me also take this opportunity to welcome the excellent cooperation demonstrated by the Conference of Members of the European Parliament from the Outermost Regions in the effort to boost the EU strategy towards these regions.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: protractor. - Madam President, it is my turn to thank all of my colleagues, and I hope that the European Commission has noted the very good unanimity of the groups, of all the political groups of the European Parliament in support of the outermost regions (RUP). This report is a collective report that we have drawn up together, and tomorrow's vote, which will be that of the European Parliament, will be a very strong signal to the European Commission so that the advances we expect can be made as soon as possible. The outermost regions, for the most part, apart from Guyana, are islands. But the management of these regions within the European Commission cannot and must not be insular. Cohesion, regional policy, this is where the main advances with regard to the outermost regions have been made, but we all know today - and this has been stressed by many of my colleagues - that the potential for future development for the ORs lie in the creation of high added value, innovation, research and development. This is why this transversality of which I was speaking must play out and for the horizontal programs we must be able to have access to a certain number of new instruments. Finally, I would like to underline the essential character of the program of options specific to remoteness and insularity (POSEI), which must not only be safeguarded, but also strengthened.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: - The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 6 July 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - As recognized in Article 349 TFEU, the outermost regions of the EU are regions with a special status, and we must therefore pursue a specific innovation policy tailored to their specific circumstances. In addition to their geostrategic significance, these regions have a number of potentials, including the proper use of renewable energy sources, the blue economy, research and development and tourism. Sustainable development in the regions concerned must be promoted, long-term investment is needed, traditional sectors must be modernized, local production must be supported and made more competitive, and more jobs must be created, especially for young people. Digital coverage as well as international infrastructure accessibility also contribute to raising local living standards. In addition to the above, it is essential to make further investment in maritime and ocean affairs, to continue the successful POSEI program, and to prevent agreements with third countries that reduce market sharing and competitiveness, as well as the monopoly of large monopolies. In addition to the role played by the Union, there is a clear need for the Member States concerned to take responsibility. Thank you for your attention!

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - There is no doubt that cohesion policy is of particular importance for the outermost regions and therefore a differentiated and coordinated approach is needed that will take into account their uniqueness in the implementation of European policies. The economic and social situation of the outermost regions requires coordinated and effective strategies to enable them to move closer to the average European level of development. In terms of agricultural policy, product differentiation can further stimulate and encourage local food production, processing and marketing, thus helping to reduce the disparities that exist between the outermost regions and other EU regions. In addition, within the Program of Opportunities for Remote and Island Areas - POSEI, the flexibility given to Member States in defining the program is crucial. However, it is crucial that the strategies, on the one hand, take into account the specific needs of the Member States and, on the other hand, respect the overarching objectives of the Union. In this context, I believe that cohesion policy needs to be strengthened in order to strengthen the economic, social and sustainable development of the outermost regions.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing. - The needs of the outermost regions have been under consideration in the European Union for several years. However, too little attention is still paid to them, and the methods used vary greatly depending on the various aspects considered by the European Commission's directorates-general. This creates shortcomings in the coherence of legislation, which are the direct reasons for the lack of cooperation between the EU and the outermost countries. Thus, the report in question rightly included an appeal calling on the Commission, the Council, the Member States concerned and the outermost regions to work together to ensure greater integration for these countries, taking full account of their specific characteristics and needs. We should find specific solutions to the problems in each case in order to ensure that all countries have access to all the European Union's horizontal programs. Particular attention should be paid to agricultural policy. In remote countries, we should do more to promote agricultural diversification, with special regard to the so-called traditional agricultural sectors, especially within the framework of the common market organization. More than ever, there is a need to ensure policy coherence so that the efforts made by the various agricultural sectors in the outermost regions to modernize and increase competitiveness do not undermine free trade agreements between the European Union and third countries. Unfortunately, this happens all too often. Protecting the European agricultural market should always be our priority.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: - The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on recent forest fires in Portugal and Spain: tools and procedures for the EU's response to prevention and civil protection (2017/2753 (RSP)).

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, as you know, on 17 June, several regions in Portugal started to face massive forest fires that tragically resulted in the loss of the lives of 64 people and injured another 210. On behalf of the Commission, I would like to express my renewed condolences to the families and the loved ones of the victims and I would also like – this cannot be repeated too often – to pay tribute to the courage and the outstanding work of the brave firefighters who fought the blaze. I know about the firefighters personally. I saw them in many areas on the ground. Europe is about solidarity and I am proud that the EU could help Portugal at a time of great need. On 18 June, Portugal requested assistance through the EU Civil Protection Mechanism. The European Union responded swiftly and substantially. Within hours, France, Spain and Italy sent firefighting aircraft and firefighters. Greece and Cyprus also offered to send firefighters through our mechanism. I would like to warmly thank those countries. I would also like to thank the Portuguese authorities for publicly recognising and praising this EU assistance because in that way they communicated the EU solidarity to their citizens. In these critical times, it is our duty to make each citizen aware of what the European Union truly stands for.  Let me mention the specific assistance provided to Portugal via the EU Civil Protection Mechanism. Firstly, seven aircraft and 135 firefighters with 29 vehicles were sent to Portugal. Over a week, a total of 747 water drops   were carried out. In addition, 61 EU Copernicus satellite maps were produced to help assess the damage. Through the Emergency Response Coordination Centre (ERCC), the Commission monitored the situation around the clock and was in constant contact with the Portuguese and other Member States’ authorities. The European Union stands ready to support the response to any new forest fire emergency in the EU in the coming months.  During the recent forest fire emergency Spain too asked our ERCC for Copernicus satellite maps. Emergency management services were therefore activated. As of today, 12 maps have been produced and 14 are in the making. For the 2017 forest fire season, reinforcement measures have also been taken. Our ERCC is continuously monitoring the situation across Europe and civil protection experts from our Member States, including Spain, are working on our ERCC premises in Brussels. However, the EU has no assets of its own and no firefighting planes. We rely on our Member States to make resources available. On that point, more could be done. As the Commission pointed out in February this year in its report on progress and the remaining gaps, the aerial forest firefighting capability should be further strengthened. This is a very important point.  But the EU civil protection legislation goes beyond disaster response. As you well know as parliamentarians, it also includes disaster risk management as an equal priority. The Commission has recently produced an overview of disaster risks that the EU may face, based on the work carried out by Member States in developing national risk assessments, for it is important to have a better understanding of all disaster risks in Europe, including forest fires. As the recent tragic events have sadly demonstrated, prevention is always better than cure. The Commission provides funding for prevention and preparedness projects and exercises. Apart from these activities, the means to fight forest fires in all parts of our continent are to be improved under the annual work programme of the EU Civil Protection Mechanism. In addition, the regional funds also play an important role in addressing climate change adaptation, disaster risk prevention and management, and environmental protection in all our Member States.  Portugal  and Spain  benefit from these funds, which also cover protecting people from forest fires. Added to that, both countries receive further support through the cross-border, transnational and interregional programmes with a specific focus on forest fire protection measures.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, I requested this debate, which I immediately counted on with the support of colleagues in the REGI committee in the wake of the terrible tragedy that has plagued my country and my region. 64 people died, more than 200 were injured, and 47 lost their lives to escape the fire on a section of a national road that, curiously, was not closed to traffic. It was an unusually destructive fire, a huge catastrophe that shocked everyone immensely. It is now up to us, after the fire is extinguished and the losses have been counted, to concentrate on supporting the victims' relatives and friends, supporting the wounded and survivors and the effort to rebuild infrastructure, housing or businesses, giving hope back to those who everything lost. I therefore warn of the need for quick and simplified help to the survivors' families, workers who have lost their jobs, the companies affected and the municipalities that, due to this tragic event, have a herculean and very hard work ahead of them. difficult. It is necessary, once and for all, to make an active prevention and responsible management of forests, an adequate planning of the vegetation cover and of the uses of the soil, to elaborate the register of the rustic property, to proceed an effective valorization of the territories of the interior, concretizing the principles of economic, social and territorial cohesion, through policies against human and infrastructure desertification to which they have been subjected for some decades. Of course, it is primarily up to Portugal and the Government to act, but the European Union can help, it can help by negotiating partnership agreements, which make up part of the multiannual financial framework, namely the European structural and investment funds or even through the Juncker plan. It can promote greater coordination and coherence of forest policies, as well as allowing synergies with other sectors forest management or even information technologies.It can increase the depth of National Civil Protection action and crisis response through a European mechanism and on the European Union's emergency response to this particular fire, we have nothing to point out, having Portugal counted, as Mr.Commissioner said, with the help of several Member States, in air and human resources and we therefore have, of course, Commissioner, and so I will conclude, that we need to know what the Commission's assessment of this cooperation with the Portuguese authorities is and to know thathow and when European aid will take place under the Solidarity Fund and the new rules on the Regional Development Fund, as losses amount to around 500 million euros according to government estimates.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, this debate is very timely, not only for Portugal and Spain, but for the entire European Union. European emergency response mechanisms worked. The necessary funds will be made available, covering 95% of the identified property losses. Today, this Parliament approved the strengthening of the solidarity fund. However, the scale of the tragedies and the climatic phenomena that have made them devastating, from a human and heritage point of view, demonstrate, Commissioner, that the level of risk has risen and it is necessary to prepare for another level of response. Yes, Commissioner, the European Union has done a lot, but it must be prepared to do more in the future. Security and defense today cover areas that go well beyond traditional areas. Combating terrorism and the effects of climate change are two new challenges that require joint work by the European Union, joint work in responding to the emergency in which the available means and the readiness to act must be reinforced, but also, and above all, to work together in cooperation to prevent and recover the economic and social fabric and the destroyed heritage. The creation of a permanent European mechanism, with its own resources for the prevention and response to natural disasters, will also allow a process of shared learning. May the fires that have occurred in Portugal and Spain, Commissioner, help us to quickly create these new capacities for action.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, the forest fire that broke out in Pedrógão Grande, Portugal, about three weeks ago, which resulted in the death of 64 people, most of whom were inside their cars, on a public road, while fleeing the flames. , challenges us all in the deepest dimension of the sense of political responsibility. How was this possible in the 21st century in a European Union country? And almost a month later, Portugal has not yet been clarified about what actually happened, what failed to prevent and combat this tragedy. We only know that successive Portuguese governments have transformed the country into an immense eucalyptus. Portugal is today, in Europe, the country of eucalyptus. We also know that the various bodies created to manage forests and to prevent and fight fires have not come to terms with each other and have completely failed and that the emergency communications system, acquired a few years ago by hundreds of millions of euros, has also failed because did not work. Anyway, we know that the Portuguese State failed in its most elementary functions and as if to demonstrate this failure about fifteen days after this tragedy, large quantities of war weaponry, including powerful explosive devices and grenade launchers were stolen from a military establishment due to unacceptable and evident security flaws and in the midst of this widespread irresponsibility, the Prime Minister of Portugal went on vacation and handed over the responsibility of his Government to his subordinate.

name: João FERREIRA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, in the report we voted on this morning on the Budget negotiations, we appreciate the fact that it was possible to include the proposal we made to reinforce the Solidarity Fund, taking into account the brutal fires that swept the center of Portugal. We underline the need for something that we have long advocated: the modification of the Fund's mobilization rules, ensuring a more flexible, timely mobilization and covering a broader range of disasters. In the face of the tragedy in Portugal, it is necessary to reach out to the victims, support the populations and restore the productive potential of the affected areas. But more is needed. In 2010, this Parliament passed a resolution, of which I was rapporteur, on a community approach to disaster prevention. Seven years later, almost everything remains to be done. I highlight the proposal to create an appropriate financial framework for disaster prevention capable of financing actions in areas such as forestry planning or the maintenance of agricultural activity in areas affected by depopulation, among many other proposals. Commissioner, it is time for the European Commission to look closely at these recommendations and act accordingly.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, first of all I want to convey my condolences for the human losses in the fires in Portugal. There, and in Spain, the causes of these superfires are quite clear: climate change, at the origin of the drought and extreme temperatures; the monoculture of eucalyptus and pine, many benefits for the wood industry but a box of matches for our mountains; urban speculation and the lack of spatial planning, reinforcing the danger for local populations; and the abandonment of the forest, where "development" today rhymes with "rural depopulation." Instead, we need something else: reorder the territory; prioritize investments in high fire risk areas and greater prevention through the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development; centrally integrate climate change into fire prevention and sustainable forest management; and, above all, rethinking the common agricultural policy to close the page on monoculture and open that of a diverse and ecological agroforestry model, with jobs, wealth and life in the rural world.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: - Madam President, the fire has frightened an entire country: Portugal. The flames not only devastated more than 40,000 hectares, but also took - and this is the worst - the lives of 64 people; later, in Spain, he isolated entire towns. The tragedies were not greater thanks to the firefighters, forest agents and other professionals who risked their lives to save others. I remember the photo of those exhausted firefighters after spending the whole night fighting the fire: their sacrifice portrays the basis of the European Union, which is solidarity. Europe is solidarity in pain, but also in hope. Europe is that outstretched hand that, with regional development funds, helps the peoples who need it most. Europe was with Italy in the earthquakes, and Europe will be with Portugal and also with Spain, even more so because in June we approved the report that allows additional aid to be given to countries affected by natural disasters. This decision will make Europe finance reconstruction work at 95%, that is, twice as much as before. Each year the Solidarity Fund can mobilize 500 million to give flexibility and help those affected in emergency situations. That is why it is so important that Brexit does not take a single euro from regional funds and the CAP. And, Commissioner, summer has just begun. In the towns of Spain he gets up early to pick up dry branches, which would be the fuel for any fire; Here we must continue working to stop rural depopulation, to give opportunities to those who want to return to the countryside, because the aridity that attracts flames is fought by repopulating remote places, promoting sustainable agriculture. The roadmap is clear: active prevention, awareness and effective forest management. In the last fifteen years, 250,000 fires burned 1,700,000 hectares in Spain. You will understand, Madam President, that our concern is real.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: - Madam President, first of all I want to show my solidarity with Portugal, especially with its victims; of course, to recognize the effectiveness of all the troops that participated in the suppression of the fire that devastated the Iberian Peninsula —Portugal and Spain— between June 17 and 24. And it is that there was one of the most devastating fires that are remembered in recent decades and that affected, specifically in Spain, an area of ​​special environmental protection, such as Doñana, with more than 190,000 hectares protected and belonging to the Natura 2000 Network. The origin, the same: climate change and, after all, the heat wave that hit the Iberian Peninsula; climate change as one of the greatest challenges that humanity faces today and that the European Union must prevent and combat, also with specific actions when these circumstances occur. Therefore, we ask that the Solidarity Fund be taken into account as regions neighboring Spain and Portugal and that this disaster be compensated, specifically in the case of Doñana, due to the high socioeconomic value of the area. Also, in the medium and long term, that the Solidarity Fund be modified to take into account these areas of special environmental protection, such as those that belong to the Natura Network, as well as that the economic criteria are better adapted to the real wealth of the region rather than the volume of GDP, because populated regions or large regions may actually have difficulty accessing these types of funds, despite their real wealth. In short, coherence between the policies and actions of the European Union in environmental policy. The environment must be provided with sufficient resources to be able to preserve it. Specifically, the Natura Network has only the LIFE program, which barely covers 20% of the financing that these types of areas need for their conservation and maintenance.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: - Madam President, Mr Ruas, Mr Marinho, Mr Ferreira, Mr Zorrinho, first of all, our embrace to you as representatives of the Portuguese and a hug to those families that I hope you will properly serve. There is a legend - I don't know if in Portugal, but in Spain - that says that the Greek Strabo wrote that a squirrel could travel the Iberian Peninsula without getting out of the trees. First, it could no longer; and, second, the squirrel would not have gone through pines and eucalyptus trees, with which Spain and Portugal have been dangerously repopulated: when they burn, they kill, generating unprecedented tragedies like the ones we are now deploring. And there is the slow death of the land, which has eroded and degraded the environment for decades, and also the drought. The forests in Spain and Portugal are not clean and there is no policy for cleaning forests and mountains that works. Around 90% of the Union funds destined for forests come from the European Rural Development Fund - it is true - and there are funds in the Natura Network and in the Water Framework Directive, but we do not have a European prevention policy that distinguishes vulnerabilities. The south and the Mediterranean are burning and there are human tragedies. We therefore need a forest policy focused on prevention, on good practices, on strategies, on political and financial instruments, to avoid tragedies, starting today.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, we are witnessing a tragedy in Portugal that has taken so many lives. Honoring the lives of these people and their families and those people who have lost everything is doing everything that has to be done. The European Union has a budget dedicated to the prevention mechanism in its budget. In Portugal, the most urgent fire prevention measure is to register the forest. It is an urgency that can save lives and until the registration is done there is no forest management that can be effective. As always we have a problem: it is very expensive. That is why I ask you, Commissioner, is the Commission available for the Portuguese Government to make an extraordinary expenditure in this area, with the maximum possible co-participation? Is the Commission available to ensure that this extraordinary expenditure is not accounted for in the deficit? Please answer, Commissioner. Prevention is the best medicine, but Brussels has to help, it cannot extend one hand and withdraw with the other, as it has done in recent years.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: – Madam President, it is exactly as Mr Ruas has already said, that, when we immediately debated this tragedy in the Committee on Regional Affairs, we also said we have to be efficient in our support. Let me touch on a couple of things the Commissioner also said about it.  It is very important that we have recently changed the regulations so that we can use the regional funds, the Regional Development Fund, and this means that for Portugal, if you look into the figures, we have some EUR 500 million available – if the Member State asks for it, and there are 12 weeks for documented requests to come in, also for the Solidarity Fund that we revised in 2014 and that is now under revision in the omnibus, to make it even better, to take these two possibilities together to have a vast support for people [now] and also for the future.  This is combining help on one hand, for emergencies as the Commissioner said, and prevention for the future. There can be a combination of those tools. It is not just this debate that we say is important, but also the question for the Commissioner to act immediately when the request of the Member State comes, because we are ready to help and to show our solidarity in concrete matters. So it is good that we are here, and also that we stand there in solidarity for other situations which we hope do not occur during the summer.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, the fires in Portugal last month will remain part of the collective memory as one of the greatest national tragedies. It has already been said, 64 people died and more than two hundred were injured. Total or partial damage to housing is equivalent to 28 million euros, 31 million in losses for the economic activities of that region, 21 million euros in losses for agricultural activities, 22 in infrastructure and municipal equipment. We have almost two hundred million direct losses, not counting indirect ones. This took place in an area of ​​the interior of the country that is sometimes outside our concerns, the aging of the population and the abandonment of the territory, a region that is the best justification for the existence of a strong and effective cohesion policy. Portugal will use the European solidarity fund, but it would be good if there was a greater allocation of this fund and the rules for its flexible mobilization were adapted. Portugal is still in mourning and thanks the European solidarity and that of its European partners.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: - Madam President, first of all I want to send my memory, solidarity and support to the brotherly people of Portugal, in these difficult times. It is going to be more and more frequent that we are faced with heat waves and greater fire risks, in the context of climate change in which we are, especially in southern Europe. Let's be clear that fire fighting operations, unfortunately, are going to be exceeded many times; That is why it is necessary to focus not only on prevention plans —which, by the way, are often not followed—, but also on proper land management. Because, in the first place, the mountains, so that they do not burn, you need to take care of them and, to take care of the mountains, you need people who inhabit the rural world. Secondly, combating the serious environmental problem that we are having is also combating the problem of cultivating species such as eucalyptus, which has already seen in Portugal what it is capable of doing. In Spain, environmental reports already warned five years ago, but it seems that the alarms continue to fall on deaf ears. Meanwhile, the fire business continues to make a minority rich, in exchange for privatization of fire fighting services and in exchange for the workers who risk their lives defending the mountains often earn less than 600 euros.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the statistics tell us that in the European Union the casualties caused by a disaster are decreasing, while the material damage is substantially increasing. But these statistics are not enough for us when we see what happened in Portugal: what happened in Portugal tells us that we must do more and that we must do better. The Commission's report, which highlighted both the progress and the gaps, tells us that we need to work to fill these gaps. You, dear Commissioner, are right when you say that Europe means solidarity. Europe means solidarity, and we must work for this. We had just included prevention as a new chapter in the new European civil protection mechanism, but we must work more on this prevention, we must work on culture, because citizens often do not know how to react in the face of disasters. We need to create a culture of prevention, of self-protection, starting with schools, even with small things: in California, for example, people have a poster on their doorstep where there are instructions on how to behave in the face of a catastrophe, a danger event in any case. Parliament was decisive in the last legislature. We will still be at your side to do what we can to build this Europe that pleases the citizens.

name: Nuno MELO
text: - Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the countries that helped Portugal in such a difficult time, Greece, France, Spain, Italy and Cyprus. I would also like to say a word of thanks also to the brother people of Timor, who exactly on the other side of the world, despite their equally difficult circumstances, approved aid of US $ 1.5 million in favor of Portugal. I would like to leave a word to the Portuguese firefighters who make their sacrifice every day help everyone else and I would like to underline, in relation to the President of the Commission, that it is not enough for us to debate the issue of global warming, which is real, we need a European forestry policy adapted to the needs of each country in Europe, especially the countries of southern Europe, those most affected by climate issues and those that least contribute to the worsening of their phenomenon. This is the final word that I would like to leave to the Commissioner, I am sure that, due to his nationality, he will continue to take this concern into account.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, first of all, I would like to add myself to the memory of all the victims of the fires of weeks ago, as well as to thank the work of the Italian, French and Spanish firefighters who joined their Portuguese colleagues in the fight against the fire. I would also like to thank you, Commissioner, for your prompt response in putting all possible means to help in this fight. Burning forests are victims of climate change, but they are, in fact, also causing, in their own way, climate change. An example: in Spain, between 2005 and 2015, fires emitted 15 million tons of CO2. For this reason, our attitude cannot be passive regarding the situation of southern European forests: they are very different forests from those of the north; Therefore, they need a different, much more active management that keeps the forest clean and its surroundings inhabited. The Mediterranean forest is not a simple tree plantation. We need to equip ourselves with a much more ambitious and adapted forestry strategy that is an obstacle to fire, one more instrument in the fight against climate change, and thus prevents our forests from being pure fuel for fires that, as has already been said, raise our emissions and attack our future. Let us work more on a day-to-day basis, preventively - you said, Commissioner - so that the Commission and Member State services in matters of emergencies are alert, but not working.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, on Saturday, June 17, Portugal experienced a brutal tragedy resulting from a forest fire. 64 people died. It is not acceptable, it is not normal. Commissioner, I would like to highlight your readiness and commitment. The government's request to activate the European Union's civil protection mechanism only took place on Sunday, the 18th. But 60 minutes after the request, there were already planes en route to Portugal. The Government of Portugal must use the Structural Funds, which can go at a co-financing rate of 95%, and the Rural Development Fund for the recovery of damages. I am talking about more than EUR 26 billion available. The Commission, Parliament and the Council must quickly mobilize the Solidarity Fund. It is time to rebuild and help the affected populations, but it is also time to learn and do everything to prevent tragedies of this type and in matters of fire, this is the responsibility of each Government. Finally, a message of solidarity to all those affected and a word of thanks to the courage of the Portuguese firefighters.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I begin by welcoming the brave and courageous Portuguese and Spanish firefighters. The fires that devastated Portugal last month were particularly dramatic and my country continues to burn, just like it does every year around this time. For a century Portugal was one of the countries where the forest grew the most. But because this growth was at the expense of a wrong reforestation policy, which replaced native species with the disorderly planting of monocultures of eucalyptus and maritime pine, Portugal was also one of the countries that most forest destroyed in the last 25 years. Every year, in the face of these tragedies, we hear the same speech in Portugal, the same promises and justifications, but the truth is that governments succeed each other, the wrong policies remain the same and in the end the drama of the victims is always the same: deaths, loss of entire working lives and irreparable environmental damage. In April, we approved the release of 3.9 million euros for the reconstruction of the areas affected by the fires of August 2016 in Madeira. The scale of the Pedrógão Grande and Gois tragedy, which caused 200 injuries, the death of 64 people and losses of 400 million euros makes it urgent to make the European Solidarity Fund more quickly available. That is what the Portuguese expect from Europe and that is what Europe owes its citizens.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, this is a tragedy of enormous proportions, which I think drew the sympathy of all Europeans and, indeed, people worldwide. It is only when you know somebody involved that it really comes home to you. The day before the tragedy in Portugal I met people on the European Union Interreg programme in my home town of Killarney, and the following day I heard that the entire family of one of the ladies on that programme had been wiped out. So obviously it is rather chilling to be aware of that, and it is so important as well that the European Union should show solidarity with these people, and indeed those who suffer from all types of tragedies, especially when caused by climate change. That is something we are trying to deal with. Mr van Nistelrooij’s point about the Solidarity Fund both to help in the immediate aftermath and also to help with prevention in the future, especially in relation to forest fires, is very important.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: - The Pedrógão Grande fire was a tragedy in human lives, as has already been said here. In the agricultural sector, losses are estimated at over 20 million euros. The Portuguese Government responded immediately and the affected farmers will be able to apply for compensation. It has become clear that European disaster response funds are essential and should now be applied in cooperation with local authorities. The Commission also responded quickly to the request for assistance through its civil protection mechanism. The Member States of the Union helped. These supports were vital. Although nobody can guarantee what motivated the ignition, the fact is that the extreme weather conditions present in Pedrógão, with humidity below 30%, temperatures above forty degrees and winds above fifty kilometers per hour, are conditions that we cannot decouple from global climate change. It happened in Pedrógão and will happen elsewhere in southern Europe. We must prepare ourselves in solidarity as Europeans.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, we extend our deepest condolences to the families of the victims of the devastating fires in Portugal. At the same time, we express our solidarity with the Portuguese people, but also with the people of Spain. The catastrophic fires give the opportunity to discuss again what should be the policy of the European Union, because we had catastrophic fires last year in Cyprus and Greece. Even now, right now, we have catastrophic fires in Mani and Crete, and I think the debate highlights the tools we need to use. Firstly, the new regulation through the support of the European Regional Development Fund is important. Secondly, the support from the Solidarity Fund, but here we must point out that, unfortunately, in order for this fund to be activated, the damage must be enormous and we must find other arrangements. I agree with the proposal; the costs of repairing the damage in Portugal, but also in other countries, should not be taken into account in the deficit regulated by the Draconian Stability Pact.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I too would like to express my deepest condolences to my Portuguese colleagues on the deaths of the recent fires and my sympathy for the injured. These fires have brought to the surface another serious problem that we will face in the coming years, especially in the European South. We know that climate change has increased drought and temperatures and created winds in many areas. This, combined with the fact that many citizens are building houses in or near forests without taking the necessary protection measures, unfortunately sets the stage for other such tragedies in the future. This must be avoided. All states must be aware of how fires must be dealt with, how they must be prevented, and when they do occur, they must cooperate by immediately sending firefighters and firefighters to deal with them. Forests are very important for the survival of the planet and we must protect them.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: - Madam President, I want to begin by expressing my regret at the death of 64 people and solidarity with the other victims. I am grateful for the prompt response from the European Commission and the support of colleagues in the face of a tragedy that cannot happen again. There is no effective fire prevention system in forests if they are not part of a forestry strategy, based on time, which projects the future and contributes to rural development. This is not done in a month. Member States are responsible for enhancing European support for rural development and especially for basic services and village renovation, reforestation and improving the viability of forests and preventing and repairing damage caused to forests by fires and other disasters , highlighting European support for the creation and maintenance of protective infrastructures, the promotion of local fire prevention activities, including the use of animals after grazing and the creation and improvement of forest fire control structures. Finally, I would like to express my great appreciation for the work and dedication of the Portuguese firefighters.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - On June 17, a national tragedy of 64 dead, to whom I pay tribute, as I pay tribute to our firefighters and to all those who worked to minimize the damage. We appreciate the prompt support from the Commissioner and other European partners, from the Spanish firefighters in particular, but we need more European support, because there are problems beyond the prevention of catastrophes of this type that have to do with structuring issues of land management. our territory, for the ordering of our forests, to prevent depopulation of the interior of the country because otherwise this type of forest fires is not combated and especially when we live the impact of climate change. We need support to reorganize our Civil Protection, to coordinate the forests, the national territory, we need support to not continue to buy equipment that later does not work, in contracts that are otherwise corrupt, we need the European Union to help us do that do not continue and we absolutely need, in addition to strengthening the European Solidarity Fund, that the national investment to be made in this reorganization effort does not count towards the capacities of the Portuguese State to react to a tragedy of this nature.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: I would like to explain here that, in the face of this human disaster, I have been a little more generous with speaking times.I hope that the colleagues who will get an answer later are not angry because of this.(End of the catch-the-eye procedure)

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much for this very interesting debate, for your constructive intervention, for your suggestions in all aspects of this very sad situation. It definitely comes at a very crucial time.  We already recognise that Europe faces numerous natural disasters; some may be predicted or anticipated while others come as a surprise. You already mentioned about the impact of the climate change, but regardless of any criticisms I would like to remind you, and myself of course, that the European Union remains the most pioneering political organisation across the world regarding climate change, and is definitely against new approaches by the new administration of the USA.  It is quite important for us to recognise this in order to show that, as Europeans, we remain very committed in this very difficult political landscape about climate change. And for this reason we must stand ready to help when there are surprises in many areas, in particular in the south of Europe. We cannot predict when forest fires will break out and when spring comes we know that sooner or later they will indeed break out. This is the destiny of some areas.  As I said, the actions taken to respond to the forest fires that broke out in Portugal in June and took so many human lives are a clear example of EU solidarity. I followed all the actions, I followed all the activities by our Member States and by our ERCC. We have here the director of this coordination centre, and I would like to say thanks for your commitment because, as I said, I followed moment by moment, minute by minute and I saw that yes, the European Union’s Civil Protection Mechanism is the manifestation of a tangible solidarity on the ground. It is very critical to recognise and to realise this in order to achieve more through this mechanism.  Definitely, the Commission will continue work to fight all emergencies, but also to prevent new ones. In fact, the work of the Commission goes well beyond pure response to disasters. We need to anticipate through our actions, to prevent future catastrophes and, as I said, prevention is better than cure. This is why we focus on prevention and preparedness. Of course a lot of other policies and actions have to be there in practice, but in our competence there is only this mechanism, and in some other areas you know from our Treaties they are national competences. It is as simple as that.  This is our structure and I think it is difficult to change this structure in this framework, particularly in the current times. In this respect I would like to stress again that the European emergency response capacity, the so-called voluntary pool, is composed of civil protection assets in expertise from our Member States that are put at the disposal of other Member States affected by a disaster. It is real example of tangible EU solidarity and this solidarity comes when it really, really matters. As the saying goes, actions speak louder than words. I am convinced that we as Europeans can be proud of putting theory into practice. We can be proud of exercising solidarity to help fellow European citizens when they need it to save lives. Improving our response capacity should be our ultimate goal for the benefit of all those who may need help one day.  Some specific answers: Mr van Nistelrooij and Mr Kelly have already spoken about our ability through the Solidarity Fund. I am sure that you know that the national authorities need to apply for this Fund’s support and provide an assessment of the damage, and then the Commission reviews the application and determines if EU support could be activated and for what amount and specifically, I think 12 weeks after. Portugal, maybe you know, has received since 2003 through this Solidarity Fund, including for the forest fires on Madeira last summer, around EUR 80 million, so the Solidarity Fund has already been activated about this request.  It is quite important to recognise that the south of Europe is more sensitive as a region for forest fires and this is why my intention as Commissioner responsible for the ERCC and the Civil Protection Mechanism is to see more improvements in our action through this mechanism, but you know that we need some new legislation or some amendments. I would like to sit together to exchange views on how to increase our cooperation and to see how this mechanism can be more effective and efficient.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: - That closes the debate.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - The fires that have ravaged the Doñana Natural Park and central Portugal highlight the vulnerability of Mediterranean countries to the risk of fires in the summer season, which is aggravated by the drought in the south of the Iberian Peninsula. The EU has a civil protection mechanism to assist countries during catastrophes together with the EU Solidarity Fund, which compensates for damages starting from a minimum limit, calculated on the basis of a percentage of GDP. This method penalizes large and populated regions, which may find it difficult to access this funding. For this reason, it would be convenient to take into account the per capita income, which is a better reflection of the real economy. Although the priority of the fund must be humanitarian catastrophes and those in which human life is affected, as has been the case in Portugal, damage to the environment and specially protected spaces must also have their place. Doñana belongs to the Natura 2000 Network, but this specificity does not contemplate specific actions with specific funding nor is it recognized as such in the European Solidarity Fund.
