name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - Considering the seriousness of what happened in Portugal and the Galician experience of years suffering the scourge of fires in which, in addition to the known impacts, we also had to regret the loss of human life during the extinction operations: It is time to end the model forest based on pines and monoculture of eucalyptus, extended continuously over kilometers and with rural, urban nuclei and roads surrounded by pyrophytes; without forgetting the depletion of waters caused by eucalyptus. We demand that eucalyptus be declared an invasive species and that the institutions act accordingly. Another contributing factor is the years and years of agrarian policies that cause the abandonment of agriculture and, with that, the abandonment of the rural environment. Experience shows that an orderly, well-managed territory, with farmers settled in the territory, taking care of the environment through the production of food is essential so that when there is a fire, it does not spread. It is also necessary, especially in the Galician case, to end the culture of the fire business, consolidating a public fire-extinguishing service. We must end these workers' insecurity and insecurity and dignify the profession of firefighter and forest firefighter.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Michael Theurer, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a Council directive on procedures for the settlement of double taxation disputes in the European Union (COM (2016) 0686 - C8-0035/ 2017 - 2016/0338 (CNS)) (A8-0225 / 2017).

name: Michael THEURER
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, I would like to thank my fellow shadow rapporteurs very much for this constructive and intensive cooperation on this report. We found good compromises. At this point and at a late hour in this House we are raising an important issue that affects many companies, but also private citizens in Europe, namely the issue of double taxation. In various committees, the main thing we have done here is to close tax loopholes, that is, to eliminate aggressive tax avoidance models because we do not accept that ordinary people pay their taxes, but large international corporations do not. At the same time, however, it is also important to this House that taxes on the same income or on the same capital do not have to be paid twice. So we do not want either double non-taxation or double taxation, and against this background we expressly welcome the initiative of the European Commission to present a legislative proposal on this. In doing so, the Commission also complied with a resolution of the European Parliament from July 2016. In it, the European Parliament stated that a clear time frame for dispute settlement mechanisms is the key to increasing the effectiveness of the current system. The arbitration convention was difficult to achieve as a compromise between the member states. It is now to be replaced by the new proposal from the European Commission. So much to praise the Commission, so much we regret that the Council, which is not present for the debate tonight, has not waited for the official approval of our report here in the European Parliament. The Council has already completed its decision-making process. At this point we want to express our displeasure bring. We believe that, even if the European Parliament does not require its consent, it would have been a matter of courtesy to wait for our deliberations to end, and we ask the Bureau of the House to express this to the Council. The main subject of the report is that we want to improve the dispute settlement procedures, which have so far been inefficient. We want to achieve legal certainty. The 10.5 billion euros - which is at issue at the moment, in over 900 cases, show that this is not a small sum, it can happen to taxpayers that they do not receive any binding information with their tax return if they are in several European countries Union operate. We want legal certainty here, we want a procedure that ensures that citizens do not have to bring long-term legal disputes at high costs. It is therefore good that there is a specific proposal that now obliges the Member States to set up a dispute settlement procedure for their citizens. Personally, I would have liked to have set up a permanent committee here, so that experts from the tax administrations would have been permanently assigned by the Member States. Unfortunately, the other groups were unable to make up their minds on this, but at least we have submitted a joint proposal which means that the deadlines that are now contained in the Council proposal should be significantly reduced again: one year instead of two years, six instead of one year Months. So we want the citizen to receive information more quickly as to whether his complaint will be accepted at all and whether it is justified. Because we consider it completely unacceptable if taxpayers and companies have to wait for years until they receive an explanation as to whether their complaint against double taxation is legally binding or not - so here is a complete one a clear plea for legal certainty and transparency.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, on behalf of my dear colleague Pierre Moscovici, I would like to thank the rapporteur, the shadow rapporteurs and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) for their high-quality report and their very constructive and comprehensive work on the Directive on Tax Dispute Resolution Mechanisms. This directive is yet another building block in the Commission’s action towards a fairer, more efficient, more competitive and at the same time, more transparent corporate tax system in the EU. Whilst proposing stricter rules against tax avoidance and ensuring that taxes are paid where profits are generated, the Commission is also very much concerned about providing legal certainty for taxpayers and ensuring that when they operate cross-border they pay taxes on their income and capital only once, not twice. Double taxation occurs when two or more countries claim the right to tax the same income or profits of a company. There are estimated to be around 900 double taxation disputes ongoing in the EU today between Member States, under the current dispute resolution mechanisms, mainly dealing with transfer pricing issues. Double taxation is a serious obstacle to cross-border investment in our single market, leading to uncertainty and discouraging cross-border trade. Under the existing procedures, unresolved double taxation disputes between Member States represents EUR 10 billion in the EU. From an investor’s perspective, robust, reliable and stable procedures and predictable behaviour on the part of tax administrations as regards eliminating double taxation are important factors for doing business in a country. To remedy the current situation, the directive provides for mandatory and binding dispute resolution mechanisms with clear timelines and an obligation to reach results. It significantly improves the existing mechanisms for resolving disputes between Member States. The text allows for a ‘mutual agreement procedure’ to be initiated by the taxpayer, under which Member States must reach an agreement within a set deadline. If the procedure fails, an arbitration procedure is launched to resolve the dispute within specified timelines. The directive is also a direct response to the calls of this House included, for example, in the ECON resolution from December 2015, known as TAXE, and its TAXE II resolution of July 2016. ECON’s report highlights some key elements of efficiency and effectiveness, such as setting ambitious timelines, ensuring independence of the members of the arbitration commission, deciding on disputed cases and enhancing transparency. As regards timelines, setting up ambitious time limits had to be balanced against the international environment and the procedures set out in tax treaties. Other elements, such as the increased number of cases, fostering the capacities of tax administration, as well as business realities and the global tax environment, involving more complicated and sophisticated cases, were also considered. As far as independence of the members of the arbitration commission is concerned, the Commission recognises the high importance of the issue. That is why we are fully committed to ensuring the right balance between the criteria of independence and integrity towards competence of the independent person, given the increased complexity and sophistication of the cases involved. With regard to increasing transparency, the publication of a summary of each decision on disputed cases, is regarded as highly beneficial. Furthermore, the Commission has also ensured that taxpayers’ rights and obligations throughout the procedure are significantly improved. Finally, the directive ensures that the mechanisms do not result in double non-taxation situations. If the affected taxpayer cannot prove that there is double taxation, Member States can decide to deny access to the procedure. I count on Parliament’s full support for this important file, so that we can continue delivering our ambitious agenda for a competitive and growth-driven tax environment; full speed ahead! The most crucial imminent steps in this regard are: the introduction of a common consolidated corporate tax base (CCCTB). The CCCTB is exactly the fair, efficient and competitive corporate tax system that the EU desperately needs – now and for the future. First, because the CCCTB will create a simpler, more stable and more attractive environment for businesses and investors inside Europe. Second, it will encourage growth-friendly business activities and will boost the competitiveness of the EU as a whole. And finally, the CCCTB will make corporate taxation fairer and more efficient. It is the ultimate tool for combating tax avoidance.

name: Neena GILL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, fair taxation is at the core of our agenda on jobs and growth. That means closing loopholes exploited by large companies to avoid paying their fair share, but also ensuring that we address anomalies like double taxation, which disproportionately affect small— and medium—sized companies who often end up footing the bill twice when they are doing business cross-border. For many SMEs this uncertainty keeps them from taking the leap towards supplying their goods and services across borders. This is where the European Union has tremendous added value.  The directive being voted on tomorrow will speed up procedures to settle tax disputes, reduce compliance costs and administrative burdens. We have managed to halve the timescale to align the process with the annual business and investment cycle. The next step, of course, is to ensure we fully implement a common consolidated corporate tax base that will prevent double taxation being charged in the first place. Let this be a strong message to those who doubt the EU’s key role in cutting red tape and making cross—border business a possibility for all. My congratulations to the rapporteur, Michael Theurer, on achieving this goal.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, the avoidance of double taxation is an important goal. It is also justified to resolve the related disputes as effectively as possible. In this respect, the new directive is a clear step forward. On the surface, the wording of the amendments adopted by Parliament is good and improves on the Commission's original proposal. The only thing I am concerned about is the reduced processing times in Parliament. The initial deadlines proposed by the Commission were in line with the impact assessment of the Directive. Some of the changes to the timetable made by Parliament are much stricter than the times considered realistic by this impact assessment. The impact assessment states how "the increase and complexity of cross-border value chains and business models can only lead to an increase in processing times." For this reason, I myself would have been in favor of keeping processing times closer to those proposed by the Commission. Now there is a danger that decisions will become hasty, which would not serve anyone.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, ending corporate tax evasion should be a priority for the Commission and governments. Large European companies carry out practices of erosion of the tax base and transfer of prices to pay taxes in the countries with the lowest rates. This is one of the main problems of European taxation, and not the double taxation that this report is about. Because we all know that the problem is that large companies do not pay taxes; and not that they pay them in two countries. We consider secrecy to be out of place in international tax cases, and publication is in the general interest. That is why we have tabled amendments in this regard. It is not understandable that a company has up to three years to claim an alleged case of double taxation and that, however, the State has only one year to examine this case. We need to give more time and resources to the tax inspectors, who are like David before the Goliath of the big corporations. Finally, we reject the idea of ​​guaranteeing impunity for tax crimes when there are open double taxation disputes. This is inadmissible. Let's stop being hypocritical. Our speech cannot be a supposed fight against tax evasion, while we legislate precisely to favor the interests of multinationals and corporate power, at the expense of the social rights of the peoples of Europe. By the way, that this document, that this report, has already been approved by the Council, without having passed through Parliament, that the Council is not here and that not even the Economy Commissioner is there, that is a mockery of the Parliament.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank Mr. Theurer for his good collaboration on this dossier and for being open to our proposals, such as, for example, that in the arbitration phase the committee that has to manage this phase is composed of integrity and independent experts, as we recommended that they be even officials of the tax agencies - which seemed better to us - as well as the idea that the European Commission has the capacity to make an assessment on the independent representatives on the panels. I also want to announce that we will vote in favor of the GUE / NGL Group amendments for greater transparency in the case of the conclusion of arbitration cases. But I want to end by addressing the Council. Point one: that they have closed the dossier without waiting for the consultation, as many of the colleagues have said, is a real joke; and above that they are not here ... I prefer to save the comment. And second: how quickly these dossiers that favor the activity of the companies close and how much it costs in the Council to obtain fiscal transparency, minimum common taxable base, etc., etc. I really wish the Council had another attitude, because that attitude is ridiculous.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, it’s a funny old world, isn’t it? On the one hand, we have people who pay little or no tax and, on the other hand, we are talking tonight about people who are subject to double taxation. Thankfully, both the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs – and colleagues here like Mr Theurer – and the Commission are beginning to come to grips with it. That is the way it should be. We passed legislation yesterday on tax avoidance and country—by—country reporting, which will help to close the loopholes allowing big multinationals to escape paying most of the tax they should have paid – and that is good. But, equally importantly, people should not be paying more tax than they are due to pay. It is rather extreme that there is EUR 10.5 billion in dispute at the moment and 900 cases, but I think we are beginning to move in the right direction on this. The Commission has come forward with a proposal which everybody accepts is good. That should be promoted because it shows that the European Union is trying to be fair to everybody, and rightly so. So well done, Commissioner.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, we have followed the processes by which multinationals try to evade and evade taxes through triangular relations, and that is the dominant element that our Parliament should be concerned with. On the other hand, of course, it should be specified that multinationals will pay taxes where they generate profits. Of course, this does not mean that taxes should be levied twice, so double taxation procedures should apply. I would like to point out to the rapporteur and the Commissioner that we must also look at the case of natural persons, because so many thousands of our fellow citizens have migrated from the countries of the South to other regions. More than 400,000 young scientists have emigrated from Greece and all of them face double taxation problems. You should also look at the issue of going to court. In Greece, in order to appeal to the tax courts, one has to pay 30% of the claim that exists from the state and this is something that does not facilitate the administration of justice.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, tax certainty, fairness and transparency will improve the functioning of the internal market and benefit investment and trade in the EU. Parliament has already focused on this, and I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on this very important report. At the same time, the swift resolution of disputes and the obligation to remove double taxation within a set time frame are crucial to position the EU at the forefront of developments in this area. This directive aims to create a coordinated common framework and the same level playing field for businesses in the Union, both big and small. And this amounts to our efforts to create a fair and effective corporate tax system in the EU, and also to tax fairness in general, since not only business, but also individuals, will benefit from the new rules. Creating a better way to solve double taxation disputes is only one additional step on the long road towards an improved tax system in the EU. More needs to be done to achieve our objective, we have all recognised this already. And your full support will be needed to provide companies through Europe with a common consolidated corporate tax base and a modern VAT system.

name: Michael THEURER
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President! First of all, I, as the Taxe 1 and 2 Special Rapporteurs, welcome the fact that you have reaffirmed the need for binding tax rules to stop aggressive tax avoidance. In particular, the GKKB / GKB is crucial. The debate here has shown that, above all, small and medium-sized enterprises suffer from double taxation and that it is therefore necessary for the functioning and fair competition to put the dispute settlement mechanism discussed here into force. It is important that a taxpayer who files a complaint will not be called in during this time. It is also important that the decisions are made public in full. However, if a complainant is afraid that company, business or trade secrets are affected, the authorities concerned should delete the sensitive parts of the decision accordingly. As a final point, we as Parliament want you, Commissioner, and the entire Commission to be responsible for ensuring that you do not stand still with this right step forward, but that you ensure that the scope of the directive is properly assessed is extended, for example to indirect taxes, income tax, inheritance tax or the taxation of occupational pensions. There are also problems here with cross-border tax assessments, and in this sense we believe that the present draft law is a big step forward, but cannot be the end point in terms of citizen-friendliness in the European Union.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: - The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 6 July 2017.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the question for oral answer to the Commission on the Opinion of the Court of Justice of 16 May 2017 on the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement by Bernd Lange, Daniel Caspary, David Martin on behalf of the Committee on International Trade (O-000057/2017 - B8-0323 / 2017) - (2017/2739 (RSP)).

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Author. - Madam President, Commissioner! You said it, Madam President: on May 16, the ECJ ruled on the Commission's question as to whether and how a trade agreement should be ratified, which competence lies with the European Union and which competence lies with the Member States. The saying is pretty straightforward - almost everything is EU competence: services, transport services, intellectual property issues, of course market opening, public procurement and also the issue of sustainability and workers' rights. The ECJ has said that workers' rights are an integral part of trade agreements. I found that very gratifying. He has excluded two things as national competence: the question of investments - if they are very comprehensive, portfolio investments - and investment dispute settlement mechanisms, especially if they do not exhaust national legal systems. It actually becomes clear what it's about. And now 50 days have passed and I have not yet heard from the European Commission. It is important to know how our partners should actually adjust to this and, of course, how citizens should adjust to who has to make trade policy decisions and how in the future. The commission is playing a submarine, they go into hiding. There are actually clear options that can be discussed. One option is: We will continue as before, with all the problems associated with it, as we experienced in the discussion about the Canada Agreement CETA, with many faults and many ambiguities up to a process that lasted several years Ratification will take time. Do we want that? I really don't think so. Or the second option: You separate the commercial part with the elements that I have just outlined - where the Court of Justice said that this is EU competence - from an investment agreement, which is then mixed Is responsible and must be ratified by the EU member states and their parliaments. So two agreements. That gives clarity. And the process is also transparent, efficient and fast. Or you can also say: If the criteria of the European Court of Justice are such that only direct investments are EU jurisdiction, then portfolio investments are simply left out, and if it is the case that an investment court only comes under EU jurisdiction if all national investments If legal remedies have been exhausted, then you make it mandatory, i.e. meet the requirements of the European Court of Justice and pack that into an agreement. That would also be a possibility. I think we really have to have that on the table by now, which options we actually want to pursue. I tend towards the middle one - that is, to separate this - but that has to be discussed. And then I would like to know from the Commission what they have been thinking over the past 50 days. Because this is not an abstract idea, Madam President, Commissioner, but just today there was political agreement on the Japan Agreement, where this question comes up again. Then there are negotiations with Mexico, Mercosur and Chile, etc. I believe that the partners need to be clear, and our citizens in particular need to be clear. So I'm looking forward to your answer.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am here on behalf of my colleague Cecilia Malmström. About the many questions raised by my colleague, the Commission sought the opinion of the European Court of Justice on the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement, to obtain clarity about the division of competences on trade and investment and to check if the EU could sign and conclude the FTA alone.  The Court’s opinion provided this clarity in an unequivocal manner. Therefore, we have now a unique opportunity to put the governance of the EU trade policy on a more stable and effective footing, allowing the EU to remain a credible negotiating partner that can better deliver for citizens. Our objective is outlined in the Reflection Paper on Harnessing Globalisation according to which ‘the EU must be able not only to negotiate broad agreements to tackle a wide range of global issues, but also to ensure these agreements can be ratified and implemented’. Let me now proceed to your specific questions as already understood. The Court confirmed that the EU has exclusive competence for most matters that were included in the Singapore FTA, such as: trade in goods; trade in services, including transport; government procurement; intellectual property; competition; trade and sustainable development; Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) liberalisation, and the substantive standards of protection for FDI.  The Court concluded that the competence is shared with the Member States for only two areas. First, non-direct investment, and second, Investor-to-State Dispute Settlement (ISDS) with regard to both direct and non-direct foreign investments. Therefore, and despite the majority of the agreement being considered as coming under the EU’s exclusive competence and the remaining parts as shared competence, the Court considered that the agreement as it stands cannot be concluded by the EU alone. This means that unless the FTA is modified, it cannot be ratified as EU-only, but would need to be presented as a mixed agreement and ratified by all national and, where appropriate, regional parliaments. The opinion gives us an opportunity to look afresh jointly with this House, the Council of course, and Member States, at ways to make EU decision-making for trade and investment policy more sound and efficient. This discussion will need to take into account the legal and political implications deriving from the Court’s opinion: in particular, we will need to respond to the questions as to whether we consider that the status quo, meaning a similar ratification process as in the case of the FTA with Canada (CETA) is sustainable, or not. Or should we rather use the clarity provided by this opinion to move to a more credible and efficient ratification process, taking into account that the EU has exclusive competence for the full scope of our new generation progressive trade and investment agreements but not for certain elements of investment protection and ISDS? How can we best respect the allocation of competences while presenting trade and investment agreements that are coherent and maximise the benefits for citizens? Last but not least, we will need to explain collectively that, whatever path may be chosen, the EU’s trade and investment policy decision-making process is, and will continue to be, a fully democratic one by the European Parliament and the representatives from the democratically elected governments of the Member States in the Council. Further to the proposals and actions made by the Commission to enhance the transparency of trade negotiations and to ensure the proper involvement of all stakeholders during the negotiations, we are keen to explore further ways to assist the Member States in strengthening the involvement of national parliaments early on in the process.  Once our exchanges produce more clarity and consensus on these matters, we will be in a position to propose concrete steps related to the distinction between EU exclusive and shared competences in the ratification process of our free-trade agreements and the negotiating mandates that will be needed for future FTAs. (Interjection from Mr Lange: ‘When?’) Once. We will see!

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: for the PPE Group. - Madam President! EU trade policy has been in crisis for the past year. The idea that the trade agreements we conclude should not only be approved here in the European Parliament and by all Member States, but also approved in 38 national and regional parliaments around Europe, has made the EU impossible as a serious negotiating partner with many of our major negotiating partners around the world. This was something that Canada learned the hard way: When Canadian Trade Minister Freeman cried, literally, left Wallonia after the Social Democratic government there, representing 3.5 million in a Belgian region, refused to accept the EU-Canada Free Trade Agreement, and then 500 million Europeans and 35 million Canadians refused to harvest free trade fruits, jobs and growth. The whole basic idea is that we polarize sovereignty, that we exchange independent decision-making for real influence and better decisions, and right now we are fighting to do just that in the area of ​​migration policy. By the same logic. But precisely trade policy, where we have had the idea of ​​joint decision-making since the Treaty of Rome in 1947 and the establishment of the customs union, and now not defending joint decision-making, it will have an extremely high price. Because it is the beginning to the end of what has been the basis of European cooperation for 60 years. And that 3.5 million Europeans in Wallonia will prevent Sweden and all other European countries from harvesting free trade fruits, I will never be able to explain to my citizens, because all Europeans are losing out on that system. But to do something about this, we need courage. Courage from the Commission to dare to propose trade agreements, pure trade agreements, as EU expertise. But even more courage is needed, I think, from politicians. In particular, from the Member States to defend free trade, to defend joint decision-making and to stand up for the trade agreements we have negotiated, and not to spread myths about them. Because otherwise we will never succeed.

name: David MARTIN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, as we have heard, this case was referred to the Court more than three years ago, which means a trade deal that we negotiated over years and initialled has been in the deep freeze for that time period. Apart from the damage that has done to us as trade negotiators, my fear about this is that it is not actually going to bring any more clarity to the situation than we had before the court case. I am afraid that nothing the Commissioner has said tonight has given me hope that this would be different. The logical consequence of the court ruling should be to leave investment out of the Singapore Free Trade Agreement and proceed as quickly as possible with a goods-only agreement. That could be ratified very speedily and it would also take a toxic matter out of the agreement. I hope that the Council, which should have been part of this debate tonight, will actually agree with this and take the matter forward but, as the committee Chair has said, this goes beyond the Singapore Free Trade Agreement. The Commission has done this, and I pleased to hear that. The Lisbon Treaty makes it very clear that this House, which is legitimately elected by the EU citizens, is the only Parliament entitled to ratify EU—only free trade deals. In future, the Council should not artificially add to the mandate for free trade agreements in order to maintain mixity. Secondly, as Mr Fjellner has said, by not doing this, we can avoid the potential scenario of any one of 43 national and regional parliaments holding our trade agreements hostage. The Court has given us a unique opportunity to put new impetus into our trade agreements. I think a majority in this House is willing to grasp that nettle. I am not yet convinced that the Commission is, and I am very worried that we have had radio silence from the European Council on this matter. The Council should be prepared to act and give trade policy a chance.

name: Sander LOONES
text: on behalf of the ECR Group.- I am Flemish.I am a Flemish patriot, a Flemish nationalist and my nationalism is a very open nationalism.In the world, we are open, convinced and driven as Flemish.But I find that others do lock themselves up, that they don't want to trade with other countries, that they see everything that is strange as a threat.And we must remove that uncertainty, with decisiveness and guts.And also by emphasizing what is evident: our identity, our story, our brand, our quality label.Being a Flemish with everything that goes with it, all freedoms, all rights and obligations, all norms and values.I would therefore like to appeal to all Flemish people: please come out and stand in the shop window, proud, evident, casual, as a Fleming.Here from this European Parliament, I wish you all a wonderful holiday, a wonderful 11th July.Long live Flanders, long live the Flemish.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I am very happy that Commissioner Malmström is absent for a good reason tonight. I know she is finalising the EU-Japan Free Trade Agreement (FTA). This is very good news for Europe. The EU must accelerate on trade deals now that the USA has decided the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) is not a priority. With regard to Singapore, I was and am a very strong supporter of this FTA, as I really believe it offers a win-win commercial deal. I am as frustrated as our Singapore counterparts that this FDA has taken so long and that it was stuck in court for such a long time. As our oral question points out, negotiations were launched in March 2010. Seven years, colleagues, is a positively biblical cycle. If we take so long with a rule-of-law country like Singapore, imagine how long we will take with bigger, more problematic countries. The Court of Justice ruling of 16 May 2017 places almost all the EU-Singapore FTA provisions within the exclusive competence of the Union. However, the two remaining areas of mixed competence have a clear effect and will probably constitute a precedent for future FTAs that the EU will negotiate.  Europe will grow not with more public debt but rather through further trade deals with countries all over the world. Time is always important, and now there is a favourable international momentum for Europeans to grasp. I want to raise three questions. What will the consequences of this Court ruling be beyond the ratification of this FTA? Can we expect the ratification next year? What will be the consequences in terms of future mandates for the negotiation of FTAs and the procedures for their ratification?

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - The judgment of the European Court of Justice was a bit disappointing. I'll admit that right away. I would have hoped that the Court would have been closer to Advocate General Sharpston's opinion and left more powers with the Member States. However, the Court has stated that arbitration and indirect investment are a national competence. The question now is: is the Commission going to do its best to sideline national, regional parliaments as much as possible or is it going to try to pursue a trade policy with the widest possible support? I'm afraid it's the first. The Commission shows this in the treaty with Japan that it wants to announce tomorrow. There is never an opportunity to debate publicly about what our trade agreements should look like. The Commission has all the information, but it mainly talks to the business community and much less to NGOs and citizens. We MEPs have a little bit of information, but we shouldn't talk about it. And citizens do not have the information at all and only hear afterwards what it has become or through leaks from organizations such as Greenpeace what has been decided. That is not good for democracy. Europe has leaders who are increasingly disconnected from its citizens, and the gap between you and us is widening.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, for me there are two essential conclusions from the Singapore judgment. One, referred to by Mr Lange, Chair of the Committee on International Trade, is that sustainable development, including labour protection, is an essential part of EU trade agreements. This means that we have to take it seriously, that it is not a side issue but rather a very important part of our trade negotiations, which also makes the agreements more legitimate and accepted by people. The second is that we need to balance efficiency with democracy. I am quite pleased when I hear from the Commission that it is now thinking about how to involve the national parliaments at an earlier stage, because if we go for more EU-only trade agreements, it means that if the Member States, including the national parliaments, are going to have any say, this has to happen very early. So here my strong call to the Council is this: please publish the negotiating mandates because that is where the political discussion in the future will happen.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, as a member of the ASEAN delegation and rapporteur for the EPP on the Singapore Agreement, I obviously have a keen interest in this topic. I must say, like other speakers, I was a bit disappointed a few years ago when this was referred to the ECJ because I thought it was a bit unfair on the people of Singapore, but thankfully it has worked out quite well, and indeed great credit is due to the Singaporean authorities for their patience in this regard.  Two weeks ago I had the pleasure of meeting their Trade Minister here, also their Ambassador to the European Union, and last weekend in Dublin I met the Ambassador to Ireland. They are very enthusiastic about this, they are very understanding of the European Union’s position, but now we look forward to the implementation of the agreement.  That is the first thing the Commission will have to do, to try and get this implemented as soon as possible. They have got their clarity now regarding ISDS. Indeed the Commission is working on a new framework for that and I agree completely with the last speaker, Ms Hautala, that if the Member States are to be involved in future, they are involved at the early stages, as soon as possible, and not to be allowed to hold up agreements as we have seen in the past, especially in relation to CETA.  So this is actually a good result, provided the Commission has the courage to take the result in their hands and do what they are being given the competence to do and make trade work for European citizens.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: - Madam President, Commissioner!The ruling of the ECJ clearly states that the main responsibility for European trade policy lies at EU level, but that the national parliaments will also have a say in extensive agreements.This finally gives us clarity on the competence issues.The ruling of the ECJ also states, according to paragraph 161, that a violation of social and environmental agreements could lead to a suspension or termination of the agreement.This would allow labor law, social and environmental standards to be effectively enforced.Commissioner, I would be interested in the following: firstly: when could the negotiating parties apply the suspension or termination of the agreement, and is this even foreseen?Second, how would this procedure work?And third: does this then apply to all agreements or only to the agreement with Singapore?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, for those of us who have been involved in European Union law for years, the Court's ruling was to be expected, because there are European Union-specific jurisdictions relating to trade policy, but there are also issues in which jurisdiction is shared. , such as the judicial settlement of disputes, investment issues, such as the observance of labor law tomorrow and the environmental standards that may apply. Therefore, I believe that the situation is being clarified. What I have said since 2014, when I came to this Chamber, is that the CETA agreement, like the TTIP, is a mixed agreement and needs ratification by the Member States. The Commission knew this and did a trick, namely approving a provisional CETA force, knowing that ratification was needed by all Member States and that Member States and parliaments had to participate. This means that there must be no transparency in the trading of CETA and -mostly- TTIP.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I appreciate the valuable comments and questions raised in this debate. We have just started to discuss this subject with you and other stakeholders. Although we have an interest in concluding these discussions as soon as possible, we are aware that, due to their legal and political complexities, they may require time. It is clear that we have the same objective. We all want to make the EU’s trade and investment policy to be more stable, effective and credible for the benefit of our EU citizens. Our analysis and discussions apply to all trade agreements that have not been ratified yet. This also includes free-trade agreements with Vietnam and Singapore.  We are considering all options that could strengthen the EU’s trade and investment policy, but we do not want to prejudge the outcome of this process before having properly discussed it with this House, Member States and other stakeholders. We are therefore looking forward to further exchanges on these issues with the European Parliament. This is a difficult position for me as I hold a different portfolio, but this is the Commission position.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: - Author!I think the last word has not yet been spoken in this debate.That closes the debate.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- Despite what the text of the question suggests, the CJEU ruling has serious consequences for the Commission's "new" trade agenda and its claim to implement free trade agreements without the unanimous authorization of the Member States.This represents a victory for democracy against the attempt to impose ISDS (arbitration tribunals between multinationals and States) and regulatory "cooperation" mechanisms as legislative actors against national courts and parliaments.A victory, therefore, against those who are promoting new trade agreements (such as the ACS and the ATCI) to deregulate the European economy, instead of submitting their proposals to the popular vote.
